sentences.text: Perhaps it was indeed unexpected. The commodities markets—and I myself—were taken by surprise when OPEC decided to cut production at their meeting in Algiers.
The group still faces challenges in achieving a meaningful and lasting impact on prices.
However, the decision was not anticipated by the market. Traders had expected more disarray, similar to the meeting in Doha last April, involving OPEC and other oil exporters.
This time, though, progress was made. The backdrop to Algiers—and previous unsuccessful agreement attempts—is the substantial drop in crude oil prices, now less than half what they were in June 2014.
This decline has heavily impacted OPEC countries' finances and economic performance.
For instance, Saudi Arabia's government had a surplus amounting to 12% of GDP in 2012, compared to a 16% deficit last year.
Angola's economy grew by 7% in 2013, but last year it was only 3%. Venezuela's situation is even worse, though the country's issues extend beyond oil prices, compounded by a political crisis.
For nearly two years, OPEC countries have experienced increasing financial strain.
Although OPEC doesn't encompass the entire market—countries like the United States, Russia, China, and Canada are significant non-member producers—the group controls about 40% of the global market.
Historically, it has influenced prices by cutting production in response to low prices.

Saudi Arabia, the largest player in the group, has often led these efforts. This year, the situation was complicated by Iran's emergence from international sanctions related to its nuclear program, with Tehran eager to regain market share.
The problem for OPEC was Saudi Arabia's reluctance to reduce production unless Iran did the same, a stance supported by longstanding geopolitical tensions between the two Gulf powerhouses.
This tension was the reason for Doha's failure in April. However, circumstances have shifted.
Iran has already boosted oil production and may increase it further, but not as easily as after sanctions were lifted. Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia appears to have softened its stance.
In tourism-reliant Antigua, a devastating disease has wiped out nearly half of the island's stately coconut palms, leaving the landscape littered with unsightly, headless trunks.
Lethal yellowing, the same disease that ravaged coconut trees in Florida and Jamaica, poses a serious threat to both the culture and economy of this 280 square kilometer (108 square mile) island.
Coconut products are integral to local cuisine, beauty treatments, and traditional medicine.
Barbara Japal, president of the island's Horticultural Society, estimates that about 45% of Antigua's coconut palms have been lost.
Street vendor Julian Rose is among those affected, having sold coconut water for $3.70 (£2.40) a bottle for four years.
Over the past year, his supply—and consequently his income—have been cut in half. "I've kept my prices the same—people won't pay more," he explains.
The official guidance is to immediately cut down and burn any palm showing signs of the disease, which include premature fruit shedding and yellowing fronds that eventually fall off.
Unfortunately, the government's limited resources have allowed the disease to spread unchecked since it was first identified in 2012.
"It affects tourism because, as we say, the 'palm is the charm,' and it really diminishes the seascape," Mrs. Japal tells the BBC.
"Seeing them stand like beheaded soldiers is devastating. It’s shocking and feels irreverent.
Coconuts play a huge role in everyday life here: people use them for cooking, and the oil is applied to skin and hair.
While it may not be mainstream medicine, the oil is part of our tradition for healing skin and cleansing the body."
Lethal yellowing spreads via a plant-hopping insect, which Mrs. Japal suspects arrived with imported trees.
Since 2012, there has been a ban on importing palms. "We had numerous plants brought in years ago," Mrs. Japal continues.
"We have a plant protection unit, but who inspects every container of 3,000 trees?"
She notes that underfunding has left the staff powerless. "Affected palms aren't properly disposed of or systematically removed unless private individuals intervene."

While there is no cure for lethal yellowing, trees can be treated with quarterly injections of the antibiotic oxytetracycline (OTC). "Local people don't use OTC; it's just too expensive," Mrs. Japal adds.
The commission is investigating tax arrangements granted to US companies for basing their headquarters in Europe.
Next month, the EU is set to announce its decision on Apple, which might face a multi-billion-pound bill for unpaid taxes.
The commission stated there was "no bias against US companies" in the investigations.
A report released on Wednesday by the US regulator warned that Brussels' actions could transform it into a "supra-national tax authority," superseding the tax regulations of its member states.
The report also noted that Brussels applied different criteria in cases involving US companies, calling the potential penalties "deeply troubling."
Apple has allegedly avoided billions of pounds in taxes by sheltering profits in Ireland under a deal with Irish authorities.
JP Morgan, acting as an investment banker for Apple, suggested the company could face a bill as high as $19 billion (£14.3 billion) in a worst-case scenario.
Several companies, including Apple, Amazon, and Starbucks, are under investigation by the European Commission for alleged tax avoidance.
Last year, the commission determined that Starbucks and Fiat received favorable tax deals in the Netherlands.

The EU's executive body is examining whether Apple was granted special tax benefits for establishing in Ireland, which were not offered to other companies, possibly breaching EU state aid regulations.
Earlier this year, the US government publicly objected to the Brussels investigation, accusing it of targeting US firms.

Recently, the Treasury Department urged Brussels to reconsider its actions against several US companies, including Apple, Starbucks, and Amazon, arguing that penalties could have significant implications for cross-border taxation.

"These investigations have global implications for the international tax system and the G20's efforts to combat tax avoidance while enhancing tax certainty to stimulate growth and investment," wrote Robert Stack, a Treasury Department deputy, in a blog post.
He argued that a charge from the European Commission might qualify as a foreign tax credit in the US, potentially lowering the companies’ tax obligations there.
The Treasury Department indicated it is considering potential responses if the commission persists on its current path.
In response, the commission insisted it was committed to applying EU law fairly to all companies doing business in Europe.
Apple has previously asserted it had no "special tax deal with the Irish government."
"We have received no preferential treatment from Irish authorities," the company stated.
In a recent decision, the judges reversed a 2013 ruling but did not stop the program, instead urging Congress to act.
The NSA's surveillance activities, revealed by former NSA contractor Edward Snowden who is now in Russia, involved collecting call data like numbers and timings, excluding conversation content.
The NSA also allegedly spied on European companies, including targeting German Chancellor Angela Merkel.
Reportedly, Germany has "drastically reduced" NSA-related internet surveillance due to the US agency's inadequate "clear justification" for each search.
According to Gordon Adams of American University, Congress could reinforce the court's decision next week.

House members are set to vote on the USA Freedom Act, a bill that aims to end the NSA's bulk data collection, although some senators wish to maintain the status quo by extending Section 215 of the USA Patriot Act, which allows such data collection.
Section 215 is due to expire in June, and extending it would enable the NSA to continue its operations.

The latest decision from the 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals in New York follows New York District Judge William Pauley’s rejection of a legal challenge from the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU).

The ACLU argued that the NSA's call tracking violated the US Constitution. The 97-page ruling states that "a provision of the USA Patriot Act permitting the Federal Bureau of Investigation to collect business records deemed relevant to a counterterrorism investigation cannot be legitimately interpreted to permit the systematic bulk collection of domestic calling records."
However, the court did not rule on the program's constitutionality, which started after the September 11, 2001, attacks.
The Snowden revelations in June 2013 sparked an international outcry, despite US officials insisting the program was fully authorized.
These measures, approved in secret by a national security court since 2006, are scheduled to expire on June 1.
Leaders in the House of Representatives favor passing a bill to end the government's bulk phone record collection and introduce legislation believed to better protect civil liberties.
Nonetheless, Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell wants to extend the Patriot Act and maintain the bulk collection program.

The White House backs "an alternative mechanism to preserve the program's essential capabilities without the government holding the bulk data," according to Ned Price, a spokesman for the White House National Security Council.
What is the levy, what is at stake, and why is the rate being increased now? The bank levy is an annual tax on the debt value of UK banks, including deposited funds, with exceptions.
Initially, the Treasury planned a lower rate of 0.05% for 2011, but in February, it opted for a standard rate of 0.075% starting in May.
The rate was slightly raised to 0.078% in March and will increase again to 0.088% from January.
The purpose of the levy is twofold: the government aims to deter banks from depending on risky borrowing methods, which contributed to worsening the 2008 crisis, and to generate substantial revenue.

Can it help address the budget deficit? The Treasury estimates the levy will generate £2.6 billion annually, which amounts to 2.1% of the forecast budget deficit by the Office for Budget Responsibility this year.
It represents roughly 19% of the pre-tax profits reported by the five major UK banks in the 12 months leading to September, though the tax applies to more banks than just these five.
What about the borrowing the government wishes to discourage? Traditionally, banks lend out money from the deposits made by individuals and businesses.
However, over the last decade, banks have adopted new, complex methods to borrow trillions from global markets.
Unlike regular deposits, there is no natural cap on this money since it can originate globally and circulate repeatedly among banks.
A substantial portion of these debts was short-term, requiring banks to return to the markets for refinancing every few days.
During the financial crisis, investors feared banks might default on their debts, triggering a market panic where investors stopped lending.
This inability to refinance threatened even profitable banks with collapse. Why are retail deposits exempt from the levy?
Bank runs typically conjure images of long queues of depositors withdrawing funds—as seen with Northern Rock.
Since the 1930s, governments have insured most citizens' deposits to prevent such depositor bank runs.
The Department for Transport announced the need for up to 60 trains, each capable of reaching speeds of 225 mph.
The contract, which includes maintenance of the fleet, is set to be awarded in 2019.
These trains are destined for the first phase of the HS2 project, scheduled to open in 2026, linking London and Birmingham.
Construction will commence later this year, promising to cut rail travel between the two cities by 32 minutes.

The second phase, shaped like a Y, will open in two parts: the Birmingham to Crewe section is expected to start in 2027, while the final segment, which extends HS2 to a new station at Manchester Airport, will be completed six years later.
Separate contracts will supply trains for this phase. Transport Secretary Chris Grayling highlighted that the new railway would accommodate over 300,000 travelers daily.
He remarked, "Building and maintaining these trains will create hundreds of jobs, providing significant opportunities for British businesses and suppliers."
Grayling added that HS2's construction would generate 25,000 jobs and 2,000 apprenticeships, and the department has engaged UK suppliers to optimize their chances of winning contracts.
The launch on Friday precedes a formal process starting in spring 2017, where interested companies can explore bidding details.

Invitations to tender will be issued in 2018. Hitachi Rail Europe plans to bid for the HS2 train contract; the company, headquartered in London, produces trains at its Newton Aycliffe facility in County Durham.
Nick Hughes, their sales director, noted: "Our HS2 trains will be British-built for Britain, incorporating Japanese Shinkansen technology with local manufacturing expertise."
Gordon Wakeford, managing director of Siemens Mobility, described the large-scale manufacturing contract as "exciting news" for the rail sector, with potential benefits for the UK supply chain.
Siemens recently enhanced its focus on HS2, appointing two executives to spearhead its rolling stock bid team.
Despite the progress, HS2 faces criticism, with opponents claiming it endangers extensive areas of the English countryside.
Earlier today, George Osborne stated he had no current plans to lower the top income tax rate further, though he didn't completely rule out the possibility.
In 2013, the coalition government decreased the highest rate from 50% to 45%. Labour's shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, criticized Osborne for not entirely dismissing a further cut.

On Sky News's Murnaghan programme, when asked about a perceived 5% tax rate reduction for those earning over £150,000, Osborne replied, “That’s not our plan.” When pressed to explicitly rule out the move, the chancellor said, “You can judge us by what we say we want to do.
Our goal is to increase the tax-free personal allowance to £12,500, so full-time workers on minimum wage won’t have to pay income tax, benefiting millions.
Our priority for higher-rate taxpayers is to raise the higher rate threshold to £50,000.
These are our key tax commitments for the next Parliament.” Later, when questioned about cutting the top rate, Prime Minister David Cameron reiterated, “It’s not our policy.

We plan to raise the basic rate threshold to £12,500, exempting another million from income tax and reducing tax for 30 million people.” Ed Balls argued, "When George Osborne reduced the top tax rate from 50p to 45p, we knew he and Cameron intended to lower it further to 40p.

If they do, it means extra tax cuts for the wealthiest.” He added, “They need to clarify their intentions and rule it out now.” These discussions also cover income tax, national insurance, and business taxes.
Meanwhile, Liberal Democrat minister David Laws accused the Conservatives of claiming undue credit for personal allowance increases.
Laws, a former chief secretary to the Treasury, noted the prime minister and chancellor didn’t push for the move during talks with the Lib Dems.
He announced his party's intention to “go further and faster” in increasing the allowance soon.
Osborne named raising the allowance as one of his “major tax commitments.” The tax-free personal allowance will rise from £10,600 in 2015-16 to £10,800 in 2016-17 and £11,000 in 2017-18.
Laws told Pienaar's Politics on BBC Radio 5 live that this was due to his party’s efforts.
Yoan Gouffran scored the first goal from close range, and another scramble in front of the net ended with Henri Lansbury mistakenly putting the ball into his own goal.
However, Newcastle’s triumph was overshadowed by the injury to their leading scorer, Dwight Gayle, who limped off after just 33 minutes.
Aston Villa's striker Scott Hogan was taken off on a stretcher late in the game, which extended Villa's winless streak to nine league matches.
Hogan, who joined for £12 million from Brentford in January, fell awkwardly while contesting a header during a Villa corner.
Gayle, the top scorer in the Championship with 20 league goals this season, seemingly aggravated the hamstring issue that had sidelined him for six matches.
Villa is still six points above the relegation zone, having gained only one point in 2017, despite initially keeping pace with the Magpies until falling behind.
Icelandic midfielder Birkir Bjarnason came closest for Villa, failing to convert Hogan’s flick-on and having a shot saved by Karl Darlow.
Newcastle’s breakthrough came shortly after Gayle left the pitch, with Villa unable to clear a Matt Ritchie cross, allowing French winger Gouffran to score.
Following that, the hosts took control and appeared poised to expand their lead, although the second goal, which lifted them above Brighton in the rankings, came under fortunate circumstances.
Jamaal Lascelles connected with a Jonjo Shelvey corner, and his shot rebounded off Lansbury near the post into the net.
Newcastle manager Rafael Benitez told BBC Radio Newcastle: "It's a very challenging league.
Every match is tough, and we faced a good team with skilled players. They pressed well early on, making it difficult for us to play as we planned.
Scoring was crucial to open up the game, and after the second goal, it became more open.
We had more opportunities and more control. Dwight Gayle seemed uncomfortable from the start and mentioned he felt something in his hamstring.
We’re unsure of the seriousness and need to evaluate." Aston Villa manager Steve Bruce told BBC WM: "Scott's injury capped off a difficult night, and we're worried about the outcome.
He's indeed injured his ankle, but we'll need X-rays and scans to know the extent.
Losing him would be significant, but we hope it isn't as severe as we fear. I felt we played well in the first half, Newcastle hadn't threatened our goal, yet we conceded a soft goal.
We gave another goal away after the restart, and the second one was unfortunate."
Imagine you're fortunate enough to be on your way to Monaco to witness the pinnacle of Formula 1 racing in a manner of your choosing.
How would you experience it? Perhaps you’re standing on a neoclassical veranda in Monte Carlo, overlooking Casino Square with a champagne flute in hand.
Or maybe you're savoring lobster and fine wine at a restaurant lining the circuit as the cars zoom by.
You might opt for the Paddock Club, where you can enjoy a grandstand seat and a spot at the Monaco Yacht Club.
Alternatively, you could find yourself bent over a Formula 1 car's exhaust, clad in a race suit under the sweltering 80-degree heat.
Chris Rea, a Jordan mechanic and multi-million album-selling car-themed singer-songwriter, recalls, "I got to wear my own suit and helmet in the garage.
I didn't want to do the VIP thing, so I took charge of Eddie Irvine's right-rear tire. I did it a few times, but Monaco was the toughest."
The scene is the 1995 Monaco Grand Prix, and Eddie Irvine returns to the pits with an issue on his right-rear wheel.
Rea remembers, "My wheel was very warm, and running in that gear was taxing, especially since I had a terrible hangover.
Thank you, Eddie Jordan, for the opportunity—and the hangover." Monaco was where it all began for Rea, not amidst F1 and entertainment elites, but at home in front of the television.
"It was a Sunday afternoon, a small live broadcast from Monte Carlo. Stirling Moss was leading, leaving everyone behind.
As Moss went by, down at the bottom of the hill, I asked my dad about these peculiar things I saw, and he replied, 'Squale - sharks.'
I was only about eight. I asked about the color, and he described it as 'blood red.'
'And who’s that driver?' I wondered aloud. 'He’s like a benign Darth Vader with his modern helmet on.
His name is Wolfgang Alexander von Trips, and he lives in a castle.' That was when it all started for me."
For 70 years, my father has carried the burden of the events involving his ship, HMS Hebe, in June 1940.
He served as the chief engine room artificer during the Dunkirk evacuation aboard the Hebe, which was stationed in Dover as a control vessel.
The Hebe made three crossings to Dunkirk during the turbulent period from 27 May to 4 June.
"It was torrid, dangerous, and nerve-wracking with constant German air attacks," recalls Harold Biles, who turned 28 amidst the bombardment.
"The Hebe lay about 200 meters off Dunkirk's beach, surrounded by thousands of soldiers.
We were on the water, they were on the beach, desperately trying to reach us. "Bombing and shellfire were relentless.

Nightfall offered some respite and a chance to rest." In the early hours of 29 May 1940, HMS Hebe's captain dispatched a small boat to Dunkirk's beach to retrieve Lord John Gort, commander-in-chief of the British Expeditionary Force, and transport him to England.
"As we sped back to Dover, I recall Lord Gort standing by the guardrail, steadied against the rise and fall of waves.
He was striking in his red-trimmed uniform but stood motionless, head bowed. "There was no celebration for evacuating 330,000 men and sparing them from Nazi POW camps.
To him, it was defeat. He had lost an army." The German attacks, coupled with trauma and exhaustion, affected the crew of HMS Hebe, as well as others in the evacuation.
My father recounts witnessing early signs of what is now known as post-traumatic stress, then often called a "lack of moral fiber."
"We were loading supplies in Dover when a low-flying RAF plane triggered panic.
A seaman looked up, screamed, and collapsed in hysterics. Three or four others joined him.
"Later, an ill-conceived order was given: anyone feeling stressed from the past week was to leave the ship and report to the dockside for hospitalization.
"Around 20 men departed, and I still remember their smiles as they stepped over the gangway.
This year has been the most challenging ever for any commissioner, with the NFL nearing an annual revenue of £16bn ($25bn) and moving forward with expansion plans in Europe, particularly London.
Meanwhile, Commissioner Goodell earns approximately £26m ($40m) a year, as American Football's professional scene grows both in popularity and controversy.

In 2014, fifty NFL players were arrested for various offenses, ranging from Tennessee's Shonn Greene, who parked illegally in a disabled space, to Minnesota's Adrian Peterson, charged with child abuse.
Among these incidents were five cases of domestic violence, notably involving Baltimore's Ray Rice, caught on camera assaulting his fiancée in an elevator.
Goodell faced criticism over the NFL's handling of the Rice situation, which was followed by a comprehensive report led by former FBI director Robert Mueller, criticizing the league's management.
The challenges have persisted into 2015, with already four new player arrests, including domestic violence and rape charges.

Despite the turmoil, the NFL continues to thrive as a business. Public scandals, such as those involving Rice and Peterson, soon faded, and attendance at stadiums surged, with over 17 million fans attending the 256 regular-season games, the most since 2008.
Television viewership has reached record levels as well. Though youth participation has declined due to concussion concerns, NFL fandom is stronger than ever, both domestically and internationally.
According to the annual Harris Report, the NFL remains the most popular American sport by a significant margin, overtaking Major League Baseball and college football combined.

The latest report from sports market research group Repucom reveals that television networks broadcasting the NFL saw increased audiences compared to 2013, with marked gains for both Thursday and Monday Night Football.
Additionally, over 47 million people watched the NFL's College Draft, generating 9.6 million tweets, all without a single pass or tackle being made.
Lisa Passey, 28, and her former partner Wayne Dale, 45, left their two-year-old son Kian and another child unsupervised while they entertained a friend.
At Worcester Crown Court, Ms. Passey admitted, "It was down to me and Wayne... it's our fault."
Both deny charges of gross negligence manslaughter. More updates on this and other stories in Hereford and Worcester.
During her testimony, Ms. Passey occasionally broke down while describing the events of the day Kian died at their home in Kyreside, Tenbury Wells.
She said, "I don't want any pity. I was stupid for not going upstairs." The court heard that while Kian was in the bath, Ms. Passey was in the garden with a friend, drinking coffee and smoking.

Mr. Dale joined them to smoke and later "burn" a CD for the friend. Kian was eventually found unresponsive in an overflowing bath by Mr. Dale, with his death consistent with drowning, as soap bubbles were reportedly found in his lungs.
The court suggested that the toddler may have turned on the taps while the adults were downstairs.
Ms. Passey was questioned about providing differing accounts to doctors, police, and social services, including telling a doctor the bath had been dry and empty.
"I was all over the place," she told prosecution barrister Jonas Hankin QC. "If you'd gone through it yourself, losing a child, you'd realize you're still trying to grieve."
She also mentioned that it was common for Mr. Dale to leave Kian in the bath, but only "for a few minutes." The trial is ongoing.
In September 2014, the body of 14-year-old Alice Gross was discovered in the River Brent in West London.
Shortly thereafter, the body of Arnis Zalkalns, a Latvian builder, was found nearby.

An inquest into Alice's death is investigating whether failures by the government and police contributed to the tragedy and is questioning why Zalkalns was allowed to live in the UK without oversight.
At the inquest held at the Royal Courts of Justice, Alice's mother, Rosalind Hodgkiss, read a prepared statement.
She expressed the family's desire to "determine whether the systems for monitoring foreign offenders and sharing cross-border information are effective."

She remarked, "While we recognize these systems may have changed significantly, we are still shocked that a foreign national with a murder conviction was neither monitored nor acknowledged in any way.
This has severely undermined our trust in our country's ability to protect its citizens.
The Home Office and police forces across the nation must ensure this never happens again."
Ms. Hodgkiss described Alice as "lively and popular," "witty, sharp, and academic," and a passionate songwriter.

She conveyed the "immeasurable devastation" Alice's death brought to the family and added, "We have numerous unanswered questions and will never fully understand what occurred that day." Alice vanished on August 28, 2014, after she went for a walk along the canal.
Her body was discovered a month later after what the Metropolitan Police called their largest investigation since the 7/7 bombings in 2005.
Pathologist Dr. Ashley Fegan-Earl testified that Alice's body was found in the River Brent, bound in a fetal position and weighed down with bricks, logs, and a bicycle wheel.
He concluded that she had been sexually assaulted and asphyxiated, likely by someone larger pressing on her torso.

Zalkalns was the prime suspect in Alice's death, and both the Metropolitan Police and the Crown Prosecution Service indicated he would have been charged with her murder had he not died. Zalkalns had been convicted of murdering his wife in Latvia in 1998.
Parliament has approved the sending of a formal invitation, which the prince must accept before ascending to the throne.
King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who was deeply revered, passed away on October 13, plunging Thailand into mourning.
Although the prince was expected to succeed his father, officials stated he wished to delay the ascension for at least a year.
He reportedly wanted to allow the Thai people time to mourn before he became king.
Correspondents note that Thailand is in a constitutional limbo since the prince, the clear heir, should have taken the throne immediately.
There have been past concerns from senior officials about how the crown prince could fill his father's role, which lasted for 70 years.
The monarchy plays a crucial role in Thailand's political landscape. Throughout periods of political unrest, including the 2014 military coup, King Bhumibol was a unifying figure.
The head of Thailand's parliament, the National Legislative Assembly, is expected to meet the crown prince soon to extend the formal invitation.
Upon acceptance, the succession will be publicly announced, but the timing remains uncertain.
Former Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda is currently acting as regent. Thailand has rarely seen routine royal successions.

The last one was 70 years ago, after the young King Ananda was found dead under mysterious circumstances, leading to an emergency parliamentary session that night where his brother Bhumibol was named king.
Despite speculation about his sister, Princess Sirindhorn, Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn has held the undisputed claim to the throne since his investiture in 1972.
Thai succession law generally follows primogeniture, passing the crown to the eldest son, but allows the king to choose an heir.
King Bhumibol consistently supported the crown prince. However, the prince's unexpected decision to delay has added another twist to this succession process.
His true motivations are unknown; public mourning would not have been disrupted had he assumed the throne immediately following his father’s death.
Sgt. Brian Wood, a veteran of the 2004 Iraq conflict, told the BBC that the allegations against him and his team had been deeply damaging.
The closure of IHAT was announced after a misconduct scandal involving a key lawyer in many abuse cases.
Veterans Minister Mark Lancaster stated that, while IHAT was established with good intentions, it was "completely abused" by legal representatives.
Sgt. Wood, who served with the 1st Princess of Wales' Royal Regiment, mentioned on BBC Breakfast that the Ministry of Defence acknowledged the government had "important lessons to learn."
Referring to the Al-Sweady Inquiry, he condemned severe allegations of unlawful killing, mutilation, and mistreatment of prisoners of war as unfounded.
"Those events simply did not occur, and I don’t understand where these claims originated," he remarked, adding that IHAT’s closure was "good news."
He noted systemic vulnerabilities that had been exploited and suggested that a more thorough examination of allegations before public release would have been preferable.
He shared the personal toll on his team, citing career impacts, marital breakdowns, and exacerbated PTSD from their experiences on the battlefield.
Former Army Captain Rachel Webster, arrested during a January 2014 raid, criticized the IHAT closure as "too little, too late."
She told ITV News, "I hadn’t done anything wrong. The humiliation was unforgettable, for myself and for other soldiers and veterans who went through this.

It has destroyed lives, including mine." Mr. Lancaster, speaking on BBC Radio 4’s Today programme, emphasized the government's responsibility to investigate abuse claims, stating, "We cannot simply ignore them."
He indicated that, without IHAT, UK troops might have faced inquiries from the International Criminal Court, but applauded the closure decision as "positive."

Established in 2010 to investigate allegations made by Iraqi civilians against UK service members, IHAT was described by the Commons defence committee as an "unstoppable, self-perpetuating machine, unconcerned with military perspectives."
On Friday, the Ministry of Defence announced that IHAT would shut down in the summer, with any remaining cases being transferred to the Royal Navy Police.
Stadium safety expert Paul Scott is directly involved, as highlighted in a Cabinet Office report finding "broken" relations behind the scenes.
This report indicates that it will take at least another year to submit a new planning application.
Nonetheless, the authors assert that building a new stadium remains "achievable," describing the business case as "sound."
The report was commissioned after Mr. Scott informed a Stormont committee in April of flaws in the proposed emergency-exiting plans for the 38,000-capacity stadium.
Despite these flaws, the report suggests replacing him as chair of the Safety Technical Group overseeing the Casement project.
The report also recommends personnel changes, which Sports Minister Carál Ní Chuilín intends to implement.
She welcomed the report's finding that the stadium is still achievable, saying it provides clarity.
The report notes "broken" relationships among key stakeholders, suggesting an independent mediator is needed to improve working relations.
Although construction was supposed to begin this year, planning permission was overturned in December 2014.
The report states, "The Casement Park project is behind schedule" and must tackle two key issues: resolving the emergency-exiting plan flaws and reapplying for planning permission.
The report includes a "delivery confidence assessment" using traffic lights—Casement is rated "amber/red."
While the report recommends Mr. Scott's replacement as chair of the Safety Technical Group, he might still remain on the team.
His successor should possess mediation and facilitation skills rather than technical knowledge.
The chairman of the Stormont committee investigating Mr. Scott's claims remarked that the Cabinet Office report is just "part of the resolution."
Democratic Unionist Party MLA Nelson McCausland stated there are more questions for the minister and her officials to answer.
"We'll convene a special committee meeting at Stormont next week, requesting the minister and permanent secretary to respond to our questions," he said.
A Syrian boy proudly displays a model house he crafted from cardboard, complete with a shiny red roof, bright blue walls, and small windows that swing open.
It’s a bittersweet achievement, reflecting his memories of a time when homes had such details, unlike the windowless surroundings of this camp.
We are in Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley, where the schoolroom, like the roughly 40 other structures, consists of wooden frames on concrete floors draped in plastic sheeting.
These makeshift walls often feature incongruous advertising images, such as black-and-white photos of men sporting sunglasses and designer stubble.
UK Prime Minister David Cameron proposes to accept refugees directly from Middle Eastern camps like this, aiming to curb the dangerous Mediterranean crossings.
This approach seems logical, though it might be too late and too limited. Welcoming 4,000 more people each year through 2020 is unlikely to significantly alleviate the situation.
Just a few miles away, over the hills, lies the Syrian border, where residents still hear the distant bombings by President Bashar al-Assad on besieged towns.

Although they find safety on this side of the border, comfort is elusive. Rats abound, the drinking water is unclean, and while the September sun is stifling, the winters bring 3-foot (1-meter) snowfalls and freezing conditions. The deteriorating conditions intensify the pressure to leave Lebanon.

Mzead al-Ali, one resident, is contemplating joining those who embarked on the dangerous journey, leaving his wife and four children, including two seven-month-old twins, behind to earn and send back money.
His brother departed for Turkey three days ago, and they haven’t heard from him since.
His mother, struggling with tears, longs to discuss it but must keep her hands pressed to her face.
Officially, this is considered a temporary settlement, not a refugee camp, but there are thousands of such settlements.
Lebanon, with a population of four million, now harbors over a million refugees from its larger, conflict-torn neighbor.
About a third live in camps like this, and even those with conventional housing face challenges.
As a government minister explained, Lebanon's burden is nearly unbearable, and tensions continue to rise.
For many years, a significant number of Haitians have traveled—often without proper documentation—to the Dominican Republic, seeking relief from poverty and unemployment in Haiti.
In 2013, the Dominican Republic's highest court ruled that children born to undocumented migrants were not automatically granted Dominican citizenship.
Following this decision, undocumented migrants were given an 18-month window to "regularize their status."
Many who failed to meet the deadline exited the country, often claiming they were expelled by authorities.

According to the BBC's Will Grant, the Catholic Church has been influential in this migration crisis, with some priests advocating for the rights of returnees while others have been criticized for supporting divisive policies.
Weekly Mass at Parc Cadeau is a modest event, held in a small hut made of wicker and palm, with congregants seated on simple wooden benches.
Observing the camp—one of several along Haiti's border with the Dominican Republic—it seems the parishioners have little to be grateful for.

It is undoubtedly one of the poorest places in Latin America. A year ago, thousands of returning Haitians arrived at Parc Cadeau, some forcibly deported and others choosing to leave to avoid confrontations with Dominican authorities.
Currently, hundreds of families still reside on the dusty ranch, living in makeshift shelters of plastic, cardboard, and rope, caught in a state of near-statelessness.
Soinicier Giles is like many at the camp—he lived for 22 years as a farmer in the Dominican Republic before being deported last year.
He takes me to a dilapidated hut where his wife Eleny and six of their eight children live; the other two were left behind during his deportation.
The conditions are severe, especially for the youngest. "We sleep directly on the floor, and it gets wet inside when it rains," Eleny says.
All her children were born in the Dominican Republic. They show signs of malnutrition and have developed skin conditions since arriving at the camp.
"They're very hungry, we all are, because we can only afford one meal a day," she says in Creole-accented Spanish.

Among the few aiding the returnees is the parish priest, Father Luc Leandre. With funding from the International Organization for Migration, he has facilitated the resettlement of some of the most desperate families to nearby communities in Haiti.
"It's a grave crisis, very, very bad," Father Leandre tells me. "The Church is like a mother to everyone, and it's my duty to help."
The advertisement, part of a government-funded anti-violence campaign, carries particular importance as fears rise about Mexico's drug violence spilling into this small Central American nation.
The first to sound the alarm was President Mauricio Funes last April. "We have information that they [the cartels] have entered El Salvador with exploratory purposes," President Funes stated.
Due to the "effectiveness" of Mexican President Felipe Calderon's policies, the cartels were scouting new operational bases, he explained.
Security forces have since been on high alert, watching for signs that criminal organizations like the Zetas—one of Mexico's most violent cartels—are establishing a presence in El Salvador.
Authorities are also monitoring potential collaboration or clashes between these cartels and local gangs.

Douglas Garcia Funes from the Salvadoran national police indicates intelligence reports suggest that gang members are already "involved as operatives in transporting drugs and money to the United States through Mexico."
In a nation with one of the world's highest murder rates, this presents a grim possibility.
It could exacerbate violence in an already troubled country, many Salvadorans note, and the government seems to be preparing for the worst-case scenario.
"We are certainly concerned, which is why we aim to take preventive measures," stated Hugo Martinez, El Salvador's foreign minister, to BBC News.

In imagery: Life inside an El Salvador jail The gangs known as "maras," originating among Salvadoran migrants in Los Angeles in the 1980s, are believed to significantly contribute to the rising crime rates.
Some estimates suggest around 15,000 young people are involved in these gangs, with some families now seeing a third generation of gang activity.

The maras exert strong territorial control in certain areas, claiming to conduct "social cleansing" by eliminating petty crime but demanding money for protection and engaging in extensive criminal activity.
A retired gang member, who wishes to remain anonymous, says being part of a "mara" offers young, impoverished Salvadorans a sense of power against broader society.
"People fear what a gang member might do, like stealing or killing," he explains.
"That's what being in a 'mara' is about." While maras are not new to El Salvador, a June incident marked a pivotal moment.
Gang members set a small bus on fire in the capital, killing 17 people, prompting the government to label it as a "terrorist act."
During Sunday's match against Roma, which was paused for two minutes, the 22-year-old striker was among three AC Milan players targeted.
"If it happens again, I'm leaving the pitch because it's just so stupid," said the Italy international.
"I was about to leave, but people would think it was because we were struggling in the game."
At that moment, AC Milan was down to 10 players when the Serie A match at their San Siro stadium was temporarily halted.
The game resumed only after Roma's traveling supporters were ordered to stop their behavior.

Roma received a 50,000 euro (£42,400) fine from the Italian Football League for this incident and issued a statement on Monday condemning their fans' actions, promising to "address this issue directly."
Fifa president Sepp Blatter criticized the penalty, telling the governing body's website: "They have not investigated what happened.

Simply imposing a monetary sanction is invalid and unacceptable." Balotelli, who netted 11 goals in 12 games since transferring from Manchester City in January, shared how the incident changed his approach to tackling such problems.
Speaking to CNN, he revealed: "I always said if it happened in the stadium, I'd act like nothing was done and wouldn't care, but now I think I've changed my mind a bit."
This season, AC Milan players have faced several instances of racial abuse. In January, a friendly against Pro Patria was suspended over racist chants aimed at Kevin-Prince Boateng.
The next month, Inter Milan was fined 50,000 euros after their fans racially abused Balotelli, a former player, during the Milan derby.
And in April, Juventus faced a 30,000 euro (£25,000) fine when their supporters racially abused AC Milan players.
The inaugural international anti-corruption summit aims to expose, penalize, and eliminate global corruption.
Political leaders, businesses, sports organizations, and charities will gather at Lancaster House on Thursday.
Prime Minister Cameron describes corruption as "the root of so many of the world's problems" and "an enemy of progress."
He stated, "It destroys jobs, hinders economic growth, traps the poorest in desperate poverty, and undermines our security by driving people towards extremist groups."
He emphasized that "the battle against corruption will not be won overnight. It will require time, courage, and determination to implement the necessary reforms.
However, we cannot hope to address major global challenges without confronting the exploitation, fraud, and dishonesty at their core.
For too long, tackling this issue directly has been a taboo. The summit seeks to change that by elevating the fight against corruption to the top of the international agenda where it belongs."
World leaders attending the summit include presidents Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia, Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria, and Norwegian Prime Minister Erna Solberg.
Russia will be represented by Deputy Foreign Minister Oleg Syromolotov. Speakers are expected to include World Bank President Jim Yong Kim and IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde.
According to the prime minister's plans, summit leaders will commit to exposing corruption and pursuing those who commit, facilitate, or are complicit in it.

Campaigners have also urged action against UK-linked tax havens, highlighted by the recent Panama Papers leak revealing how some wealthy individuals use offshore firms to evade taxes and avoid sanctions.

A Downing Street spokesperson stated, "We are in discussions with the Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies with major financial centers about their attendance, and we expect many to join the summit."
Robert Barrington of Transparency International said, "The prime minister is creating a platform for committed governments to enact significant changes and set the agenda for future generations.
Now, it’s crucial that other governments are persuaded to adopt ambitious goals and that the UK government resists last-minute efforts by less committed countries to dilute the summit's objectives."
The Chiefs secured a bonus point before halftime as Thomas Waldrom scored two tries, with Jack Nowell and Mitch Lees also crossing the line.
Frank Halai responded for Wasps right before the break, and Ashley Johnson along with Lorenzo Cittadini scored after halftime, bringing the home side even.
Waldrom then completed his hat-trick, and Moray Low's late try cemented a convincing victory for the visitors.
Exeter delivered a sharp first-half performance, scoring four tries within the first 34 minutes to lead 27-6, while Jimmy Gopperth kicked two penalties for Wasps.
George Smith's grubber kick enabled Halai to score in the corner at the halftime whistle, and Gopperth's conversion made it 27-13 at the break.
Johnson and Cittadini powered over for Wasps to level the match on 52 minutes, but Waldrom secured his hat-trick to regain Exeter’s lead.
Despite losing Henry Slade to a knee injury in the second half, Exeter regained control, with Low scoring their sixth try.
The Chiefs will lose their top spot if unbeaten Saracens defeat Newcastle Falcons on Sunday.
Wasps director of rugby, Dai Young, remarked, "Today was a real leveler, bringing us back to earth.
Exeter demonstrated superiority across all areas. We were disappointing at the line-out, which we usually excel in.
Exeter made it look easy, and that calls for credit, but we must improve. Sometimes praise can lead to complacency, and you must guard against that."
Exeter director of rugby, Rob Baxter, stated, "The performance was excellent. Wasps fought back surprisingly well.
They've experienced intense performances recently, which can be draining and impact their ability to compete consistently.
Our goal was to pressure Wasps with line speed and scoreboard pressure to exploit any fatigue from their past games."
Wasps lineup: Piutau; Tagicakibau, Daly, Jacobs, Halai; Gopperth, Simpson; Mullan, Johnson, Cittadini, Davies, Gaskell, Jones, Smith, Thompson.
Replacements: Shervington, McIntyre, Cooper-Wooley, Myall, Hughes, Simpson, Jackson, Leiua.
Exeter lineup: Dollman; Nowell, Slade, Hill, Short; Steenson, Chudley; Moon, Yeandle (capt), Francis, Lees, Parling, Johnson, Salvi, Waldrom.

Some schools may be moved from council control and converted into academies due to the "Trojan Horse" investigations regarding claims that hardline Muslim groups are attempting to take over schools in the city.
There are four ongoing investigations into these allegations. A government source stated that all options are still on the table.
Park View, a school implicated in the claims, released a statement on Thursday denying accusations of extremism.
The education watchdog Ofsted and the Department for Education are set to present reports in June outlining the next steps for schools facing these accusations.

It is reported that ministers have engaged with successful schools and academy trusts about assuming control of schools with concerns, possibly transitioning them from local authority control into central government-funded academies led by accomplished headteachers.
Outstanding school groups like the Perry Beeches chain in Birmingham might play a part.
Since some accused schools are already academies, they may be reassigned to different academy trusts.
Birmingham City Council stated it would withhold comments on any proposed actions until Ofsted's inspection reports are released.
"However, we can confirm that we maintain regular contact with the DfE, and this matter has not been discussed with us," a council spokesperson noted.
The GMB union expressed outrage, stating: "It is disgusting that the government is anticipating the investigation’s results and planning to hand these schools to their associates in academy chains."
Prior to the Trojan Horse claims, Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw publicly suggested that the local authority might need restructuring.

Birmingham is the largest local authority in England, and private consultations have suggested it would be challenging to find a private contractor capable of managing its extensive range of services.

Alternatively, some or all of the council's education and children's services could be transferred to an independent trust, a model used before in Hackney, London, where central government had deemed radical intervention necessary.

At a meeting with school representatives last week, Birmingham City Council's chief executive, Mark Rogers, warned of a "firestorm" following the release of the Ofsted reports and advised attendees to prepare for "significant structural changes" within the education department.
Issues arise because the six-digit codes used by booking systems to identify travelers are easily guessed.
Two researchers highlighted these weaknesses by altering a flight booking and seat assignment for a reporter.

They presented their findings at the Chaos Communication Congress in Germany. In a blog, Karsten Nohl and Nemanja Nikodijevic from Security Research Labs (SRL) explained that the computer systems behind airline bookings date back to the 1970s and 1980s.
Although these systems have been updated with web services, they lack the security measures needed to prevent misuse.
Specifically, the systems do not verify or authenticate who is accessing flight details.
Moreover, most reservation systems do not limit the number of attempts to access booking information.
These flaws can be exploited, the researchers noted, as the codes identifying travelers use a limited character set.
This allows attackers to bombard servers with queries to access someone’s details.
"With just passengers' last names, booking codes can be easily found online," they wrote.
This access enables attackers to steal personal data, redirect frequent flyer benefits, or enhance phishing scams.
Some attacks could allow someone to completely change flight details, potentially enabling free travel.
SRL demonstrated this vulnerability by collaborating with German TV station ARD to alter a reporter’s flight, seating him next to a German politician.
The researchers urged airlines and travel agents to act quickly to secure traveler data.
As a first step, they advised limiting the number of queries per booking. Most flight bookings are processed by Amadeus, Sabre, and Travelport.

Amadeus stated it was "assessing" the researchers' findings and planned to "address" the identified issues, working with partners to close these gaps. It also mentioned limiting query attempts for bookings.
Sabre claimed to have "numerous layers" of security for its flight itinerary systems, adding that discussing these measures would compromise security. Travelport has yet to respond to SRL’s findings.
Talha Asmal, a 17-year-old from Dewsbury, was identified as one of four suicide bombers in an attack on security forces near an oil refinery south of Baiji, according to reports by The Guardian.
Isis social media claimed that Asmal, known as Abu Yusuf al-Britani, participated in the attack.
His family expressed their devastation over the news, stating that Asmal would be Britain's youngest known suicide bomber.
Previously, another teenager from West Yorkshire, Hasib Hussein, was nearly 19 when he detonated a bomb on a London bus during the 7 July 2005 attacks.
In a statement, Asmal's family described him as a loving and kind teenager who never showed any violent or radical tendencies.
They believe his youth and naivety were exploited by unknown individuals who targeted him online, grooming him into radicalization.
They said: "Talha fell under the influence of individuals who preyed on his innocence, leading him to his death under the orders of cowardly Isis handlers."

The family is deeply heartbroken and devastated by the tragic events. West Yorkshire Police commented: "We are aware of media reports regarding the death of a British National in Iraq. The identity has not been confirmed, and we cannot comment further."

Asmal had traveled to Syria with Hassan Munshi, another teen from Dewsbury. Munshi's brother, Hammaad Munshi, was arrested at 16 in 2006 after police discovered a napalm-making guide on his computer, making him the youngest convicted under the Terrorism Act.
According to British police, at least 700 people from the UK have gone to support or fight for jihadist groups in Syria and Iraq.
A BBC News database tracks those who have died, been convicted of conflict-related offenses, or remain in the region.

If any graffiti is spotted, it will likely be in perfectly punctuated English. However, what’s also notable is the growing number of students from the UK studying in the Netherlands, with numbers increasing steadily.
During the UK university application season, UK students are including Dutch universities in their open day tours, as these institutions market themselves like offshore Russell Group counterparts.
After the hike in English tuition fees to £9,000, there were predictions that students would seek more affordable options overseas, and this trend appears to be unfolding.
This term, 2,600 UK students are enrolled in Dutch universities, marking a 33% increase in a year.
Headteachers from independent schools are advocating for including Dutch universities on the UCAS application form.
The University of Groningen exemplifies this trend, experiencing a 33% rise in UK enrolments, reaching about 300 students and necessitating special open days.
This 400-year-old institution, the second oldest in the Netherlands and ranked in the top 100 globally, now identifies as an English-speaking university.
It offers more English-taught degree courses than Dutch ones, attracting students from across Germany, China, the UK, and the Netherlands.
For families attending open days in Groningen from England, tuition fees are a constant consideration. Phoebe Watkinson and her father, Phil, journeyed from Wirral.
Phoebe believes that attending an affordable European university would give her an "edge" in the job market, showing qualities like bravery, as it’s not far from home.
She feels the distance is manageable, being as quick to return home from the Netherlands as from other parts of the UK.
Her father, recalling a time when higher education was free, struggles with the concept of accruing such debt.
"I would be extremely pleased if she came here," Mr. Watkinson remarked, noting the academic, social, and financial benefits.
"Most people might cite 'lower fees' as the main reason for considering foreign universities," he says, "but there’s much more to it."
Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford expressed that the concept was "attractive" and might effectively address poverty and inequality.
Advocates believe it could assist unemployed individuals who hesitate to accept jobs for fear of losing their benefits.
However, Patrick Minford from Cardiff University's Business School criticized it as "not a workable scheme."
Universal Basic Income (UBI) proposes giving everyone a fixed amount of money, regardless of employment status, with no obligation to demonstrate job-seeking efforts.
In Scotland, the policy garners support from various political parties, and feasibility studies are underway for potential pilot programs in Glasgow and Fife.

Jamie Cooke, the RSA think tank's head in Scotland, told the BBC's Sunday Politics Wales program: "Transitioning from unemployment to employment won't result in penalties under UBI; you'll continue receiving consistent payments, allowing you the security to choose between work, training, or launching your own business in a beneficial manner."
Contrarily, Prof Minford, a former adviser to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, remarked: "The scheme is impractical due to excessive costs.
It imposes a heavy tax burden, discouraging those higher up the income scale, who bear the financial load."
Earlier in January, Mr. Drakeford told the assembly he was drawn to UBI for its potential to simplify and aid those who currently navigate complex part-time work and benefits arrangements.
He noted, however, that political leaders would need to convince the public of the scheme’s merits.
When asked about Mr. Drakeford’s comments, Prof Minford expressed concern for Wales, stating: "It's quite worrying.
I hope Wales doesn't follow Scotland's path toward this costly socialist experiment."
Nineteen sailors lost their lives and 30 others were injured when the Type 42 destroyer was directly hit during the Falklands War on May 25, 1982.
The ship sank in just 20 minutes, taking with it numerous documents and equipment deemed "important to the security of the United Kingdom," according to Clive Gale.
Gale was part of a 39-member Royal Navy team that conducted several dives on submerged ships, including HMS Coventry, over four months starting in autumn 1982.
Reflecting on the HMS Coventry search, he recalled, "We were very aware we were diving on a war grave and the lives lost with the ship.
Visiting their final resting place leaves a lasting impact." Operation Blackleg was a physically demanding and perilous mission, with some dives extending up to eight hours.
Gale noted, "We were 8,000 miles away from any rescue facilities. Hostilities with Argentina persisted, and there was a 500lb (227kg) unexploded bomb somewhere in the wreck.
The entire mission was filled with near misses. Cutting into underwater steel traps oxygen, and a spark can cause violent explosions.
One diver lost the front plate of his helmet and nearly drowned. I was knocked unconscious and had to be rescued by a colleague."
Gale acknowledged that the mission, 300ft (91m) below the ocean's surface, aimed to "recover or destroy certain items."
However, some recovered items, like the cross of nails, weren't officially listed.
"I removed the large brass plaque while someone else retrieved the bell, and the cross of nails was discovered," he added.
"These personal items belonging to the ship's crew were then presented to Coventry Cathedral after our task was completed."
Gotabhaya Rajapaksa faces charges for allowing a private company to set up a floating armory, allegedly costing the state over $75 million (£57m).
Mr. Rajapaksa, who denies any misconduct, held the position of defense secretary during his brother Mahinda Rajapaksa’s presidency, which concluded last year.
These charges were issued by a special anti-corruption commission in a Colombo magistrates court.
The floating arsenal was discovered off southern Sri Lanka, along with another cache of weapons in the capital, shortly after Mahinda Rajapaksa lost the election.
The Rajapaksa family’s abrupt fall from prominence includes several ongoing investigations.
Avant-Garde Security Service, the private firm involved, claimed the weapons were meant for protecting commercial ships, but police reported complaints about the firearms being used for intimidation.
Gotabhaya Rajapaksa also faces accusations—though he denies them—related to human rights abuses during the 2009 defeat of Tamil Tiger militants.
Other members of the Rajapaksa family are under scrutiny for alleged corruption.
Earlier this month, Namal Rajapaksa, Mahinda's eldest son, was arrested for suspected money laundering, which he denies.

Namal’s brother, Yoshitha, is charged with money laundering, while Mahinda’s other brother, Basil, a former economic development minister, has been arrested three times for suspected fund misuse and money laundering; he is currently out on bail.
President Maithripala Sirisena has vowed to investigate claims that the Rajapaksa family embezzled billions in public funds during Mahinda's near-decade in power.
The former president, now an opposition member, has also faced severe criticism for alleged human rights abuses by the Sri Lankan military during the prolonged conflict with Tamil separatists.
Security forces continue to search for the students abducted by Boko Haram militants on April 14.
Initial confusion arose when the military mistakenly claimed that most of the girls had been rescued.
Parents and some girls who escaped report that over 200 students were taken from their school in Chibok, Borno state, by gunmen overnight.
A local government official confirms the incident, estimating the number of missing students at around 100.
Nigeria's military states that most girls managed to escape or were freed, releasing a statement indicating only eight girls remain missing.
However, locals assert that many are unaccounted for, prompting parents to search the Sambisa forest near the Cameroonian border, where they report finding no Nigerian soldiers.
Major General Chris Olukolade, a military spokesman, acknowledges the incorrect report about the girls' release, stating it was "not intended to deceive the public."
Parents maintain that over 200 girls are still missing. No rescues have been made by the military.

Asabe Kwambura, headmistress of the Chibok school, urges the government to intensify efforts to save the girls and appeals to the kidnappers, believed to be Boko Haram members, to "have mercy on the students."
Kwambura informs the BBC that at least 190 girls remain missing, contradicting a local state governor's claim that around 80 students are unaccounted for.
Footage from the school after the attack shows classrooms set ablaze by gunmen.

A government source attempts to clarify the discrepancy, explaining that it was initially thought only science students were seized before their exam, but authorities later realized 105 art students were also in the hostels.
Nigerians express anger at the government's response on social media, with lawyer Ibrahim M Abdullahi tweeting the first #BringBackOurGirls hashtag.
Hundreds march in Abuja to protest government "indifference" to the mass abduction.
A Chibok community leader warns the girls may have been taken to neighboring states and forced into marriage with militants, reporting 230 girls missing, an increase in the figure.
Desperate parents in Chibok stage protests urging the government to intensify the search for the missing girls, with demonstrations occurring in towns and cities across Nigeria.

Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr carries out a thorough physical examination on Daisy the sheep, checking for heat, swelling, crepitus, or lameness—signs that might suggest disease or osteoarthritis.
However, Daisy isn't just an ordinary sheep; she's one of 13 clones living on a farm owned by the University of Nottingham.
She's among four clones (alongside Debbie, Denise, and Diane) derived from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal born in 1996.

Despite the passage of time in sheep generations, Kevin Sinclair, a professor of developmental biology at Nottingham and the lead author on the study, explains they are Dolly's identical twin sisters and identical to the original ewe.
"Where there was one Dolly, there are now five," he says. We observe the sheep being examined in a straw-lined pen at the university’s Sutton Bonington Campus.
Each of the 13 sheep undergoes the same rigorous tests, which they appear accustomed to enduring.
Though not eager, they tolerate the joint manipulations with a resigned patience.
Their calmness may stem from being some of the most closely monitored animals worldwide.
Prof. Sinclair mentions the broader implications of the research, stating, "The future of cloning science might depend on these results.
A crucial question following Dolly’s creation is: do these animals age normally, and how healthy are they?"

This inquiry centers on a fundamental concern with the cloning process—because DNA is extracted from adult animal cells that have undergone multiple divisions, some "age-memory" could affect the next generation.
"This could imply that the clone might be biologically older than it appears," Sinclair notes.
"A newborn clone might look like a lamb but could suffer from age-related diseases prematurely."
Dolly herself died relatively young for a sheep, at six-and-a-half years. She, along with some flockmates, contracted a virus causing lung lesions, leading to their euthanasia.
Allan Whittern managed the grocery store on Suffolk Parade from 1932 until he passed away 50 years later, in 1982.
After the store closed in 1991, the door painted with his image was donated by his son to the Wilson Art Gallery and Museum in the town.
The Cheltenham Trust, which operates the gallery, plans to restore it for a future exhibition.

Thelma Whittern, Allan’s daughter-in-law, explained the story behind the door's painting: it featured Mr. Whittern’s portrait after he declined a Whitbread representative’s request to place an advertisement on the warehouse door.
Wisecracking, Allan suggested the man paint his portrait instead, and that's exactly what happened.

Thelma mentioned that since its disappearance, many have inquired about it. "People used to pass by in semi-darkness and see the portrait, saying 'goodnight Mr. Whittern,' as if he was leaving the warehouse.
Since it's gone, we've had numerous people ask, 'where is it? What happened to it? You haven't destroyed it, have you?
'” A crowdfunding campaign has collected over half of the £3,000 required for restoration.
Another £1,400 must be raised by Friday. Chloe Moorhead from the trust stated, "Preserving Cheltenham’s rich heritage is vital for both the trust and the town.
This is a wonderful chance for people to contribute to saving an essential piece of Cheltenham’s art history for future generations."
The case is believed to be the first alleged breach of the Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures (TPim).
The suspect, identified only as BM for legal reasons, appeared at the Old Bailey charged with failing to contact a monitoring company and report to a police station twice in January.
The Home Office has declined to comment on the matter. TPims replaced control orders in January 2012.
As of the last disclosure in March, BM was one of nine British citizens under a TPim.
The BBC is unaware of any other individuals charged in court for breaching a TPim.
The Home Office stated, "We do not comment on individual cases. The police investigate all breaches of TPims and will prosecute when feasible."
Individuals under a TPim may be required to stay overnight at a specified address and report daily to a police station.
Additional restrictions can include bans on contacting certain people, visiting specific locations, or traveling abroad.
Labour has argued that TPims have "weakened" public protection against terrorism.
In March, David Anderson, the independent reviewer of terror laws, noted that TPims might be less effective than control orders due to their two-year maximum duration.
The court heard that BM is facing two counts of breaching Section 23 of a TPim order.
The charges specify that on January 16, he failed to contact a monitoring company, and on January 27, he failed to report to a police station.
BM, who has a grey beard and wore a white shirt at the hearing, cannot have his name or address published for legal reasons.
Prosecutor Louise Gray requested a provisional plea and case management hearing date of July 2.
BM was granted unconditional bail but remains subject to his TPim restrictions. No trial date has been set.
The Beyond Caravaggio exhibition showcases works by the Italian artist and 30 other European artists influenced by him.
Collaborating with the National Galleries in London and Dublin, Edinburgh hosts the final stop for pieces inspired by the artist known as the "bad boy" of early 17th-century art.
This marks the first display of Caravaggio's works and those of his followers in Scotland.
Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio died at 39 in 1610, having lived as a fugitive after killing a man during a tennis-related quarrel.
Christopher Baker, acting director at the Scottish National Gallery, described Caravaggio as a "revolutionary artist" to BBC Scotland.
He explained: "Caravaggio is the archetypal bad boy artist, with a tumultuous personal life, frequent court appearances, and a history of murder.
Yet, his creativity was immense, producing extraordinary pictures that profoundly impacted and inspired other artists from across Europe compelled to emulate him in Rome and Naples.
This exhibition captures that narrative." Among the paintings is The Taking of Christ (1602) from the National Gallery of Ireland, indefinitely loaned by the Dublin Jesuit Community.
Rediscovered in 1990 at a Jesuit residence in Dublin, Aidan Weston-Lewis, curator at the Scottish National Gallery, lamented that it was offered for free to Scotland's gallery in 1921 but declined.

He mentioned that it was the only Caravaggio painting in a private Scottish collection, acquired by William Hamilton Nisbet in Rome in 1802 from the Mattei family, who commissioned it 200 years earlier.
It was displayed at Biel House in East Lothian for 120 years. Mr. Weston-Lewis noted: "His descendants bequeathed a substantial collection to the Scottish National Gallery.
Due to limited space, some paintings were selected. Regrettably, this one escaped inclusion."
The doctors' union expressed concerns that patient care was compromised when GPs had to see up to 60 patients daily.
They urged for increased funding so GPs could spend at least 15 minutes with each patient.
NHS England stated that consultation lengths were at doctors' discretion and did not impose a national limit of 10 minutes.
However, the NHS Choices website mentions that "GPs spend an average of 8-10 minutes with each patient" and advises planning to cover all discussion points.

Earlier this month, the BMA released a report on "safe working in general practice," suggesting reorganization and warning that GPs face "unsustainable pressure" from their rising workload and staffing shortages.
The report aims to spark discussion and proposes a model applicable across the UK.
Dr. Nicola Hulme, a GP in Cheshire, found NHS England's remarks about unlimited appointment times "insulting."
She pointed out that given the high demand, they must operate with 10-minute slots to finish within a 12-hour workday.
She often runs late to address patient issues thoroughly, starting paperwork after 7 pm and usually not getting home before 8 pm after starting at 7:30 am.
"No one enters medicine for an easy path; we're all hard workers, but the current intensity and demand are unsafe," she said.
Dr. Ali Alibhai, working in central London, noted that managing numerous chronic diseases like diabetes makes eight-minute consultations inadequate for safe care.
Dr. Brian Balmer of the BMA’s GPs' committee noted that many patients, given an aging population, have complex conditions requiring more time for treatment.
He warned that GPs are forced to shorten care and conduct an "unsafe number of consultations," suggesting a limit of 25 consultations per day, similar to recommendations in other EU countries.
Dr. Balmer stated, "We need a revamped approach to how patients receive care from their local GP practice.
Consultation times should increase to 15 minutes, supported by government funding as promised."
The King's Fund, a health think tank, reported that GPs are under "huge pressure due to increased workload without corresponding growth in funding or workforce."
In the past, trainee doctors had to wait up to four years to experience real consultations.
To address this, Aberdeen University developed GP Live, a software that streams consultations directly to students.
This initiative aims to attract more students to general practice and address recruitment shortages.
The software broadcasts consultations shortly after they occur, giving students a glimpse into the life of a GP.
The system uses the University’s Digitally Enhanced Learning Spaces (DELS), where students engage in interactive learning using 55-inch displays and advanced web conferencing tools.

Developed by Dr. John McKeown, a senior clinical lecturer and GP at Cults Medical Group in Aberdeen, he explained: "The main attraction for students is witnessing consultations nearly in real-time, which offers immediacy that resonates with students accustomed to digital interactive learning."
Dr. McKeown emphasized making sessions engaging by discussing the GP's approach during the consultation, including communication strategies, consultation direction, and recommended actions.
He noted a key advantage of the system is its ability to facilitate discussions on varying practices, highlighting diverse issues.
He added: "Students gain valuable insights into challenges faced by GPs, whether in less affluent areas or remote rural locations."
The system allows students to work through multiple consultations sequentially, mirroring a typical GP morning.
This showcases a range of skills—interpersonal, diagnostic, and more—applied during a regular workday.
Dr. McKeown highlighted the growing demand for new GPs in Scotland by the time current first-year students graduate.
Berlusconi commented to an Italian newspaper that Americans have chosen Mr. Trump, urging, "now let him go to work."
Both Berlusconi, a media mogul, and Trump, a real estate tycoon, transitioned from business to politics.
Although legal troubles have surrounded Mr. Trump, unlike Berlusconi, he has not faced criminal convictions.

At 70, the man who triumphed over Hillary Clinton in Tuesday's election is one of America's most recognized and vibrant billionaires, with Forbes estimating his net worth at $3.7 billion (€3.4 billion, £2.9 billion).
Berlusconi, at 80, served four terms as Italy's prime minister before criminal convictions in 2013 and 2015.

Forbes values him and his family at $5.9 billion. When asked about their similarities, Berlusconi told Corriere della Sera that despite some clear parallels, his entrepreneurial journey greatly differs from Trump's, whom he has never met.
He didn't elaborate but may have referred to their distinctive hairstyles or controversial personas.
Italians have quickly noted resemblances between the new U.S. president and their former prime minister, even dubbing them "Trumpusconi" on social media.
In the interview, Berlusconi refrained from outright celebrating Trump's win but explained why he believed Clinton lost.

Trump, he argued, "was chosen by Americans tired of the old political order," indicating a mistake common among left-leaning groups globally: confusing "political correctness" with addressing people's actual needs.
Italy faces a constitutional reform referendum on December 4, viewed as a verdict on current Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's leadership.
He has vowed to resign if defeated, a prospect polls suggest is narrowly possible, which could empower Italy's anti-establishment Five Star Movement.
Its founder, ex-comedian Beppe Grillo, labeled Trump's election a turning point for media and intellectual elites. Could a Trump-style revolt spread across Europe?
Fr Alec Reid, an 82-year-old member of the Redemptorist order, passed away at 06:40 GMT on Friday in a Dublin hospital.
Fr Reid played a discreet yet pivotal role as a mediator between the republican movement and the SDLP, and was one of the witnesses who verified the decommissioning of IRA weapons.
More recently, he participated in discussions with Basque nationalists seeking independence from Spain.
One of the most enduring images of the Northern Ireland Troubles was captured in 1988 when Fr Reid was photographed praying over the bodies of Army corporals Derek Wood and David Howes.
These soldiers were dragged from their car, beaten, and shot by the IRA after accidentally entering a republican funeral in Belfast.
The bloodstained image of Fr Reid administering last rites exemplified his deep faith and conviction, as noted by a Ministry of Defence spokesperson.
Sinn Féin president Gerry Adams referred to Clonard monastery in west Belfast, where Fr Reid was based during the Troubles, as "the cradle of the peace process."
He recalled being with Fr Reid at St Vincent's Hospital, Dublin, on Thursday night and planned to visit again on Friday.
Adams said, "Fr Reid lived the gospel message, advocating for dialogue even when it was not the official stance, and was unwavering in his pursuit of peace."

Northern Ireland Secretary of State Theresa Villiers expressed her condolences, stressing the debt of gratitude owed to Fr Reid for his significant role in the peace and reconciliation efforts in Northern Ireland.
Former SDLP leader John Hume remarked that Fr Reid was "more than a mediator" and played an active role in seeking an end to violence.
Hume highlighted Fr Reid's courage, determination, and selflessness, which significantly shortened and eased the path to peace.
He urged people to honor Fr Reid’s legacy by continuing to pursue reconciliation.
Michael D. Higgins, the President of Ireland, noted that Fr Reid’s compassionate last rites to the two British corporals in 1988 amidst such brutality offered a powerful image of humanity.
As news of Fr Alec Reid's passing spread, there were tears and tributes throughout west Belfast.
The decision to cancel the event was made after forecasts predicted more bad weather.
Performances were halted on Saturday due to ongoing thunderstorms, forcing many of the 92,000 attendees at the open-air event to take shelter in cars and tents.
Organizers were compelled to cancel the festival after local authorities revoked its license early on Sunday morning.
They expressed regret on Facebook (in German), acknowledging it was a necessary measure, as fan safety was their top priority.
Some critics on Facebook have blamed the organizers for not terminating the event sooner.
Attendees at Rock am Ring, held at an airport in the town of Mendig, about 100 km (62 miles) west of Frankfurt, were instructed to vacate the festival grounds by noon on Sunday.
At least eight people were seriously injured by a lightning strike early on Saturday morning.
Central Europe has been gripped by severe storms and rain in recent weeks, resulting in 11 deaths in Germany.
The Rock am Ring festival, a major event in Germany, also suffered lightning strikes last year, with 33 people hospitalized.
The festival’s website frequently warned fans about potential heavy rainfall and thunderstorms.
Initially, the Rock am Ring organizers, now in its 31st year, announced on Saturday that the event would proceed as planned, concluding on Sunday evening.
The line-up included bands like Red Hot Chili Peppers, Black Sabbath, Foals, Deftones, and We Are Scientists.
