Last weekend, lightning injured 35 people, three seriously, at a football match in southwest Germany.
Another 11 people were injured in a lightning strike at a Paris park during a children's birthday party.
A UK study, published in the journal Nature, reports that hearing partially improved in gerbils when the nerves responsible for transmitting sound to the brain were rebuilt.
Although achieving similar results in humans could dramatically enhance hearing—from not being able to hear traffic to understanding conversations—such a treatment remains a distant possibility.
To engage in activities like listening to the radio or chatting with a friend, the ear must convert sound waves from the air into electrical signals the brain can interpret.
This conversion occurs deep within the inner ear, where tiny hairs generate an electrical signal from vibrations.
However, around 10% of individuals with profound hearing loss have damaged nerve cells, hindering signal transmission, much like a relay baton dropped after the first leg.
Researchers at the University of Sheffield aimed to replace these relay-dropped nerve cells, known as spiral ganglion neurons, with new ones.
There is much excitement about using stem cells to restore ear nerves, yet this technique won't benefit the majority of those with hearing loss.
Most cases arise from damage to the delicate hairs converting mechanical vibrations to electrical signals.
The research group has also transformed embryonic stem cells into preliminary forms of these hair cells.
However, injecting them into the ear to restore hearing remains challenging, as the hair cells must be precisely placed and oriented.
Prof Dave Moore remarked that repairing the hair cells with stem cells is "almost an impossible task," suggesting it is more plausible to grow and transplant a new ear.
The team used stem cells from a human embryo, capable of developing into any cell type, from nerves to skin, muscle to kidney.
A chemical mixture converted these stem cells into ones resembling spiral ganglion neurons, which were then carefully injected into the inner ears of 18 deaf gerbils.
After ten weeks, the gerbils exhibited an average 45% restoration of their hearing range.
Dr. Marcelo Rivolta explained: "This would mean transitioning from profound deafness, where even the sound of a truck on the street is inaudible, to the ability to hear a conversation."
After a harrowing four-day, 129-kilometer (80-mile) journey on foot, Kai arrived alone at a camp in Bentiu, a northern town.
He fled from Leer, a small town in Unity State recently engulfed in conflict. The clashes between rival forces compelled him to leave his family behind, as fear overwhelmed him.
"At night, they'd come shooting at us, and we'd scatter," Kai recounts, "We used to run into the swamp, keeping only our heads above water."
He lost track of the days spent hiding there. His family's cattle were stolen, his brother—who helped tend the herd—was killed, and their home was destroyed.
Although he found refuge, he remains anxious about his family. "I don’t know if they're safe; they could be alive or dead because the fighting continues.

Now I'm torn between going to school or returning home for my parents." Festus Mogae, ex-President of Botswana and chair of a commission overseeing the 2015 peace agreement, warns that the persisting conflict might lead to an "uncontrolled escalation of violence."
Battles have erupted around Yei in the southeast, Leer in the north, and Nasir in the northeast, worsening security and severely affecting road transportation.
Commodity prices have surged, with inflation soaring to 700%. Humanitarian groups now rely heavily on expensive air transport.
Planes carrying grain, pulses, and vegetable oil daily from Juba or Gambella in Ethiopia deliver hundreds of tonnes of supplies to drop zones near camps.
Even fuel for vehicles and generators is airlifted. Unicef's representative in South Sudan, Mahimbo Mdoe, states the crisis demands increased supplies, personnel, and security.

"Malnutrition in Northern Bahr al-Ghazal has tripled, requiring three times the usual amount of supplies for children," Mdoe says, describing the situation as "dire" with up to six million children affected.
He cautions that without change, conditions could deteriorate for civilians, especially women and children, complicating efforts for humanitarian workers.
In August, the UN Security Council established the Regional Protection Force (RPF) to secure Juba amid the power struggle between President Salva Kiir and his dismissed Vice-President Riek Machar.
Greater Manchester Police (GMP) has apologised for racial stereotyping after using a faux terrorist shouting "Allahu Akbar" during a mock terror attack.
The organisers of a meeting at Longsight Saath Saath are demanding an investigation.
GMP stated it has no intention of issuing additional statements regarding the training exercise that took place at the Trafford Centre.
The mock suicide bombing scenario involved an extremist group modeled after Daesh, although GMP clarified that the event was not linked to any specific terror threat.

Syed Azhar Shah, who chaired the meeting with about 30 attendees, said that the apology from GMP's assistant chief constable Garry Shewan was inadequate and would only be accepted if those responsible resigned.
He acknowledged the value of the training exercise but found it "shocking to portray Muslims as terrorists" and suggest that only one group could commit such acts.
He expressed concern about the impact on children and the community who might see themselves as either terrorists or British citizens.
Mr. Shah announced further events to "condemn this" and ensure it doesn't happen again, asserting that one apology "would not mend so many hurts."
A meeting participant noted that depicting a Muslim as a terrorist sent "the totally wrong message" and created division between the community and GMP.
"We are all British citizens. Islam does not permit any killing," the participant added.

Greater Manchester's police and crime commissioner, Tony Lloyd, described it as "frustrating" that the operation was "marred by the ill-judged... and unacceptable decision" to have the terrorist shout "Allahu Akbar" before detonating fake bombs.
Other locations involved in the three-day counter-terrorism exercise included Redbank Community Home in Newton-le-Willows.
Monitor is assessing the financial sustainability of Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust "on behalf of patients," according to the NHS regulator.
Concerns arose when a planned £7.8 million deficit increased without a visible recovery plan.
The hospital attributed this larger deficit to increased demand and staff recruitment.
Alan Tobias OBE, the hospital chairman, stated: "The overspend results from essential investments in services and staffing to maintain high standards of patient care, along with rising attendance.
We welcome this review to demonstrate to Monitor, patients, and stakeholders that our future financial plans are robust and sustainable."
The hospital has committed to reducing the deficit while ensuring "high quality care for local people" and aims to achieve a surplus within three years.

Monitor announced that its investigation will assess the hospital trust's finances, evaluate its financial management capabilities, and explore strategies for enhancing sustainability for the benefit of regional patients.
Additionally, the investigation will review how the trust collaborates with local health and care organizations to tackle its financial challenges.

Katherine Cawley, regional director at Monitor, commented: "People rely on Southend for quality healthcare now and in the future, and we are concerned that this could be jeopardized by the trust's poor financial performance.
We initiated this investigation to understand the trust's financial position better and discover ways to improve it."
The severe weather impacted Norfolk and Lincolnshire, leading to home evacuations and the cancellation of an air display.
BBC Weather reported that 50mm of rain fell in an hour in Cambridgeshire, damaging the banks of the River Nene in March.
A Tesco customer described water "pouring through the ceiling near the fresh fish counter."
Richard Mayer, 32, became trapped in his car at Bar Hill while visiting to purchase a home.
He explained from his vehicle: "Water is lapping over the curb. People can walk through it, but it's much too deep to drive through.
I'm parked on the pavement to stay elevated, near the Bar Hill roundabout by Tesco.
Cars are everywhere, and flooding worsens as people try to drive through, causing engines to fail and block the road."
Fire service group commander Ryan Stacey stated: "We have seven crews in March, Doddington, and Wisbech St Mary, assisting with evacuations, salvaging belongings, and pumping water from homes.

We cannot confirm exact numbers, but we are assisting at least 60 properties." He cautioned against driving through standing water, noting: "It can damage your car, and there may be hidden hazards beneath the water."
A rest center was established at St John the Evangelist Parish Hall in Queens Street, March.

Additionally, west Norfolk saw reports of flash flooding. Norfolk Fire and Rescue Service handled about 40 flood-related calls, with ongoing incidents in Swaffham, Necton, Outwell, and Downham Market.
Cambridgeshire police advised avoiding driving unless absolutely necessary due to the heavy rainfall.

Chief Inspector Nick Night noted, "We are aiding partners like the Highways Agency, Fire and Rescue Service, Fenland District Council, and Cambridgeshire County Council in road closures, evacuating residents, and retrieving vehicles from floodwater.
We don't have sandbags, so please don't call 999 requesting them." The UK Power Network was working to restore electricity, with about 400 homes still without power at 21:00 BST on Friday.
The location is central but undesirable, squeezed between fast-food shops at the shabby end of Nemanjina Street, near the city's main railway station.
The bustle around the entrance and Arabic script signs in the windows indicate that newcomers from the Middle East continue to arrive in Serbia's capital.
Inside, the scene is one of organized chaos. On the ground floor, young men awkwardly occupy hard-backed chairs, waiting their turn at the computers lining one side of the room.
Those at the machines wear headsets and engage in lively Skype conversations. Upstairs, the atmosphere changes entirely.
Confused-looking families gather in a cramped "safe space" managed by Save The Children.
Parents guide their children towards a pile of toys, while a small boy cries uncontrollably.
The familiar scent of the refugee journey—damp, unwashed clothes—begins to permeate the air.
"They are Yazidi people from Iraq," explains Marjan, a translator struggling to communicate with the new arrivals.
There are over two dozen individuals in this extended family group. They bypassed the typical route through Greece and Macedonia, opting for entry through Serbia’s eastern border with Bulgaria.

In the strip-lit, windowless meeting room, overflowing ashtrays and half-finished mugs of Turkish coffee suggest it has been a tense morning. The center's manager, Vladimir Sjekloca, pauses to explain the situation.

"There are always people in Belgrade," he states. "Around 400-500 a day." Vladimir notes that despite the increased restrictions and the official closure of the Balkan route (though hundreds still breach the border fence from Greece into Macedonia), people continue seeking passage to Western Europe.
They have simply altered their methods. "Entering through Bulgaria is an old smuggling route, likely to be used more frequently.
Afghans tell us, 'That way is cheaper [than the sea crossing from Turkey to Greece] and we can't swim anyway.'"
Before its shutdown, nations along the route coordinated transport, moving people from Macedonia to Slovenia's border with Austria on official trains and buses.
This made the journey relatively smooth and minimized the risk of refugees falling prey to smugglers.
However, now those desperate to reach Western Europe are once again dealing with unscrupulous individuals.
"The journey through Bulgaria is fraught with abuse," Vladimir says. "People suffer at the hands of the mafia and smugglers—and they receive no protection from the system."
In a fiery speech targeting Donald Trump, Mrs. Clinton made it clear she aims to appeal to the political center in the upcoming general election.
Although her address was billed as a national security speech, it didn't introduce any new proposals.
Instead, it was a strong, often mocking critique of the presumptive Republican nominee, framed in patriotic terms that could also resonate with Republicans.
Mrs. Clinton positioned herself as the true protector of American values and a steady-handed commander-in-chief who views America as an exceptional nation.
In contrast, she claimed Mr. Trump sees America as "weak" and "an embarrassment," quoting him as saying the military is a "disaster" and labeling the country a "third-world nation."
Speaking in San Diego, which hosts 95,000 military personnel, she was introduced by the spouse of an active-duty naval officer and had 20 US flags prominently displayed behind her.

Despite still contending in the primary, Mrs. Clinton is undoubtedly courting independent and Republican voters concerned about Mr. Trump's unpredictable foreign policy views and his remarks on women, Mexican immigrants, and Muslims.
On Thursday, Ruth Guerra, head of Hispanic media relations for the Republican National Committee, resigned.

Mrs. Clinton has the capacity to attract moderate Republicans disenchanted by their party’s stance on social issues like gay marriage, abortion, and gun rights, yet who perceive her to be firm on foreign policy.
Back in late April, after her victory in the Pennsylvania primary, Mrs. Clinton urged "thoughtful" Republicans, independents, and Democrats to unite against divisive Republican candidates.
While House Speaker Paul Ryan finally endorsed Donald Trump on Thursday after hesitating for weeks, top Republicans aren't rushing to support Trump just yet.
Several Republican governors and senators are choosing to avoid the party's convention in July.
Some lifelong Republicans are even openly declaring their intent to vote for a Democrat for the first time this November.
Mrs. Clinton's emphasis on American global leadership might not resonate with the GOP base, which is growing more isolationist, but it is appealing to many moderates and foreign policy experts.

On Twitter, #RepublicansforHillary trended for a day after Doug Elmets, a former Reagan administration official, remarked on US cable TV that "four years of Hillary Clinton is better than one day with Donald Trump as president."
Terence Brannigan, chairman of the Maze/Long Kesh Development Corporation, spoke after roads around the former prison site became congested on the event's first day.
Mr. Brannigan noted that rural roads were "not designed for that kind of traffic," but assured that work is underway to improve the infrastructure.
"In 12 months, things will be different," he stated. "However, let's be realistic; in 12 months we won't have two roads linking to the motorway network just yet.
Currently, efforts are in progress to establish two motorway links, one from the east and one from the west.
We are conducting environmental studies to obtain clearance, followed by planning approval, which will lead to the construction of these roads."
The three-day event, expected to draw up to 80,000 attendees, has moved from its previous venue at the King's Hall in Belfast.
On Wednesday, First Minister Peter Robinson expressed hope that access issues would be resolved.
Mr. Brannigan emphasized that addressing infrastructure has been a priority for the corporation, but acknowledged the "rigorous process" involved.
"Long queues can detract from what is otherwise a magnificent show, a fantastic event, and a showcase for Northern Ireland," he remarked.
"Funding is secure, so lack of finances or support is not an issue. However, we must adhere to due process, which can be frustrating."
This year's show attendees are encouraged to use public transport, with the Balmoral Show website offering details on travel arrangements by car or public transit.
Following the closure of 24 more shops, police have arrested 186 alleged offenders.
The Home Office expressed satisfaction that numerous retailers were barred from profiting from this hazardous trade.
Nonetheless, the charity DrugWise stated that the ban has driven these activities underground.

Legal highs gained popularity in the drug scene around 2008, featuring substances that mimic the effects of illegal drugs like cocaine, cannabis, and ecstasy, with names such as Spice and Black Mamba.
The Psychoactive Substances Act, which criminalizes the production, distribution, sale, and supply of these drugs, was enacted at the end of May.
Commander Simon Bray, from the National Police Chiefs Council, reported that London's Metropolitan Police had seized nearly 14,000 nitrous oxide canisters since the law's introduction.
While it’s hard to measure the direct impact on drug use, Mr. Bray inferred, “intuitively I think it must have had an effect,” suggesting that the restrictions likely deter casual first-time users.
Many people were mistakenly convinced these substances were legal and, therefore, safe.
The Angelus Foundation, which raises awareness about the risks associated with legal highs, noted that several online sellers have also ceased operations.
Jeremy Sare, the charity's director of communications, told the BBC, "I think the ban has made a big difference, and we support the legislation. We're surprised online sales haven't surged.
Traders seem to have stopped selling. It’s early days, and the situation might evolve over 12 months, but many seem to have closed.
Previously compliant with the law, they’ve now stopped as regulations have changed.” He identified homeless people and prisoners as the primary users of these substances.
Greg, who moved from Essex to west Wales, shared his experience with a legal high called Holy Smoke on BBC Radio 5 live.
"I used just a little... and my head began spinning, causing paranoia. I wanted to go home and hide but couldn’t walk correctly.

I honestly thought that I was going to die. It’s reported as still being pretty accessible, with many people assuming it remains legal," he said. "Alison," a recovering drug user, also had experience with legal highs.
MP Brendan O'Hara is hosting a reception to present plans for transforming the former NATO base at Machrihanish into the center of space tourism in the UK.
Out of five proposed sites in Britain, including three in Scotland, Machrihanish is being considered as a potential spaceport.
The UK government had previously aimed to establish a spaceport by the end of 2018, launching a consultation in 2014 and later creating a shortlist of potential locations.
This list included Prestwick in South Ayrshire, Stornoway in the Western Isles, Newquay airport in Cornwall, and Llanbedr airport in Snowdonia National Park.
Last May, the government incorporated spaceport licensing in the Queen's Speech and introduced an airport-style licensing system, allowing any appropriate location to qualify as a spaceport.

The Department for Transport stated this approach could facilitate "viable business models at a range of locations," leading both Prestwick and Campbeltown to seek investment to prove they are ideally suited to becoming the UK's first operational spaceport.
Officials indicated that a future spaceport would not only serve space travel and tourism but also satellite launches.
The Machrihanish base, near Campbeltown, has twice been approved for space flight and was an official emergency landing site for NASA's Space Shuttle in 1981.
Tom Millar, chairman of DiscoverSpace UK and the Machrihanish Airbase Community Company, expressed local support for the bid, emphasizing the potential economic benefits.
He noted, "Our site offers significant potential with a runway exceeding 3,000 meters, ample land for development, and supportive planning from Argyll and Bute Council.
Our safety case is robust, situated in a sparsely populated area with direct sea launch capabilities."

SNP MP Brendan O'Hara called the decision to base the spaceport in Kintyre a "no-brainer," adding, "A spaceport would bring significant economic benefits to Argyll and Bute, and it's an exciting opportunity for Scotland to lead the UK's space travel efforts. The sky is not the limit."
The sum in question is more than double the amount initially estimated in an inquiry concerning FN staff.
The parliament suspects that the funds were directed to FN assistants who were not actually working for MEPs but were instead involved in FN party activities in France.
These allegations, which the FN denies, have now been forwarded to French investigators.
Ms. Le Pen is campaigning for the runoff in the presidential election on 7 May.
Her opponent, the liberal centrist Emmanuel Macron, is currently ahead in the polls.
The alleged fraudulent payments, dating back to 2012, involve Ms. Le Pen and several other FN MEPs.
The FN is a staunch critic of the EU, rejecting its liberal, free-market policies.
Ms. Le Pen claims she is the target of a politically motivated vendetta. What defines Marine Le Pen as far-right? Explore: Le Pen and the Rise of the National Front.
The European Parliament is withholding half of Ms. Le Pen's salary and expenses as it tries to recover the funds it claims she owes.
The FN currently holds 24 MEP seats, the largest delegation from France. Ms. Le Pen has ignored a summons regarding this issue in France, citing her MEP immunity.
BBC's Hugh Schofield in Paris notes that FN supporters are typically quite skeptical of the EU and may not view the alleged fraud as particularly concerning.
On Tuesday, Ms. Le Pen stepped down as FN leader, stating she needed to rise above partisan interests in the presidential election.
Jean-François Jalkh, the new temporary FN leader, has immediately come under fire over comments from a 2000 interview.
In it, he is quoted as doubting the Nazis' use of Zyklon B cyanide gas for mass murder in death camps.
"I consider it technically impossible—again, impossible—to use it...in mass murder.
Why? Because you have to wait several days to decontaminate a place where Zyklon B was used," Le Monde quoted him.
When questioned by Le Monde, he dismissed it as "utter rubbish" and said he did not recall the interview.
A year ago, FN founder Jean-Marie Le Pen was fined €30,000 (£25,278; $32,600) for calling the Nazi gas chambers a "detail" of World War Two, a conviction for contesting crimes against humanity.
He received a similar conviction in 2012 for describing the Nazi occupation of France as "not particularly inhumane."

Marine Le Pen, his daughter, faced widespread criticism on 9 April after suggesting that France was not responsible for the 1942 round-up of 13,000 Jews, who were deported from France to Nazi death camps.
Mr. Haldane remarked that any increase in interest rates could "unnecessarily raise the risk of the economy falling below critical velocity."
He is regarded as the most cautious decision-maker regarding interest rate hikes.

Since the 2009 financial crisis, interest rates have remained at 0.5%. The first increase is anticipated in late 2016, with forecasts delayed after the Bank of England's latest inflation report mentioned weakened global growth prospects.
During a speech to the TUC, Mr. Haldane noted that the next rate change could just as likely be a cut as a hike.
"Policy in the UK needs to be ready to respond in either direction based on how the data unfolds," he stated.

He pointed out that wage growth might be weaker than expected, potentially leading inflation to fall short of the Bank's November predictions, which projected inflation rising above the 2% target in two years.
Currently, the Consumer Price Index is at 0.1%. "Given these circumstances, I believe the case for raising interest rates is still not sufficiently clear," Mr. Haldane said.
"The economic plane seems to be losing speed on the runway, making it a risky time to contemplate take-off.
Additionally, inflation trends do not presently assure me that the target will be met, even two years from now."
He also emphasized the challenges of the UK's increasingly costly housing market.
"The UK housing market is in disarray," he told the TUC. "There is a chronic and growing imbalance between demand and supply that is driving house prices to extraordinary heights."
By the time a baby takes its first breath, many crucial neural pathways have already been established.
These connections can influence how a baby perceives the world and might play a role in the development of conditions like autism, according to scientists.
However, understanding how this complex neural network forms in the womb remains largely unexplored.

Researchers from Guy's and St Thomas' Hospital, King's College London, Imperial College, and Oxford University are working to develop a detailed dynamic wiring map of brain growth that has been previously unattainable.
By tracking nerve bundles during the last three months of pregnancy, they hope to gain insights that can help address developmental issues when the process goes awry.

Prof David Edwards, director of the Centre for the Developing Brain and lead researcher, highlights the importance of prenatal scans: "There is a troubling number of children with developmental issues due to factors occurring around birth or shortly beforehand.
Scanning babies before birth is vital to capture changes in the brain, a period when many potential problems seem to manifest."
The Developing Human Connectome Project aims to study over 1,500 babies to explore various facets of their neurological development.

The study will examine brains of babies still in the womb, as well as those born prematurely and full-term, to establish benchmarks for normal development and assess influences from birth-related complications.
Their findings will be shared with the broader research community. Central to the project are advanced MRI techniques, which can now capture details of the developing brain previously inaccessible.

Foetuses often move freely within their amniotic sacs, complicating imaging. However, researchers at the Centre for the Developing Brain have devised methods to offset these movements, constructing complete three-dimensional images even as the foetus moves.
The 19 December attack resulted in twelve deaths. Amri fled to Italy, where police in Milan shot him dead.
Investigators suspect that Bilel A., 26, was either involved in planning the attack or was aware of it.
He was arrested on suspicion of benefit fraud due to insufficient evidence of his involvement in the attack.

On Wednesday, federal prosecutors' spokeswoman Frauke Koehler stated Bilel had known Amri since late 2015, and they had met for "very intense conversations" at a restaurant the evening before the attack.
Bilel's home, located in an asylum shelter, was searched by authorities, who confiscated communication devices for examination.
He reportedly used at least two false identities in several German cities between April and November 2015.
Investigators are also examining a former flatmate of Amri as a potential witness.
Amri attempted to contact this person twice on 19 December, though it remains unclear whether they spoke.
More than two weeks after the attack, German prosecutors confirmed without doubt that 24-year-old Anis Amri was responsible.
Investigators across Europe have gathered more details about the night of the attack and Amri's subsequent escape to Italy.
On Wednesday, Italian police confirmed the gun Amri used to kill Polish driver Lukasz Urban was the same one he fired in Milan four days later.

Just before the attack, Amri allegedly went to Friedrich-Krause-Ufer, a street where he shot Mr. Urban, then visited a mosque and returned to the truck to launch the attack at Breitscheidplatz, a few miles away.
Surveillance cameras later captured Amri near Zoo station, making an index finger gesture associated with the jihadist group Islamic State.
Although the details are unclear, Amri apparently fled to the North Rhine-Westphalia region in western Germany.
His final journey took him through the Netherlands, Belgium, France, and Italy, taking advantage of the Schengen zone's open borders.
Some aspects of Amri's story remain undisclosed, and Swiss police announced they have launched an investigation into the Berlin attack after receiving information from another law enforcement agency.
Casper Read, a 15-year-old traveling alone to his grandparents in France, was asked to leave a flight when another passenger was assigned the same seat.
His mother, Stephanie Portal from Worthing, West Sussex, shared that Casper felt "kicked off and cheated."
EasyJet has apologized, provided compensation, and is investigating the incident. "There was an adult demanding the seat, and Casper was forced to leave.
I don't know if it was a random choice, or if they assumed Casper would be easier to remove, but it’s wrong," Ms. Portal said.
Casper was initially sent to the cockpit, expecting a new seat, but was soon escorted off the plane and directed to the information desk.
Without assistance, he navigated the airport alone, missing three earlier flights before being placed on the last one, enduring a 10-hour wait.
Ms. Portal explained that an EasyJet manager informed her the airline overbooks by up to five seats because passengers sometimes don't show.
Those who check-in last, rather than those who purchase tickets last, risk losing their seats.
"The whole system needs reform, and the attendants' actions were irresponsible," she said.
"Children shouldn't be removed from flights, and affected passengers should get priority on the next available one.
Airlines shouldn't gamble on passengers not showing up." Casper, typically easy-going, felt "kicked off and cheated," his mother added.
An airline spokesperson stated: "EasyJet regrets that Casper Read's flight from London Gatwick to Toulouse was overbooked on July 20.
We are investigating why he boarded without being informed at the gate. EasyJet has procedures for unaccompanied minors, which weren't followed in this instance."
In February, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) reported that the increase in potential buyers reached its lowest point in nearly a year.
Improved mortgage deals have helped absorb some of the pent-up demand, the organization noted, but added that prices are still expected to rise.
Meanwhile, data from mortgage lenders indicate that the government's new Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme has lowered the average deposit needed from first-time buyers.
The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) reported that in January, the typical first-time deposit decreased to 18%, down from 20% in December.
However, the number of loans to first-time buyers and existing homeowners dipped, reflecting the usual seasonal slowdown.
Mortgages issued to home buyers in January were 16% lower compared to December, yet they were 30% higher than in January the previous year, showcasing the growth in sales over the past year.

Simon Rubinsohn, Rics' chief economist, suggested this lull might persist. "The growth in buyer numbers that we've witnessed for several months began to slow in February as the surge in interest from last summer started to stabilize," he remarked.
"This indicates that the pent-up demand accumulated during the downturn is gradually being met."
Rubinsohn also noted that bad weather, including floods, might have deterred property viewings.
Despite this, Rics highlighted a shortage of properties entering the market, likely driving prices higher.
The cost of a home in the UK continued to climb in February, albeit more slowly than in previous months.
Rics reported that 45% more chartered surveyors observed price increases rather than declines in February.
Their surveys show that home prices have risen nationwide for 11 straight months.
According to the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS), released in February, the average UK home price surpassed £250,000 for the first time.
The ONS stated that house prices rose by 5.5% last year. However, other sources present lower figures.
The Nationwide Building Society, one of the UK's largest mortgage lenders, reports the average UK home is valued at £177,846, with annual price growth exceeding 9%.
A review of 5,000 studies on golf and wellbeing found that the physical health benefits of playing golf increase with the player's age.
This analysis is part of the Golf and Health Project, led by the World Golf Foundation.
The project aims to explore research gaps such as golf's impact on mental health and muscle strengthening.
Dr. Roger Hawkes, executive director of the project, stated that the goal is to add "scientific rigour" to the claims about golf's health benefits.
"We've felt that we've underestimated golf's potential impact on health for several years," he remarked.
"We have a preliminary review that outlines existing knowledge, and we're planning to examine this research and identify knowledge gaps, so that in five years, we'll have solid evidence."
Firming up this information through thorough research will provide valuable resources.
Lead researcher Dr. Andrew Murray noted, "Evidence suggests golfers live longer than non-golfers, experiencing improvements in cholesterol, body composition, wellness, self-esteem, and self-worth.
Since the sport can be played by people of all ages, it showcases numerous health benefits across demographics."
The study indicated that playing golf can help individuals meet and exceed government recommendations for moderate to vigorous physical activity.
It noted that golfers walking 18 holes cover four to eight miles, while those using an electric cart travel about four miles, burning at least 500 calories.
World Golf Foundation CEO Steve Mona emphasized the importance of the Golf and Health Project for the sport's development.

"Everyone agrees golf is beneficial," Mona said. "Academic validation through in-depth research will provide substantial resources for governments, politicians, professional tours, governing bodies, golf businesses, PGA Professionals, and more, to the sport's advantage."
The research was released to coincide with the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship in St Andrews this week.
For more information on starting golf, check out the Get Inspired activity guide on the sport.
Katie Milby, a 13-year-old from the UK, has Morquio A syndrome, a degenerative disease affecting around 105 people in the country.
This condition causes a gradual decline in mobility, health, and stamina. Her friend, Kyle Pirrie, initiated a petition to make the drug Vimizim available through the NHS.
Although there's no cure for Morquio syndrome, Vimizim can significantly enhance the quality of life for those affected.
The drug works by replacing a missing enzyme, helping children to grow, improving their stamina and ability to walk, and alleviating pain.
The drug's manufacturer has been supplying it at their own cost but plans to halt this unless the NHS in England and Scotland decide to fund it.
According to Katie, a student at Stranraer Academy, her life would drastically change without the drug. "I wouldn't be able to move; I'd just be in so much pain," she said.
"And I probably wouldn't be able to go to school." This situation led her friend to start a petition, which has gathered nearly 2,000 signatures.
Kyle commented, "As a friend, I felt bad that she might be denied the treatment.
She has a great outlook on life—she's funny and friendly. I would hate to see her in constant pain."
Alex Fergusson, MSP for Galloway and West Dumfries, also supports the petition.
"This medication isn't cheap, but, as Katie asked, how do you put a value on a human life?"
Fergusson noted. "There are slightly over a hundred patients in the UK, with only five in Scotland.
Those treated with Vimizim report a significant reduction in pain and other symptoms."
Without treatment, life expectancy rarely exceeds the mid-20s, but Vimizim can extend it considerably.
Fergusson praised Katie and her friends for raising the petition to ensure the treatment's accessibility.
The Scottish Medicines Consortium is currently assessing the drug and expects to publish their decision in early September.
The government is offering a package including a pay raise and a lower retirement age for prison officers.
This deal will be subject to a union member vote. Last month, up to 10,000 prison officers in England and Wales protested against what they called a "surge" in jail violence.
They staged a 24-hour protest but went back to work when a High Court injunction demanded they end it.
The agreement allows officers to retire at age 65, three years earlier than the current state pension age, without any cost to them and with full pension benefits.
Uniformed staff will receive a consolidated pay increase of 0.5% to 1% annually for the next three years, in addition to performance-related pay rises.
They will also benefit from a "recognition and retention" package worth £1,000.
Prisons minister Sam Gyimah stated that the government and the POA have agreed on substantial health and safety reforms and new powers for governors regarding staff deployment in prisons.
The POA prompted action last month following failed discussions with the government over health and safety concerns.
This occurred after several serious incidents in prisons across England. In October, Jamal Mahmoud, an inmate at HMP Pentonville, was killed in a stabbing that also injured two others.
Additionally, prisoners caused nearly £1m in damages during a riot at Bedford prison last month.
Days later, at HMP Isle of Wight, an inmate attacked a prison officer with a razor blade.

To address safety concerns, Justice Secretary Liz Truss announced £1.3bn investment in new prisons over the next five years, which includes hiring 2,100 more prison officers, implementing drug tests for inmates upon entry and exit, and granting governors more autonomy.
Commenting on the new pay deal, she said: "This agreement is a good offer that appropriately acknowledges the hard work and dedication of officers nationwide doing a challenging job."
Fay, at 33, is poised to earn a record 185th cap as Scotland faces Slovenia in their opening Euro 2017 qualifier on Tuesday.
Since her debut in 1998 against the Czech Republic, Fay has been a cornerstone of the national team.
Reflecting on previous competitions, particularly the Holland matches, Fay considered whether it was time to retire.
The Celtic goalkeeper faced a pivotal decision after Scotland's two-leg loss to the Netherlands in the World Cup play-off for Canada.
She pondered many questions, with the ambition to reach a major championship being paramount.
"Qualifying for Euro 2017 would likely be the highlight of my career," she revealed.
Under coach Anna Signeul, Scotland has never had a better opportunity. The draw, featuring Belarus, Macedonia, and top seeds Iceland, is favorable.
With the tournament in the Netherlands two years away and expanded to allow two teams from most groups to qualify, expectations are high.
"There's external expectation for us to qualify, but we can't underestimate any team," Fay cautioned.
"We're not arrogant enough to guarantee we'll qualify. Instead, we focus on our strengths and hard work in each game.
We will respect every team and if we do that, I'm confident we will excel in this group."
The Scots are staying in Nova Gorica, near the Italian border, although the match is held in Ajdovscina, about 30 minutes away.
"The setting is beautiful," Fay commented on the venue nestled in a valley surrounded by towering mountains.
"The pitch suits us well, and hopefully they'll water it a bit before the game. It's an ideal place to start our campaign."
The network will initially consist of at least 600 spacecraft, with the potential to expand to over 2,000.
Its goal is to provide global broadband connectivity from orbit, with a particular focus on connecting schools.
Such an extensive constellation necessitates significant advancements in satellite manufacturing, especially for Airbus.
Europe's leading space company typically spends months and hundreds of millions on building specialized platforms, but the OneWeb initiative demands high volume and low-cost production.
This requires innovative assembly line techniques similar to those used in automotive and aircraft manufacturing, aiming to produce three units per shift at under a million dollars each.
Airbus CEO Tom Enders admits he initially considered the OneWeb concept unrealistic.
"Traditionally, everything in space has been 'gold-plated'; it had to work flawlessly, with the most expensive materials, etc.
We have had to think differently, focusing on being commercial and cost-effective, which is crucial for the OneWeb business model," he explained to BBC News.
Airbus and OneWeb have launched their first assembly line in Toulouse, France, with two additional lines planned for a new factory complex in Florida.
The standout feature of these lines compared to conventional satellite cleanrooms is the trolley robot that transports satellites between work stations.
But the transformation goes beyond automation; it involves suppliers and components adjusting to a new production scale.
The first 10 satellites from the Toulouse line are scheduled for launch in April next year, with additional batches following in November.

The launch frequency will then ramp up significantly. Establishing the OneWeb constellation demands the most extensive rocket campaign in spaceflight history, involving over 20 Soyuz launches to deploy clusters of 32-36 satellites at 1,200 km above Earth.
By the end of 2020, nearly 300 satellites should be operational, with over 600 a year later and more than 800 by mid-decade.
OneWeb and Airbus are contending with other firms like SpaceX, Boeing, ViaSat, and others seeking regulatory approval for similar mega-constellations.
However, not all will secure the necessary multi-billion-dollar financing, and Airbus sees OneWeb as having the first-mover advantage.
Kelly, 25, returned late from a trip to Australia and was subsequently benched for Saturday's loss to Leigh in the Qualifiers.
Peacock stated that discussions are "ongoing" regarding Kelly's disciplinary issue and his potential involvement in Sunday's match against London.
When asked about Kelly's future at the club next season, Peacock told BBC's Super League Show: "It's all up to Albert. Right now, everything is uncertain."
Since joining Hull KR at the start of 2015, Kelly has been instrumental, having led the Robins to the Challenge Cup final last season.
A win against Leigh could have moved Rovers to second place in the Qualifiers table, but the 25-18 home defeat left them in fourth, struggling to secure their Super League status for next season.
Former England captain Peacock added, "It was a tough decision because Albert has played very well for us this year, especially considering the game's significance.
But when you show compassion and allow someone time at home, and they extend their stay, disrupting preparation for possibly our most important game this year, you have to set boundaries.
It's disappointing, but his actions ultimately let down the club, the players, and the fans, as he chose to prioritize other matters over our collective goals."
Meanwhile, stand-off Maurice Blair will miss the match against London as he has been allowed to return to Australia for his brother's funeral.
The public vote, known as a referendum, is set for Thursday, June 23, 2016. Here’s Newsround’s breakdown of the ongoing relationship between the UK and the European Union.

In 2013, British Prime Minister David Cameron pledged that if the Conservative Party won the next general election, he would allow voters to decide whether the UK should remain in or leave the European Union. After winning the election last year, this promise is now moving forward.
A referendum is a vote in which all adults can participate, typically answering a "Yes" or "No" question.
The side with more than half the votes wins. The European Union (EU) is a coalition of 28 European countries whose governments collaborate.
It was founded after World War Two, based on the belief that closer cooperation among countries could prevent another war.
Joining is like becoming part of a club: members must adhere to rules but gain certain advantages.
Each member contributes funds, mostly through taxes, which the EU uses to influence how people live and conduct business in Europe.
The EU has its own parliament, composed of Members of the European Parliament who are elected by residents of EU countries.
One key role of the parliament is to modify, approve, or reject laws applicable to all EU countries.

The entry timeline for member countries is as follows: 1957: Belgium, France, Netherlands, Germany, Italy, and Luxembourg; 1973: Denmark, Ireland, and the UK; 1981: Greece; 1986: Portugal and Spain; 1995: Austria, Finland, and Sweden; 2004: Hungary, Poland, Czech Republic, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, and Cyprus; 2007: Bulgaria and Romania; 2013: Croatia.
The EU was largely established to facilitate trade, simplifying buying and selling between countries.
Immigration rules have also been eased, allowing freer movement within the Union.
EU laws impact numerous aspects of life, such as work hours, health and safety regulations, and even fishing quotas.
Throughout the UK's 40-year EU membership, there has been a persistent debate over its role.
Some argue that being part of the EU enhances the UK's wealth and significance, while others believe it diminishes British sovereignty.
Lexi Brown, whose full name is Alexys, passed away at her home on Emmadale Close in Weymouth on Thursday.
Authorities are currently investigating the circumstances that led to her becoming trapped.
A post-mortem examination is scheduled for this week. Initially, the fundraising appeal aimed to raise £2,000.
Alison Record, who launched the Just Giving campaign, expressed her heartbreak over Lexi's death.
The appeal page states: "Everyone is now aware of the tragic loss suffered by the Brown family with the passing of their cherished daughter, Lexi.
This is an inconceivable pain to endure, and they deserve the freedom to grieve without worrying about the financial burden on their family."
According to Record, "This tragedy has shattered them; they need time together, and all funds raised will help provide this opportunity."
Numerous comments have been left on the appeal page, showing solidarity and support.
Steph Harris commented: "Sending thoughts during this painful time, fly high beautiful princess.
Love Steph and family xxx" Lesley Andrews wrote: "While money won't ease the pain, each penny carries a lot of love.
Take care. xx" Aster Group, the housing association in charge of managing the property, is collaborating with the police in their investigation.
The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) is also examining the incident. Dorset County Council clarified that it did not install the disabled lift at the home.

Media playback is not supported on this device. At the Great City Games, 30-year-old London 2012 gold medalist claimed victory with a final jump of 8.18m, outpacing Uruguay's Emiliano Lasa, who jumped 7.96m.

Holly Bradshaw set a new British women's pole vault record at 4.80m. The event began with a minute's silence to honor the victims of Monday's tragic attack in Manchester, where a suicide bomber killed 22 and injured 116 as attendees left an Ariana Grande concert at Manchester Arena.
The council and police authorized the Great City Games to proceed in the city center, with the Great Manchester Run also planned for Sunday, broadcast on BBC One from 12:30 to 14:30 BST.
This was the first major event since the attack and attracted thousands to a sunny Deansgate and Albert Square, where a vigil was held earlier for the attack victims.
Rutherford provided a standout performance in the square, securing his win with an 8.08m jump on his second attempt, before extending his lead in his final jump.
"It's been amazing to see everyone out here supporting us," Rutherford remarked.
"It's been a tough week, and I'm thrilled to give you something to smile about.
Manchester is one of my favorite cities, not just for the football, but for the fantastic support you all show for sports.
It's truly special." Media playback is not supported on this device. Bradshaw had an outstanding evening, surpassing her personal best and breaking her previous British pole vault record.

Starting at 4.50m, the 25-year-old from Preston succeeded on her third attempt, overcoming her competitors, including Britons Rachel Gibbons, Sally Peake, and Belgium's Chloe Henry, who couldn't clear beyond 4m.
Bradshaw then exceeded her 2012 record of 4.71m, clearing 4.80m on her first try.
"It was nerve-wracking at the start," Bradshaw, who finished sixth at London 2012 and fifth in Rio, told BBC Sport.
"But conditions were excellent. Once I focused, I was thrilled to jump 4.72 and then 4.80. My training has been great, and I'm in the best shape I've ever been."
The £570 million extension of the Chilwell and Clifton tram lines began in March 2012, with public services starting at 06:00 BST.
Although it faced criticism for disrupting businesses and commuters, Nottingham City Council maintains that the project will significantly boost the local economy.
Initial delays were attributed to the unanticipated relocation of pipes and cables, followed by necessary track bed replacements.
The project features an initial budget of £570 million, 28 new stations, 11 miles of new track, 22 new trams, and a capacity for 20 million passengers.
Contractor Vinci has reported that these issues led to a £165 million loss in its civil engineering division.
Jane Urquhart, responsible for NET operations at Nottingham City Council, described it as "a really great day" for the city.
"With trams running every seven minutes, it will improve access to key locations across the city," she noted.
"The tram system is core to the city's integrated transport network, supporting efforts to reduce congestion, enhance the environment, and make Nottingham a better place to live, work, or visit."
Despite resisting setting an opening date, NET and the city council have completed final testing in recent weeks.

Steve Barber, vice president of the Light Rail Transit Association and a former Broxtowe borough councillor, expressed relief over the project's completion, noting its potential positive impact on Beeston and the city.
Stephen Knight, a butcher in Clifton, remarked, "We are optimistic. Trade dropped by a third due to disruptions, but workers have been supportive.

Now we hope to see the public return, despite ongoing parking restrictions." Lisa Withers, a local florist, was thrilled to be on the first tram from Clifton, noting the regeneration it promises for Nottingham.
"Today is fantastic for the city," she said, "and I believe the tram will drive progress for residents, workers, and visitors alike."
The central bank decided unanimously to raise the key interest rate to between 0.5% and 0.75%, citing stronger economic growth and rising employment.
Despite this, the bank stated it anticipated only "gradual" rate increases in the short term.
Fed Chair Janet Yellen described the economic outlook as "highly uncertain" and regarded the rate hike as merely a "modest shift."
She suggested that with the incoming Trump administration, rates might need to increase more quickly next year.
President-elect Trump has pledged to boost growth through tax cuts, increased spending, and deregulation.
During a post-announcement news conference, Yellen noted it was premature to speculate on Trump's economic strategy without further details.

However, she pointed out that some Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) members have already incorporated anticipated increased spending into their forecasts, which has led to an expectation of three rate hikes next year instead of the two forecasted in September.

Addressing the news conference, Yellen remarked, "We are operating under a cloud of uncertainty... All the FOMC participants recognize the considerable uncertainty about potential changes in economic policy and their effects on the economy."
Yellen also refrained from responding to Trump’s public comments on the Fed or his use of tweets for policy announcements and criticism of companies.
"I strongly believe in the independence of the Fed," she said, adding, "I won't offer the incoming president advice."
The interest rate increase was anticipated, marking the first rise since the previous year.

Rates have been near zero following the global financial crisis, but the U.S. economy is showing recovery, as evidenced by recent data on consumer confidence, job growth, house prices, and expansions in manufacturing and services.
Yellen characterized the rate hike as a reflection of confidence in the economy's progress and the expectation of continued progress.
While inflation remains below the Fed's 2% target, the Fed expects gradual price increases over the medium term.
The Fed statement noted, "Economic conditions will warrant only gradual increases in the federal funds rate," adding that the rate is expected to stay below longer-term levels for some time.
Additionally, the Fed released its economic forecasts for the next three years.
Alexander Wotherspoon, 83, appeared at Paisley Sheriff Court facing charges related to the death of 17-year-old Eilish Herron, resulting from driving without due care and attention.
In September 2014, Eilish was struck by Mr. Wotherspoon's car at an Asda petrol station in Linwood.

The charge alleges he lost control of the vehicle while reversing. Mr. Wotherspoon, who resides in Houston, Renfrewshire, and uses a zimmer frame for walking, denied claims that he started the engine and reversed with the driver’s door open, leading to a loss of control.

According to the charge, his vehicle hit the Renault Clio Eilish was refueling, causing her to fall, displacing her car, and ultimately reversing over her, dragging her underneath and inflicting fatal injuries.
The incident occurred at the Asda petrol station in Phoenix Retail Park, Linwood, on 10 September 2014.
Sheriff Susan Sinclair has postponed the case for a trial in August and continued Mr. Wotherspoon’s bail.
Previously, Eilish's mother, Shanneal, 47, expressed: "Eilish was a wonderful girl, a typical teenager who cherished her life, family, and sports.
She was my best friend, and we shared many laughs. Her absence is indescribable for our family, as we are very close-knit."
Eilish was passionate about netball and played for Paisley Juniors, also volunteering as a junior coach.
Following her death, Netball Scotland inaugurated the Eilish Herron Young Coach of the Year Award, an annual award honoring young coaches.
Jason Alexander, 39, misused a company credit card to purchase nearly £91,000 worth of iPads, phones, and computers.
Residing in Griffithstown, Torfaen, Alexander pled guilty to fraud and received a two-year prison sentence in January.
On Thursday, at Cardiff Crown Court, a judge mandated that he repay £115,000 to his former employers.
"It appears your actions were motivated by a sort of philanthropic intent," stated Judge Stephen Hopkins QC.
"You spent up to £5,000 on various items, only to sell them to employees for as little as £180, under the guise of enabling them to afford these items."
Alexander must pay £115,867 within six months or face an additional 18 months in jail.
"Your actions have profoundly affected numerous innocent people," the judge remarked.
"Those who bought goods from you now feel foolish and distressed. The impact on your colleagues was significant, leading to decreased morale.

This constituted a severe breach of trust over many years." As the purchasing manager at Northern Automotive Systems, a car parts company in Gilwern near Abergavenny, Monmouthshire, Alexander made 287 online purchases through sites like Amazon, eBay, and Argos.
While the company's typical monthly credit card bill was a few hundred pounds, under Alexander, it rose to nearly £10,000 a month.
His fraudulent activity was uncovered when suspicious company managers asked employees if they had acquired discounted electronics.
To conceal his scheme, Alexander deleted emails and falsified invoices, receipts, and card statements.
During his 14-year tenure, he also used company funds to buy petrol for his white Land Rover, a red Mini, and his partner’s Ford Fiesta.
The 39-year-old cyclist, who claimed silver in Beijing in 2008, suffered a back injury during training.
She parted ways with cycling on a critical note regarding her treatment as an athlete.
Houvenaghel plans to resume her career in dentistry, where she anticipates being treated equally, saying, "As a woman in my thirties, I will be treated as an equal."
She had previously criticized her Great Britain teammates and coach Shane Sutton for excluding her from the team pursuit events at the London Olympics two years ago.
"The past decade of my life has been dedicated to professional cycling and it has, for the most part, been extremely rewarding," she expressed.
"I have consistently dedicated myself entirely to my role as a professional sportswoman, and I am immensely proud of my achievements from the start."
The County Londonderry native secured an Olympic silver for Great Britain in the individual pursuit in Beijing and won team pursuit golds at the World Championships in 2008, 2009, and 2011.
Based in Cornwall, Houvenaghel represented England in the 2006 Commonwealth Games before earning silver for Northern Ireland in Delhi four years later.
She hoped to conclude her track career with a final podium appearance in Glasgow but has been forced to withdraw due to an injury.
"Deciding to end one's sporting career is never easy," she admitted. "It is disappointing to withdraw from the Commonwealth Games competition.
However, I wish my Northern Irish teammates every success in Glasgow. In the future, I hope to contribute something back to the sport, but for now, I am eager to pursue my dentistry career."
Commenting on Houvenaghel's remarks about sexism in cycling, former Team GB track cyclist Victoria Pendleton concurred that women face different treatment.
The Olympic gold medalist and former world champion stated on BBC Radio 5 live: "The world of sport, unfortunately, remains predominantly male-dominated, and navigating it can be challenging."

Pendleton, who retired after the 2012 Olympics at the age of 31, added: "Throughout my career, I sometimes felt that I wasn't as well supported as a female, and had to adopt a more male-oriented approach.
I can understand how she could have benefited from a different kind of support."
Portugal, leading their Euro 2016 qualifying group, chose to rest Cristiano Ronaldo against Cape Verde, ranked 38th in the world.
Cape Verde took the lead through Odair Fortes, and Admilson Gege extended their advantage after halftime.
Host Portugal faced further setbacks when defender Andre Pinto was sent off an hour into the match.
Although eliminated early from this year's Africa Cup of Nations, Cape Verde ranks between Wales and Scotland in FIFA's world standings.
Located roughly 400 miles west of Senegal in the Atlantic Ocean, Cape Verde secured a 2-0 victory over Portugal.
The match concluded with Portugal unable to score, despite efforts such as Ukra's right-footed shot narrowly missing the target from outside the box, assisted by André Almeida.
Portugal earned numerous free kicks due to fouls from Cape Verde players, including Jeffry Fortes and Nuno Rocha.
Several substitutions were made by both teams, including André Almeida replacing André Gomes for Portugal, and Ricardo replacing Júlio Tavares for Cape Verde.

Despite Portugal's attempts, including a missed header by André André from a Vitorino Antunes cross, Cape Verde's defense held strong, with Sérgio Semedo receiving a yellow card late in the game. The match ended with Portugal unable to overcome Cape Verde's early lead.
Katharine of Aragon passed away at Kimbolton Castle in 1536 and was buried after a grand funeral at the cathedral.
An annual festival commemorates her death, with a Catholic mass—a rarity in an Anglican cathedral—held in her honor.
This intriguing story is part of the BBC's People's Passion series, which examines the role of cathedrals today.
Henry VIII cast Katharine aside because she couldn’t provide a male heir for the Tudor dynasty.
Stuart Orme from Vivacity Heritage, which co-organizes the Katharine of Aragon Festival, noted, "She was cherished for her piety and dignity."
Many sympathized with Katharine after her divorce, believing she had been unjustly treated.

Despite living in reduced means after her divorce, she had a lavish funeral on January 29, 1536, attended by four bishops and six abbots. Her tomb featured black marble with gilded inscriptions and designs.
Mr. Orme explained that Oliver Cromwell's soldiers stole the gilding during the 1643 sacking of the cathedral, and a later dean used the marble for his summerhouse floor in the 1700s.

It wasn't until the late 19th century that Katharine Clayton, the wife of a cathedral canon, began a campaign for all English Katharines to contribute towards a new marble slab, the one visible today.
The funeral's anniversary is commemorated with the Katharine of Aragon Festival on the Friday and Saturday closest to January 29.
A Spanish embassy representative is invited to a civic service on Friday, with a Catholic mass on Saturday.
Hundreds of children, dressed in Tudor costumes, learn about 16th-century life through historical reenactments.
Flowers and Katharine’s emblem, the pomegranate, are placed on her tomb. As a princess in Spain, she chose the pomegranate for its medieval symbolism of fertility.

In a remarkable performance that saw the Lions triumph over Sri Lanka A, their record-breaking 367-run partnership contributed to an impressive 425-1 total—ranking as the second highest in List A games.
Duckett excelled with an undefeated 220 off 131 balls, marking the ninth-highest List A score ever, while Bell-Drummond added 171 off 139 balls.
"These players are fully capable of playing international cricket," said Flower, now coaching the Lions.
The tri-series was a success for Flower's team, which won twice against both Pakistan A and Sri Lanka A, with batsmen exceeding scores of 150 in every match.
Duckett scored 163 not out, powering the team to a seven-wicket victory against Pakistan A on July 19, and continued his form in Monday's 140-run win.
Dawid Malan, a 28-year-old Middlesex batsman recently called up for England's Twenty20 squad against Sri Lanka, hit 185 in an 88-run Duckworth-Lewis victory against Sri Lanka on July 21.
Established international Sam Billings, with experience in five ODIs and seven T20s, scored 175 in Sunday's second win over Pakistan.
"These young players will improve English cricket as they fight to secure their place," Flower told the Tuffers and Vaughan Cricket Show on BBC Radio 5 live.
"These young men must push to earn their spot. Their innings and partnerships were incredible; the selectors will surely take notice."
Flower, who led England's national team from 2009 to 2014, especially commended Northants' 21-year-old opener Duckett, calling him "a very talented young man."
"While we can't predict the future, there's no reason Duckett shouldn't have a successful international career," Flower added.
Arek Jozwik, aged 39, was assaulted in Harlow, Essex, last month. A few days afterward, two other Polish men were attacked during a vigil for Mr. Jozwik.
According to Essex Police, Polish officers have been deployed to "reassure the community."
The police commissioner for Essex noted that there has been an increase in offensive remarks directed at non-British people following the Brexit vote.
Essex’s Police and Crime Commissioner, Roger Hirst, expressed on the BBC: "There is certainly a shift in public sentiment... that wasn't apparent a few months ago.

It seems to correlate with the Brexit decision." To stay updated on this and other news from Essex, the community engagement team, including 2nd Lieutenant Bartosz Czernicki and Chief Sergeant Dariusz Tybura, will spend seven days interacting with the public to provide reassurance, he noted.
Chief Inspector Alan Ray from Essex Police pointed out that some residents told him, "We don't trust police officers based on our experiences in Poland," while others welcomed the Polish officers.
Mr. Jozwik succumbed to head injuries on August 29, two days after reportedly being knocked to the ground with a single punch in The Stow, Harlow.
Chief Inspector Ray emphasized that the presence of Polish officers aims to provide reassurance across all communities.
"There is apprehension towards both Polish and English police from various communities.
While some will have confidence in us, others may not." Six teenagers have been arrested and are currently out on police bail concerning Mr. Jozwik's death.
Lord Advocate James Wolffe warned that Scots' safety and security would suffer without the UK's participation in Europol.
In an online article, he supported the Scottish government's call for the UK to adopt new regulations for the EU police agency.
If the Home Office does not opt in, the UK will lose its membership by May 2017. Wolffe was set to meet with MEPs and senior lawyers in Brussels on Wednesday.
In EurActiv, he expressed: "I firmly believe it is not in Scotland's, the UK's, nor Europe's interest to abandon criminal justice cooperation mechanisms due to the referendum outcome.
We should remain fully engaged to maximize our contribution and influence on their development."
The UK must decide whether to join the new Europol regulations by December 2016.
Scotland's Justice Secretary Michael Matheson urged the UK government to confirm participation.
Wolffe echoed this, stating that involvement in Europol and Eurojust is crucial for Scotland.
He added, "Without them, our citizens' safety will, in my opinion, be compromised.
The threat from transnational crime is too pressing to weaken our commitment to police and judicial cooperation in Europe."
UK policing and fire minister Brandon Lewis responded: "The prime minister has assured that law enforcement cooperation will continue post-EU, and we will secure our citizens' safety.

The government will soon decide on opting into the new Europol regulation. The UK remains a full Europol member, with the choice to opt into its new legislative framework as long as we are in the EU."
Since 2011, Scottish courts have handled 541 cases involving the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) through Europol, resulting in 367 extraditions from Scotland.
Additionally, the Crown Office issued 45 EAWs to swiftly bring individuals back to Scotland to stand trial for serious crimes.
In the past year, the EAW system has been further strengthened in the UK through access to the Schengen Information System.
He, along with his son Bello Abba Mohammed, is accused of diverting $1.5 million (£1 million) intended for purchasing arms for soldiers combating the Islamist Boko Haram militants.
Both have pleaded not guilty. President Muhammadu Buhari, who assumed office in May, launched an investigation into military weapon procurement, uncovering phantom contracts worth $2 billion.
Last month, former national security adviser Sambu Dasuki was arrested and faced 19 charges of fraud, money laundering, and criminal breach of trust related to the case.
Mr. Dasuki, responsible for directing efforts against Boko Haram under President Goodluck Jonathan, denied the accusations.

Bello Haliru Mohammed, who served as Mr. Jonathan's defense minister from 2011 to 2012 and currently holds a senior role in the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP), appeared at the Abuja High Court on Tuesday in a wheelchair and was moved to a hospital after the case was adjourned, according to the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC).
His son was detained in prison pending a bail hearing scheduled for Thursday. Boko Haram's six-year campaign to establish an Islamic state in northeastern Nigeria has claimed thousands of lives.
Soldiers had expressed concerns over inadequate equipment despite the military's substantial budget.

They now report being better equipped since President Buhari's tenure began. However, supporters of the previous president argue this improved armament is due to orders placed during Mr. Jonathan’s administration, notes the BBC’s Abuja editor, Bashir Sa’ad Abdullahi.
Before and after their 2-0 friendly victory over Romania in Falkirk on Friday, players chose not to speak to the media.
This decision comes as Anna Signeul's team prepares for next month's Euro 2017 finals in the Netherlands.
The Scottish FA expressed its disappointment in a statement, noting that the players have decided against fulfilling their media obligations.
However, the organization hopes to reach a resolution before Tuesday's friendly against Sweden in Vaxjo.
"We confirm that we are in talks with the Scotland Women's national team players about terms and conditions leading up to the women's Euros in the Netherlands next month," the statement read.
"We aim to resolve this issue promptly through discussions with their advisors."
Scotland's players who are based in the country are being financially supported to go full-time in preparation for the finals, where they will compete against England, Portugal, and Spain.
A funding package arranged by the Scottish Football Partnership, Sport Scotland, and energy company SSE will provide the necessary finances until the tournament concludes.

About half the team is expected to benefit from this plan. Head coach Signeul distanced herself from the negotiations, stating that coaches should not be involved, as it's a matter between the players and the SFA.
"I'm not involved at all in that process," Signeul said, noting that the same is true for men's head coach Gordon Strachan.
"Men's teams also negotiate contracts, and I don't believe Gordon is involved in these matters either; it's separate from the coaches." Signeul is set to announce her squad for Euro 2017 on June 20.

Amid fierce market competition, Sainsbury's, the UK's second-largest supermarket, reported a 1.1% drop in like-for-like sales, excluding fuel, in the 16 weeks leading to September 24th, while total sales decreased by 0.4%.
Despite these declines, Chief Executive Mike Coupe expressed confidence that their strategy would enable them to outperform major competitors.
To counteract challenges from rapidly expanding German discount chains Aldi and Lidl, Sainsbury's has adopted a strategy of lowering prices on everyday products instead of relying on promotions.
During this quarter, they reduced the prices of items like broccoli, onions, Margherita pizza, and own-brand nappies.

Coupe claimed customers consistently prefer Sainsbury's over rivals. In a significant move, Sainsbury's completed a £1.4bn acquisition of Argos-owner Home Retail Group, aimed at diversifying customer shopping options.
Following this, Sainsbury's plans to open 200 digital collection points in its stores by the year's end.
Home Retail Group reported a 2.3% rise in like-for-like sales in the second quarter leading to August 27th, prior to Sainsbury's acquisition.

Facing competition from online giant Amazon's grocery delivery service, Sainsbury's is also expanding a test of its "Chop Chop," a one-hour delivery service in London using bicycles, enhancing customer shopping flexibility.
Sainsbury's has faced two consecutive years of declining profits, with analysts predicting another drop in the 2016-17 fiscal year.
Underlying profits for the year ending March 12 fell from £681m to £587m. Over the past six months, the group's shares have declined by 9%.
John Ibbotson, director of Retail Vision, critiqued Sainsbury's simpler pricing strategy and elimination of multi-buy promotions as "distinctly underwhelming" in the current tough market.
However, he projected that Argos could positively impact Sainsbury's bottom line and enhance its internet offerings and logistics.
He cautioned, though, that integrating the two companies would be demanding, and emphasized the importance of maintaining focus on Sainsbury's core grocery business.
Meanwhile, Aldi recently revealed the ongoing price war's impact on its profit margins, indicating no immunity to market pressures.
The suspension occurred shortly after Germany's Lufthansa announced it would halt services to Venezuela.

The German airline cited millions owed to them in ticket revenue by Venezuela. The country's economy, heavily reliant on oil, has been severely impacted by the global decline in oil prices, leading to high inflation and persistent shortages of basic goods.
Several airlines have reported difficulties in converting their earnings into dollars due to Venezuela's currency controls, making it impossible to transfer funds abroad.
Latam Airlines stated it would suspend flights to Caracas Airport "temporarily and for an unspecified duration."
Flights on the Sao Paulo to Caracas route would be terminated first, within days, followed by the cessation of routes from Lima and Santiago by the end of July.

Venezuela's currency controls initially imposed by the late President Hugo Chavez in 2003, have been tightened further in the past two years, compelling numerous airlines to cut back operations as they faced challenges repatriating billions of dollars in revenue held in bolivars.

Some airlines have started requiring passengers to pay fares in dollars. The Venezuelan government claims it is using its dwindling foreign reserves to purchase essential goods such as medicines and industrial equipment.
Recently, Coca-Cola announced a halt to production of some soft drinks due to sugar shortages, while Bridgestone ended its over 60-year presence in the country.

A smart doorbell, a connected camera, a child's toy, and a child monitoring locator were all discovered to be prone to simple attacks due to default passwords and poor security practices, which could have exposed data to attackers, according to research teams.
Fortunately, all four companies took action after receiving warnings, improving their code and closing security loopholes.
"The issue with the Internet of Things today is that everyone is unwittingly becoming part of the IT sector," said Tod Beardsley, security research manager at Rapid7.
He identified issues with two devices, highlighting that while IoT manufacturers are confidently developing code, few take the necessary design steps to ensure their smart devices are secure.

Beardsley reviewed two devices from different companies, finding that communication by the bear toy with the web was poorly configured, potentially allowing attackers to learn about the child owner, their family, and home network.
Similar security risks were found with the HereO watch, which could have let an attacker join a family's group of watches.

HereO's chief technology officer, Eli Shemesh, stated his team resolved the issue within four hours of notification and expressed gratitude for Rapid7's input as well as support from the global IoT community in maintaining a zero-tolerance environment for user safety.
Shemesh assured that since HereO had not yet commercialized its GPS watches, no child was ever at risk of malicious activity.

Meanwhile, Context IS researchers identified security vulnerabilities with a Motorola Focus outdoor camera, which could allow an attacker to take control of the camera remotely and use it as a gateway to infiltrate the connected network.
Security experts at Pentest Partners detected issues with Ring, a smart doorbell equipped with a video camera that streams video callers to a phone app.
By removing the device cover and pressing its setup button, the Wi-Fi network key could potentially be retrieved, according to the firm.
All security flaws identified by the researchers have been reported to the respective companies, who have since patched or fixed these issues.
Ken Munro from Pentest Partners noted that Era Home Security promptly addressed the reported bug.
According to an informal rotation system, the ninth Secretary-General should come from Eastern Europe.
However, the region risks losing this opportunity due to a lack of robust support for national candidates at home and insufficient regional unity in backing a single contender.
Although the selection process has become more transparent with open hearings, it has resulted in 11 candidates, eight of whom are from Eastern Europe.
The pool includes former or current foreign ministers from Moldova, Macedonia, Montenegro, Croatia, Serbia, and Slovakia, as well as Slovenia's former president.
Bulgaria has put forward Irina Bokova, the current head of UNESCO, the UN's cultural and educational branch.

Observers note that these candidates could undermine each other's chances, clearing the path for strong contenders like Argentina's Susana Malcorra, New Zealand's Helen Clark, or Portugal's former UNHCR head, Antonio Guterres.
A Security Council straw poll in July will offer clearer indications of each candidate's support.
More candidates may emerge; Kristalena Georgieva from Bulgaria is reportedly considering entering the race.
She expressed interest to the BBC, noting, "I am obviously watching the race closely.
Many people are encouraging me to join. Let's see what happens." She is backed by several countries.

Initially, Ms. Bokova was a leading candidate, with significant Russian support, but her prospects have suffered due to a critical UNESCO investigation and her stance on Palestinian statehood, which the U.S. opposes.

Currently, nearly half of UNESCO's budget goes towards staff salaries. By contrast, Ms. Georgieva has a notable record at the World Bank, and as a former EU commissioner for humanitarian affairs and current commissioner for budgetary affairs.
She led an initiative that proposed saving $1 billion annually by directly funding those in need.
More information on the candidates and the selection process can be found on the UN's website.
Richard Gowan of the European Council on Foreign Relations remarked, "Insiders say that either Kristalena Georgieva or Antonio Guterres could give the UN the kind of push it needs."
Many agree that the next UN leader should be a skilled manager with experience in international organizations.
Jenny Rathbone and Mike Hedges are separately applying to participate in a ballot that, if they win, will allow them to propose a bill to ban agency fees.
Mr. Hedges described these fees as a "tax" affecting some of the poorest society members, with students being heavily impacted.
However, a letting agent argued that a ban could undermine efforts to professionalize the sector.
The Welsh Government expressed willingness to explore how such legislation might be implemented.
Similar charges have already been banned in Scotland, and the UK government plans to consider banning them in England.
Though Wales lacks firm plans for a ban, the Welsh Government is "actively considering" it, amid criticism for not acting sooner.
