Assembly members (AMs) from all opposition parties support a ban. AMs can propose new laws through a random ballot.
Mr. Hedges stated that these fees are a major issue in university cities and areas with high housing demand.
He estimates about 20 AMs may apply to enter the ballot, but only he and Ms. Rathbone are known to be pushing for the ban.
Cardiff Council AM Jenny Rathbone noted that having both of them apply "doubles the chances of one of us being picked."
Catherine Iannucci, a 21-year-old history and politics student at Cardiff University, lives in a house with six co-tenants and reported paying £80 each to secure their home, totaling £560 in fees.
Ms. Iannucci, a member of Labour Students who has researched agency fees for Ms. Rathbone, said, "It's a significant amount of money.
We don't really know what they're for or what they cover." She also paid a month's rent as a deposit plus £50.
"During the term's middle, when we search around February, nobody has spare money.
It adds pressure for the rest of the term," she explained. She supports a ban as long as rents don’t increase as a consequence.
The new cement material effectively develops mineral phases capable of trapping radioactive isotopes attempting to pass through.
Atomic-scale investigations suggest this cement can retain its trapping ability for at least 2,000 years.
Researchers at Sheffield University assert that their mix is up to 50% more effective than previously proposed barriers.
Eventually, the government will select a site for an underground facility to store hundreds of thousands of cubic meters of nuclear waste accumulated over the past 60 years.
Much of this waste will be immobilized and backfilled with cement, which must prevent radioisotopes from dispersing far into the future.
Experiments by the Sheffield team were conducted at the Diamond Light Source in Oxfordshire, the UK's prominent synchrotron, which uses X-rays to examine samples at the smallest scales.
Diamond now features a dedicated lab, known as a beamline, for long-duration studies.
This facility enabled Dr. Claire Corkhill and colleagues to assess the properties of various cement mixes over the last 18 months.

"We've obtained high-resolution data, which allows us to create predictive models to understand phase formation and timing up to 2,000 years—coinciding with when we expect water interaction with a geological disposal site," mentioned Dr. Corkhill of the Sheffield NucleUS research group.
Their optimal cement, provisionally named No7, includes blast-furnace slag. The sulphides from slag react with water to form sulphate mineral phases, which are excellent at absorbing technetium-99.
"Technetium-99 is a prevalent fission product found only in nuclear reactors and is highly mobile in the environment.
However, our cement effectively locks it within its structure, preventing environmental transport," Dr. Corkhill explained.
Their research indicates No7 greatly outperforms the currently proposed Nirex Reference Vault Backfill cement barrier.
However, research continues on other mixes to discover even more effective solutions.
This cement research was presented at the AAAS annual meeting, along with the Diamond facility for long-duration experiments.
This unique facility allows scientists to study the temporal behavior of materials, where samples are placed on a robotic bench and monitored autonomously.
Teams held discussions with F1's commercial chief Bernie Ecclestone and Jean Todt, president of the FIA, regarding the failure of the new elimination format.
Despite the teams' preferences for reverting to the 2015 system, Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff noted that Todt and Ecclestone declined to do so.

The FIA proposed a new aggregate system that will be reconsidered next week. Lewis Hamilton secured the fastest qualifying time for Sunday's race in Bahrain, yet during the first and second sessions, there were moments without any cars on track towards the end.
Red Bull team principal Christian Horner stated that all parties agreed the newly introduced system, where the slowest car is removed every 90 seconds across three sessions, is not ideal.
Horner remarked, "There's a reluctance from the promoter and FIA to return to 2015.
The teams are willing to go back. A compromise has been suggested for teams to contemplate. Let's consider what's on the table now.
If we don't agree to a compromise, we're stuck with the current format, and everyone agrees it's not right."

Horner and Wolff expressed uncertainty about why Ecclestone and Todt were against reverting to the 2015 format, where all eligible cars continued to the end of a session before the slowest few were eliminated, gradually reducing car numbers over three sessions.
Todt explained at a Saturday news conference that race promoters requested a different system, fearing the 2015 format lacked excitement.
Ecclestone has emphasized his desire to mix up grids so the fastest cars aren't always leading.
Horner mentioned the proposal to return to the 2015 format, but with grid positions based on drivers' two fastest laps instead of just their single fastest.
Horner suggested the plan "requires further examination, possibly with an aggregate time of two laps instead of one, needing thorough consideration before proceeding to a vote."
The Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index revealed that UK services saw the largest month-on-month increase in the survey's history.
Initially, the pound surged to $1.3372 against the dollar but later settled at $1.3312, marking a modest rise of 0.13%.
Some analysts believe this data suggests the UK could sidestep a recession later this year.
"Sterling strength is on the horizon as today's PMI figures imply the reported post-EU referendum activity drop might be temporary," said Ranko Berich of Monex Europe.
"This changes the prospects of a severe economic downturn in the third quarter, which many believed was inevitable," he added.
However, other analysts advised caution. "These PMIs are just surveys—robust economic data in the coming months will be vital.
It's easy to overinterpret a single month's survey. We're not out of the woods yet," noted Neil Wilson, markets analyst at ETX Capital. The FTSE 100 barely reacted, dipping 15 points to 6,879.
Banks dragged the index down, with Royal Bank of Scotland decreasing by 3.5% and Lloyds Banking Group slipping 2.1% after negative Deutsche Bank comments.
Mining stocks were a bright spot, with BHP Billiton and Randgold Resources rising by 1.3% and 1.6%, respectively.
Marks and Spencer shares fell 1.4% after confirming plans to cut over 500 jobs at its head office. US financial markets were closed for Labor Day.
Forty-nine children lost their lives and more than 70 were severely injured when a fire engulfed the ABC nursery, which lacked an emergency exit.
Victims' relatives have long sought justice, claiming the nursery failed to comply with safety regulations.
However, a lawyer representing the group said the arrest warrants targeted the wrong individuals.
Prosecutors requested these warrants for the nursery's director and some management and teachers.
Gabriel Alvarado, from Hands United for Our Children, called this decision "erroneous," arguing it was directed at the wrong people.
He noted that some of those facing arrest had risked and even injured themselves trying to save the children.
Alvarado mentioned one teacher facing arrest has a daughter who suffered burns on 95% of her body in the fire. "This girl could now witness her own mother being imprisoned," he remarked.
The fire began in a warehouse in Hermosillo on June 5, 2009, quickly spreading over the roof to the nursery where the children were napping.
The nursery lacked a sprinkler system and fire extinguishers, had faulty smoke alarms, and poorly trained staff.
The relatives argue the tragedy could have been prevented with proper safety measures.
They also highlight that a nursery should not have been located near a building storing tires and flammable materials.
They are frustrated that despite many officials being put on trial, only the government official who conducted the nursery's final safety inspection has spent time in prison.

Their frustration grew after a media report last year suggested the warehouse fire might have been intentionally set to destroy compromising local government documents. The official report, however, attributed the fire to a short circuit.
England's upcoming match marks their first competitive game since their lackluster exit from the World Cup.
Hodgson has stated, "We need to perform well here. If the result isn't favorable, we must learn from this setback and focus on long-term success.
Winning this single match won't insure greatness in 2016, just as losing it won't make us a subpar team."
Monday's fixture initiates England's qualifying campaign for the tournament in France, featuring 24 teams in the European Championships for the first time.
After facing Switzerland, Hodgson's team will engage in nine more matches in Group E over the next 13 months, aiming to secure a spot at the finals.
Automatic qualification is granted to the top two teams in each group, along with the best third-placed side.

The remaining third-place teams will compete in play-offs. England's previous competitive encounter ended in a goalless draw against Costa Rica in Brazil last June, eliminating them from the group stage after losses to Italy and Uruguay.
Hodgson, appointed in 2012 and having led England to the Euro quarter-finals that year, acknowledges the lingering disappointment from the World Cup.
Still, he asserts that this challenging fixture in the Euro 2016 qualifiers isn't an entirely fresh start, as he prepares for the upcoming European Championship finals.
"We’re not in the early stages of development," he noted. "We're progressing, despite the World Cup setback.
This isn't a completely new squad. Players like Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling have been with us before.
However, it's still early days, and we must ensure that we're much stronger in the next two years."

The game against Switzerland follows England's narrow 1-0 friendly victory over Norway at Wembley, where Hodgson showed frustration when confronted with the statistic that his team managed only two shots on target, including Wayne Rooney's penalty goal.
Asked about facing criticism post-World Cup, Hodgson replied, "There's no nasty side to this.
I love this job. It's a magnificent opportunity. Coaching your country is the pinnacle of a coaching career.
Am I aware there was a downturn in popularity following the World Cup disappointment? I'd be surprised if there hadn't been."
The Private Infrastructure Development Group (PIDG) has accumulated a £27 million surplus following increased donations from the British government.
The National Audit Office (NAO) has advised ministers to closely monitor PIDG's expenditures.
Recent projects funded by PIDG include a steel foundry in Nigeria and a hydropower scheme in Uganda.
PIDG has updated its travel policy, previously allowing board members to claim more costly flexible business class tickets.
However, Margaret Hodge, Chair of the Commons Public Accounts Committee, criticized the Department for International Development (DfID) for inadequate oversight of spending.
Mrs. Hodge pointed out, "It's outrageous that 15 flights were booked since 2011, each costing over £5,000.
Only now has PIDG revised its travel policy. DfID needs to better control such administrative costs."

Established in 2002 by the UK, Switzerland, Holland, and Sweden, the PIDG aims to foster private investment in infrastructure projects in developing countries, like roads, telecoms, sanitation, housing, agriculture, power, and industry.
The UK, providing 70% of PIDG's funding, is expected to contribute £700 million by 2015.
UK funding for PIDG increased fivefold in 2011, in line with the government's policy of promoting private investment in the developing world.
Despite this, the NAO noted that a significant portion of these funds remains unallocated to projects, with the PIDG Trust holding £27 million.
Amyas Morse, head of the NAO, commented, "While PIDG benefits poor communities in challenging settings, DfID lacks sufficient evidence to prove that funding PIDG is the optimal choice.
Moreover, DfID's financial oversight has been weak, allowing PIDG Trust to retain nearly £27 million of DfID funding since 2012.
Although recent progress has been made to address these issues, more proactive measures should have been taken earlier, considering the 2011 decision to increase funding for PIDG."

The report also criticizes two PIDG subsidiaries, GuarantCo and the Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund (EAIF), established by UK Prime Minister Tony Blair in 2002, which are incorporated in the tax haven of Mauritius.

War on Want has condemned this setup, arguing that it contradicts Prime Minister David Cameron's commitment to tax justice for impoverished nations. The NAO remarked that this arrangement "raises reputational risks" for DfID.
The region's chief operating officer has announced that the claims of head coach Sean Holley and forwards coach Jonathan Humphreys will be reviewed.
New Zealander Hore, a former Wales fitness coach, stated: "We will definitely consider both situations."
Johnson is set to become the senior assistant coach for Scotland's head coach Andy Robinson. Hore explained: "We've been discussing our next steps for quite some time.
We want to review the blueprint we initiated four years ago when we brought Johnson in to help develop our coaches and establish effective systems.
Are we satisfied with our current progress? We need to assess this now and decide if we should bring in someone new or continue with our internal team.

If we choose to stay internal, we need to decide who will lead." Hore acknowledged that the holiday season has made it challenging for the Ospreys' decision-makers, like joint managing directors Roger Blyth and Mike Cuddy, to convene on this issue.
"Many directors have been away because of the holidays, and the news about Johnson leaving arrived sooner than expected," Hore noted.
"So, we still have some work to do." The Ospreys managed to end a streak of three losses with a 17-12 victory over Cardiff Blues on New Year's Day at the Liberty Stadium.
It’s understandable that even a seasoned gardener like him might appear a bit uneasy.
Many of us would be unsure of how to react when handed a giant vegetable in front of a crowd of photographers.
Still, it's likely this will be featured prominently in newspapers and remembered by the public.

It serves as a reminder that before Mr. Corbyn tackles the challenges he's sure to face this week—be it nuclear weapons, balancing the economy, or the decision-making process within Labour—his team’s main goal must be to navigate the week without incident.
Party conferences create intense, unique atmospheres where the carefully planned speeches can be overshadowed by unforeseen events, however trivial.
Such moments can change perceptions or reveal truths that political parties might prefer to ignore, and at times, they lead to senior politicians losing control.
I recall back in 2003, watching Conservative aides cringe during a speech by their leader, Iain Duncan Smith, as he vowed the "quiet man" would "turn up the volume."
Throughout that week, Conservatives convened in corners, pondering how to replace him, with his awkward speech contributing to his eventual exit.

In 2006, Cherie Blair's spontaneous and later denied remark, "It's a lie," when Gordon Brown praised her husband, rapidly circulated the conference center, exposing the deep bitterness between their factions.

In 2008, David Miliband's photograph clutching a banana wasn't the sole reason he made the front pages; it was his overheard comment about avoiding a “Heseltine moment” that highlighted his leadership ambitions, making the banana picture newsworthy.
The previous year, Sir Menzies Campbell was already under scrutiny for lackluster leadership of the Liberal Democrats.
I vividly remember the awkward media visit to an eco-friendly house near Bournemouth, where aides allowed him to be photographed examining an organic toilet.
That moment epitomized the shortcomings of his party apparatus, and weeks later, he departed.
For Labour this week, Jeremy Corbyn’s "marrow moment" may quickly fade from memory.
To advance his agenda, Team Corbyn’s foremost task may be to prevent any missteps.
In the chaotic conference arena, even veteran political teams have struggled to maintain control.
In prison, inmates can read books, watch television, and play computer games. Facilities include a kettle, sink, safe, and often a toilet.
According to residential officer Kerry Payne, the deprivation of liberty serves as the punishment, not life inside the prison.
She explains, "Prison isn't for punishment anymore. It's for giving offenders a chance to pause and change their lives, as they don't get that stop-gap otherwise.
Problems tend to escalate if uninterrupted." Inside prison walls, some inmates share their experiences.
James, 27, has cycled through various prisons like Polmont, Barlinnie, Kilmarnock, and Dumfries since age 18.
Outside, he's a joiner; inside, he's a "hall passman," cleaning sections of the prison for £10 a week.
His cell is small, barely accommodating a bed, sink, and toilet. Prisoners have safes with locks that staff can override during checks.
James's room is adorned with posters, a stereo, and a television that costs him £1 per week.
"It's tiny, but it's mine," he remarks. Jason is halfway through a 13-month sentence at HMP Dumfries.
At 38, he has lost track of how many times he's been imprisoned since first being detained at 14.
"It's like a revolving door for me," he admits. Does prison help him? "No, I have to help myself. Prison doesn't help me.
Over the years, I've started reflecting more, possibly because I'm older now, considering change and avoiding repetitive mistakes—but it's taken time."
Will this be his last sentence? "That's my intention." He attends art classes in prison, enjoying them, but doubts he'll continue outside.
"I've got other issues to address first," Jason states. Does he enjoy prison life? "Absolutely not." Would he prefer freedom?
"Definitely." Ryan, a former police officer, has 12 weeks left of his sentence and served the initial three at HMP Addiewell in West Lothian, his local prison from Lanarkshire.
Fabian Picardo, Gibraltar's chief minister, informed the BBC that he is in discussions with Scotland's First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, about various options.
One idea being considered is for Gibraltar and Scotland to retain the UK's EU membership since both voted to remain.
Ms. Sturgeon confirmed ongoing talks with Gibraltar. Northern Ireland might also be part of these discussions.
Mr. Picardo told Newsnight, "Some parts of what is currently the UK could stay in the EU while others leave."

This approach would mean maintaining existing access to the EU for those areas that remain, while different arrangements would be negotiated for those that exit, but not necessarily under Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, which outlines the exit process for member states.
There is a historical precedent for this concept. Denmark joined the EEC, the EU’s predecessor, in 1973 along with the UK and Ireland.
Greenland, part of Denmark, gained autonomy in 1979 and left the EU in 1985 after a referendum.
Nicola Sturgeon has previously stated that a second Scottish independence referendum is "highly likely," following the recent vote to leave the EU.
Over 95% of Gibraltar's voters chose to remain, and most also wish to stay part of the UK.
Gibraltar overwhelmingly rejected shared sovereignty with Spain in a 2002 referendum.

Mr. Picardo emphasized that Gibraltar's status as a British Overseas Territory should not lead to exiting the EU, stating, "Gibraltar has clearly expressed, perhaps even more than Scotland, our desire to continue accessing the EU single market.
My duty is to protect Gibraltar's interests and find partners in the UK who will do the same."
After the recent referendum, Spain reiterated its interest in shared control of Gibraltar.
Spain's acting Foreign Minister, Jose Manuel Garcia-Margallo, remarked, "The Spanish flag on the Rock is closer than before."
However, in his first interview since the referendum, Mr. Picardo dismissed any Spanish claims, firmly stating that Gibraltar would not concede any sovereignty advantages.
Media playback is not supported on this device. In Barcelona, a 16-year-old from Plymouth set a new record with a time of 1:04.30, beating Jessica Hardy’s 2009 mark by 0.15 seconds.
Earlier, Meilutyte achieved a time of 1:04.52 during qualifying, the second-fastest ever and a new European record.
In the 200m individual medley final, Sophie Allen finished seventh while fellow Brit Siobhan-Marie O'Connor was eighth.
London 2012 Olympic champion Meilutyte aims to secure Lithuania's first-ever World Championships gold medal in Tuesday’s final.
Media playback is not supported on this device. "I’ll relax tomorrow to conserve energy for the final," she stated.
"Achieving my biggest target already, I'll give it my all in the final. Winning gold would be the cherry on top."
Her coach Jon Rudd remarked, "It feels surreal, reminiscent of winning Olympic gold.

We aimed for the world record tonight to focus solely on the medal tomorrow." Russian rival Yuliya Efimova promises stiff competition, ensuring Meilutyte stays alert, but Rudd believes more is possible.
Briton O'Connor advanced to the medley final after Australian Emily Seebohm withdrew to focus on her preferred 100m backstroke.
At the halfway point, O'Connor was second but faded, finishing eighth as Hungary's Katinka Hosszu clinched victory.
Surprisingly, Olympic champion Ye Shiwen only secured fourth place. "I need to learn to swim these better," explained O'Connor.
"I often start too fast and got overly excited in the final." Allen, 21, shared: "Disappointed not to achieve a personal best like in the semi-final."
"It's thrilling, fun, and incredible to witness the youthful energy this sport continues to exhibit."
After winning the toss and opting to bat with the pink ball, the hosts navigated the opening session smoothly.
However, Craig Overton (2-35) intervened, dismissing Jimmy Adams (47) and Rilee Rossouw in quick succession.
Jack Leach (2-54) and Tim Groenewald (2-27) then accelerated Hampshire's collapse.
Hampshire subsequently sent Somerset in to bat for six overs, which ended at 18-0.
Despite being part of England's squad for the recent T20 series against South Africa, Overton didn't play, yet his crucial spell here shifted the momentum.

With Liam Dawson (53) and Adams establishing a steady opening partnership, Overton edged out Adams and had Rossouw caught by Steven Davies, marking Rossouw's fifth duck in his last eight County Championship innings.
Dawson was soon dismissed lbw by Lewis Gregory (3-51), and despite James Vince's 47, Hampshire's batting crumbled under Leach's precise left-arm spin.
Securing a batting point, Hampshire skipper George Bailey declared, but Marcus Trescothick (10 not out) and newcomer Eddie Byrom, unbeaten on one, comfortably reached stumps under the floodlights.
Hampshire all-rounder Liam Dawson commented to BBC Solent, "The crowd numbers haven’t changed yet.
It’s early days, and it might eventually work. From my experience, they need to reconsider the type of ball used.
If the current balls persist, we'll see boring cricket. They go soft quickly." Somerset's Craig Overton shared with BBC Radio Bristol, "The ball behaves oddly—it swings but then softens fast.

It offers little help to bowlers and makes scoring tough because it's so soft. We anticipated a challenging bat after lights, so closing nought down with Tres and Eddie is ideal. Being with the England squad was insightful, and I hope to play next time."
Matthew Todd Miller, a 24-year-old US citizen, was sentenced to six years of hard labor on September 14, 2014, for what North Korean state media called "hostile acts" against the country.
He had been detained since April 10, when North Korean outlets reported that he destroyed his tourist visa and sought asylum.
The youngest of four sons, Miller grew up in Bakersfield, California, where both his parents worked as oil engineers.

Former classmates described him as "quiet but extremely intelligent." He learned Korean during his first visit to South Korea four years earlier while visiting a brother stationed there with the US Air Force.
A neighbor from California mentioned that Miller liked South Korea so much he decided to stay.
Notes presented in court, purportedly in Miller’s handwriting, indicated he became a fugitive due to involvement with Wikileaks, the organization known for leaking US state secrets.
However, the BBC's Stephen Evans in Seoul noted it was unclear whether these notes were written under duress or if the allegations were true.
In a recent CNN interview, attended by North Korean officials, Miller stated, "I will say that I prepared to violate the law of the DPRK before coming here."
He admitted to deliberately committing a "crime" but didn’t specify his actions. The charges he faced at trial were unspecified.
Simultaneously, Korean-American Pae Jun-ho, known as Kenneth Bae in the US, was arrested in November 2012 upon entering the northeastern port city of Rason, near North Korea's border with China.

Described as both a tour operator and Christian missionary, North Korea accused him of using his tourism business to form groups aimed at overthrowing the government. He was sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in May 2013.
Bae's trial and conviction occurred amid high tensions between the US and North Korea following the latter’s third nuclear test, and efforts to secure his release have failed.

His family reports he suffers from diabetes and liver problems. Jeffrey Edward Fowle, a 56-year-old US citizen from Miamisburg, Ohio, entered North Korea on April 29, 2014, and was detained while attempting to leave between mid-May and early June.
Fowle, a father of three and a city employee, entered as a tourist but reportedly left a Bible in his hotel room, an act North Korea considers incendiary.
Although he faced trial for unspecified charges, he was released after negotiations and returned to the US in October 2014.
Once again, you sympathize with the families of those who perished and those who survived the disaster aboard these flights.
Such tragedies seem relentless. Within a year, two Malaysian aircraft have vanished, along with 537 passengers.
The AirAsia incident on its December route to Singapore claimed 162 lives. It's not just the crashes themselves; it's the alarming fact that entire planes are suddenly plummeting without warning.
Given this, one might assume air travel is becoming increasingly perilous, but this is a misconception.
When you consider the number of accidents and fatalities relative to the vast numbers flying today—3.2 billion passengers last year—we are actually in a golden era of aviation safety.

Safety analysts at Ascend report that 2014 was nearly the safest year ever, with one fatal accident per 2.38 million flights, an improvement over the previous year's rate of one accident per 1.91 million flights.
This statistic excludes the Malaysian airliner lost over Ukraine, where 298 lives were claimed, as it is classified as a war loss rather than an accident.
Even if you include that incident, the year fares relatively well historically.

The Aviation Safety Network documented 21 fatal accidents in 2014 (including Ukraine), compared to 29 in 2013 and 23 the year before. Nearly 1,000 people died in 2014, which is 700 more than the prior year.
These figures are grim, yet pale compared to 1972 when 2,370 passengers died—and far fewer people flew back then, possibly only a quarter of today's numbers.
Why has flying become safer? Primarily, technological advancements. David Learmount from Flightglobal illustrates, "Think of a car in the 1970s—the brakes, handling, lack of safety features.
Aircraft follow a similar pattern." While aerodynamics were well understood by the 1940s, technological advancements have made significant impacts.
Every new aircraft generation surpasses the previous in safety through better computers, designs, and materials.
Yet, there's another critical aspect contributing to this safety increase: each tragedy educates designers further.

A couple of decades back, Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) was the leading cause of aviation fatalities—a seemingly innocuous term describing catastrophic outcomes when aircraft inadvertently collide with unseen terrain during landing, often due to nearby hills.
The introduction of the Enhanced Ground Proximity Warning System marked a turning point in preventing such incidents.
"It's akin to a sat nav that guides flights through hills and mountains, even in cloudy conditions," David explains.

The team's current aspirations of securing a spot on the fourth row of the grid — or potentially the third if things go exceptionally well — and earning some solid points, highlight their decline from former glory.
This is a team that's celebrated 182 Grand Prix victories with a win rate of 23.18%, claimed 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles.
Astonishingly, despite their poor recent results, they still boast two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, arguably the best driver on the track.
The downturn began in 2013 when McLaren lost its edge in chassis design despite having the best engine.
Currently, while they've regained form with the car, the Honda power unit remains problematic.
This situation starkly contrasts their historic partnership with Honda—a collaboration that once marked the pinnacle of their success in F1.
In 1988, with legends Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, McLaren dominated by winning 15 out of 16 races, outshining even Mercedes' later achievements.
They continued this dominance for four more years, then faced a significant downturn similar to today's, before bouncing back with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines in 1998-99.
Remarkably, the team's last constructors' title was at the start of those victories with the 'Flying Finn.'
In 2007, they almost recaptured former glory when Alonso and Lewis Hamilton were teammates, finishing the season tied for points, just a single point behind Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen.
However, after being caught with Ferrari's technical documents, McLaren was disqualified from the constructors' championship and fined $100 million.
Another scandal followed two years later, dubbed 'lie-gate,' after Hamilton and sporting director Dave Ryan misled stewards at the Australian Grand Prix.

This led to Hamilton's public apology and Ryan's dismissal. Victory was frequent until 2012, with Hamilton and Jenson Button winning seven races, but aside from Hamilton's 2008 title, championships became elusive—and now wins are scarce.
McLaren's current struggles aren't entirely unexpected. Their F1 journey, like that of many long-term competitors, has been marked by cycles of triumph and decline.
Bolivians participated in a vote regarding a constitutional amendment. Currently, both the president and vice-president are restricted to two consecutive five-year terms.
President Evo Morales, who has held office since 2006, and his supporters were advocating for him to contest another term.

As nearly all votes were tallied, the "No" faction maintained a narrow but decisive lead over supporters favoring Mr. Morales's re-election, thus upholding the constitutional limit on serving beyond two consecutive terms.

Despite the restriction, Morales was permitted to run for a third term in 2014, with the constitutional court ruling that the ban didn’t apply to his first term, since it occurred before the new constitution was enacted.
Consequently, Morales will not be eligible to run in the 2019 presidential elections, though he will complete his current term, ending in 2020.
Upon provisional results confirming a "No" victory, Morales declared "the fight will continue," assuring that his administration's plans would proceed.
Some critics within his party wish for him to groom a successor, while opposition figures view this as an opportunity to challenge the ruling parties.
Morales remarked that he had "lost a battle, but not the war." Celebrations took place in Santa Cruz, a stronghold for the opposition.
Several opposition leaders, along with members of Morales's own party, celebrated the outcome as a triumph for democracy.
Former President Carlos Mesa opined that it demonstrated "no one is indispensable."

Samuel Doria Medina, who had been defeated by Morales in three presidential contests, affirmed Bolivia's victory, tweeting that "the people told them 'no'" after the government initiated the referendum.
Although Morales won the last election with 61% of the vote, the proposed constitutional modification was viewed by many as excessive.
Even within his own party, some felt it was time for younger politicians to emerge and take the reins.
Recent allegations regarding Morales's supposed influence to benefit a Chinese construction company employing his former girlfriend also affected his approval ratings.
He denied these allegations and committed to investigating the contract allocations.
The identified parts, potentially from a Buk surface-to-air missile system, are deemed "of particular interest" due to their potential to identify those responsible for the crash.
However, investigators have not yet confirmed their "causal connection" with the incident.
In July 2014, Flight MH17 went down in an area controlled by Russian-backed rebels, resulting in the deaths of all 298 individuals on board.
This included 283 passengers, of whom 80 were children, and 15 crew members on the Malaysian Airlines flight.
Among the deceased, approximately two-thirds were Dutch nationals, with numerous Malaysians and Australians also affected.
Ukraine and several Western countries have claimed that pro-Russian rebels shot down the plane, possibly using a Buk missile system supplied by Russia.
Both Russia and the rebels deny culpability, attributing the incident to the Ukrainian military instead.
The Joint Investigation Team (JIT), in conjunction with the Dutch Safety Board, announced that these parts had been "secured during a previous recovery mission in eastern Ukraine."

According to their statement, "The parts are of particular interest to the criminal investigation as they might reveal more details about those involved in the MH17 crash. Therefore, the JIT is further investigating the origin of these parts."

Fred Westerbeke, from the Dutch Prosecutor’s Office, reported that seven fragments were found, which were definitely not part of the aircraft, and further analysis suggested they likely came from a missile system.

"Additional investigation is needed to determine what these fragments precisely are and if they belong to the system that brought down MH17," he stated. "Confirming this could signify a breakthrough."
The Dutch Safety Board remains cautious, asserting that no causal link has yet been established between the recovered parts and the crash.
The consensus is that the aircraft was likely downed by a surface-to-air missile, as reflected in the investigators' preliminary report from last September.

This report highlighted that damage to the aircraft's fuselage and cockpit was consistent with impacts from numerous high-energy objects from outside the aircraft, aligning with a Buk missile engagement.
The pressing question persists: Who fired the weapon—Russian-backed separatists, the Russian military, or even the Ukrainian forces, who also operate a Buk variant?
While the missile parts could assist in answering this, satellite intelligence might reveal more details.
The team at King's College London suggests that smokers are more likely to develop schizophrenia and at a younger age.
A study published in Lancet Psychiatry, which analyzed 61 separate studies, indicates that nicotine from cigarette smoke may alter the brain.
Experts called this a "pretty strong case" but emphasized the need for further research.

Smoking has been linked to psychosis for a long time, but it was commonly thought that patients with schizophrenia smoke due to self-medication to mitigate symptoms like hearing voices or experiencing hallucinations.
The King's team analyzed data from 14,555 smokers and 273,162 non-smokers, suggesting that a higher rate of smoking before schizophrenia diagnosis implies it is not merely self-medication.

Dr. James MacCabe from King's Institute of Psychiatry, Psychology and Neuroscience stated, "It's very difficult to establish causation with this study type, but we hope this reveals the potential role of tobacco as a causative factor in psychosis, leading to more research and clinical trials for clearer evidence."
Most smokers don't develop schizophrenia, yet researchers believe smoking heightens the risk.
Typically, one in 100 people will develop schizophrenia, which may rise to two in 100 for smokers.
Researchers highlighted that nicotine alters brain chemical dopamine levels, a known factor in psychosis.
Prof Michael Owen, director of the Institute of Psychological Medicine at Cardiff University, acknowledged the researchers' "pretty strong case" for smoking increasing schizophrenia risk.
"Proving causation is challenging without randomized trials, but there are already many reasons to target public health initiatives toward those with mental illnesses."
The charity Rethink Mental Illness noted, "42% of cigarettes in England are smoked by individuals with mental health issues, so any findings linking smoking and psychosis are worrying.
Longer-term studies are necessary to fully understand this potential connection."
The tone of the new series is more serious and darker, akin to Doctor Who's latest season.
While not everyone embraced the change, the team behind Atlantis is ready for any criticism.
"The show is designed to fit a pre-watershed slot," explains Johnny Capps, executive producer and co-creator of Atlantis.
"I believe audiences are far more sophisticated today. Children encounter darker and more intriguing material than ever before, so we must cater to that level of sophistication."
With a later airtime of 8:30 pm, the team aims to attract both adults and children.
The shift towards a darker narrative is not necessarily negative. "It’s beneficial to explore life’s complexities and emotional tales," Capps says.
"These stories are richer, offering a family audience insights into life by showcasing both its bright and dark aspects, and illustrating the consequences of emotional narratives."
Jack Donnelly, who plays Jason, was initially concerned about how the changes would be received.
"It’s vastly different from the first season," he shares with Newsbeat. "I discussed it with Mark (Addy) and Rob (Emms) recently, and it feels like a reboot rather than a follow-up.
The series is now darker and more serious; every episode is serialised, each leading into the next, unlike standalone stories before."

Is the team ready for any backlash? "To some extent, yes," Jack acknowledges. "Honestly, Rob, Mark, and I were worried initially because we established a rhythm last year, with humor softening serious moments.
We had to pivot, following the producer’s guidance for a new direction." After viewing rough cuts of some episodes, Jack notes, "It may not suit younger viewers like it did last year.
However, I believe the show has improved overall. The new direction adds more interest to the series."
Ethiopia remains one of the world's poorest nations, with roughly one-third of its population surviving on less than $1 (63p) per day.
Yet, it boasts one of the fastest-growing economies globally. Opinions are split regarding the wisdom of investing in Ethiopia.

Since 2004, the economy has been expanding at around 10% annually. While the government anticipates continued double-digit growth, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) projects a slowdown to 6.5% in 2013.
Despite these predictions, the IMF figures remain impressive given the global financial climate and Ethiopia's scant natural resources.
Coffee is a major export for Ethiopia. In the capital, Addis Ababa, coffee exporter Michael Girma recalls the challenges of launching his enterprise.
"To start up in the export sector, you need to operate with your own cash. Then, you can approach the banks," he explains.
Besides exporting coffee, Girma owns a café, bar, and pizzeria, collectively employing 140 people.
Despite increasing competition, his ventures yield a 20-30% profit margin annually, fostering his optimism.
"A lot has changed in the past seven years," he says. "You need to be aggressive, but not arrogant."
Foreign investors are welcomed, though certain sectors are reserved for domestic investors.
"Restricted sectors are those supplying local needs. If foreign investors want to pursue export-oriented projects, there’s complete freedom," he states.
"Otherwise, competition would be tough." Despite persistent high inflation, some investors believe the potential of Africa's second most populous nation is underappreciated.
Earlier this year, Shultze Global Investments established a $100m equity fund to support Ethiopian businesses.
In a nondescript building overlooking Addis Ababa, Berhane Demissie allocates these funds.
"Ethiopia offers substantial opportunities for investors," she notes, highlighting agriculture as a growth area.
"Anything can thrive in Ethiopia due to our diverse climates and soils, extending to value-added agricultural processing and exports," says Ms. Demissie.

With 85% of Ethiopians relying on agriculture, she emphasizes government efforts to ensure farmers access finance and fertilizers to boost productivity. Ms. Demissie envisions this leading to poverty alleviation.

The message may take some time to reach India. The country celebrated a rare achievement when Girisha Hosanagara Nagarajegowda won a silver medal in the Men's High Jump F42 class for athletes with impairments affecting their arms or legs.
India reveled in Girisha's success, as medals often escape the nation's Paralympians.
Yet, questions arise about India's ability to convert this celebration into enhanced awareness of disability rights.
The nation is notoriously unfriendly towards disabled individuals, with most public places still lacking essential facilities.
Even before Girisha's triumph, media coverage focused on issues at the Athletes' Village.

Several athletes reported that the Paralympics Committee of India failed to secure accommodation for escorts and coaches, complicating athletes' routines by denying them valuable time with their coaches.
Weightlifter Farman Basha told CNN-IBN that his preparation was greatly hindered because he couldn't navigate the village freely without his escort.

"I was confident of winning a medal, and now my training is wasted," he said. CNN-IBN's editor, Rajdeep Sardesai, hosted a special show questioning whether India treats its Paralympians as second-class citizens.
Other media outlets soon joined the discussion, highlighting the irony that the controversy garnered more attention than the Games themselves.
Despite winning only one medal, the Games offered many inspiring tales, which the media largely neglected.

On the CNN-IBN show, Olympic silver medallist Rajyawardhan Singh Rathod expressed no surprise at the treatment of Paralympians, noting the need for significant changes to ensure equal rights for disabled people in India.
"An overall attitude shift is necessary in our country," he remarked. Another issue overlooked by Indian media was the absence of female athletes in the Indian Paralympic contingent.

Although officials attributed this to qualification challenges, the root of the problem is deeper: most educational institutions lack basic sporting facilities for the disabled, and those with resources seldom encourage participation from disabled women.
Despite the controversy making headlines, Girisha's achievement remains untarnished.
He persevered against odds to ensure India did not leave London empty-handed. Hailing from Karnataka in southern India, Girisha belongs to an average middle-class family.
Eric Bikubi, 28, and his partner Magalie Bamu, 29, have been found guilty at the Old Bailey for the murder of Kristy Bamu, whom they accused of practicing witchcraft.
The couple from Newham believed Kristy was controlling and negatively influencing a young boy, as presented to the jury.
Originally from the Democratic Republic of Congo, where witchcraft is known as Kindoki and exorcisms are conducted in some churches, their actions echo a troubling reality.
A 2010 Unicef report noted that 20,000 children accused of witchcraft were living on the streets of Kinshasa, DR Congo's capital.
Although the DR Congo has laws criminalizing accusations of child possession, my 2008 visit to Kinshasa revealed little change.
This led me to a slum at night, where I knocked on the door of a shack that served as a church.
Pastor Tsimba welcomed me and introduced me to three children he claimed were afflicted by Kindoki.
The children, aged between six and 12, had been held there for days, deprived of food, and forced to work, with their parents paying for this ordeal.
The dimly lit room flickered with candlelight as the pastor loudly prayed and brought each child forward.
He ordered them to lie down and slapped their stomachs harder each time. Then he poured hot wax on them, causing them to grimace silently with wide, staring eyes.

In a bizarre conclusion, Pastor Tsimba pressed a pipe against their belly buttons, pretended to suck out a piece of meat, and triumphantly spit it into a bowl, claiming it was fed to them by a witch and had infected them with Kindoki.
The children, now quiet and bewildered, were declared "delivered" by him. I informed a social worker about their situation.
A dedicated man, he promised to help but faced challenges, as his unit hadn’t paid him for months, leaving him without funds for petrol or bus fare. He continued his work on foot.
There are many remarkable achievements to consider, such as Olympic gold medals, world records, and election to Parliament.
In 1979, Sebastian Coe, a promising young middle-distance runner, achieved three world records in just 41 days at the age of 22.
He broke the world records for the 800m, one mile, and 1,500m, becoming the first person to hold all three simultaneously. This milestone earned him the title of Sports Personality of the Year.

In 1980, Coe cemented his Olympic legacy during the Moscow games. Despite fierce competition with his fellow Brit, Steve Ovett, Coe won gold in the 1,500m and claimed silver in his favored 800m race, where he finished behind Ovett.
Four years later, in 1984, Coe overcame illness to return to the Olympic track in Los Angeles.
He made history by winning a second consecutive gold in the 1,500m, beating fellow Brit Steve Cram, while Ovett was unable to finish.
Coe again finished second in the 800m, this time to Joaquim Cruz. After retiring from athletics in 1990, Coe shifted to politics.
In the 1992 election, he won a seat in Parliament for the Conservatives by defeating the Liberal Democrat candidate in the Falmouth and Camborne constituency by over 3,000 votes.
He lost the seat in 1997 when Tony Blair's Labour Party came to power but later served as chief of staff to William Hague during his tenure as Leader of the Opposition.

In 2005, Coe played a pivotal role in securing the Olympics for London. Initially trailing Paris and Madrid, London clinched the games under Coe's leadership, thanks in part to a compelling speech before the final vote.
Coe remarked that organizing the Olympics was "on a different planet" compared to winning medals.
He became Chairman of the London Organising Committee for the Olympics and Paralympics and significantly contributed to the Queen's appearance in the James Bond scene during the opening ceremony.
In 2015, Coe became president of the IAAF, a position he claimed was his greatest achievement despite his illustrious career in athletics.
He defeated Sergey Bubka, a former Olympic pole vaulter, with 115 votes to Bubka's 92.
Six individuals are facing attempted murder charges for allegedly setting fire to a newspaper that a man had used to cover himself.
A seventh person is charged with not assisting the Polish man, who was ultimately rescued by passing bystanders after the attackers left the scene.
The shocking attack, captured on CCTV, has stirred widespread concern across the country.
Six of those accused are from Syria, while the seventh is from Libya, and their ages range from 16 to 21.
Reports from German media indicate they arrived in Germany between 2014 and 2016, with some arriving as unaccompanied minors.
This incident has reignited discussions on the care of unaccompanied minors in Germany and fueled the ongoing debate regarding the effectiveness of CCTV cameras in preventing crime.
The attack happened around 2:00 am (1:00 am GMT) on Christmas Day at the Schoenleinstrasse underground station in Berlin's Neukölln district.

The alleged mastermind, a 21-year-old Syrian, is accused of igniting a handkerchief and placing it near the victim's head before fleeing, causing the flames to spread to the man’s backpack and a plastic bag.
A train driver intervened using a fire extinguisher, and passers-by helped to extinguish the fire.
Following the release of CCTV images of the incident, six suspects turned themselves in to the police.
The alleged ringleader was apprehended near his residence. He claims he was intoxicated and does not recall the events.
Nonetheless, he will be prosecuted as an adult and faces a minimum sentence of three years if convicted. All suspects have been detained since December 27.
When the 22-year-old student was in primary school, he was assaulted and robbed by a group of youths in a side street.
While this incident happened long ago, he still feels the need to cross the road when confronted with a large group of people.
This is understandable, given that everyone in his family has experienced similar targeting.
France's ethnic Chinese population has endured casual racism for years and is often stereotyped as easy targets for crime, but they now feel they have reached a breaking point.
In August, Zhang Chaolin, a 49-year-old tailor and father of two, lost his life in a hospital after being attacked by three teenagers in the north Paris suburb of Aubervilliers.
He was kicked in the sternum, fell, and hit his head on the pavement. Allegedly, the goal of the attack was to steal his friend's bag, but Zhang only had sweets and cigarettes.
This tragic event prompted over 15,000 ethnic Chinese to gather in Paris's Place de la Republique on September 4th, voicing their deep-seated insecurity.
France has Europe's largest Chinese community, estimated at more than 600,000 people.
However, compared to other migrant groups like those from Africa, they have not been in the country as long.
David, born in Paris to parents who moved from China in the early 1990s, has faced public jabs such as being asked if he eats dogs and being called a "spring roll head."
He has been told to "go back to his own country" and "work with his little Chinese hands."
These slurs are familiar to East Asian migrants and their descendants across the West.
According to British Chinese and French Chinese people, racist remarks toward their communities are tolerated more than those directed at more established migrant groups.
In France, Asian migrants are perceived to be victims of particularly vicious violence.
"These attacks are rooted in their beliefs about us," says David, who fears using his real name.
Aubervilliers, a working-class area with a significant immigrant population, is home to over 1,200 mainly Chinese wholesalers and serves as a vital European textile hub.
Buyers travel extensively to negotiate prices for Italian and Chinese-made garments.
Activists report that at least 100 attacks against Chinese nationals occurred in the suburb during the first seven months of this year alone.
France does not compile statistics by ethnicity, which makes the actual number of incidents hard to determine.
Meriem Derkaoui, the suburb's communist mayor, condemned Zhang's murder as "racist targeting."
SKT's five members shared a $2 million prize for their 3-2 victory over a team sponsored by phone maker Samsung.
This win marks SKT's third championship title in four years, having also won in 2015.
The final, which took place at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, lasted six hours and was witnessed by nearly 20,000 League of Legends (LoL) fans.
Lee Sang-hyeok, known as Faker, from SKT, was honored as the tournament's most valuable player.
The tournament's total prize pool amounted to $5 million, with Samsung's second-place finish earning them $750,000.
Fan contributions boosted the prize money available to the teams. Gaming journalist Philippa Warr, writing for Rock, Paper Shotgun, described the final as "breathtaking."
Samsung made a remarkable comeback after losing the first two games, with a "beautiful" 70-minute third game victory.
Samsung then won the fourth game with more ease, leading to the decisive match.
Warr noted SKT's "fluidity" and experience secured them the title, the prize money, and the Summoner's Cup trophy.

LoL is a highly popular game where two teams of five battle over a small map. Each player controls a hero with various attack and defense abilities, and the winner is the first to destroy the opposing team's base.
Riot Games, the creator of LoL, reports that approximately 100 million people play the game each month.
Jack Lopresti described a letter sent to party members calling for a new candidate as an "attempt to destroy my character and reputation."
The Filton and Bradley Stoke MP left his wife for fellow MP Andrea Jenkyns, who gave birth to their son in March.

Mr. Lopresti was reselected during a meeting on Friday evening. Earlier this month, an anonymous letter to Conservative Party members in the constituency claimed many felt Mr. Lopresti was not representing their interests effectively.
The letter also suggested that "several excellent people" should be considered as prospective parliamentary candidates.
In response, the local party assured members that "appropriate legal action" would be pursued if the author of the letter was identified.
Mr. Lopresti was first elected in 2010 and won re-election with a nearly 10,000-vote majority five years later.
Last November, it was reported that he became engaged to Ms. Jenkyns, who defeated former Labour shadow chancellor Ed Balls to become MP for Morley and Outwood in 2015.
Their son, Clifford George, was born in March. "For the past month, my family and I have faced a vicious smear campaign with racist undertones," he explained.
"Since the day after Clifford's birth, my office has been inundated with fake calls from individuals claiming to be national journalists and with menacing threats of illegally recorded conversations.

This has deeply troubled my staff. "I have received numerous messages of support from party members and constituents, and I am confident that this recent attempt to undermine me has been orchestrated by a small group of individuals.
"I believe this may be due to personal choices I’ve made in my private life, which some disapprove of.
"I love my fiancée Andrea and am incredibly proud of my young son Clifford, and nothing can change that."
Under house arrest since Friday, Mr. Besigye described Uganda's election as "the most fraudulent electoral process," calling it a sham and a creeping military coup.
President Museveni, who has been in power for 30 years, garnered nearly 61% of the votes, while Mr. Besigye received 35%.
Foreign observers reported the election occurred in a climate of fear and intimidation.
EU chief observer Eduard Kukan praised Ugandans' "remarkable determination" to vote but noted that the National Resistance Movement's dominance skewed the campaign's fairness.
The election was marred by sporadic violence and opposition claims of fraud, alongside blocked social media and messaging apps.
"Today, I am under house arrest," Mr. Besigye stated. "My home is sealed off, and I cannot leave.
No one can visit me. I also face an electronic blockade, with no internet access at my residence.
The regime is displaying its harsh power openly. This isn't an electoral process; it's a creeping military coup."
This election marked the fourth time Mr. Besigye, representing the opposition Forum for Democratic Change, challenged President Museveni.
The two were once allies, with Mr. Besigye serving as Mr. Museveni's personal doctor during their guerrilla warfare days.
Besigye was reportedly confined to prevent him from independently announcing his vote count.
Mr. Museveni, who seized power in 1986, is credited with restoring stability in Uganda, but critics accuse him of growing more authoritarian.
Former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi, Mr. Museveni's nearest rival, is also reportedly under house arrest.
The National Resistance Movement celebrated its victory, claiming that Mr. Museveni's opponents "failed to offer any alternative." Uganda's old guard is employing new election strategies.
A survey of 2,750 young people aged 11 to 18 revealed that one in ten checks their mobile phone for notifications at least ten times a night.

Conducted by Digital Awareness UK and the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference, the study highlights concerns that night-time phone usage leads to students arriving at school tired and less focused.
These organizations suggest a "digital detox," recommending that devices be put away 90 minutes before bedtime or kept out of the bedroom entirely.

Among the 45% of respondents who admitted to checking phones when they should be sleeping, nearly all (94%) are active on social media, with 10% feeling stressed about missing out if they don't check their devices before bed.
Within this group, 75% are listening to music, and over half (57%) are watching films.
Alarmingly, 32% of these young people say their parents are unaware of their after-hours device usage.
Charlotte Robertson, co-founder of DAUK, stated: "Excessive social media consumption is a major issue affecting physical and emotional well-being.
Many children wake up to over 100 notifications from overnight conversations. They feel pressured to respond to messages at 1 AM to seem cool and stay in the loop."
Mike Buchanan, HMC chairman, added: "The data indicates that most phone checkers are motivated by not wanting to miss out.
Clearly, fatigue from late-night phone use is affecting concentration and academic performance.
However, rather than demonizing technology, we should acknowledge the reality and aim to encourage its positive use."
All the goals were scored in the second half at a packed Monrovia stadium, with state president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf in attendance.
Mitis Mulbah netted twice and Benjamin Sarkoh scored once, leading Liberia to a memorable victory over Kabylie, one of Africa's top ten clubs.
Mulbah broke the deadlock amidst a goalmouth scramble at the 58-minute mark and sealed the win after Sarkoh capitalized on a mistake by Algerian goalkeeper Malek Asselah.
This unexpected heavy defeat for Kabylie added to the woes of Algerian football, following the Desert Foxes' group stage exit from the recent Africa Cup of Nations.
Another Algerian team, Mouloudia Alger, also suffered defeat, losing 2-1 away to Bechem United of Ghana, though they managed an away goal for the return leg next weekend.
In other matches, Rayon Sports of Rwanda are well on their way to the last-32 of Africa's second-tier club competition after a 4-0 victory against Al Salam Wau of South Sudan in Juba.
Savio Nshuti ignited a second-half scoring spree with a goal after 54 minutes, and Pierrot Kwizera, Nova Bayama, and Moussa Camara added to the tally.
Bosnian Enes Sipovic scored the decisive goal as Ittihad Tanger of Morocco, participating in continental football for the first time, rallied to beat Douanes of Niger 2-1 in Niamey.
Morocco celebrated further success as MAS Fes, a second-division team, took advantage of playing at home to secure a 3-0 lead over former African champions CARA of Congo Brazzaville.
A blunder by the Congolese goalkeeper, allowing a harmless cross to slip through, gave Ivorian Koffi Boua an easy opening goal for the 2011 Confederation Cup winners, Fes.
Al Hilal Benghazi of Libya triumphed despite being unable to host their match at home, defeating Ulinzi Stars of Kenya 1-0 in Cairo, with Ahmed Al Abbar scoring just after halftime.
Volcan of the Comoros exceeded expectations by holding Vipers of Uganda to a 0-0 draw in Kampala, raising the prospect of a first continental success for a club from the Indian Ocean island nation.
Record three-time winners CS Sfaxien of Tunisia are among 12 clubs to receive byes to the round of 32.
The Confederation Cup, like the Champions League, will showcase a new format this season, with increased prize money.
The qualifying rounds before playoffs against Champions League last-32 losers have been reduced to two, and the group stage has been expanded from eight clubs to 16.

At a Buckingham Palace garden party in the pouring rain on Tuesday, the Queen remarked "Oh, bad luck" when informed that a Metropolitan Police commander had led the operation during the Chinese leader's visit.
The Queen's candid comments were unusual for her and raised some unresolved questions about the visit.

Simply put, there's still much unknown. Police Commander Lucy D'Orsi was reportedly "seriously, seriously undermined by the Chinese," according to the Lord Chamberlain who introduced her to the Queen.
Commander D'Orsi described the situation as "quite a testing time" and recalled, "they walked out of Lancaster House and told me the trip was off."
The Queen seemed well-versed in the matter and added, "They were very rude to the ambassador."
Ms. D'Orsi responded, "They walked out on both of us." Whether Chinese officials threatened to cancel the entire state visit or just a portion remains uncertain.
It’s unclear if the issues were related to security arrangements, given the pressure on Ms. D'Orsi, or had broader diplomatic implications.

We simply do not know, and the police have not released a statement. During their state visit, President Xi and his wife Madame Peng were guests at Buckingham Palace, so it stands to reason that the Queen would be privy to such details.
Meanwhile, the Metropolitan Police faced accusations from human rights groups of mishandling protesters during Mr. Xi’s visit in October 2015.
In response, Commander D'Orsi stated her disappointment over claims that the Met was "working to the bidding of the Chinese to suppress protest."

The Queen's remarks were inadvertently captured by Peter Wilkinson, her official cameraman, and released to broadcasters as part of the standard "pool" arrangement for royal events, which prevents multiple news crews from attending each engagement. Only then were the Queen's unusually candid comments noted.
At the time, Mr. Xi stated that he believed his visit would elevate UK-China relations to "a new height."
Buckingham Palace did not comment on the "private conversation" but assured that all parties cooperated closely to facilitate a smooth visit.
Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Lu Kang remarked that the president’s trip to the UK was very successful and "marked the start of the Golden Era between China and the UK."
Thanks to the Queen's comments, we now know it was, at least, a challenging period behind the scenes for both the police commander and the British ambassador.
At halftime, the Warriors led Leinster 13-6, with Zander Fagerson scoring a try, and both Duncan Weir and Leinster's Fergus McFadden kicking two penalties each.
In the third quarter, Luke McGrath and Taqele Naiyaravoro traded tries. After Naiyaravoro received a yellow card, Leinster gained the lead with a penalty try and McFadden added a late penalty.
The visiting team, strengthened by the return of six Scotland internationals and aiming for their first away victory over Leinster since 2011, broke the deadlock in the 13th minute.
This came after a series of phases ended with 19-year-old prop Fagerson pushing over from close distance.
Weir converted the try, and shortly after, McFadden succeeded with his first penalty.
Another penalty from the winger narrowed the lead by the 21st minute, crediting Aaron Dundon's efforts during a ruck penalty and precise line-out.
Weir capitalized on another Leinster mistake, slotting a brilliant 43-meter penalty following a maul collapse.
He repeated a similar kick six minutes before halftime after Mike McCarthy was penalized at a maul.
Leinster missed an opportunity to score a third penalty when McFadden’s attempt drifted wide following a yellow card issued to Pat MacArthur for a reckless tackle that sidelined Dundon.
Resuming play, Leinster leveraged their numerical advantage; scrum-half McGrath initiated a play that saw Garry Ringrose sprint up the touchline, culminating in McGrath's converted try by McFadden.
However, the scores were level for just six minutes. The Scots responded with strong attack sequences, culminating in Naiyaravoro's powerful try.

Leinster regained the lead with a penalty try; substitute Isaac Boss found an opening leading to Isa Nacewa's kick, which Naiyaravoro was judged to have intentionally knocked over the line, leading to his sin-binning after a TMO review.
McFadden's conversion gave Leinster a scoreboard edge, which they maintained when McFadden landed his third penalty.
Leinster's lineup included Nacewa, Ringrose, Te'o, among others, with Boss, Dooley, and others as substitutes.
Glasgow Warriors featured Lamont, Naiyaravoro, Vernon, and more, with Hart and Yanuyanutawa among the replacements.
The portraits transformed the founder of China's Communist Party into a pop art icon, reminiscent of Warhol's takes on Marilyn Monroe and Campbell's soup cans.
Originating from a photo in Mao's Little Red Book, this portrait series stands as one of the 20th century's most iconic images.
The forthcoming auction is anticipated to reach up to $15 million (£12.1 million).

This particular Mao portrait was sold in 2014 in London for £7.6 million ($9.4 million), and the anonymous current owner is now offering it through Sotheby's in Hong Kong, with the auction set for April 2.
Warhol initiated his Mao silk-screen portrait series in 1972, coinciding with the U.S. and China's warming relations following President Nixon’s historic Beijing visit.
The photograph Warhol employed was featured on the Little Red Book's inside cover, a symbol of Chinese communism and propaganda.
Over a billion copies have been published, making it one of the most widely distributed books ever. During Mao's rule, owning and carrying a copy was nearly compulsory.
Warhol's series yielded almost 200 variations and sizes, paralleling his earlier works on Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley in the 1960s.
Choosing Mao marked a shift from Warhol’s focus on mundane commodities or glamorous subjects.
Chairman Mao was a revered yet feared political figure, an unusual choice for Pop Art’s bold colors.
Today, it remains a sensitive subject in China. In 2013, a major Warhol exhibition excluded the Mao portraits, sparking debate in Chinese media over whether they represented respect or satire.
Nevertheless, Chinese investors are increasingly purchasing Western art, constituting about one-fifth of global art buyers.
Economic pressures like the yuan's decline and capital control measures are fueling interest in international art investments.
Thus, Warhol's depiction of Mao might eventually find its place in China via global markets. Reporting by the BBC's Andreas Illmer.
Hamilton labeled the change as "too drastic" and the "worst-looking" alteration in Formula 1 history.
In 2009, Henry, the son of John Surtees, tragically died during a Formula Two race after being hit on the head by a loose tire.
"I experienced the tragedy of losing Henry, which certainly could've been prevented by a development like this," John Surtees remarked.
Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel stated that the device can be as "ugly as possible" as long as it saves lives, and the German believes Henry Surtees "would still be here if we had this type of system."
John Surtees, who won the 1964 drivers' championship with Ferrari, stated, "Lewis could perhaps think a little more about the 'halo' and consider his responsibility as a world champion.
Change occurs, and sometimes changes are inevitable. The governing body may have no choice but to impose these regulations due to the momentum and direction they've taken.
Henry was hit by a wheel weighing 28kg, so having a 'halo' could have made a difference."
Meanwhile, McLaren's Fernando Alonso sees the 'halo' device as a "necessary" step.

"It's the future of F1, as we can't afford any serious injury or fatal accident like those in the last two years," said the two-time world champion, referring to Jules Bianchi and Justin Wilson's fatal injuries.

"I realize the 'halo' looks a bit extreme aesthetically—perhaps a canopy or another solution will be developed soon—but hopefully next year, all cars will have such a system." Explore more about the 'halo' here.
Following Ryan Lochte's false claim about being robbed at gunpoint during the Rio Olympics, skin care company Syneron-Candela and Japanese mattress maker Airweave issued announcements.
Lochte, who has 12 Olympic medals and millions in endorsements, faced consequences after the incident.
Speedo, his largest sponsor, stated: "We cannot condone behavior that contradicts our brand values."
Lochte, 32, expressed respect for Speedo's decision and gratitude for their partnership over the years.
On a US talk show, he admitted, "I made a mistake and learned from it. My immature, intoxicated behavior tarnished the Games."
Ralph Lauren, which had a short-term sponsorship with Lochte for the Rio Olympics, removed his images from its website and won't renew the contract.
Both Ralph Lauren and Airweave continue to support the US Olympic and Paralympic teams. Syneron-Candela emphasized their high standards for employees and partners.
Speedo decided to donate $50,000 from Lochte's sponsorship fee to Save The Children's Brazilian program.
Although the exact value of Lochte's Speedo deal is undisclosed, the contract ends this year after a decade.
Forbes estimated Lochte earned roughly $2 million in endorsements during the 2012 London Olympics.
Despite a less stellar performance in Rio, Forbes expected his endorsements to range between $1 million and $2 million.
The controversy began when Lochte and teammates returned to the Olympic village after a late night and, unable to access a locked toilet at a garage, urinated outside.
They initially claimed they were robbed by fake police but later, Lochte admitted to exaggerating the story while intoxicated.
Although evidence, including CCTV footage, contradicts his account, Lochte denied lying to Brazilian police.
His actions were condemned in the US, and the media extensively criticized him, with the New York Post calling him the "Ugly American" and running the headline, "Liar, Liar, Speedo on Fire."
In July, Boro emerged as the most active Premier League club, bringing in eight new players.
"We're not rushing. We have the team's core; we just need to keep progressing," Karanka told BBC Tees.
"The better our players, the better our chances of remaining in the Premier League."
After narrowly missing promotion through the 2015 play-offs, Boro tied with Brighton on the last day of the previous season.
This earned them promotion on goal difference and marked their return to the top flight after seven years.

The Teesside club remained unbeaten throughout pre-season but conceded a goal just 14 minutes into their 3-1 victory over Aston Villa on Saturday, which raised concerns for Karanka about defensive vulnerabilities.
The 42-year-old stated, "We need more players, especially central defenders. That’s the area where we need improvement.
I don't want to place all the pressure on Dael Fry. He's excellent, with a bright future, and improves daily.
But he needs to develop steadily, and we need to bring in more players for that."
While Karanka aims to strengthen the defense, his priority is ensuring new signings integrate quickly.

"The key for me is that new players settle well into the team," he said. "We're blending players who fought to stay in the Championship two-and-a-half years ago with players who were in the Champions League one or two years ago.
Yet, the team spirit remains unchanged." Middlesbrough is set to kick off their Premier League campaign at home on Saturday, 13 August, against Stoke City.
The Office for National Statistics identified Oldham as having the highest proportion of deprived areas in England, with West Bromwich in the West Midlands following closely.

In contrast, Guildford in Surrey was deemed the least deprived town. The study assessed various factors, including income, employment, health, education, skills and training, crime, disability, access to housing, and the built environment in cities and towns across England and Wales.
It revealed that the north-west of England contained five of the ten most deprived towns and cities, while the West Midlands had three in the top five.

Although Oldham ranked as the overall most deprived, West Bromwich recorded the poorest performance in employment and income, sitting at the bottom of the ranking for 109 areas in both categories and second lowest for education. Meanwhile, Birmingham was ranked lowest for housing.
On the other end, Guildford, Woking, and St Albans were found to have the highest proportion of areas with minimal deprivation.
The ONS study also noted that 29 out of 45 towns and cities in southern England had average house prices exceeding £200,000, compared to only three out of 64 in the North and Midlands.
Since 2010, Cambridge experienced the highest increase in house prices at 47%, while prices in Swansea dropped by 4%.

According to the ONS, Burnley in Lancashire is the most affordable place to buy a home, with average prices at £166,000 for detached homes, £120,000 for semi-detached homes, £69,950 for flats, and £54,498 for terraced houses, thus bringing the overall average to £78,000.

Conversely, St Albans has the priciest housing, averaging £675,000 for detached homes, £529,400 for semi-detached, £400,000 for terraced houses, and £255,000 for flats, totaling an average of £390,000.

Eddie Moores, Oldham Council's cabinet member for health, stated that efforts in the last five years have focused on improving health, wages, skills, and employment through initiatives such as Get Oldham Working, the Oldham Education and Skills Commission, and the Warm Homes Oldham project, which has helped over 3,300 people escape fuel poverty.
He further mentioned investments in the borough's most extensive post-war regeneration program to ensure benefits from a growing economy.
Sandwell Council Leader Darren Cooper remarked that massive cuts from the central government have significantly drained resources from the local economy.
A team from Glasgow University studied Glaswegians' recorded speech from the early 20th century to the present, uncovering evidence of common UK accent changes.
These include swapping "f" for "th" in words like "think" and dropping the letter "l" in words such as "people," changing it to "peopo."
Despite these changes, the researchers noted that the Scottish accent remains distinctive.
Professor Jane Stuart-Smith, director of the university's phonetics laboratory, led the three-year Sounds of the City study.
"We were quite surprised by what we found," she stated. "The assumption is that traditional dialects across the UK are being eroded, with some even dying out altogether.
However, we've discovered that Scots accents, particularly in Glasgow, are actually thriving.
Interestingly, contrary to what is happening in England, Scottish accents are not diluting into a more homogenized, anglicized accent and remain very distinctive."
As part of their study, the Glasgow team created a digitized collection of recorded speech sounds.
Their findings indicate that the distinctive Scots accent has experienced two types of changes.
The first consists of common accent shifts spreading across the UK, like the "f" and "l" examples, influenced partly by dialect contact and popular TV shows set in London.

The project also identified a second set of subtler changes specific to Scotland, affecting vowel pronunciation in words like "boat," "goat," and "coat," as well as stop sounds in words such as "pin," "top," and "cat."

While they expected these sounds to remain stable or change similarly to Anglo-English accents, the evidence showed they were evolving locally in Scotland, independent of Anglo-English trends, and had been doing so for over 100 years.
The Glasgow team suggested that the catalyst for some changes was around World War I.
The study focused on six audio recordings from 1916, held by the British Library, of Scottish soldiers in German prisoner-of-war camps.
These recordings revealed that Scottish accents were already changing a century ago, and perhaps even earlier.
The project’s research and findings will be shared with students and other researchers through an online resource.
Cambridge University Press is analyzing media coverage from the 2014 Brazil World Cup and rating the 'confidence levels' for England out of 100.

These scores fluctuate based on the language used to describe the team. Following the 2-2 draw with Ecuador on June 4, England's confidence was at 38, and it rose to 40 after the 0-0 draw with Honduras on June 8.
The following day, it jumped to 77. As England heads into the game in Manaus, the Cambridge Confidence Index places their current rating at 70.
Over the past two weeks, researchers have evaluated millions of words from a diverse array of media sources.
Dr. Claire Dembry from Cambridge University Press stated, "Our wide range of sources allows us to offer unique insights into the mood surrounding the England team.
It's intriguing to see the nation's confidence ahead of the Italy game, despite lackluster performances against Ecuador and Honduras."
Positive terms like "progress," "strong," and "joy" have been increasingly applied by players, coaching staff, and fans.
Adam Lallana, 26, and 18-year-old Luke Shaw, both looking to leave Southampton, have been spoken of more positively than any other England players.
Neymar became the most discussed player after scoring twice in Brazil's 3-1 win over Croatia.
The word "controversial" emerged after a disputed penalty for Brazil's first goal and anti-World Cup protests in several host cities.
Cambridge will continue to monitor positive and negative indicators throughout the tournament to measure shifts in perceived confidence in the England team.
In a study by University of Westminster academics involving 18,000 children aged seven to 15 from 16 countries, England ranked seventh in child independence.
The research highlighted that allowing children to explore their local areas alone positively impacts their health and development.
However, fear of traffic was cited as the primary reason parents restrict this freedom.
