Between 2010 and 2012, children and parents were surveyed about the activities children could undertake unsupervised in their neighborhoods.
The study noted that many children under 11 lack the freedom to navigate their local areas on their own.
Even older children face restrictions on activities, despite approaching an age where adult rights, like driving, are typically granted.
Finland emerged as the top country for independent mobility, followed by Germany.
The survey found that most Finnish children can move around without supervision.

In contrast, in England, while most primary school children can cross roads alone, only 28% are allowed to travel home from school independently, with even fewer permitted to go out after dark, use local buses, or visit places other than school.
At the secondary level, less than 25% of children are allowed out alone after dark.
Ben Shaw, director of the Policy Studies Institute, stated: "It's crucial to protect children, but gaining independence is key to their development.
Transitioning from primary to secondary school is often seen as the right time for this, but delaying can lead to a spike in road accidents at that age."
European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has stated that the process should start "immediately."
Several EU foreign ministers have also urged Britain to commence promptly. However, Mr. Hammond maintained that "nothing is going to happen at the moment."
The timing of the formal notification to leave the EU is under Britain's control, and discussions will not begin until a new prime minister is chosen to succeed David Cameron, he explained.
Mr. Hammond's stance received backing from German Chancellor Angela Merkel's chief of staff, who argued that British politicians should carefully consider the implications of leaving the EU.
"Politicians in London should take the time to reconsider the consequences of the Brexit decision—but I emphatically do not mean Brexit itself," Peter Altmaier told Reuters news agency.

Mrs. Merkel emphasized that the EU should not be "particularly nasty in any way" during negotiations and that deterring other countries from exiting the bloc shouldn't be a priority in these discussions.
According to the EU, the UK can initiate formal negotiations by triggering Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon, which sets a two-year deadline for a deal.
This can be done through a formal declaration either in writing or verbally at a European Council meeting, which includes ministers from each EU member state.
UK PM David Cameron has announced that he will resign by October, allowing his successor to lead the negotiations.
Since Thursday's vote, speculation has surged about when and how the UK might begin formal negotiations.
The UK's decision to exit the EU has caused widespread upheaval across Europe, leading leaders of Eurosceptic parties in France, the Netherlands, and Italy to demand their own referendums.
In response, some EU politicians advocate for swift reforms to prevent further unrest.
French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron proposed drafting a new mission statement for the EU and putting it to a referendum across all member states.
"We've never had the courage to organize a true European referendum in its real sense," he said at a conference.
"We would first build this new project with European peoples and then submit this new roadmap, this new project, to a referendum [across the bloc]."
The first summit of EU leaders without British representation is set for Wednesday, the day after Mr. Cameron's discussions with members.

Following the news of "Brexit," global stock markets and the pound dropped significantly, and credit rating agency Moody’s downgraded the UK's credit rating to "negative." What are the next steps for Brexit?
Williams, 25, sustained an ankle injury during Wales' victory over South Africa.
Reports indicate that he has agreed to join the European champions for the 2017-18 season.
Scarlets head coach Wayne Pivac stated, "Once that decision is finalized, we won't hide it."
He added, "Liam is resting this week, but there are no updates on his contract status. I'm comfortable with what Sanjay [Williams] shares with me.
I haven't focused much on future plans, but we have [the new Kiwi wing/full-back] Johnny McNicholl here."
Pivac hopes Williams will be ready for the European Champions Cup matches against Toulon on December 11 and 18.
Jonathan Davies, Gareth Davies, Samson Lee, and Jake Ball from the Wales squad are set to return to regional play, while Scott Williams and Ken Owens will be taking a break.
Scotland flanker John Barclay is undergoing an assessment after his international duties, and South African lock David Bulbring might need surgery for a shoulder issue.
"Three internationals are taking some time off due to their significant time on the pitch during preseason and training," Pivac added.
"We need to be strategic with upcoming games and opportunities for breaks; some players had rests during the Treviso and Dragons games earlier this season."
Wales prop Rob Evans is expected to make his season debut against Zebre after recovering from wrist surgery.
"He's eager and full of energy, but we need to channel it, and he's definitely being considered for the trip," said Pivac.
"Rob is up for the challenge of reclaiming his Scarlets and Wales jerseys. He knows it's time to get to work from day one."
The Scarlets are advancing contract discussions with regional captain Owens and his usual stand-in captain, Kiwi center Hadleigh Parkes.

"We've held off on Ken because he's been with the international camp. I'll sit down with him next week to discuss the future. As our current captain, we hope he isn't going anywhere," explained Pivac.
President Obama requested funds from Congress following a week of national protests regarding perceived injustices in policing.
The unrest began in Ferguson, Missouri, where riots ensued after a grand jury decided not to indict a white police officer for the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man.
Protests quickly spread across the U.S., culminating in a mass walkout on Monday, during which students and workers staged lunchtime demonstrations in several cities to draw attention to the issue.
"This is not solely a problem in Ferguson, Missouri. It is a national issue," President Obama stated.
"However, it is a problem that can be solved." The president spoke after a series of meetings at the White House with mayors, civil rights leaders, and law enforcement officials.
These discussions focused on a program that currently provides surplus U.S. military tactical gear to local police departments at no cost.
President Obama announced he had requested recommendations from federal agencies to ensure this program does not contribute to a "militarized culture" in domestic policing.
The Ferguson police department faced criticism for its heavy-handed response to protests following Michael Brown's shooting in August.
President Obama's funding request, spanning three years, includes money to purchase 50,000 body cameras for police officers and resources to reform law enforcement agencies.
Body cameras could offer crucial evidence in police interactions with civilians, especially in contentious situations like the Ferguson incident.
He expressed that stories of discrimination shared by young people at the White House on Monday "contradict my beliefs about America's potential."
Furthermore, he introduced a task force on modern policing, headed by Philadelphia Police Commissioner Charles Ramsey.
Additionally, on Monday, a commission gathered in Ferguson to address issues related to Brown's fatal shooting.
Established by Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, this 16-member panel will explore changes in areas such as public engagement with law enforcement and community stability.

Officer Darren Wilson, who shot Brown, resigned over the weekend, following the earlier decision not to charge him, which ignited a national conversation about the relationship between black communities and law enforcement.
Wilson claimed he feared for his life, while Brown's supporters argued the teenager was trying to surrender and some witnesses indicated the 18-year-old, who was unarmed, had his hands up.
Regulator NHS Improvement planned to release data on hospital deficits but was advised against it by the government.
NHS Improvement expressed disappointment that the results would have to wait until after the election to be published.
Neither the Department of Health nor the Conservative Party commented on the situation.
In a statement, NHS Improvement explained that the publication date needed agreement with the Department of Health, which had not happened due to the election on 8 June.
"We sought guidance hoping to agree on a publication date, but it became clear, after speaking with the department, that releasing the data would breach Cabinet Office guidelines," they said.
"Although disappointing, the financial results for the provider sector must be withheld until after the general election."
The financial health of the NHS in England has been subject to intense debate. In the 2015-16 fiscal year, hospitals and trusts accumulated deficits totaling £2.4 billion.

The latest figures, covering up to March's end, will confirm the deficits for the 2016-17 fiscal year and are typically released before NHS Improvement board meetings, with the next one due before the end of May.
NHS Improvement is understood to want to publish the numbers as usual, ideally within a week, but Whitehall officials have advised delaying until after polling due to purdah rules.
The purdah convention restricts civil service announcements during election campaigns, a policy some argue is too limiting.
Dr. Mark Porter, BMA council chairman, stated, "The government is evidently scared, avoiding confronting the funding crisis that strains the NHS.

Delaying the figures won't solve our health service's real issues." Dr. Mark Holland, president of the Society for Acute Medicine, commented, "The general election and purdah seem to halt numerous vital NHS decisions.
It is justifiable and fair that data concerning the NHS in England is released."
Shadow health secretary Jon Ashworth added, "This is a cover-up that denies the public an accurate view of the NHS.
We demand complete transparency, allowing everyone to understand the NHS's true state when voting."
NHS England raised eyebrows at the campaign start by announcing that monthly performance figures—such as A&E waiting times—due on 8 June wouldn't be published because it was polling day.
On the day he was scheduled to travel to Cardiff for a Heineken Cup press event, Saracens informed him of an "important squad meeting" in Munich.
He obliged, although the meeting turned out to be a day-trip to Oktoberfest, where the team, led by their captain, enjoyed themselves so much that one member missed the midnight flight home.
European rugby officials were displeased, fining Saracens £4,250 for instructing Steve Borthwick to prioritize Oktoberfest over Heineken Cup responsibilities.
Saracens' chief executive, Edward Griffiths, remained unapologetic, claiming, "We're trying to be a little bit different, which will always raise eyebrows.
Maybe others should look at what we're doing." During a match against Leicester the following weekend, Bavaria's drinking music blared through the speakers.
In autumn 2010, with Griffiths at the helm for just over 18 months, changes began that saw the arrival of South African director of rugby Brendan Venter.
Despite Saracens' history as a middling club that struggled to compete at the highest level, Griffiths and Venter instilled a new culture.
Eight months after the Oktoberfest trip, Saracens clinched their first Premiership title.
Three years later, they were on the brink of achieving a Heineken Cup and Premiership double, facing Toulon and Northampton on consecutive Saturdays.
Although they were defeated by Toulon, the Premiership title remained within reach.

Before Saracens, Griffiths was the chief executive of the South African Rugby Union, credited for having the 1995 World Cup-winning Springboks learn all verses of the national anthem, Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika, and coining the slogan "one team, one country."
Dubbed as the "cult of Saracens," Griffiths' unique approach has garnered respect.
While sports administrators often juggle financial and competitive demands, Griffiths claims to be merely "interested" in the outcomes of both finals—a statement that might even be overstated.
In December 2012, David Brown fell ill at Maghaberry Prison and later died in the hospital from a brain hemorrhage.
According to the Prisoner Ombudsman, staff left him unattended for five minutes while he was unresponsive and failed to raise the alarm promptly.

The watchdog deemed the Prison Service's response as "inadequate." Tom McGonigle, the Prisoner Ombudsman, reported that the nurse treating Brown was not informed it was an emergency and other prisoners were not confined to their cells during the incident.
Mr. McGonigle noted, "While improvements were possible, the investigation's key finding is an alternative outcome for Mr. Brown was unattainable."
The Prisoner Ombudsman's office in Northern Ireland investigates all in-custody deaths, including those from natural causes.
The report on David Brown's death revealed he had painkillers in his system, which were prescribed and within therapeutic ranges during toxicology testing.
"This is significant given the speculation about a white powdery substance found near Mr. Brown's nose at his death," stated the ombudsman.
Although the report criticized the prison staff's initial response upon discovering Brown unconscious, it did not fault his medical care during imprisonment.
A clinical reviewer involved in the investigation concluded no earlier diagnosis was possible, nor was an alternative outcome for Brown achievable.
The ombudsman's report identified four areas for improvement in the prison's case management, including record-keeping and post-incident staff support.
These issues had been previously raised with the prison authorities and the South-Eastern Health and Social Care Trust, which treated Brown.
The Northern Ireland Prison Service (NIPS) accepted the ombudsman's four recommendations and claimed they have been implemented.

The health trust also accepted their recommendation and assured the ombudsman that it has been reiterated to staff and will be addressed at a "Lessons Learned" forum. Mr. McGonigle conveyed his sympathies to Brown's family.
The former captain, now 33 years old, replaces Glamorgan wicketkeeper Mark Wallace, who retired on February 10.
Mitchell, succeeded by Joe Leach as captain for 2017, becomes the 14th PCA chairman since its inception in 1967.
"Daryl's election by over 400 of his peers reflects the high esteem in which he's held," said PCA chief executive David Leatherdale.
"There were strong candidates, but Daryl's long tenure of 13 or 14 years means the players know and respect him.
He's trusted in our circles. It's ironic that, having once been his boss at Worcestershire, he's now effectively my superior as PCA chairman."
Worcestershire opener Mitchell is set to serve for four years, matching the duration of his new contract signed at New Road in December.

He won a closely contested election against candidates like Durham's former England fast bowler Graham Onions, Leicestershire batsman Paul Horton, Somerset's James Hildreth, and Northamptonshire all-rounder Steven Crook.
Pending approval at the PCA's AGM on February 21, Mitchell will be the third Worcestershire captain to hold this position, following Tim Curtis (1989-96) and Vikram Solanki (2009-13).
"I've made it known I wanted to remain captain," Mitchell revealed to BBC Sport.
"Admittedly, October was tough for me, but signing the new contract put that behind me. I’d have pursued this election regardless, as I enjoy staying active.
However, with some perspective now, not being captain might ease some pressure and allow me to focus more on my batting next season.
It's exciting to take on this role, although I need to stay focused. It might be a hidden benefit," he added.

The previous PCA chairmen include Roger Prideaux (1967-68), Jack Bannister (1968-70), Mike Edwards (1970-73), Peter Walker (1973-75), David Brown (1975-80), Chris Balderstone (1980-84), Geoff Cook (1984-89), Matthew Fleming (1996-2003), Martyn Ball (2003-07), and Dougie Brown (2007-09).

Dyke, appointed in 2013, initially intended to stay for another year. However, he reconsidered after facing opposition to his proposed reforms from some FA councillors and a minority of board members.
Upon succeeding David Bernstein, Dyke, now 68, set goals for England to reach the Euro 2020 semi-finals and win the 2022 World Cup.
He believes the state of football has improved financially, administratively, and in coaching since he took over.
Despite this, he acknowledged it would be a "fight" to persuade the FA Council to implement "much-needed, significant reform."
In his statement, Dyke added, "I had already decided that if reform was not possible, I would leave this summer, a decision I shared with several colleagues.
Now, even if reforms pass, I may not be the best person to manage the aftermath."
Previously, Dyke, a former BBC director general, focused on modernizing the FA and increasing English players in the Premier League.
He drew attention for making a throat-cutting gesture when England was placed in a tough 2014 World Cup group with Italy and Uruguay.
Earlier this month, Dyke, a vocal critic of Fifa under Sepp Blatter, remarked, "we should shoot ourselves" if England failed to advance from their group at Euro 2016 in France.
Listen to reactions to Dyke's announcement on BBC Radio 5 Live's Football Daily podcast.
Bernstein expressed he was "not particularly surprised" by Dyke's decision, as neither he nor Dyke had enacted "any substantial change" due to the "extreme difficulty" of pushing through reforms.
"I can understand his frustration; it mirrors mine," Bernstein told BBC Radio 5 Live Sport, suggesting only government or regulatory "outside intervention" could make a difference.
BBC Radio 5 Live's sports news correspondent Richard Conway addresses questions stemming from Dyke's decision.

Q: Why is Dyke frustrated? A: In 2014, Dyke criticized the FA Council for being "overwhelmingly male and overwhelmingly white," feeling its members, from both professional and amateur sectors, don't represent modern English football.

Yet, they influence major policy decisions, and many of the council's 120 members would lose their positions if the proposed changes are accepted. Q: What will happen now? Dyke is known for his political resilience.
Prosecutors stated that Darren Byrne, 40, assaulted his wife, Maria Byrne, 35, at their residence in Theydon Bois after she discovered his affair.
The jury heard that Mr. Byrne poured white spirit on his unconscious wife and turned on the stove before leaving the house.
At Chelmsford Crown Court, Mr. Byrne is contesting charges of murder and arson related to the February incident.
Prosecutor Andrew Jackson explained that the couple argued on the morning of February 13 after Maria found out he was still involved with a married woman.
Mr. Jackson said, "The prosecution contends that Maria Byrne's second discovery of his alleged infidelity triggered the alleged murder."
The court was informed that after dousing his wife's body with the flammable liquid, Mr. Byrne went for a walk with the family dog.
CCTV footage showed he was gone for over an hour. Upon returning to find his plan had failed, he staged a scene, according to the prosecutor.
He called emergency services, reporting that his wife was "burned" and said, "The stove was on and the frying pan's on the other side of the room.
She's not breathing." Mr. Byrne told paramedics that his wife had been preparing a bacon sandwich for him and was dead when he returned, the court heard.
A post-mortem found white spirit on Mrs. Byrne's clothes, and a half-empty bottle of it was discovered in the garage, the jury was told.
The couple's two children were not home at the time of their mother's death. The trial is ongoing.
Valentina Milluzzo's family claims her doctor refused to abort her fetuses due to his status as a "conscientious objector" to abortion.
However, the hospital firmly denies these allegations. Milluzzo's burial has been delayed pending further investigations.
She was admitted to Cannizzaro Hospital in Catania, Sicily, on September 29 after complications led to premature labor at 19 weeks of pregnancy, following fertility treatment at another facility.
Her condition remained stable for over two weeks until October 15, when her blood pressure and temperature dropped, leading to a deterioration.

The family's lawyer alleges one of the fetuses had breathing issues, and the gynecologist refused to perform an abortion to save Milluzzo, reportedly stating, "As long as it's alive, I will not intervene."
No action was taken while the troubled fetus was alive, and the lawyer states both fetuses died hours later.
Milluzzo's health worsened overnight as she developed an infection, and she was transferred to intensive care on October 16, where she passed away.
Angelo Pellicano, Cannizzaro Hospital's head, refuted the lawyer's claims, explaining there was no conscientious objection because the miscarriage was involuntary due to severe circumstances.
He told the Ansa news agency, "I rule out that a doctor could have told the family what they say he told them."
Sources informed Ansa that the doctor was not listed as a "conscientious objector."
Catania's prosecutor postponed Milluzzo's burial for a post-mortem examination.
There are reports of potential investigations into hospital staff, though unconfirmed.
Paolo Scollo, a senior doctor at the hospital, commented that while all doctors in his department are "objectors," external doctors are brought in when necessary.
He clarified that this case involved a spontaneous miscarriage, and no external assistance was required, suggesting the doctor was not negligent.
Earlier this year, data revealed that 70% of Italian gynecologists refused to perform abortions in 2013, with even higher rates in southern Italy, including 87.6% in Sicily.
Abortion has been legal in Italy since 1978, permitted during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, and allowed beyond only if the mother's life is at risk or there are fetal complications.
Italy, being predominantly Catholic, sees higher objection rates in its southern regions.
Media playback isn't available on this device. In midweek, O'Neill and Keane reached new agreements with the Football Association of Ireland (FAI), although the contracts remain unsigned.
Their Irish team kicks off its Euro 2016 campaign against Sweden on Monday. "We're happy to stay on.
I really enjoy the job, working with the players, the staff, and the FAI," said Keane, 44.
The former Manchester United star has openly expressed his ambition to return to club management after previous stints at Sunderland and Ipswich.
Since joining the Republic of Ireland team in November 2013, Keane has twice been considered for the Celtic job but chose to stay as O'Neill's assistant.
"As for club management, I'm 44, so there's ample time for that," he noted. "I definitely want to return to it, and by 'short term,' I mean the next few years, not weeks."

During a generally lighthearted press conference at the team’s base in Versailles, Keane only appeared serious when questioned about a potential contract clause allowing him to negotiate with clubs over the next two years.
"What’s written in my contract is none of your business," the Cork native responded.
"Who do you work for? What's your contract? Do you get paid well? That's none of my business."

In a relaxed manner, Keane even joked about the Republic’s tournament facilities, 14 years after his notorious departure from the pre-World Cup training camp in Saipan in 2002. "The FAI has done excellently. Lessons have clearly been learned.

If I had to find a fault, maybe my bed’s a bit too soft," he quipped. "The facilities are outstanding; they're a testament to everyone involved here—the training pitch, the hotel, the location. It's fantastic. We're really enjoying it."
The mayor of London faced criticism for giving his barrister wife, Marina Wheeler, a ride through the city on a single-seater bicycle last Thursday.
Riding a "backie" is illegal under the 1998 Road Traffic Act, which can result in a fine of up to £200.

The mayor apologized, stating he was unaware he was breaking the law. Sam Jones from the cycling charity CTC called his actions "very naughty," emphasizing that cyclists should not carry passengers in this manner or violate the law.

A video of Mr. Johnson and his wife, captured by passengers in a car in North Kensington, shows Ms. Wheeler sitting on the saddle without a helmet, holding her handbag, while Mr. Johnson pedals standing up.

When informed by the passengers that he was breaking the law, Mr. Johnson dismounted the bike, saying, "Night, night," to them. In the footage, the passengers can be heard saying, "Mate, you all right?
Saddling, that's a good one, eh?" Another remarks, "You're not allowed to do that, mate."
According to Section 24 of the Road Traffic Act, a single bicycle should not carry more than one person unless it is designed for it.
The mayor, a strong advocate for cycling, is associated with London's "Boris bikes" available for public hire.
His spokesperson said: "The mayor apologizes for the brief ride he gave his wife on his bike!

He was unaware of violating the Road Traffic Act. He didn't plan to cycle all the way home from North Kensington to North London with Marina on the back; instead, he intended to take her to a main road to catch a black cab.
The mayor is a great supporter of cycling and the black cab trade, which explains his attempt to combine the two."
In the footage, some Kenyan soldiers are seen holding white shopping bags, while others appear to take white boxes from a mobile phone store.
The attack by suspected al-Shabab militants on the Nairobi shopping center on September 21 resulted in at least 67 deaths.

The Kenyan military is currently investigating the looting allegations. News agencies report that the CCTV footage was filmed near the entrance of Westgate Mall's Nakumatt supermarket, which offers a range of products from food to electronics.
In one segment, soldiers are observed leaving the supermarket, passing a blood-stained floor, with plastic bags in hand.

In another clip, soldiers are spotted near a mobile phone store; one reaches over the counter to remove a white item, followed by others taking similar items, identified by Reuters as mobile phone boxes.
The Westgate attack led to a four-day siege, causing extensive damage to the shopping center.
The Kenyan military has initiated a probe into the looting claims, which correspondents suggest have outraged many Kenyans.
Over the weekend, The Nation, Kenya's leading newspaper, published an article titled "Shame of soldiers looting Westgate."
The footage of alleged looting emerged as Kenyan authorities announced the discovery of a body they believe to be a fourth attacker.
"Today, Sunday, October 20, 2013, we recovered a fourth body, identified from CCTV footage as a terrorist," said Kenyan Interior Minister Joseph Ole Lenku.
"DNA and other investigations will confirm their identities. We also recovered four AK47 rifles used in the assault and 11 magazines."
Initially, officials reported 10 to 15 gunmen involved, but CCTV footage suggests only four militants.
It remains unclear if some attackers managed to escape. The Somali militant group al-Shabab claimed the attack was a response to Kenyan military operations in Somalia.
Last week, the BBC's Newsnight revealed that one suspected attacker was identified as Hassan Abdi Dhuhulow, a 23-year-old Somali-born Norwegian national.
His family fled to Norway in the 1990s, but he returned to Somalia in 2009 and allegedly joined al-Shabab.

Sources within al-Shabab informed the BBC Somali Service that Dhuhulow attended a training camp in El Bur, central Somalia, and participated in multiple operations in Mogadishu and Kismayo, gaining notoriety in jihadist circles.
The 30-year-old from County Down made history as the first Irish cyclist to win a world track title in 117 years, achieving victory in the scratch race in Belarus in 2013.

That same year, Irvine also captured a World Cup gold in Manchester. "Missing out on the Olympics played a big role, and I lost my passion for cycling," the Northern Irishman explained. He continued, "The drive to train and devote all that time has faded.
Continuing would just be wasting my time." Irvine claimed silver in the individual pursuit in Belarus shortly before winning the scratch event at the 2013 World Championship.
That year was a whirlwind for Irvine, who also earned silver in the points race at the World Championships and a European bronze medal, all while dealing with injuries.
Shortly after his success in Belarus, Irvine fractured his leg at the Tour of Taiwan and suffered muscle injuries at a track event in Belgium.
Despite these setbacks, Irvine ended 2013 as the top-ranked scratch rider in the UCI world rankings and secured a scratch silver medal at the 2014 Track Cycling World Championships.
His achievements in 2013 earned him the title of BBC Northern Ireland Sports Personality of the Year.

After winning silver in the scratch race at the 2014 World Championships in Colombia, Irvine was seen as a promising medal candidate for the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow, hoping to better the team pursuit bronze he won with Northern Ireland in Delhi in 2008.
However, Irvine's performances in Glasgow were disappointing, and injuries hindered his efforts to regain form.
Irvine mentioned that "aches and pains" influenced his decision to retire. "I loved that I helped make cycling more mainstream," he said.
"I'm proud of my world and European successes, and it's rewarding to have my name in the history books."
The media playback feature doesn't work on this device. During a 0-0 match against the Republic of Ireland in Dublin, Real Madrid forward received his second yellow card of the season.
This means he'll miss the match against Group D leaders Serbia on June 11 due to suspension.

"We need to fill that gap and aim for a good result," Gunter stated. Aston Villa defender Neil Taylor will also miss the match in Belgrade, potentially facing a three-match suspension following a challenge that resulted in Republic captain Seamus Coleman needing surgery for a fractured right leg.
Reading defender Gunter, now Wales' joint-third most capped player, believes that Wales can succeed even without key players like Bale, the world's second most expensive player.
"We've previously managed without key players and always emphasized that we are not a one-man team," Gunter noted.
"For Gaz to perform well, he needs the team, and that remains true. Although it's preferable to have him, we're determined to achieve our goals without him," he added.
Bale, who has netted four goals in this campaign, hasn't missed a competitive international since October 2013, playing 21 consecutive competitive matches.
His absence is challenging for Wales, currently third, four points behind Serbia and the Republic of Ireland midway through, having drawn four of their five Group D matches.
But Gunter said there's sufficient time to string together wins and remarked on the unpredictability of other match outcomes.
“We wanted a few more points, but qualifying is always tough. We're still unbeaten, close to turning draws into wins.
Despite challenges, we've faced worse. We've historically succeeded in various places, and we need to recall that positivity."

The Dublin draw was overshadowed by Everton defender Coleman's severe injury. The media playback feature doesn't work on this device, but Coleman received extensive on-field treatment, using oxygen before being stretchered off.

When asked about any provocation, given Republic midfielder Glenn Whelan's earlier incident with his Stoke teammate Joe Allen, Wales manager Chris Coleman commented, "Our team will stand up for themselves, as necessary."

Former Warrington full-back Richie Mathers criticized the "iPitch" at Stobart Stadium, sharing images of grazes on his body via Twitter and calling the surface, on which his team won 32-14, an "absolute joke."
In response, Widnes suggested that Mathers' injuries were likely caused by the icy conditions during the match.

The club's chief executive, Julie Gaskell, explained: "We had four games on the pitch this weekend, and considering the extreme weather—with temperatures dropping to minus seven on Friday night—we believe the injuries match those expected in such conditions.
Similar injuries occurred in Salford's game on Saturday. Our players have trained on a similar surface for nine months without issues, and any problems would have surfaced by now."
Gaskell further noted that over the last four weeks, there have been no reported injuries during five-a-side football and boys and girls tag rugby on the iPitch.
The Rugby Football League confirmed that their match commissioner found no concerns with the surface, which is the sport's first artificial pitch.
RFL spokesman John Ledger stated, "We are confident in Widnes continuing the use of the iPitch.
It didn't pose more danger than any other surface over the weekend, and the extreme weather conditions may have been a factor."
During a campaign rally, he labeled the South Carolina senator an "idiot" and urged the crowd to dial the number he provided.
When a Politico reporter called the number on Tuesday, Senator Graham was the one who answered.
Recently, Mr. Graham had accused Mr. Trump of being a "jackass" following Mr. Trump's disparaging remarks about Senator John McCain.

Fellow Republicans and veterans groups have increasingly criticized Mr. Trump for seemingly belittling Mr. McCain's military service, particularly his time as a prisoner of war in Vietnam, by saying, "He's a war hero because he was captured.

I like people who weren't captured." Despite the backlash, national polls indicate Mr. Trump holds a double-digit lead over his nearest Republican competitor—a lead established largely before his controversial comments about Mr. McCain.
As Mr. Trump continues to dominate media coverage in the crowded Republican race, his rivals are growing increasingly frustrated.
Since launching his campaign in June, he has made headlines by labeling undocumented Mexican immigrants as "rapists" and "criminals."
"The world is literally falling apart, and all we're talking about is Donald Trump," Mr. Graham remarked on CNN on Monday.
Criticizing the military history of Senator McCain, a former prisoner of war left unable to lift his arms above his shoulders due to brutal torture, would typically be a fatal move.
However, Trump thrives in the modern media landscape and the frantic style of contemporary campaigning.
His provocative statements only fuel more coverage and social media buzz, which in turn seem to boost his polling numbers.
It appears that for a significant segment of Republican voters, notoriety translates into popularity. Trump has mastered this political demolition derby.
At a private event in Vancouver, Uber CEO Travis Kalanick acknowledged that the company is losing more than $1 billion annually in China, as reported by Canadian tech news site Betakit.
Reuters later confirmed the figure with Uber China. Uber, which started operating in China in 2014, competes with the country's leading taxi app, Didi Kuaidi, and is active in over 40 Chinese cities.
The company announced plans last year to expand to 100 Chinese cities within the following 12 months.
Kalanick stated, "We're profitable in the USA, but we're losing over $1 billion a year in China."
He identified China as Uber's largest international market, although its market share lags behind Didi Kuaidi.
"We face a strong competitor that's unprofitable in all their locations, yet they're purchasing market share."
Kalanick noted that the company had grown its share from a mere 1% at the start of 2015 to about 30-35%.
Didi Kuaidi, supported by Chinese tech giants Tencent and Alibaba, has also teamed up with Lyft, Uber's US competitor.
Kalanick disclosed that he raised around $200 million to help Uber compete in emerging markets, according to Betakit.

He added, "I'd rather focus on building than fundraising, but if I don’t engage in fundraising, I'll be squeezed out as others buy market share." Uber operates in 380 cities globally, according to its website.

On the Sunday Politics Scotland programme, Employability Minister Jamie Hepburn referenced a report by the Fraser of Allander Institute, which indicated that Scotland's economy was nearing recession and underperforming compared to the UK overall.

The report primarily attributed this to the oil price downturn. Mr. Hepburn noted, "About two-thirds of the sluggish growth is due to the oil and gas downturn," while also acknowledging other underlying issues.
He emphasized that we should also focus on the strengths of Scotland's economy.
Dean Lockhart from the Scottish Conservatives argued that the SNP must take responsibility for the economic conditions, labeling it as a "real indictment."
Referring to the report, he claimed Scotland had experienced "a lost decade under the SNP."

Jackie Baillie of Scottish Labour pointed out that growth has stalled under the SNP, stating, "Over the past 10 years, the Scottish economy has grown by just 1.2%, a stark contrast to the 17% growth seen in the prior seven years."
An economist on the programme also highlighted how the drop in oil prices, alongside other deeper issues, affected the economy.
Prof. David Bell from the University of Stirling explained, "The oil price fall significantly impacted the North-East and had ripple effects throughout Scotland.

Other parts of the economy have also lacked dynamism over the past decade." He suggested focusing on long-term factors, such as increased infrastructure investment and a clearer skills policy, to attract businesses to Scotland.
David Johnstone, Managing Director of After Digital, reported a shortage in key technical skills, noting, "Finding qualified candidates is challenging.
While marketing roles attract numerous applicants, technical development positions face a skill shortage."
He pointed out the difficulty for colleges and training providers to stay updated with industry developments.

A committee led by Paralympic champion Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson has proposed that Wales could be the first nation to elevate physical education (PE) to a core subject within its national curriculum.

This shift would allow more time for sports in schools, but teaching unions express concerns that expanding the core curriculum might undermine the focus on existing subjects. The Welsh government has stated it will consider this recommendation.
Education Minister Leighton Andrews is keen to explore ways to boost physical activity among children and young people.
Arwyn Jones, the BBC Wales education correspondent, notes that increasing exercise opportunities is essential, but simply adding PE to the core curriculum involves more complexity than it might seem.
Currently, the core subjects in Wales are Welsh, English, mathematics, and science, which the government prioritizes with dedicated time and resources.
Teaching unions worry that adding to the core could dilute each subject’s priority.
With over one-third of young people in Wales being overweight or obese, straining the NHS with costs exceeding £70 million annually, promoting PE is increasingly vital.
If PE becomes a core subject, schools would need to allocate more time, resources, and teacher training to it.

Enhanced focus on PE would require teachers to demonstrate proficiency during initial training, bring qualified specialists into schools, and undergo rigorous assessment by educational consortia and Estyn, the schools inspectorate.
Continuous monitoring of progress would also be necessary. Despite the boldness of this proposal, the group believes it's a crucial step.

The report, which includes input from Sports Wales chair Laura McAllister, states that the Welsh government’s commitment to physical literacy necessitates elevating PE's status as essential as reading and writing.
However, while supportive, teaching unions caution against overcrowding the core curriculum.
Dr. Philip Dixon, director of ATL Cymru, emphasizes the need for a clear focus: "We should decide on a small core.
Literacy and numeracy are priorities; including PE may be wise, but it’s ultimately the government’s decision."
Sir Keir Starmer has argued there is a "very strong case" for the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) to have the final say on prosecuting cases.
At present, police forces in England and Wales decide whether to refer a case to the CPS following an investigation into a death.
The CPS has stated that cases should be brought to a prosecutor's attention as early as possible.
According to the Department of Transport, 113 cyclists were killed in the UK last year.
A BBC Newsbeat Freedom of Information request revealed that between 2007 and 2014, there were 276 recorded incidents of cyclists killed in accidents involving motor vehicles.
Of these cases, 148 (54%) led to the driver being charged. Among those found guilty, fewer than half received prison sentences.

Sir Keir, now a Labour MP, told the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme that if a death is involved and requires a criminal investigation, it "really ought to go off to the CPS for the final decision."

In Scotland, if evidence suggests driver fault in a cyclist's death, a report is submitted to the Procurator Fiscal, though data from a 2014 Freedom of Information request to Police Scotland indicates this happens infrequently.

Cycling advocates are urging for a shift in liability presumption in civil cases, as currently there is no bias towards either party. My father, Mick, was killed last year while cycling through central London.
After spending three weeks in a coma, he passed away. During the inquest, the driver said she only realized something had occurred after hearing a noise, like "something falling from the sky."

The coroner ruled it an accidental death. We questioned the police's investigation efforts from the beginning, feeling potential witnesses weren't pursued as they should have been, and our situation seemed overlooked.

A year after my father's death, we held a vigil where the accident took place. That day, police informed a journalist they would refer the case to prosecutors, potentially leading to a trial, which felt like progress.
However, just four days later, the police told the same journalist the case was closed.
I still seek answers about my dad's crash, and our only remaining option is a private prosecution.
Ian Toothill believes he is the first cancer patient to conquer the world's highest mountain.
A Sheffield Wednesday supporter, he planted a Sheffield United flag at the summit to raise money for charity.
The 47-year-old personal trainer reached the peak on Monday and has amassed nearly £31,500 ($40,600) for Macmillan.
He tweeted: "Nothing to see here, just some cancer dude and [Sheffield Wednesday] fan on the summit of Everest with a @SUFC_tweets flag."
Originally from Sheffield and now residing in Willesden Green, London, Mr. Toothill has experience climbing in the Himalayas.
Diagnosed with bowel cancer in June 2015, he was declared cancer-free in early 2016 only to find out later it had returned.
Doctors informed him he had "just several months left to live." In a February interview with BBC Radio Sheffield, he stated: "I'm determined to prove anything is possible."
He reached the top of the North Col route on May 16 and the summit of Everest on June 5.
Miss NJP tweeted: "What an amazing achievement and a wonderful moment for @IanToothill.
Feeling emotional. So glad you made it to the top #climbingforcancer." He planted the rival team's flag at the summit after a friend donated £1,000 as a challenge.
Accompanying Mr. Toothill for part of the climb was Leslie Binns from Rotherham, who had previously abandoned his summit attempt to save another climber's life last June.
Mr. Toothill's fundraising exceeded its target of £29,100, reaching nearly £31,500.
Malorie Bantala, aged 22, gave birth to a stillborn boy at 32 weeks following a violent incident in London this June.
The attack allegedly occurred because she refused a termination, prompting Kevin Wilson and a 17-year-old to assault her.
Both deny charges of child destruction and grievous bodily harm. The Old Bailey heard that Mr. Wilson became furious when Miss Bantala refused to have an abortion and insisted on keeping their child.
Speaking in his defense, the teaching assistant apologized for his behavior towards her but claimed he was "napping" at home in Bermondsey, south-east London, during the assault.
He told the jury he was "shocked and surprised" to learn of the pregnancy and had lied to Miss Bantala, saying he planned to go to Ghana as he wasn't interested in "playing happy families."
He stated, "I told Malorie that I'm too young to have a child and to have an abortion."
Between May and June, Mr. Wilson said he didn't communicate with Miss Bantala after a dispute arose when she informed friends he was the father and accused her of infidelity.
He revealed that, prior to Miss Bantala losing the baby, he had "moved on" with another girlfriend who also became pregnant but did not have a child.
On June 15, the day of the attack, Mr. Wilson worked at a school for children with behavioral issues before walking home.
Following the assault in Peckham, south-east London, Miss Bantala suffered life-threatening internal injuries. Her stillborn son was delivered via Caesarean section. The trial is ongoing.
Prince Harry received a warm welcome in Surama village, located in the Iwokrama rainforest, when he was adorned with a feathered headdress before observing a cultural dance around a pole.
He spoke with rangers to understand efforts in rainforest conservation and the advantages of eco-tourism.
During his visit, Prince Harry also stopped by a school and explored the Kaieteur Falls, known as one of the world's tallest freefall waterfalls.
On the second-to-last day of his Caribbean tour, the prince flew to the Iwokrama International Centre, closely connected to the Prince of Wales, its patron since 2000.
His itinerary included a visit to Fairview village to honor its elders and tour the local school.
An open-air community hall hosted the prince, where he received gifts, including a painting of traditional homes.
During a speech, he commended the remote community, saying: "My father spoke fondly of his time here when he was much younger and had more hair.
The work you're doing is remarkable, and your leadership is vital for preserving this area."
The day's final visit was to Kaieteur Falls, which boasts a 250-meter drop, five times the height of Niagara Falls.
Earlier in the week, Prince Harry joined Rihanna in Barbados for a celebratory concert, where they participated in an HIV test to spotlight World AIDS Day in Bridgetown.
Guyana stands as South America's sole English-speaking nation, having changed hands between the Dutch, French, and British from 1780 to 1813.
It was the site of the 1978 Jonestown massacre, where more than 900 members of the People's Temple sect led by Jim Jones died in a mass suicide. Click here for further exploration of Guyana.
Editing an entire game down to its key moments typically demands a meticulous individual to pinpoint the most critical periods of play.
However, scientists in Spain are working to streamline this process by developing a computer capable of doing the task.
This technology aims to automatically edit games by identifying crucial highlights.
Researchers at the Polytechnic University of Catalonia have been developing this system for several years and have recently published an 18-page report detailing its mechanics.

Arnau Raventos, the lead professor on the project, shared with Newsbeat that they are collaborating with local television companies in Spain to simplify the job for those who currently edit game summaries manually.
Here’s a brief overview of how it works: the system analyzes what are known as key-frames.

The computer examines every segment of the match to detect indicators of significant events, such as clusters of players, zoomed-in action, heightened crowd noise, or the sound of the referee’s whistle.
Arnau refers to these instances as "occasions." He explains, "We aim to identify specific combinations of moments in a football match.
A goal qualifies as an occasion." For instance, suppose a defender falls in the penalty box—everyone gathers, a whistle blows, faces fill the shot, and a penalty occurs.

Theoretically, this technology should capture such moments. Nevertheless, the system is still in development, and even casual football fans might find its current limitations frustrating, as it hasn't yet consistently detected the exact moment a goal is scored.
In trials across five matches, the technology identified 70% of the goals. "We need to be honest," says Arnau.
"Currently, it's not feasible to create a fully automatic summary that catches every goal."
Despite this, the technology effectively discards non-essential moments, like panoramic views, which simplifies the editor’s task.
For more updates, follow @BBCNewsbeat on Twitter and Radio1Newsbeat on YouTube.
Natural Resources Wales (NRW) stated that the impact on sites of special scientific interest (SSSIs) "could not be fully mitigated."
The £1.1 billion proposal for the M4 would traverse four SSSIs within the Gwent Levels.
Welsh Government lawyers argued that environmental concerns must be balanced with other interests.
During the Newport inquiry, it was revealed that approximately 105 hectares of land designated for protecting water invertebrates would be lost due to the scheme.
The Gwent Levels' unique network of ditches, known as reens, were originally constructed during Roman times and now serve as habitats for various rare species.

The Welsh Government has committed to replacing lost reens with new ones. Dr. Jessica Poole from Natural Resources Wales (NRW) informed the inquiry that discussions with the Welsh Government have led to her approval of the proposed design for the new reens.
However, she expressed concerns about their effectiveness, noting it may take time for them to support the aquatic insects the sites aim to conserve.
She acknowledged the challenge of replicating a complex ecology developed over centuries.
NRW argued that the Welsh Government had not shown the project met its legal obligation to promote sustainable development.
Dr. Poole mentioned that adopting the alternative blue route, recommended by transport expert Prof. Stuart Cole, would "significantly reduce" the motorway's impact on SSSI land.

The inquiry was informed that several concerns raised by NRW in response to the project's draft plans had been addressed, and NRW was now satisfied with issues related to water quality, drainage, and protection of species like otters and bats.
Morag Ellis QC, representing the Welsh Government, emphasized it is the role of Welsh ministers to balance potential impacts on SSSI land with other public interests concerning the new motorway.
She argued that claiming adverse effects were "fully mitigated for" wrongly sets a legal standard.
Ellis described NRW's modifications to its initial objections, following thorough discussions with the Welsh Government, as "a major step forward."

The proposed deal is intended to help alleviate Europe's migration crisis. However, Mr. Gove criticized Turkey, saying it has experienced an "erosion of fundamental democratic freedoms," and argued that the EU should protest instead of offering "concessions."

David Cameron has stated that it would take "literally decades" before Turkey could join the EU, emphasizing that the UK holds a veto on this, as the agreement of all EU members and 28 national parliaments is required for a new country to join.
Despite this, Mr. Gove pointed out that the "official British government policy" supports Turkey's membership without requiring a public referendum on new countries joining.
He argued that the EU referendum on June 23 was the UK's "only chance" to express views on free movement from Turkey.

Earlier in the EU referendum campaign, Turkey's EU membership bid and a proposed deal allowing Turks visa-free travel in exchange for Turkey accepting migrants who crossed the Aegean Sea to Greece sparked controversy.
On Wednesday, at Vote Leave's headquarters, Mr. Gove, a prominent Out campaigner, revisited the topic, warning of the security risks of expanding the EU to include Turkey.

He stated, "With the growing terrorism threat, it's difficult to see how visa-free travel for 77 million Turkish citizens and creating a border-free zone from Iraq, Iran, and Syria to the English Channel is in our security interests.
"It's even harder to understand why this would be wise when extremists might believe the West is opening its borders to appease an Islamist government."
Mr. Gove also expressed concern that Turkey's "democratic development" has regressed under President Erdogan.
He insisted, "We and the European Union should strongly protest this erosion of fundamental democratic freedoms," yet lamented that concessions continue to be made to Erdogan.
Meanwhile, the prime minister has claimed that Leave campaigners are making "very misleading claims about Turkey" and the EU.
This issue touches on immigration and free movement within Europe. Last month, Mr. Cameron said, "It would take decades, literally decades, for this to happen, and even then, we could still say no."
He added, "The fact that the Leave campaign is getting something as straightforward as this wrong should call into question their judgment on the larger issue of leaving the EU."
In Nairobi and other cities, many shops remain open. According to the Kenya National Commission on Human Rights, at least 24 people have died in violence since the election on August 8.
Mr. Odinga claims the election was rigged to secure President Uhuru Kenyatta's victory and has called for a "day of mourning for the fallen patriots."
However, Kenyans on Twitter are encouraging a return to normalcy with the hashtag #TurudiKaziniChallenge, which means "Let's return to work" in Swahili.
President Kenyatta has also appealed for peace, stating, "At the end of the day, we are all Kenyans.
We shouldn't fight or destroy each other's property or take lives." He added, "Kenyans have put the election behind them, and most have returned to work."
In Nairobi's Kibera slum, a stronghold for Mr. Odinga, some young people have been burning tires, as reported by the BBC's Tomi Oladipo.
Despite agreeing that the election results were rigged, some of Mr. Odinga's supporters in Kibera have reopened their shops, unable to afford further business losses.
In Mombasa, businesses operate as usual. Kisumu, another Odinga stronghold in the west, shows a mixed response to the strike, with some shops open and others closed.
Official results gave President Kenyatta about 54% of the vote, while Mr. Odinga received 45%.
On Sunday, Mr. Odinga called for a strike, telling his supporters, "This is a failed regime resorting to killing instead of addressing the real issue.
The vote was stolen; there’s no secret about that." Foreign observers have labeled the poll free and fair.

Both Federica Mogherini, the EU foreign affairs chief, and former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan have urged Mr. Odinga to seek legal recourse, but the opposition coalition claims this is not an option.
A report commissioned by Food Standards Scotland revealed that in-store promotions are skewed heavily towards foods high in salt or sugar.
Academics from Stirling University, who authored the report, have advocated for a "retail revolution" to facilitate healthier consumer choices.
Despite these findings, the Scottish Grocers' Federation criticized the report, claiming it overlooked ongoing efforts to promote healthy eating.
Food Standards Scotland (FSS) highlighted that Scottish obesity rates, now at 30%, could rise to 40% by 2030.
Professor Leigh Sparks, the report's author, discussed the issue on BBC Radio Scotland's Good Morning Scotland, citing an imbalance in the types of foods promoted in stores.
"In retail environments, most promotions favor products that are less healthy for consumers," he said, noting the prevalence of supersized items like large boxes and bags of crisps.
He suggested manufacturers should alter product compositions, while retailers need to offer better consumer information and adjust their promotional strategies.
"Retailers are increasingly aware of the issue and are exploring solutions," he added.
"However, voluntary schemes have yet to make a significant impact due to the dominance of unhealthy promotions." The report also supports the implementation of a sugar tax.

FSS senior dietary adviser Dr. Gillian Purdon emphasized the report aligns with FSS's views on extending the sugar tax beyond soft drinks, reformulating products to lower sugar, fat, and salt, resizing portions, addressing unhealthy food promotion, and improving product information in both retail and dining establishments.
"This report will aid in developing methods to enhance the offering and promotion of healthier food by the retail sector," she stated.
"To foster healthier eating, a combination of measures is required. Regulation of promotions on high-fat, salt, and sugar food and drink in both stores and dining venues should be prioritized."
Previous FSS research indicated that about 50% of purchases of less healthy foods are made during promotions, whereas the figure is roughly 30% for healthier options.
The report concluded, "The current setting for consumer choice in-store impacts the health and diet of Scottish consumers.
Voluntary or self-regulated efforts, or relying solely on consumers to make informed choices, are insufficient."
A video of Bailey Matthews, who abandoned his walking aid to cross the finish line, has received over 27 million views on Facebook.
Bailey, hailing from Doncaster, was honored with the Richard Whiteley Award during a ceremony in Leeds on Friday night.
Cricketer Joe Root was awarded the Sporting Achievement Award. Now in their 27th year, the Yorkshire Awards celebrate the diverse accomplishments of individuals and businesses in the county.
Bailey participated in a children's event at Castle Howard in North Yorkshire in July, where he swam 100 meters, cycled four kilometers, and ran 1.3 kilometers.
Despite stumbling twice near the finish line, he got back up and completed the last 20 meters without his walking frame.
Bailey's family expressed their pride, saying, "We are extremely honored to receive the Richard Whiteley Award for Bailey's efforts, and it is even more special as proud Northerners."
Sheffield-born Root rose to the top of the ICC world rankings as a batsman after aiding England in regaining the Ashes from Australia.
At 24, he has solidified his reputation as a key player for England, nearing 3,000 Test runs.

Calling the award a "real honor," Root thanked those who have supported him. TV chef Rosemary Shrager, a long-time resident of Yorkshire, won the Woman of the Year Award, while Rotherham-born William Hague was titled Man of the Year.
Former MP for Richmond, Hague stated, "Whatever I have done, and wherever I have been in the world, I have never stopped being a Yorkshireman, and never will."

Sir David Wootton received the Lifetime Achievement Award, and Huddersfield-born poet Simon Armitage won the Arts and Entertainment Award, adding to his accolades that include a BAFTA-winning film, Feltham Sings, for which he received an Ivor Novello Award.
The Business Enterprise Award went to Howarth Timber, a company that started as a one-man operation in Leeds in 1840 and now employs over 1,000 people.
North Yorkshire farmer Gareth Barlow received the Countryside Award, while junior football coach Stephen Shipley was honored with the Community Hero Award.

Sharad Bheswakar, a leading cricketer and sports icon in Nepal, faces an unusual dilemma: despite being born and raised in Nepal and playing for its national team, he is not officially recognized as a Nepali citizen.
His father is Indian and his mother is Nepali, which should legally entitle him to citizenship.
Nevertheless, his attempts to obtain Nepali citizenship have been unsuccessful. "I've been trying for almost eight to nine years to get my citizenship.
I'm still encountering problems. It's really frustrating at times," he explains.
In the past, he received a special travel document enabling him to participate in international matches.
According to the Nepali Citizenship Act of 2006, citizens can typically apply for citizenship at age 16, provided their mother or father can endorse the application.
However, cultural biases in Nepal often result in women facing significant hurdles when transferring citizenship to their children, especially if the father is absent or not a Nepali citizen.
Without citizenship documents, individuals are barred from obtaining a driver's license, opening a bank account, pursuing higher education, or conducting legal transactions.
The United Nations highlights the prevalence of this issue. Robert Piper, the UN Resident Humanitarian Coordinator, notes, "From our observations, this is a considerable problem.
The Election Commission's findings reveal that over 2 million people interviewed in villages—excluding urban areas—were unable to present citizenship documents."
Usha Kala Rai, a former member of the dissolved Constituent Assembly, emphasizes that Nepal's bureaucracy discriminates against women.

"Many women suffer from violence and discrimination, especially those who have traveled abroad for work, survivors of rape, abandoned individuals, and divorcees—all risk losing their identity," she says. Bhagwati Chettri, 55, is a Nepali who was deserted by her husband years ago.
Since she never acquired citizenship from her parents or husband, her two children, now reaching adulthood, lack legal identity.
"I've been trying for the last eight years to get a citizenship certificate," she laments.
Jeremy Corbyn is set to announce during his visit to Birmingham on Tuesday that a Labour government would increase Carer's Allowance by 17%, benefiting around one million people in its first year.
This proposal aims to raise the weekly allowance from £62.70 to £73.10. The government plans an additional £2 billion investment in social care over three years.

Currently, Carer's Allowance supports about 6.5 million UK residents who care for elderly, disabled, or seriously ill friends or relatives for a minimum of 35 hours weekly, earning no more than £116 after tax.
Mr. Corbyn views the increase as a means to assist carers, primarily women, who often resign from their jobs to care for elderly family members at home.
He told the BBC that while caring can be rewarding, it shouldn't lead to financial hardship or isolation.

In his upcoming speech, the Labour leader will blame "Britain's social care crisis" on Downing Street's £4.6 billion cut to council care budgets, resulting in unpaid carers shouldering more responsibility.
He will emphasize that the care provided by these carers saves taxpayers £132 billion annually, and that these often unrecognized heroes deserve not just praise, but essential financial support.
Labour believes that a £10 weekly boost to Carer's Allowance is both moral and economically sound.
Corbyn advocates funding this increase by reversing the Conservative cut on inheritance tax, which only benefits Britain's wealthiest.
He sees this move as a pivotal step toward modernizing the social care system and bolstering support for family carers.

Labour estimates adjusting Carer's Allowance will cost £538 million by 2020/21, funded by canceling the anticipated £650 million inheritance tax cut for estates up to £1 million passed between married couples without death duties.
The Conservatives, however, argue Labour’s promise to uplift the allowance is financially unfeasible.

Luke Hall, a Conservative member of the Commons work and pensions select committee, acknowledges the significant societal contributions made by carers and asserts the current government’s efforts, which have already increased Carer's Allowance by £450 annually since 2010.
Two years later, Jones has become a mother herself and says this experience has given her a deeper understanding of what Gemma Foster, a mother of one, went through.
“Being a wife and a mother made me grasp the seriousness of that family unit breaking apart because I'd go home at night and have a baby to put to bed,” she reflects.

“It made me understand what it means for two people who come together out of love, have a child, and then separate... how to parent in each other’s lives without causing more harm to the child despite the personal hurt.” Jones occasionally brought her son to the set, though he doesn’t appear in the show; she jokes he "looked much better than I did" on camera.
She now looks forward to spending more downtime with him. “Work-life balance is challenging for everyone, so I try to keep work separate,” she explains.
“I am very grateful because I've done a lot of work and now am taking a significant break.

I'm around until Christmas, just hanging out at the play park in my Converse.” The second series of the BBC One drama resumes with Gemma's estranged husband, Simon (played by Bertie Carvel), returning with his new family to the fictional town of Parminster, where she lives and works.
They deal with the harsh fallout of their divorce, with their son Tom caught in the crossfire.
Jones acknowledges that the show can be “uncomfortable” to watch at times but believes it has a “weird, sexy edge.” “We all know what it’s like to be in a room with an ex-partner,” she says.
“Everyone has had relationships and exes, and been in challenging situations. I’m sure Bertie and I have drawn on our own thoughts and feelings to portray these emotions.
However, the writing style and the show’s tone allow us to push the boundaries.

It’s fantastical yet deeply rooted in realism, showing how far you could go if truly pushed.” Carvel, known for his role as Miss Trunchbull in the West End's Matilda, found Mike Bartlett’s writing “exciting” and called the Doctor Foster storyline a “real page-turner.” “He creates incredibly three-dimensional characters,” the actor notes, adding that playing a character who evolves in the viewer’s eyes was “really fun.” “Often, you find yourself seeing things from a completely different perspective,” he remarks.
The Association of School and College Leaders (ASCL) will host seminars across major cities in England to address new legislation mandating schools and colleges to tackle radicalisation.
Kamal Hanif, head of Birmingham's Waverley School and an expert on Islam and citizenship, will lead these sessions.

The union states that the seminars are intended to support and guide senior school leaders in light of incidents like the case of three London schoolgirls who traveled to Syria in February and ended up in Raqqa, an Islamic State stronghold.
Their families later criticized authorities for not sharing crucial information that could have stopped the girls from leaving.
Under the Counter Terrorism and Security Act 2015, educational institutions are required to prevent youth from being drawn into terrorism.
Scheduled for June and July, these seminars will help school and college leaders fulfill these responsibilities by providing them with practical advice.
They aim to foster an environment of equality and diversity while educating teachers on the use of social media to indoctrinate young people into extremist ideologies.
Hanif notes that the seminars will enhance understanding of radicalisation and extremism.
He aims to help head teachers "identify situations" and address them properly without causing undue alarm.
Young people often spend a significant amount of time online, where they may encounter extremist ideas without opposing viewpoints.
These seminars will aid schools and parents, who often are unaware of their children's online activities, to recognize warning signs and appropriately address concerns.
They will equip school leaders with counter-narratives against extremist propaganda.
Hanif will be joined by Sara Khan, a counter-extremism campaigner and co-founder of the organization Inspire, as well as ASCL's parliamentary specialist, Anna Cole.
Khan states that the seminars will clarify what is expected from schools under the law, as many misconceptions exist about the statutory requirements for schools and students.

Cole emphasizes the importance of early intervention and risk assessments to prevent the criminalization of young people, advocating for an open culture where diverse views and ideas can be freely discussed.

Research conducted on mice and pigs indicates that a protein-infused patch promotes healthy cell growth and reduces scarring, which often follows a heart attack, impairing the heart's ability to pump effectively.
Reports in Nature suggest this patch could transform treatment methods. During a heart attack, blood flow cuts off, leading to muscle cell death.
Scientists propose that repairing or replacing some of these cells might mitigate long-term damage.

In this study, an international team treated animals with heart attacks by applying a collagen patch soaked in a protein called Fstl1, which naturally occurs in healthy hearts but depletes in a key heart layer post-attack.
Two weeks after application, the hearts developed new muscle cells and blood vessels, and showed improved pumping ability.

Prof Pilar Ruiz-Lozano from Stanford University, which holds the patent for the patch, noted: "Many were so sick prior to receiving the patch that they would've been candidates for heart transplantation.
The goal is for a similar strategy to eventually aid human heart attack patients with significant heart damage."

Prof Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic from Columbia University, commenting in Nature, mentioned this could lead to new heart infarction treatments but emphasized the necessity for further research to assess effectiveness in larger animals and humans.
The Renewable Heat Incentive scandal might have served as the catalyst, but it wasn't the true reason for the election.
"The real driver was Sinn Féin and republicanism's desire to revisit the election; they've effectively rallied their voters."
"We ran a positive campaign, and the public's response was encouraging. We'll be at Stormont on Monday with work to address. I've stated that when Sinn Féin succeeds, it benefits everyone."
"I suggested that in a normal society, people would vote based on performance, and felt neither the DUP nor Sinn Féin deserved another mandate.
I didn't receive a mandate strong enough to justify my continued position, so I'm stepping down."
"This is a triumph for those who chose devolution over direct rule, favoring power-sharing.
It's imperative for all parties to ensure power remains with our Assembly, not returned to Theresa May and James Brokenshire."
"It was a promising day for Alliance—our vote increased, even in areas where we've traditionally struggled.
This effort in building vote share is promising for re-establishing devolution."
"The concern now is the very existence of this place as a political entity, with middle ground and non-sectarian power-sharing rejected.
The DUP and Sinn Féin seem unwilling to share power." "There is a shared responsibility for everyone to engage intensively in the short time available to establish a strong and stable administration.
The UK government approaches the days ahead with positive intent." "Mike Nesbitt's resignation was appropriate, preventing unpleasant party discussions.
Future talks will primarily involve the DUP and Sinn Féin, with the SDLP and UUP participating peripherally."
"We're now faced with the two parties being neck-and-neck—a reality that requires attention to the concerns voiced during the election. Like all parties, there are lessons we must learn."
"The high voter turnout underscores the continued support from Northern Ireland's people for the Good Friday Agreement's institutions and its devolved power-sharing government."

The pledges are part of the party's five-year government plan, which promises increased free childcare and more apprenticeships, along with an M4 relief road and a South Wales Metro public transport network.
Plaid Cymru criticized the programme as "lacklustre," while the Conservatives accused Labour of failing Wales.
The most costly commitments include providing 30 hours of free childcare weekly over 48 weeks for parents of three and four-year-olds, and offering 100,000 apprenticeships to people of all ages.
The programme outlines the Welsh Government's objectives, with details of cuts expected when the draft budget is published in October.
A Welsh Government spokesperson mentioned a thorough review of spending due to financial uncertainties from Brexit, hinting at difficult decisions.
"Salami slicing won't suffice this time," he said, indicating that some projects and services would face cuts.
In response on BBC Radio Wales, the first minister acknowledged impending cuts, citing a shrinking budget necessitating hard choices.
He remarked that long-standing schemes may need reassessment. The "Taking Wales Forward" programme echoes many promises from Labour's Welsh Assembly election manifesto in May.
Mr. Jones emphasized Labour's commitment to fulfilling election promises, such as constructing an M4 relief road and developing a South Wales Metro.
He stated that Brexit poses uncertainties but Labour's focus is on enhancing the economy and public services, deemed essential to daily life.
On local government reform, Mr. Jones mentioned future wider service delivery, without confirming council mergers.
Plaid Cymru AM Rhun ap Iorwerth claimed the government's programme illustrates the "gulf" between the parties, despite pledges made in exchange for Carwyn Jones's re-election as first minister.
"A lacklustre manifesto has unsurprisingly led to a lacklustre government programme," Mr. ap Iorwerth noted.

The Football League plans to introduce an additional division comprised of 20 teams from the 2019-2020 season, resulting in a total of 100 teams across five divisions, an increase from the current 92.
Currently, 24 teams each play in the Championship, League One, and League Two. According to the Football League, this change aims to alleviate fixture congestion and enhance member finances.
The Premier League and the Football Association have expressed their support "in principle."
To move forward, 90% of the existing 72 Football League clubs must approve the proposal.

A decision is set for their annual general meeting in June 2017. Football League chief executive Shaun Harvey told BBC Sport that this initiative offers "clear benefits for everyone," signaling a potential catalyst for future changes in English football. Despite this, reactions among Football League clubs vary.
Accrington owner Andrew Holt dismissed the plan as having "no merit," while former Leyton Orient chairman Barry Hearn sees potential value.
Some club executives complained they were uninformed about the plan before Thursday's announcement.
Although some fear financial struggles, Harvey believes the proposal is beneficial; he notes that the Premier League and FA support it due to "potential benefits on an international basis."
He emphasized the need for collective solutions for the future of English football.
The FA acknowledged the need to review the fixture schedule for "the benefit of all," expressing interest in ongoing discussions.
Bradford City's joint-chairman Mark Lawn opposes changes to a structure he feels suits most clubs.
As his team competes in the League One play-offs, Lawn argues that reducing from 23 home games would lead to lost revenue.

Meanwhile, Mark Devlin, Brentford’s chief executive, praises the Football League for an "innovative and far-reaching approach," seeing the proposals as a promising method to address issues faced by Football League clubs.
Approval requires the support of 65 Football League clubs (90%) at next year's AGM.
The Football League board is not recommending any action but encourages members to thoroughly consider the proposal.
During her appearance at the Code Conference, Facebook's Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg announced the decision to retain Peter Thiel in his board position.
Thiel, who aims to confront Gawker's alleged "bullying" tactics, has been criticized for leveraging his wealth to purportedly suppress parts of the media.
This is potentially problematic for Facebook, as it seeks cooperation from media outlets to host articles on its platform, provide exclusive video content, and allow Facebook to sell advertising.
"Peter acted independently, not as a representative of Facebook," Sandberg clarified at the event in California.
She added, "Our board members are independent with distinct opinions shared publicly, which strengthens Facebook as they offer strong, diverse perspectives."
Despite this, some experts question the sustainability of Thiel's board role, considering he was one of Facebook's early investors.
"Facebook traditionally views itself as a tech company but now faces the responsibilities of being a publisher," media consultant Steve Hewlett explained to the BBC.
"If you consider Facebook a publisher, this is a clear conflict of interest. Imagine a billionaire on the board of The Times or the BBC suing others for their publications."
The conflict between Gawker and Thiel dates back to 2007, when Gawker published an article titled: "Peter Thiel is totally gay, people."
Recently, Thiel disclosed to the New York Times that he funded a legal team to support "victims" of Gawker's reporting in lawsuits against the company—actions he described as "philanthropic."
One such lawsuit resulted in Gawker being ordered to pay Hulk Hogan $140 million for invading his privacy by publishing a sex tape.

Gawker is appealing the verdict, which endangers its future. Nick Denton, Gawker's founder, has challenged Thiel's involvement and questioned his continuing role at Facebook, asking in an open letter: "As a board member of Facebook, have your personal views on politics and news influenced corporate decisions?"
Despite donating 64 million shares of Microsoft, equivalent to 5% of his wealth currently valued at $89.9 billion, he remains the world's richest person.
Since 1994, Mr. Gates, 61, and his wife Melinda have contributed a total of $35 billion in cash and stocks to various charitable causes.
Although the donation was made in June, it became public on Monday following a filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mr. Gates now owns just 1.3% of Microsoft. Previously, he donated $16 billion in shares in 1999 and $5.1 billion in 2000.

Most of their prior contributions have supported the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which focuses on reducing global poverty, combating infectious diseases, and providing widespread access to technology.
