While it is unclear who received this latest donation, federal filings often indicate a new contribution to a foundation, according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy.
In 2010, Mr. and Mrs. Gates, along with investor and philanthropist Warren Buffett, launched the Giving Pledge.
As of May 2017, 158 individuals or couples have committed to donating at least half of their wealth to charity.
This recent donation stands as the largest charitable gift of the year globally.
The second largest gift was from Mr. Buffett, who donated nearly $3.2 billion to the Gates Foundation last month.

The third largest came from Michael Dell, founder of Dell Computer Corporation, and his wife Susan, who donated over $1 billion in May to their foundation, which addresses children's issues and community projects.
The two countries were unable to sign an agreement on sharing river water due to objections from the chief minister of West Bengal, India.
Additionally, there was no arrangement for India to gain overland access through Bangladesh to its northeastern states.
However, there was positive news for tens of thousands of "stateless border people."

The countries agreed to initiate a deal where approximately 50 Bangladeshi enclaves within India would be integrated into Bangladesh, and around 100 Indian areas in Bangladesh would become part of India.

According to officials, residents of these areas will be allowed to choose whether they want to become Indian or Bangladeshi as part of a protocol between the leaders, with details to be finalized later.

BBC Bengali editor Sabir Mustafa points out that failing to reach an agreement on sharing Teesta river water is a significant setback for Bangladesh's PM Sheikh Hasina, who had invested her reputation in securing the deal.
Mustafa also notes that current relations between the two countries are the closest since the early 1970s when India aided Bangladesh’s independence from Pakistan.
However, this warmth is overshadowing a growing unease about the relationship's nature.
Concerns exist that India's leadership might be aligning too closely with Bangladesh's Awami League, led by PM Sheikh Hasina.
This could lead to strained relations if the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) gains power.
Additionally, there is concern in Bangladesh over Sheikh Hasina's perceived eagerness to fulfill Indian demands.

The visit's significance diminished when India indicated at the last moment that a major river-sharing agreement wouldn’t be reached, taking away some of the shine from the first visit by an Indian prime minister to Bangladesh in 12 years. Both sides agreed only to revisit this issue later.
Prime Minister Singh stated post-talks that "substantial progress has been made on sharing water of common rivers," though further discussion is needed.

It is largely believed that the deal failed due to last-minute objections from West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, who was concerned that India might be supplying an excessive amount of water to Bangladesh.
Kepler-452b orbits a star at a similar distance to Earth’s orbit, although its radius is 60% larger than Earth’s.
Mission scientists consider it the most Earth-like planet discovered so far, capturing astronomers’ interest due to its potential to host liquid water—a key requirement for life.
NASA's science chief, John Grunsfeld, referred to Kepler-452b as "Earth 2.0" and "the closest so far" to our planet.

Located about 1,400 light years away, this new finding was introduced by Jon Jenkins, Kepler data analysis lead at NASA's Ames Research Center in California, who likened it to "a new kid on the block."

This discovery joins other Earth-like exoplanets, such as Kepler-186f. While Kepler-186f, announced in 2014, is smaller and orbits a cooler red dwarf star, Kepler-452b circles a star similar to our Sun, being just 4% more massive and 10% brighter.
Its orbit lasts 385 days, making the year 5% longer than Earth's. Although Kepler-452b’s mass cannot be directly measured, models predict it could be about five times Earth’s mass.

If rocky, it might have active volcanism and gravity twice that of Earth. Part of a group of 500 potential planets identified by the Kepler telescope, Kepler-452b is the first among them confirmed as a planet.
Twelve of these candidates are less than twice Earth's diameter and are in the habitable zone, where liquid water might exist given suitable conditions.
Dr. Suzanne Aigrain from the University of Oxford, who did not participate in the study, expressed that Kepler-452b’s properties are the most Earth-like she has seen confirmed to date.
She emphasized the significance of finding 12 planets within the habitable zone, having radii below twice that of Earth, highlighting the expansion of the Kepler planet catalogue.
An Inverness resident has alleged that his former employer is deliberately ignoring his correspondence.
James Nicol claims he was exposed to asbestos while working on council houses in the 1980s and seeks acknowledgment from Highland Council for his exposure.
However, the local authority stated that they cannot comment on Mr. Nicol's situation, pointing out that any claims would be managed by solicitors.
Now 85, Mr. Nicol was employed as a laborer by Highland Regional Council, which is now Highland Council, and believes he encountered asbestos while refurbishing council properties in Inverness.
Later, he also worked as a school janitor for the regional council. In March of this year, he was diagnosed with mesothelioma, a terminal lung cancer almost always caused by asbestos exposure.
He noticed his health was declining during a swimming session and subsequently saw his doctor.
"I could swim, but not at the same speed, which led me to visit my GP," Mr. Nicol explained to BBC Scotland.
"After seeing my GP, I underwent x-rays, scans, and a biopsy in Aberdeen." The diagnosis was confirmed at his local hospital, Raigmore in Inverness, where he was told, "it was all bad, no cure Mr.
Nicol." Although he still receives a local authority pension, Mr. Nicol claims Highland Council has ignored correspondence from his solicitor regarding his condition.

A Highland Council spokesperson clarified: "We cannot comment on this matter. When solicitors are appointed to make claims against Highland Council, communications occur through the solicitor, not directly with the claimant."
Clydeside Action on Asbestos, a charity founded in 1984 initially to support shipyard workers, is now aiding people from various employment fields, including more women.
Senior welfare rights officer and director Phyllis Craig noted, "We're seeing many from construction, as well as teachers, nurses, doctors, policemen, and firemen."

She highlighted the misconception that women were only exposed to asbestos through washing their husbands' overalls, asserting that women in buildings like hospitals and schools were equally at risk as their male counterparts.
Recent law changes in Scotland provide sufferers and their families with more rights than elsewhere in the UK.
Some, like former textile factory worker Annie McGhee from Motherwell, may qualify for a government one-off payment.
In Northern Ireland, it's just another Tuesday as political issues dominate the headlines again today.
Despite the deadline supposed to end yesterday at 4 PM, the political impasse continues.
The Belfast Telegraph expresses its frustration over the stalemate among the MLAs, suggesting they should have their salaries halted after three months if no agreement is reached.
It highlights the cost of their salaries to taxpayers, £13.5 million annually, equating to the disastrous Renewable Heating Incentive scheme that crippled the power-sharing executive.
Former Assistant Chief Constable Alan McQuillan warns of public outrage if MLAs continue to receive their paychecks without a functioning executive.

He emphasizes the threat to jobs and public services due to the political void, stating that full pay for non-functioning MLAs would provoke anger among people affected by the failure to reach a deal.
Political commentator Malachi O'Doherty comments on the challenging position of Secretary of State James Brokenshire, who must determine Northern Ireland's path forward amid the stalemate.

He cautions that a wrong move by Brokenshire could further divide the region. The Belfast Telegraph also reports on the anxious wait faced by the family of a missing Londonderry man, wondering if the body found in the River Foyle on Monday is that of the 23-year-old Jack Glenn, who disappeared after a night out on February 2.

Meanwhile, the News Letter's front-page editorial, 'Morning View,' condemns Sinn Féin for holding Northern Ireland "to ransom," questioning when London will ignore Dublin's pressure and acknowledge that a party with 72% of voters against it should not dictate the Province's future due to indifference toward its failure.
It argues that while London fears a resurgence of violence, it must stop acting timidly from such concerns.

It concludes by assuring readers that its stance is not sectarian, pointing to its independent critique of the RHI scandal, while acknowledging that Northern Ireland is now facing another governance crisis.
Matthew Daley, 35, denies murder but acknowledges attacking Donald Lock, 79, in Findon near Worthing last July, claiming diminished responsibility.
At Lewes Crown Court, it was revealed that, contrary to previous beliefs of Asperger's syndrome, Daley had long undiagnosed paranoid schizophrenia.

Forensic psychiatrist Dr. Roderick Ley assessed him after the incident. Mr. Lock, a retired solicitor, was stabbed after his car collided at approximately 16 mph with the rear of Daley's vehicle on the A24 in West Sussex on July 16.
Daley had made an emergency stop, forcing Lock to brake suddenly. The great-grandfather, who had recently been declared free of prostate cancer, died at the scene.

During the trial, it was disclosed that Daley, previously residing on St Elmo Road in Worthing, had suffered from mental health issues for a decade, with his family repeatedly urging experts to commit him for treatment. Dr. Ley informed jurors, "The diagnosis of Asperger's was incorrect.
He has a long-standing paranoid schizophrenic illness that went undiagnosed for years."
Dr. Ley noted that Daley wasn't constantly psychotic and tended to "downplay" his symptoms.
He also displayed "narcissistic," "histrionic," and "self-centered" traits, making full recovery unlikely.
Another specialist, Dr. Philip Joseph, a consultant forensic psychiatrist, concluded that Daley was not psychotic at the time of the stabbing based on all the evidence.
Jurors also heard from John Daley, Matthew's father, who described his son as a "nice guy" fond of his family and animals and someone "scrupulously honest," struggling to lie.
Concern about his son's mental health arose after Matthew began hearing voices, prompting John to start a journal to document his son's treatment and concerns for his future.
"I didn't want to look back in my 80s wondering, 'What did I do?'" John stated. The trial continues.
The 23-year-old goalkeeper, currently on loan from Chelsea, made crucial saves in a penalty shootout when the Chairboys ousted Blackpool from the EFL Trophy back in January.
In this match, with only four minutes remaining, Blackman once again proved his skill by saving Brad Potts' penalty, ensuring a draw.
Early on, after 10 minutes, Adebayo Akinfenwa had the first chance but shot wide.
Midway through the first half, Potts attempted a speculative shot that clipped the crossbar.
Just before half-time, Paris Cowan-Hall's low drive was met by a smart save from Blackpool's goalkeeper, Dean Lyness.
Following the break, another effort by Potts was sensationally cleared from the goal-line by Blackman, despite Blackpool's claims that the ball had crossed the line.
Blackman's standout performance reached its peak in the final moments as he magnificently saved Potts’ close-range attempt.
Match summary: Wycombe Wanderers 0, Blackpool 0, full time. In the second half, Luke O'Nien (Wycombe) won a free kick in the defensive end after being fouled by Neil Danns (Blackpool).
Another foul by Michael Harriman (Wycombe) granted Neil Danns (Blackpool) a free kick on the right wing.
Wycombe substituted Sam Saunders for Sam Wood. Following a foul by Jack Payne (Blackpool), Joe Jacobson (Wycombe) gained a free kick.
Blackpool won a penalty after Max Müller (Wycombe) committed a foul; Potts’ right-footed shot was saved in the bottom right corner.
Jamille Matt drew a foul in Wycombe's penalty area. Myles Weston's header came close but missed left.
Wycombe substituted Alex Jakubiak for Paris Cowan-Hall. Cowan-Hall won a defensive free kick after Tom Aldred (Blackpool) committed a foul. Luke O'Nien received a yellow card for a bad foul.
Will Aimson (Blackpool) earned a defensive free kick. Blackpool substituted Neil Danns for Jordan Flores and Jamille Matt for Mark Cullen.
Jack Payne missed with a right-footed shot outside the box. Cowan-Hall earned another free kick from Kelvin Mellor's foul.
Nathan Delfouneso’s right-footed shot was blocked from the center. Wycombe brought on Myles Weston for Dayle Southwell.
Yellow cards were issued to both Jordan Flores (Blackpool) and Marcus Bean (Wycombe).
Following the arrest of a former ombudsman investigator over the alleged theft of sensitive security documents, concerns have been raised.
These documents reportedly contain information that police and MI5 believe could endanger lives.
The Police Federation of Northern Ireland (PFNI) described the situation as "astounding and very worrying."
On Sunday, detectives from the PSNI's Serious Crime Branch arrested a 69-year-old man in Dartford, Kent, after conducting a joint search with local police.
It is understood that he retired from the ombudsman's office years ago and the documents do not pertain to any current investigations.

Mark Lindsay, PFNI chair, stressed the need for fairness in investigations involving police officers, stating, "Police officers require the same protections as any member of society, which are currently lacking within the ombudsman's office," during an interview on BBC's Good Morning Ulster program.
He added that while the Police Ombudsman’s office plays a crucial role, it must maintain the confidence of police officers.
The police have launched a criminal investigation and suspended the release of further sensitive materials to the ombudsman’s office pending a review of security protocols.
Ulster Unionist MP Tom Elliott insisted that the ombudsman's office faces serious questions.
He argued, "When there is alleged wrongdoing, PSNI should be involved earlier to ensure independent investigations," as he spoke to the BBC, noting a gap that needs addressing.
A spokesman for the ombudsman informed the BBC that police had alerted him last week about the theft of sensitive material from the office.
The Police Ombudsman’s office stated the suspension of material sharing is expected to be temporary.

In the 2013/14 academic year, 99,293 students attended further education (FE) colleges, but by 2015/16, this number had decreased to 82,818, according to data from the Department for the Economy (DfE).
Over the same period, enrolments at FE colleges dropped by 15%, as some students can register for multiple courses.
The DfE reported 180,825 enrolments in 2013/14, declining to 153,817 by 2015/16.
Particularly affected was Belfast Metropolitan College (BMC), which saw its enrolments plummet from 36,685 in 2014/15 to 28,514 in 2015/16—a decline of 22.3%.

BMC provided no comment on this reduction. NUS-USI President Fergal McFerran voiced his concern over the "staggering drop" and urged the executive to significantly increase funding for tertiary education and student financial support in the upcoming budget.
South Eastern Regional College experienced the smallest decline, with enrolments decreasing by 8.3% from 35,832 in 2013/14 to 32,858 in 2015/16.
FE colleges offer various courses for diverse learners, but sources within the FE sector told the BBC that enrolment declines may be due to budget constraints, leading to course and staff cutbacks.
In 2015/16, over 400 staff were offered voluntary redundancy. Additionally, leisure and non-regulated courses were reduced, affecting enrolments from lifelong learners.

DfE figures show a notable drop in non-regulated course enrolments from 39,000 in 2013/14 to about 24,500 in 2015/16, a consequence of DfE's "Further Education Means Business" strategy, aimed at prioritizing economically focused courses.
Gerry Campbell, chief executive of Colleges NI, emphasized that further education is crucial for Northern Ireland’s economic future.
Despite the decline in residential and leisure courses, he noted increased efforts by colleges to offer more economically relevant courses.
The Department of the Economy confirmed a £10 million reduction in the FE colleges budget for 2015/16.
Fans finally received the happy ending they'd been anticipating, as Miranda Hart's title character tied the knot.
The New Year's Day episode attracted 7.3 million viewers according to overnight figures, while the first segment of the finale on Christmas Day had 6.7 million viewers.
Neela Debnath of The Independent described the conclusion as "sweet and heart-warming," noting its surprisingly touching and tender moments, despite some pratfalls.
The finale focused on Miranda confronting her mother and embracing her true self.

Gerard O'Donovan from The Telegraph remarked: "New Year's Day delivered all the humor and joy we could have wanted in a masterclass of romantic comedy writing and performance, culminating in a wedding."
Mark Lawson in The Guardian pointed out: "As fans wished, Miranda had two classic falls in her comedic farewell.
Her promising career, beyond this inventive and well-acted sitcom, hints that critics won't see her metaphorically fail."
Ahead of the final episode, Hart tweeted: "Happy New Year Day and farewell to my creative baby day.

8pm BBC One. No guarantees, but you MIGHT spot @GaryBarlow." The show, originally on BBC Two in 2009 before moving to BBC One, centers on Hart’s character, a shop owner who often makes social blunders.
Patricia Hodge plays her mother and Sarah Hadland portrays the assistant manager.
The series and its star have garnered awards from the Royal Television Society and the British Comedy Awards.
The third series' first episode was the most-watched TV program during Christmas 2012.
The 41-year-old actress will soon star alongside Jude Law and Melissa McCarthy in the American comedy "Spy," directed by Paul Feig of "Bridesmaids," set for a UK release in May.
Additionally, Hart will publish "Peggy And Me," an autobiographical book about her life with her dog Peggy, later this year.
WBC cruiserweight champion Tony Bellew, 34, achieved an unexpected victory by stopping David Haye in a heavyweight fight last month.
However, when questioned about the possibility of facing WBA and IBF champion Anthony Joshua, Bellew responded, "Absolutely not.
I don't need that kind of fight. He's far too good for me." His promoter, Eddie Hearn, suggested Bellew might next face WBO champion Joseph Parker.
Parker, 25, from New Zealand, is set to defend his title against Romanian Razvan Cojanu in Auckland next weekend.
Reflecting on Joshua's 11th-round victory over Wladimir Klitschko, Bellew expressed, "I still dream about winning a heavyweight world title, but a different one than AJ has."
The Liverpudlian fighter is considering retirement following his surprising win over Haye last month in his heavyweight debut.
However, regarding the possibility of fighting Parker, Bellew commented, "I trust Eddie knows what he's doing."
Hearn confirmed that a Bellew-Joshua matchup isn’t planned, stating on BBC Radio 5 live's Sportsweek, "Tony and Joshua are good friends."
Bellew, formerly cruiserweight, isn't a natural heavyweight, having stepped into that class to fight David Haye in March.
He weighed in at 96.6 kg for the fight against Haye, while Joshua was at a career-high 113 kg against Klitschko on Saturday—a difference of nearly 20 kg.
Also in Bellew’s future considerations is WBC heavyweight champion Deontay Wilder, who seeks a unification bout with Joshua, should he capture the WBO belt from Parker.
"I plan to secure the WBO belt, and after dealing with any mandatory challengers, aim for a major fight early in 2018," said Wilder.
After sharing his story with the BBC, Jahangir, a father from Afghanistan, received a call from President Ashraf Ghani, who promised that arrests would be made.
Eight years ago, Jahangir's wife was reportedly raped in Badakhshan province. Jahangir claims he has struggled to have the accused arrested due to their political influence.
His wife recounted the ordeal to BBC Persian: "I begged them, ‘For God's sake, I just gave birth; I'm like your child, even your daughter is older than me,’" she said.
"They beat me terribly, and I still had their bite marks on my body years later."
Analysis by Inayatulhaq Yasini, BBC Pashto: Jahangir and his wife's decision to speak out challenges a taboo in Afghanistan, where victims of sexual crimes often remain silent.
Following media coverage, President Ghani assured Jahangir that the case would be properly investigated and justice served.
The victim told the BBC, "I want justice to protect other women from such a fate."
The increased publicity pressures the Afghan government to address the incident and find a resolution.
There is hope that Jahangir and his wife's courage will inspire other victims to come forward and influence how such cases are handled.
Jahangir, a policeman, told the BBC that eight men were initially arrested, but six have since been released due to their political ties.
He says his family fled to Kabul for safety and has threatened suicide if the situation doesn’t change: "If they are not put on trial, I'll have to end my life to escape this torment."
Jahangir made this threat publicly on Afghan TV and later met with the interior ministry to advocate for his case.
During an interview with the BBC, he received another call from President Ghani and started crying.
Sworn in as president in September, Mr. Ghani pledged to prioritize addressing corruption.
While political corruption and violence against women are prevalent, they rarely attract substantial attention.
A notable exception was the national outrage in October when five men convicted of gang-raping four women were executed.
Sterling initially regained some of its losses, yet many believe the currency would drop if Britain decided to leave the EU.
Analysts predict a sharp decline in sterling's value should a Brexit vote occur.
This concern stems from the belief held by many—though not all—economists that exiting the EU would harm the UK's economic performance. EU membership impacts trade and the UK economy significantly.
During the negotiation of new arrangements, there would be uncertainty about British exporters' access to the EU market, possibly making it more difficult to sell to this market.

Additionally, foreign investment may suffer due to this uncertainty, worsening the situation as the UK faces a large current account deficit, which encompasses trade in goods and services along with some international financial transactions.

This deficit requires financing through loans and foreign investment in financial assets, and apprehensions about economic prospects might lead foreign investors to demand lower sterling prices to finance the deficit.
There is an alternative view, notably from Economists for Brexit, that the UK would thrive outside the EU.
However, in the short term, the prevailing view affecting markets, especially sterling, is likely the majority opinion.
Our currency market reports typically emphasize spot rates, immediate exchange rates for currency purchases.
Investors can also buy options—rights to buy or sell currency (or other financial assets) in the future at a predetermined price.
Options provide insurance against exchange rate fluctuations. If the expected change doesn't occur, the option isn't exercised, providing insurance at a cost.
This segment of the market indicates that investors anticipate a leave vote would weaken sterling.
David Cameron expressed that a stadium would "inspire young people and bring jobs and wealth" to the county.

Labour criticized the idea as a "cynical" tactic to divert voters, while the Liberal Democrats raised concerns about funding sources, and Mebyon Kernow expressed skepticism about the Conservatives' promise.

Disputes over planning have cast doubt on the stadium's future. In March, Cornwall council members postponed a decision on approving the construction of a supermarket intended to finance the stadium, jeopardizing the plans according to supporters.
Revised proposals for the stadium at West Langarth are slated for submission to the council in May.
Cameron mentioned intentions to have the Department of Culture, Media and Sport collaborate with Sport England, Cornwall Council, and local sports teams to facilitate its construction.
"The stadium proposal is exciting. If extra funding is needed, I will make that money available," he asserted.
However, Stuart Roden, Labour candidate for Truro and Falmouth, described Cameron's announcement as "a cynical empty promise that will lead nowhere.
It is merely smoke and mirrors, and voters won't be fooled by this unfunded diversion."
Simon Rix, the Lib Dem candidate in the constituency, commented to BBC News: "I'm hugely supportive of a stadium in the right place if funding can be secured.
But, like Conservative promises regarding the NHS, they aren't clarifying where the funding will come from."
Stephen Richardson, Mebyon Kernow candidate for Truro and Falmouth, expressed doubt, saying: "Forgive me if I don't believe a word of any David Cameron promise during the election campaign."

Neil Trotter confessed to secretly photographing women at Edinburgh's Waverley Station and Glasgow's Buchanan Galleries from June to September 2014.
The 54-year-old from Falkirk was warned by a sheriff that "women should be able to walk without fear" in public spaces.
In addition to this, Trotter was placed on the sex offenders register for 10 years.
A previous hearing at Edinburgh Sheriff Court revealed that Trotter commuted into Edinburgh daily by train for work.

On Monday, September 29, a fellow passenger noticed him behaving in "a curious, a sinister manner" at Waverley Station, deliberately trying to get very close to a woman in front of him on the escalator.
Prosecutor Aidan Higgins explained that Trotter was clearly using his phone to secretly take photos up the woman's skirt.
The commuter reported his suspicions to British Transport Police, who identified Trotter from CCTV footage.

He was arrested the following day as he left the station. Examination of Trotter's phone and computer showed he had used his mobile on various occasions between June 11 and September 29, with 22 videos capturing images under women's skirts.
Defense solicitor Neil Hay stated that Trotter felt "most ashamed of his actions" and fully understood his behavior was unacceptable.
Hay also mentioned that Trotter had "lost his career, nearly bankrupted his family, and brought shame upon himself and those close to him."
Sheriff Peter Braid sentenced Trotter to 18 months in prison, telling him, "You've pleaded guilty to taking images of women clandestinely driven by voyeuristic impulses for sexual gratification.
That this went on for more than three months, in public places where women should feel safe, required significant planning.
The societal outrage at such offenses warrants no alternative but a custodial sentence as punishment and deterrence."

Media playback is not supported on this device. Mark Cavendish, who has claimed 30 stage victories in the Tour de France, started his competition by finishing sixth in the scratch race, the first of six events.
He secured the second-fastest time in the individual pursuit and placed seventh in the elimination race, with three events remaining on Monday.
Becky James shattered the women's sprint Olympic record during the qualification round and is set for Monday's quarter-finals, alongside fellow Briton Katy Marchant.
At 31, Cavendish kicked off his campaign with a challenging sixth-place finish in the scratch race.
Denmark’s Lasse Norman Hansen, the London 2012 Olympic champion, and Roger Kluge secured the top two spots by gaining a lap advantage over the field.
During the individual pursuit, Cavendish posted a time of 4:16.878, overtaking reigning world champion Colombian Fernando Gaviria Rendon temporarily.
However, Hansen set an astonishing new Olympic record with a time of 4:14.982, surpassing Sir Bradley Wiggins' 2008 record.
Despite Hansen winning back-to-back events, he fell to sixth overall after being the first rider eliminated in the elimination race, where the last rider every second lap exits the race.
Cavendish looked steady as others were eliminated but was disqualified for overtaking outside the track lane, placing seventh.
France's Thomas Boudat, the 2014 world champion, leads with 106 points, just two points ahead of Italy’s Elia Viviani, winner of the elimination race.
Cavendish holds third with 96 points. Monday’s fourth event, the time trial, starts at 14:21 BST, followed by the flying lap and points race events.
Wales’ Becky James, who garnered a silver in Saturday's keirin, continued her impressive performance by setting a new Olympic record during the sprint qualification.
Her time of 10.721 seconds surpassed Victoria Pendleton’s 2012 London record of 10.724, marking her as the fastest qualifier.
She easily defeated Azerbaijan's Olga Ismayilova by 0.165 seconds to advance to Monday's quarter-finals, starting at 14:00 BST.
Marchant also progressed by defeating Canada’s Monique Sullivan after posting the second-fastest qualifying time.
Australia’s defending champion, Anna Meares, was beaten by Lithuania’s Simona Krupeckaite but secured a place in the last eight via a repechage race.

At the heart of the media's frustration lies the tightly controlled nature of modern political campaigns, dominated by carefully staged photo opportunities from all major parties.

This election season could be dubbed the "hi-vis, hard hat campaign," particularly for figures like David Cameron and George Osborne, who have avoided spontaneous interactions with the public to prevent unexpected challenges from voters.
Yet, there is an intriguing aspect of this election that offers a glimpse of authentic, unfiltered politics: the election hustings.

These events have been a notable success this general election season. The origin of the term 'hustings' piques curiosity, and according to research by a Christian charity, a record number of these events have been hosted in churches.
Having attended several hustings, I can attest that their effectiveness stems from the direct and often personal nature of the debates.
Voters actively engage politicians, cutting through campaign sound bites to address overlooked issues.

This dynamic was evident at a hustings at the All Nations for Christ Church in the Normanton area of the Derby South constituency, where the audience largely consisted of African Caribbean community members.
Politicians from all parties, including Dame Margaret Beckett, present to defend her 6,000-vote Labour majority, fielded questions on immigration, Europe, and education.
One question, however, resonated deeply: Why are African Caribbean graduates three times more likely to be unemployed six months post-graduation?

Research by the Bow Group think-tank and Elevation Networks, a youth employment charity, involving 2,500 students over two years, revealed the disparity in opportunities offered to black students versus their white counterparts.
An outraged audience member declared, "That's outrageous and disgraceful," drawing support from the Green Party.
Green candidate John Devine, seeking election in Derbyshire's Amber Valley, responded, "That indicates some form of discrimination in the job market."
There was a call for employers to be legally required to audit their hiring practices.

This complex issue required a nuanced response, yet Evonne Williams, the Conservative candidate for Derby South, carefully avoided commitment, saying, "It's something we haven't considered, but I'm happy to take it back to the party."
As for Labour's Dame Margaret, she promised to review the Equalities Act to determine if it requires modernization and updates.
Jamie Robinson, a medical researcher, shared with the BBC's World Have Your Say programme that train staff abandoned passengers by locking themselves in a service room.
His account matches that of French actor Jean-Hugues Anglade, who recounted being trapped against a metal door and receiving no help despite passengers' urgent pleas.
The incident took place on a high-speed train from Amsterdam to Paris on a Friday.

Mr. Robinson noticed trouble right after the Thalys train passed through Brussels, observing three train staff members hurrying through his coach, carriage 11, adjacent to carriage 12, where the gunman appeared.
"They said nothing. A man was followed by two women," he recalls. "They seemed frightened, did not alert us, ran to the end of my carriage, opened a service door, and locked it behind them."
Carriage 11 was at the front of the train, and the locked door led to an area off-limits to passengers.
Soon, people began fleeing from carriage 12, some wounded, others reporting a gunman shooting at people.
"We were trapped, about 20 to 30 of us, including Jean-Hugues Anglade and his family.

We were in the dark," Robinson recounts. Anglade, who hurt his hand trying to activate the train's alarm, also spoke of staff securing themselves in a private cabin, noting they could have guided passengers to a safer luggage area.
He told Paris Match (in French), "We shouted for the staff to let us in, we yelled 'open!'
but there was no answer." Agnes Ogier, the CEO of Thalys, announced an internal investigation, stating the staff would need to "explain their actions during this dramatic event."
Robinson remembers after 10 tense minutes, a man entered their carriage, informing them a gunman had been subdued, bringing relief.
This man was later identified as Anthony Sadler, one of the Americans who helped overpower the attacker.
Robinson describes the "explosive relief" that followed as passengers were in shock.
The passengers remained silent and motionless until they arrived at Arras station, where the suspect, Ayoub El-Khazzani, a 25-year-old Moroccan, was detained.
Calls have emerged for Douglas Ross to resign from his role as the party's justice spokesman due to his absence from a justice committee meeting in the Scottish Parliament.
He was officiating a football match between Sporting Lisbon and Real Madrid as an assistant referee on Tuesday.
Mr. Ross earns up to £40,000 a year as a self-employed specialist assistant football referee, based on his register of interests in the Scottish Parliament.
Additionally, he serves as a councillor for Moray Council, but his trip to Portugal caused him to miss its policy and resources committee meeting the same day.
SNP MSP Ben Macpherson pointed out that this isn't the first instance where Mr. Ross's refereeing has interfered with his parliamentary duties.
Reports indicate he missed an important vote while in Switzerland for World Cup referee training.
Macpherson criticized, "The arrogance and blatant disregard of 'three jobs' Tory Douglas Ross is astounding.
Previously, when he skipped responsibilities for refereeing commitments, it was dismissed as a 'one-off' by the Tories.
Now it merits a straight red card. He clearly values his £40k-a-year weekend job and trips to European cities more than his legislative and council duties, showing contempt for his constituents.
If Douglas Ross can't commit to his roles, he should either step back from refereeing or immediately resign from Holyrood's justice committee.

Ruth Davidson should remove him from the frontbench team." A spokesperson for the Scottish Conservatives stated, "Earlier this year, Ben Macpherson invited Douglas to discuss refereeing with clubs in his constituency—presumably, that invitation has been withdrawn." Mr. Ross did not provide a comment.
Mr. Abe described his 90-minute meeting at Trump Tower in New York as "candid" and held in a "warm atmosphere."
During his campaign, some of Mr. Trump's remarks raised questions about established US alliances, including with Japan.
This meeting marked Mr. Trump's first in-person encounter with a world leader following his election win.
The US and Japan have been crucial allies since World War II, with the US aiding Japan's economic recovery.
The president-elect has pledged to abandon the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, which Mr. Abe supports to counter China's growing economic influence.
Despite its likely cancellation upon Mr. Trump's assumption of office, the deal was approved by the Japanese parliament.

Mr. Trump has also suggested Japan should pay more for the US military presence on its territory and proposed that Japan and South Korea develop their own nuclear weapons to counter North Korea's missile threat.
The meeting was reportedly arranged when Mr. Abe phoned the president-elect to offer congratulations, noting his upcoming travel through New York en route to an Asia-Pacific trade summit in Peru.
After the meeting, Mr. Abe commented, "We had a very candid discussion over a significant period and in a very warm atmosphere.
I believe that without mutual confidence, the alliance cannot function in the future.
Following today's discussion, I'm convinced Mr. Trump is a leader in whom I can place great trust."
Though Mr. Abe shared limited details, he mentioned their agreement to meet again for broader discussions on various issues.

Additionally, Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner, now key advisers, also met with Mr. Abe at Trump Tower. There is media speculation about Ivanka possibly becoming ambassador to Japan.
Since the election, Mr. Trump has been engaging with numerous world leaders and potential cabinet members from his offices in Manhattan.
Meanwhile, Vice President-elect and transition leader Mike Pence has expressed optimism about working with Democrats.
Following meetings with Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer and House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, Mr. Pence stated his eagerness to find common ground for moving the country forward.
Concurrently, President Barack Obama urged his successor to resist Russia if it diverges from US "values and international norms."
Ponds on the surface of the Khumbu Glacier in the Himalayas have expanded and merged into larger bodies of water.
Climbers must cross this glacier, including the perilous Khumbu Icefall, to ascend the formidable peak.
The rapid melting of glaciers in the region raises concerns amid rising global temperatures.
Scientists warn that this is a novel situation for Khumbu, though other Himalayan glaciers have also seen an increase in newly formed lakes.
These glacial lakes pose a risk, as they can overflow, causing downstream flooding, loss of life, and damage.
This is the first scientific expedition to the region following the devastating earthquake last April.

"About a decade ago, there were isolated ponds on the Khumbu Glacier, but over the past five years, they have begun to enlarge and connect," said Ann Rowan, who led the field survey from the universities of Sheffield and Leeds.
Dr. Rowan’s team focuses on studying debris-covered glaciers, particularly Khumbu.
"Notably, on the left side of the glacier's lower section, there are about seven or eight large ponds now beginning to link and form a chain," she shared with the BBC.
"Water from the glacier's upper part flows through these ponds, encouraging them to connect.
Presently, the glacier seems to be disintegrating and might develop a few large, potentially hazardous lakes on its surface."
Dr. Rowan’s team reviewed 15 years of satellite images of Khumbu and conducted three ground surveys since 2009.
They found that parts of the lower debris-covered region are shrinking due to ice loss underneath, facilitating water bodies' formation and expansion.
Their study shows that over the past 15 years, the glacier's surface has declined at about two meters per year.
Unlike the typically smooth glaciers elsewhere, many in the Himalayas are covered in debris—sand, gravel, and rock.
Scientists note that rising temperatures are causing ice loss in the upper parts of many Himalayan glaciers, reducing ice flow to their lower parts and leading to shrinkage.
A Kamo Hovhannisyan own goal set Albania on the path to victory, with Ledian Memushaj scoring the second goal from a free-kick and Armando Sadiku adding a third with a tap-in.
This win allows Albania to move past Denmark into second place in Group I. Portugal, already secure as group winners, defeated Serbia 2-1, despite Serbia having two players sent off.
Manchester City's Aleksandar Kolarov received two yellow cards, and Chelsea's Nemanja Matic was shown a straight red for a violent action against Portugal's Andre Andre.
With Portugal having already clinched the top spot in Group I, they rested captain Cristiano Ronaldo for their match in Serbia.
Ronaldo's former Manchester United teammate, Luis Nani, put Portugal ahead early with a left-footed goal.

Serbia's Zoran Tosic later equalized with a strong strike in the second half. Joao Moutinho, coming off the bench, secured the win for Portugal with a shot from the edge of the box 12 minutes before full-time.
Albania's win means Denmark finishes third and faces a play-off to qualify for France next summer.
The match concludes with Armenia 0, Albania 3. In the second half, Armenia's Aras Özbiliz won a free kick on the right wing after a foul by Burim Kukeli.
Varazdat Haroyan committed a foul, giving Armando Sadiku a free kick. After a delay due to Odise Roshi's injury, play continued.
Shkelzen Gashi’s right-footed shot was saved, while Aras Özbiliz's attempt from a free kick was off target.
Albania made a substitution with Amir Abrashi replacing Migjen Basha. Karlen Mkrtchyan won a free kick for Armenia following a foul by Sadiku.
Armenia's Varazdat Haroyan tried a through ball to Vardan Pogosyan, who was caught offside.
Gael Andonian was booked for a bad foul, while Migjen Basha received a yellow card for a foul against Gevorg Ghazaryan.
Artur Sarkisov won a free kick on the right wing after Taulant Xhaka's foul. Goal!
At Sheffield Crown Court, a woman recounted being just 12 years old when Basharat Hussain and two other men picked her up from a children's home and abused her.
She also described being taken to Blackpool, where several men raped her. Mr. Hussain, who denies these allegations, is among seven individuals on trial for suspected child abuse in Rotherham.
Due to the sensitive nature of the case, the witness's identity remains confidential.
She testified that the initial abuse occurred after Mr. Hussain and several other Asian men took her and a friend out for a meal.
"I felt very grown-up," she said. "They treated us to dinner, and I didn't feel I could refuse."
She further disclosed that at age 16, she was taken to Blackpool to work in a restaurant, a move that prosecutors allege was orchestrated by Mr. Hussain.
She claimed she was kept there for months and forced to have sex almost daily, later returning to Rotherham with several sexually transmitted infections.
Arshid Hussain, 40, of High Street, East Cowick, Goole, faces 30 charges, including five counts of rape.
Qurban Ali, 53, of Clough Road, Rotherham, faces four charges, including rape and conspiracy to rape.
Majid Bostan, 37, of Ledsham Road, Rotherham, is charged with indecent assault.
Sajid Bostan, 38, of Broom Avenue, Rotherham, faces seven charges, including four counts of rape.
Basharat Hussain, 39, with no fixed address, faces 15 charges, including two counts of rape.
Karen MacGregor, 58, of Barnsley Road, Wath, South Yorkshire, faces four charges, including conspiracy to rape.
Shelley Davies, 40, of Wainwright Road, Kimberworth Park, Rotherham, faces three charges, including conspiracy to rape.
During cross-examination, Gillian Batts, defending Mr. Hussain, asked the witness, "The truth is you've never met Basharat Hussain, have you?" To which the witness replied, "Yes, I have."

It is alleged that Mr. Hussain was part of a group of seven people involved in the sexual exploitation of children between 1987 and 2003, reportedly targeting, sexualizing, and subjecting them to degrading and violent acts. The trial is ongoing.
The president-elect mentioned that Mrs. Trump and Barron would relocate to Washington "very soon, after he's finished with school," though no specific date has been set.

Despite transition spokesman Jason Miller emphasizing the Trumps' enthusiasm for their new roles, explaining that the delay was to avoid disrupting Barron's schooling mid-year, social media criticism persisted.
One Twitter user, Pamela Benbow, remarked, "The First Family residing in the White House symbolizes our nation to us and the world.
Melania Trump's decision is appalling." Some joked that Mrs. Trump's tastes in interiors influenced the decision, while others speculated about its implications for the Trumps' marriage.

The strong reactions are not entirely unexpected, as only two other First Ladies in U.S. history never lived in the White House: Martha Washington, because it wasn't built yet, and Anna Harrison, because her husband died before she could move in.
Nonetheless, Mrs. Trump's choice has its supporters. As one Twitter user noted, "Good, this is what most responsible parents do with a child Barron's age."
This aligns with Mrs. Trump's consistent focus on Barron, as she stayed home during the campaign to care for him in Trump Tower.
Their situation is not unique; many mothers and children have adapted to life in the White House.

William Seale, a historian with the White House Historical Association and author of *The President's House*, noted that Frances Folsom Cleveland, wife of President Grover Cleveland, only lived in the White House during the social season and spent most of her time at a private home the president purchased.
Known as "Oak View" or "Red Top" for its red roof, this home accommodated the young bride, who was the first and only First Lady married in the White House at age 21, while her husband was 49.
Mr. Seale added, "It's more common than not for children to stay back to finish school.
It seems normal to me that she wants Barron to complete his school year. I don't find it surprising."
He also noted that President John Tyler's children did not move to the White House immediately after he assumed office following President William Henry Harrison's death.
The Home Office has decided to suspend the Detained Fast Track (DFT) system due to concerns over safeguards, especially regarding "vulnerable applicants."
Immigration minister James Brokenshire expressed hope that the DFT system could resume in a few weeks.
Approximately 800 applicants are affected by this suspension and can now apply for bail, with about 100 potentially needing release from detention.
Introduced in 2000, the DFT system aimed to expedite legal hearings and appeals while keeping applicants detained, used in cases deemed straightforward by officials.
Last month, the Court of Appeal ordered the immediate suspension of the system after a High Court ruling highlighted "structural unfairness."

Mr. Justice Nicol, from the High Court, placed a "legal stay" or temporary delay on his ruling on 12 June, following a case by the campaign group Detention Action, allowing the system's operation until all appeals were exhausted.
BBC home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw noted officials were concerned about the robustness of their procedures.

In a statement to the House of Commons, Mr. Brokenshire acknowledged the system faced "significant legal challenge," identifying risks to the safeguards for vulnerable applicants, and declared a temporary suspension of the detained fast-track policy.
He hoped the suspension would be brief, only a few weeks, resuming only once structures are in place to reduce any risk of unfairness.
The suspension means detained asylum seekers awaiting hearings will be reassessed at a "senior level" to determine if they can be released to proceed with their asylum applications normally.

Mr. Brokenshire clarified that those meeting the general criteria for detention would not be directly impacted by the DFT suspension, as many are detained for reasons such as the risk of absconding or imminent removal.
Applicants will only be released if detention cannot be justified outside the DFT process.
He stated that applicants facing removal to a safe third country or those posing a risk to the public, including foreign offenders, still face detention.
In 2013, the DFT system accelerated around 4,300 asylum applications or decisions.
Gordon Strachan's team suffered their second defeat in four games, dropping to fifth in Group F, which raises more questions about the manager's future.
Former Scotland striker Steven Thompson rates their performance out of 10. Although the goalkeeper had no chance with the goals, he had little to do aside from retrieving the ball from his net.
The Derby winger, unexpectedly chosen, defended well despite being out of position.
Returning after a long absence, Scotland's standout player posed a real threat in attack and worked tirelessly.
He played better than in Slovakia, but was unlucky with the first goal despite a good block.
Missed a prime chance to equalize, failing to direct a free header on target. Given a rare start, he did well to contain England’s threats for extended periods.
The captain always shows determination and effort, but was prone to losing possession.

Having recently returned from retirement, how long will he stay? The Celtic captain brought expected energy and aggression to the midfield but was largely ineffective, lacking enough ball involvement to influence the game.
Surprisingly included despite limited playtime at West Brom, he squandered a golden chance early in the second half, pulling a shot wide from close range.
Another player often guilty of giving the ball away, yet offered some threatening set-pieces.
He should have scored after Forrest’s miss when presented with a clear goal opportunity.
He led the line with positive energy in the first half but made a poor decision not to pass to Snodgrass during a promising counter-attack.
Fatigue set in during the second half as Scotland ultimately faltered. Entering when the game was virtually decided, he had little chance to make an impact.
Subbed in for the injured Anya, he wasn't given much to do as England controlled possession and limited threats. Entered too late to affect the game.
Pre-tax profit dropped 49.7% to £27.7 million for the first half of the year ending June 30th.
The firm explained that its emphasis during this period was on operational improvements, which caused its financial performance to temporarily lag.
Ladbrokes CEO Richard Glynn stated the company is now "well positioned for growth," noting significant progress.
"We now have the products, platforms, people, and brand needed to succeed," he added.
Last year, Ladbrokes partnered with software developer Playtech, transitioning its gaming products to a new system.
While the switch caused more disruption than anticipated, the transition is complete.
The company has also upgraded 9,000 gaming machines with more advanced models and closed 46 underperforming shops, nearing its annual goal of 50 closures.
Ladbrokes indicated that additional closures are "inevitable," but specifics are yet to be determined.
The firm's UK performance was affected by "industry-wide, customer-friendly results" in January's football and June's horse racing events.
Additionally, adhering to the Association of British Bookmakers (ABB) voluntary industry code impacted revenues.
This code encourages responsible gambling by allowing players to set limits on spending and time on gaming machines.
Despite these challenges, their World Cup results were "strong," with mobile bets up 1,100%.
"The board remains confident in the business's outlook, aiming for performance in line with expectations for the year," the statement concluded.
Ladbrokes shares rose 3% in early trading. Peel Hunt analyst Nick Batram noted the profit decline was expected.
"While results are disappointing, they align with forecasts. It's positive that Ladbrokes is addressing key areas for improvement," he commented.
The new polymer £5 note, slightly smaller than its paper predecessor, will be available in branches before being distributed more widely in Scotland.
It continues to showcase Sir Walter Scott and The Mound on the front and maintains the bridge theme on the back.
Existing paper £5 notes from the Bank of Scotland will gradually be withdrawn, although those still circulating can be used at shops, banks, and cash machines.
The Bank of Scotland plans to replace its £10 paper note with a polymer version next year.
The new plastic material is reportedly cleaner and more resistant to damage from crumpling or spills.
In September, the Bank of England introduced £5 polymer notes featuring Winston Churchill, marking its first polymer release, though other areas in the UK have already adopted this material.
Polymer banknotes consist of a thin, see-through plastic film with images printed using special ink layers, allowing for transparent sections that resemble small windows.
More than 20 countries, including Scotland, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada, already use polymer notes.
Last year, the Clydesdale Bank released the UK's first fully plastic note with a limited edition £5 commemorative note, which entered full circulation last week, replacing the paper version.
This note highlights Scottish engineering pioneer Sir William Arrol, along with the Forth Bridge and the Titan Crane on the front, and the reverse features several images of the Forth Bridge.
The Royal Bank of Scotland plans to introduce its new £5 polymer note on 27 October, featuring Scottish novelist and poet Nan Shepherd.
Scientist Mary Somerville has been chosen for the bank's £10 polymer note, set for circulation next year, making them the first women to appear on the main issue notes.
Shasta County Sheriff Tom Bosenko emphasized that the injuries of Sherri Papini, a 34-year-old mother of two, were not symbolic but conveyed a message.
Her husband, Keith Papini, revealed on Wednesday that she endured "repeated beatings."
Authorities are currently searching for two Hispanic women, last seen in a dark-colored SUV.
Mrs. Papini was found with a bag over her head and chained at the waist and wrists along a highway, roughly 140 miles (225 km) from her northern California home, early last Thursday.
She was abducted while jogging near her residence in Redding, California, on November 2.
Sheriff Bosenko commented on the unspecified message branded on her skin, suggesting it was either an exertion of power and control or a message contained within the branding.
He noted her blonde hair had been cut off, speculating the perpetrator was "a very sick person" intent on altering her appearance and humiliating her.

Keith Papini described his wife to ABC News as being "covered in bruises ranging from yellow to black" and added, "My Sherri suffered tremendously, and any visions you may have of her appearance are not as graphic and gruesome as the reality."

Her nose was broken, and "her now emaciated body of 87 lb (39 kg) was covered in multicolored bruises, severe burns, red rashes, and chain markings." Police have cleared Mr. Papini of suspicion after he passed a polygraph test.
In a written statement, Keith Papini expressed frustration over "rumors, assumptions, lies, and hate," calling them exhausting and disgusting.
He acknowledged public interest but refused to address each false claim, asserting there was no hoax or fabricated race war.
Since her release on November 24, Mrs. Papini has spoken to investigators at least three times.
Authorities plan to release a sketch of the suspects, who are believed to be armed with a handgun, soon.
The shutdown, the first in 17 years, has led to over 700,000 employees being on unpaid leave since October 1, closing national parks, tourist sites, government websites, and office buildings.

The country's 1.4 million active-duty military personnel remain on duty. However, nearly half of the Defense Department's 800,000 civilian employees stopped working at the onset of the shutdown, except those involved in "national security" activities.
On October 5, the department announced it would recall most of these employees.
Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel stated this decision was based on the Pay Our Military Act, passed by Congress just before the shutdown.
The act allows those whose roles support the "morale, well-being, capabilities, and readiness" of service members to be exempted from furloughs.
Hagel noted, "I expect us to significantly reduce—but not eliminate—civilian furloughs under this process."
The Department of Energy can continue operating briefly without sending employees home, but plans are ready if the shutdown persists.
Under these plans, some facilities will close, with only 1,113 of 13,814 staff required to remain.
Exemptions include those overseeing the nation’s nuclear arsenal safety and operating power infrastructures.
The National Nuclear Security Administration, which handles nuclear weapons and naval reactors, will keep 343 employees on task for safety and property protection.
Over 400 staff will continue work at the Southwestern and Western Area Power Administrations, managing hydroelectric power and power lines in the southern and western U.S.
Some employees from other departments will stay on to protect "human life and property."

Most department staff have been furloughed, but the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will continue operations to provide essential public safety services like weather and shipping updates.
Some Bureau of Industry and Security employees remain on duty to review exports.
Essential transport roles, including air traffic control and inspections related to airports and hazardous materials, continue, with 36,987 out of 55,468 personnel working.
Staff overseeing commercial space launches also remain active. Suspended activities include facility security inspections, routine security background checks, and the employee drug testing program.
The Republican Party is deeply divided. The rhetoric from its members is often too inflammatory.
While some might claim Republican voters are "idiots," the general public tends to be more discerning.
The US electoral map favors candidates who win key high-population "swing" states, making it challenging for Republicans.
Consider this: a recent survey of three critical swing states—Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania—shows a virtual tie between the two prospective nominees.
These states, which hold a combined 67 electoral votes, supported Democrat Barack Obama in both 2008 and 2012.
If added to the states Mitt Romney won in 2012, the total rises to 273 electoral votes—three more than needed to secure the presidency.
Furthermore, a national tracking poll released on Wednesday shows Donald Trump closing in on Hillary Clinton, causing significant concern among Democrats.
However, more rational voices point to the fact that the Reuters/Ipsos national poll, showing Clinton at 41% versus Trump’s 40% with 19% undecided, was conducted online.
The Quinnipiac swing-state poll also heavily sampled white voters, who tend to lean Republican, suggesting that Trump's support might not be growing as much as it appears.
Election analyst Nate Silver cautions against jumping to conclusions based on these polls, reminding us that the election will have many ups and downs, and polls can be unpredictable.
Although political analysts obsess over every poll, the indication that Trump is competitive with Clinton should question early predictions of a landslide for the Democrats.
Trump has a path to the presidency. While it's improbable, it exists. This potential path hinges on the Rust Belt—states like Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, and Wisconsin.
Even if Florida, with its rapidly expanding Hispanic population, sides with Clinton, Trump could win if he takes those states.
He seems aware of this strategy. "We'll win places many say you can't win, like Michigan," Trump asserted at an April rally in Indiana.
Should Scotland become an independent country? For some, those six words on four million ballot papers left no room for doubt.

To the true believers, Scotland was undeniably a nation. These purists disregarded debates over oil prices and government bonds, instead finding inspiration in long-standing tales of Scottish freedom fighters like William Wallace, Robert the Bruce, and Andrew de Moray from the 13th and 14th centuries.
Some independence advocates looked to the Jacobite risings of the 18th century, which sought to restore the House of Stuart to the British throne.
Others recalled the brief 1820 rebellion led by Lanarkshire weaver James Wilson and his fellow radicals, who were executed for demanding parliamentary reform.
Yet, this intense historical nationalism was largely personal. Wilson's slogan, "Scotland Free, or a Desert," which appeared on motorway bridges in the 1980s, was absent in 2014.
Those days seemed relegated to history. As the late New York governor Mario Cuomo once said, "You campaign in poetry.

You govern in prose." However, in Scotland, the 2014 independence campaign was predominantly practical, emphasizing what the late Professor Sir Neil McCormick termed "utilitarian nationalism"—seeking independence as the best path to Scottish prosperity.
This was not a fight to honor battles like Stirling Bridge or Bannockburn nor to avenge Flodden or Culloden, but rather for economic reasons.

Ultimately, the "Yes" vote lost. On a damp, drizzly autumn morning in 2014, Scotland awoke to a clear, albeit not overwhelming, decision to remain in the Union: 44.7% voted for independence, while 55.3% voted against.

Why? Among "the 45"—as the losing side became known—some felt betrayed, believing a powerful alliance of business interests, media, and even British security forces had coerced voters into rejecting independence.
The establishment's messaging, reinforced by a predominantly hostile press, was decidedly negative, despite many "No" voters feeling a positive, even sentimental, connection to the Union.
Supporters of the UK often expressed sadness and dismay at the thought of ending a 300-year-old relationship.
To illustrate, someone on Twitter commented on The Times's front page, noting: "He's white, so let's highlight that he's jobless, a lone wolf, and has mental health issues."

The Times was far from the only publication facing such criticism. On Thursday morning, the Daily Mail dedicated an entire page to an editorial expressing strong displeasure with a Guardian cartoon suggesting the Finsbury Park mosque attacker was influenced by reading their paper and The Sun.
I also tweeted about this issue. However, what captivates me most is the criticism aimed at Facebook and Google for not doing enough to remove online far-right material that glorifies the attack.

Recently, political pressure has intensified on these tech giants, along with smaller firms, to ensure the internet isn’t a "safe space" for terrorists. The political instinct that Something Must Be Done has surged dramatically.
At a recent press conference, Theresa May and Emmanuel Macron pledged not only collaboration on this matter but also fines for companies that delay removing hateful content.
This pressure has re-emerged following an attack by a white man on Muslims, suggesting a broad scope of web content could face disapproval.
Will an anti-Semitic attack lead to demands for Facebook and Google to address anti-Semitism?
Could rising sectarian tensions in India lead to calls for the removal of Hindu nationalist content?
Possibly. It's crucial to grasp the complexity of this issue and consider the consequences of directing our demands for action toward these powerful companies.
First, we must distinguish between the issue of encryption and the broader one of hateful content—a distinction some British politicians have overlooked.
Messaging apps like WhatsApp appeal to terrorists because they offer end-to-end encryption, making infiltration by security services difficult.
Weakening this protection by introducing a backdoor to encryption invites exploitation by various bad actors, from foreign powers to cybercriminals.
As for addressing hateful material, the challenges are both practical and philosophical.
Practically, managing the sheer volume of content is nearly impossible, even with Artificial Intelligence.
Russia was suspended by the IAAF in November 2015 due to state-sponsored doping, extending this ban on Monday to include the 2017 World Championships.
Criticized by the IAAF, Mutko acknowledged, "there were many abuses and breaches," but insists "colossal work has been done" over the past year.
Russia hopes for reinstatement by November, contingent upon restoring its national drug-testing agency, still suspended amid allegations of covering up doping incidents.
Since assuming his role in October, Mutko has been vocal following the McLaren report's claims of a state-supported Russian doping program.
In January, he controversially suggested that female doping results could be skewed by sexual activity days before testing.
However, on Monday, he stated, "Athletes broke the rules, and many coaches do not understand how to train without doping; it's high time for them to retire."
Russia will skip the World Championships starting on 4 August in London, though some athletes might compete under a neutral flag.
The IAAF is considering 35 athletes who can demonstrate independent drug testing records from agencies other than the suspended Russian body.
Russian track federation vice president Andrei Silnov, though against the idea of neutral athletes, questioned whether the nation's issues were as severe as the IAAF claimed.
"It's all being solved, slowly but surely. We're doing what we need to do," Silnov remarked. "They say we have a culture of doping. What culture of doping?"
He accepted an alliance offer from Francois Bayrou, a fellow centrist and devout Roman Catholic.
Recent polls indicate that support for Mr. Macron, the favorite to win the election, has slightly declined.
On Wednesday, two staff members of far-right candidate Marine Le Pen were detained in connection with a financial investigation.
Her chief of staff is under formal investigation for allegedly misusing EU funds to pay parliamentary assistants, according to French media.
Her bodyguard was also questioned. The National Front (FN) leader denies any wrongdoing and dismissed the inquiry as a "political dirty trick."
She holds a strong lead in opinion polls for the first round in April but is predicted to lose in the second.

Mr. Bayrou, who has run for president three times and garnered over 18% of the vote in the 2007 election, announced he would not run this year and offered to ally with Mr. Macron to avert "the failure of France."
He stated that Ms. Le Pen poses a "major and immediate threat to our country and Europe."
Mr. Macron, a free-market liberal, welcomed the alliance proposal, telling Reuters: "The alliance proposed by Francois Bayrou... fully matches our commitment to renewal and unity."
Analysts predict Mr. Bayrou’s supporters will now split between Mr. Macron and his conservative opponent, Francois Fillon.
A new poll shows Mr. Macron and Mr. Fillon are tied for the crucial second-place position in the first round, both at around 19%.
In the same poll, taken before the alliance was announced, Mr. Bayrou was projected to secure 5.5%, while Ms.
Le Pen would get 26%. In the second round, Mr. Macron is projected to defeat Ms.
Le Pen by 61% to 39%, while Mr. Fillon would also beat her, but by 57% to 43%. Early in the campaign, Mr. Fillon was expected to easily reach the run-off with Ms.
Le Pen and win, but a scandal over payments to his family damaged his image in January.
On Wednesday, he consulted with former Prime Minister Alain Juppe, whom he defeated in the Republican primaries, according to Le Figaro newspaper.
Ms. Le Pen has been accused by the European Parliament of misusing approximately 340,000 euros (£289,000; $359,000), as reported by AFP news agency.

Allegations include paying her bodyguard Thierry Legier for a bogus job and compensating her chief of staff, Catherine Griset, as her EU assistant in Brussels while she was actually working for the party. Mr. Legier and Ms. Griset were questioned on Wednesday.
Media playback isn't supported on this device. The match was physical and abrasive, exactly as head coach Eddie Jones wanted for England's return to form.
Jones aimed to set the tone at Murrayfield and left satisfied with a win. We can expect to see progress in England’s play over the coming games.

Their tactics focused on direct play, utilizing the forwards. However, Centre Jonathan Joseph rarely received the ball, and the wingers mainly handled it from kick returns, indicating England still needs to refine their backline strategy.
Statistically, England's set-piece performance was excellent. Captain Dylan Hartley's line-out execution was nearly perfect, with only one miss out of 15 attempts.
Jones's vision of a robust set-piece game and an abrasive pack came to fruition against Scotland.
England also capitalized on both clear-cut opportunities to score tries, which is promising, though Joseph likely wants more involvement.
Media playback isn't supported on this device. Owen Farrell, his center partner, also wasn't prominent, and full-back Mike Brown didn’t perform as expected.
Improvement will come with time. I'm not entirely convinced by the pairing of Owen Farrell and George Ford at fly-half and inside center.
When two specialized number 10s split their focus on game organization, they don't engage enough directly; Farrell carried the ball only three times and Joseph four against Scotland.
This shows the midfield isn't operating at full potential, although their combination did lead to Jack Nowell's try.
Ideally, an inside center capable of both playmaking and posing an individual threat would suit better than having a fly-half in that role temporarily.
A player eager to be more involved, like Henry Slade—though currently injured—would be perfect.
For now, England is adapting as best as they can given their limited resources.
The 35-year-old winger has signed a one-year contract with the Mitsubishi Dynaboars in Division Two of the Japanese League.
Williams scored twice in his final match for the Ospreys. "It was a last-minute offer which required a quick decision," Williams shared on Twitter.
"I am very excited about this new venture." In February, Williams announced his departure after declining the Ospreys' offer to continue his playing career in Wales for a tenth season.
In December 2008, he was named International Rugby Board Player of the Year, having scored 58 tries in 87 games for his country, and two in four Tests for the British and Irish Lions.
He concluded his international career dramatically with a last-minute try in Cardiff on December 3rd.
As a double-Grand Slam winner, Williams also holds the record as the Ospreys' top try-scorer with 57 tries in 141 matches, capping his final game for both club and country with a late score.
However, his last appearance in Europe was with the Barbarians in Cardiff on June 2nd.
Although expected to remain with the Ospreys at Liberty Stadium next season, the Welsh team has permitted him to pursue this "once-in-a-lifetime" opportunity.

The Ospreys stated, "Given Shane's exceptional service to the team, we understand the unique chance this presents for him and his family to explore a new culture and will not prevent him from taking it.
We wish them the best in Japan and eagerly await Shane's return to Ospreylia after his playing commitments, where he will continue to represent us with distinction off the field."
Williams ranks second on the all-time international try-scoring list, behind Australia's David Campese.
He is also following in the footsteps of former Ospreys teammates Jerry Collins and Filo Tiatia, who moved to Yamaha Jubilo and Toyota Verblitz in Japan in 2011.
Jung, 33, clinched his third victory after winning at Burghley and Kentucky, finishing with a flawless showjumping performance in Sunday's final event.
Andreas Ostholt of Germany secured second place on So Is Et, while Britain's Gemma Tattersall achieved third on Arctic Soul.
Jung's triumphant completion of the Grand Slam parallels Pippa Funnell's 2003 feat. "We need some time to fully grasp this momentous occasion.
It's a significant achievement," Jung remarked. Zara Tindall secured her Olympic qualification, finishing 23rd on High Kingdom, the horse with which she won a team silver at London 2012.

Team GB's selections won't be finalized until July, but Tattersall, Tindall, Kristina Cook (seventh on Star Witness), Izzy Taylor (eighth on Allercombe Ellie), and Ben Way (12th on Galley Light) have met qualifying standards.
Jung dominated throughout dressage, cross-country, and showjumping, culminating in a record low of 34.4 penalty points at Badminton Park.

Ostholt finished with 43.4 points, and Tattersall with 44.6. Tattersall made a compelling case for Olympic selection, clearing all 13 obstacles faultlessly in the showjumping finale alongside Ostholt and Jung, maintaining their positions from Saturday's cross-country.
Jung's lead allowed for two poles to fall during his final run, yet he completed without a blemish, receiving a standing ovation from the sell-out crowd.
Jung is now a strong contender to defend his Olympic individual eventing title and could potentially lead Germany to a team victory in Rio.
He praised La Biosthetique as "the best in the world," noting their unprecedented accomplishment in holding Olympic, world, and European titles in 2012.
Jung's determination bodes a challenge for Great Britain—second in team eventing in London 2012—as he broke a Badminton points record set in 2006.
He became the first rider since 2007 to lead from dressage to the conclusion, but his Grand Slam achievement is what will etch Badminton 2016 in eventing history.
Out of 77 horse-rider pairs, 46 completed the week. New Zealand's Sir Mark Todd finished fourth, sparking hope he might compete in his seventh Olympic Games at age 60.
An investigation into Pembrokeshire council's interactions with Michael Smith reveals that his foster carer application was halted merely by chance.
The Western Telegraph has exclusively obtained a confidential 2015 report, which uncovers that a head of service initially neglected to disclose child protection concerns about Smith.
The council expressed regret over the disclosure of the report, stating it was unfortunate a member of the authority shared it against advice.
Smith, based in Haverfordwest, worked as a youth employee for the council from May 2001 to January 2012 and faced three disciplinary hearings during his tenure.
Allegations included allowing a child to sit on and drive his Land Rover, letting a child ride without a seatbelt, and hosting at his home a young person reported missing by their foster carer.

The report, created by an independent social worker, indicated that Smith exhibited numerous grooming behaviors while employed by Pembrokeshire council, although no direct abuse allegations surfaced during that period.
Smith was dismissed for gross misconduct, and in September 2013, police launched an investigation following accusations of sexually abusing a boy.
In July 2014, Smith was sentenced to six years in prison after pleading guilty to sexually assaulting a child under 13, inciting sexual activity, and taking indecent photographs.
He also admitted to possessing 1,136 indecent images of children. In 2010, Smith applied to Pembrokeshire council to become a respite foster carer.
The fostering team sought the Head of Youth Service’s input on his application.

The report noted that the head responded "very positively." A reference form sent to the head asked to "highlight any concerns" with Smith's employment, including disciplinary proceedings and their outcomes.

The head left this section blank. It wasn’t until the papers were distributed to the foster panel that a member remembered Smith had been previously investigated for inappropriate behavior and disciplined.
This recollection led the panel to deem Smith unsuitable for foster care approval.
The report noted that by omitting crucial information, the panel might have mistakenly believed there were no concerns or disciplinary actions against Smith.
It was only by chance that a panel member recalled the 2005 safeguarding investigation, preventing Smith from becoming a foster carer.
"I wouldn’t say I’m tough...just lucky," said Reg Foggerdy, who vanished last month while hunting a feral camel in Western Australia.
Police trackers discovered him sitting under a tree on October 12, roughly 15 km (9 miles) from where he went missing.
As a diabetic who recently suffered a heart attack, he admitted he had lost hope.
"I’ve heard of people dying after three days without water; I don’t know why I survived six days," he told 7News.
"A part of me thought about lying down and giving up. I was picturing my family finding me like that."
Clad only in a t-shirt, shorts, a cap, and flip-flops, Mr. Foggerdy became disoriented in the desert’s blistering heat while chasing the camel.
He revealed he used a stick to stir up an ants' nest and ate the insects for nutrition, a survival trick he learned from British expert Bear Grylls. "They tasted quite good.
On the first day, I had about 12, and on the second day about 18. If anyone wants to call me 'Ant Man,' I don’t mind," he said.
The retired miner saw police search helicopters several times, gathering all his energy to wave his hat at them, but they couldn't spot him.
Ultimately, a local Aboriginal man gave police the key clue—Mr. Foggerdy’s slipper print.
After narrowly escaping death, he feels rejuvenated. However, when asked if he would return to the scene of his ordeal, he replied, "I might go back and look for my gun."
Sports Direct disclosed a significant decline in half-year profits, attributing part of the downturn to the weakened pound.
The retailer, previously criticized for working conditions, reported a 25% decrease in pre-tax profits, totaling £140.2 million.
Despite this, the firm announced plans to purchase a corporate jet for £40 million.
Chief Executive Mike Ashley acknowledged the challenges faced over the past six months, describing them as "tough for our people and performance."

In detailing the company's results, Mr. Ashley noted, "Our UK sports retail business remains the driving force for Sports Direct, but our outcomes have been impacted by unfavorable exchange rates and our reassessment of risks related to stock levels and the performance of our European stores."
