Amidst scrutiny during his tenure as chairman, Mr. Hellawell utilized the results statement to criticize the treatment of the company, stating, "I firmly believe that the intense political, union, and media campaign against our company has not only damaged our reputation but also influenced our customers and adversely affected the morale of our employees."
He questioned whether the scrutiny was ethically motivated, pointing out that the critics' actions harmed the very people they claimed to support.
"The board acknowledges our failings but emphasizes the disproportionate, inaccurate, and misleading commentary.
Our employees, the backbone of our organization, are blameless in this scenario.
They're increasingly upset and angered by the barrage of negative comments that they consider unjustified."
Sports Direct has faced several scandals in recent months. The HMRC has investigated whether workers at its Derbyshire warehouse received wages below the minimum legal standard.
Additionally, a critical report by the Business, Innovation, and Skills Committee claimed that company employees were "not treated as humans."
As the criticism around staff treatment intensified, MPs alleged an attempt to record their private conversation during a visit to the Shirebrook warehouse.
More recently, an inquiry into the company's accounts was initiated, and multiple senior employees have resigned.
Dave Forsey stepped down as chief executive, succeeded by Mr. Ashley. Acting Finance Director Matt Pearson was replaced by interim appointee Herbert Monteith in October.
An understated indication of shifting priorities within Sports Direct appears in the interim results, under "corporate assets and facilities," noting the forthcoming arrival of a corporate plane.
Australia, aiming for their fourth consecutive World T20 title, elected to bat first and put up a score of 148-5.
Elyse Villani shone with a half-century, the first in a final, scoring 52 off just 34 balls.
Yet, the highlight was the dynamism of 18-year-old Windies opener Hayley Matthews, who delivered a spectacular 66 off 45 balls, including three sixes, in a pivotal 120-run partnership.
The West Indies secured victory with three balls remaining, and their men's team later achieved a T20 double triumph.
Despite losing all eight previous T20 internationals against Australia, the West Indies faced nerves as they bowled on the prestigious grounds of Eden Gardens.
Villani capitalized on errant full tosses to reach her fifty swiftly, and Meg Lanning contributed with three consecutive fours in her 52.
Meanwhile, Ellyse Perry showcased elegance with two striking sixes during a brief 28-run performance.
Australia's defense tightened, conceding only one single from the last over. However, the Windies initially started slowly in their chase, managing just three runs in the first two overs.
Momentum shifted with Matthews and captain Stafanie Taylor hitting 16 from the fifth over, bowled by Perry, reaching their century stand by the 14th over.
Matthews departed with 29 runs needed from 26 balls, and Taylor's innings of 59 concluded leaving only five runs to get from eight deliveries.
The final over required three runs, which were secured following an overthrow that led to exuberant West Indian celebrations.
The men's team joined the festivities as they arrived for their own final against England.
This victory marked a significant revival for West Indies cricket, following their Under-19 team's triumph over India in the 50-over World Cup in February.
West Indies captain Stafanie Taylor expressed her long-awaited joy, remarking, "I've been waiting for this for a long time, and it has come at the perfect moment.
Our batting carried us through, and it was wonderful having the men's team supporting us."
Men's captain Darren Sammy texted her saying, "Staf, you are going to do it; you girls are going to do it."

Australian skipper Meg Lanning acknowledged the Windies' efforts: "Full credit to the West Indies—they played excellently, though we fell short of the result we desired. A target of 160 would have been ideal, but we expected to defend our score."
Talks have been ongoing for weeks regarding the Northern Ireland international, as Manchester City has had two offers rejected for a player West Brom insists is not available.
Evans, who spent nine years at Manchester United before moving to Albion in 2015, has two years remaining on his contract.
West Brom also declined a £10m bid from Leicester for the 29-year-old. Evans joined United as a schoolboy and went on to win three Premier League titles and two League Cups, making 198 appearances.
He moved to West Brom after former United manager Louis van Gaal excluded him from his plans.
Last year, Arsenal expressed interest in Evans, but West Brom dismissed their approach for their captain.
City manager Pep Guardiola stated last month he was still aiming to sign another central defender before the transfer window closes.
His fourth choice for that position is Eliaquim Mangala, who likely lacks a long-term future at City.
Former Everton winger Pat Nevin commented on BBC Radio 5 live that Manchester City's weakness at center-back is well-known.
While Virgil van Dijk would be ideal, Jonny Evans, at 29, is likely at his peak.
He's comfortable with both two or three at the back and decent with the ball. It's hard to find a downside.
Just consider the difficulty of finding center-backs in the Premier League right now; many argue he's not worth it, but given the scarcity, he certainly is.
Germany's uninspiring performance in Tbilisi was concerning, but the match in Frankfurt following their 1-0 victory over Georgia compounded worries about Monday’s potential outcome.
According to Mats Hummels' comments to BBC Scotland, Germany hadn't returned to their peak form yet, but against a strong Polish team, they came close.
This was especially evident in their attacking play. Germany relentlessly pressed forward, their sharp passes exposing weaknesses in Poland's defense.
Within 20 minutes at the Commerzbank Arena, Germany seemed to have overwhelmed the Poles, making the 2-0 lead appear as if it could easily multiply to five or six by game’s end.

Thomas Muller, who scored the opening goal, was in fine form during this period, his seemingly laid-back approach masking a keen intelligence that consistently finds him in the right positions in the opponent's box.
With Karim Bellarabi, the Bayer Leverkusen winger, Germany has found yet another attacking asset.
Despite his national debut during a loss to Poland last year, he has since become a regular in Joachim Low's lineup, proving his worth on Friday night.

Teaming up on the left with another new addition, Cologne full-back Jonas Hector, Bellarabi outmaneuvered Lukasz Piszczek, the seasoned Borussia Dortmund defender, contributing to Muller’s goal and creating chaos in the process.
This implies that whoever Gordon Strachan chooses at right back, possibly Alan Hutton, will need support to prevent Germany from dominating.
Concerns over some of Scotland’s starters lacking club playtime were noted, but similar issues didn't hinder Germany's Bastian Schweinsteiger and Mario Gotze.
Schweinsteiger had only started two of Manchester United’s six competitive matches this season, while Gotze started just once in the Bundesliga for Bayern Munich.
Nevertheless, both were pivotal in Germany's victory over Poland. Playing as a striker at times, Gotze moved to find space, allowing Muller to exploit openings.

He scored twice—once from the edge of the box after skilfully evading Polish defenders—and even hit the post, demonstrating why Low steadfastly supports him despite Pep Guardiola’s ongoing dilemma about his role at Bayern.
The Project Loon team, part of the company's X research lab, announced advancements in machine learning that allow them to predict weather patterns.
This leap means the firm can better control the paths of its balloons, enabling them to target specific regions instead of navigating the globe.
By clustering fewer balloons, the project becomes more cost-effective, as Google's head of ambitious projects, Astro Teller, explained.
"We can now experiment and provide service to a specific area with around ten, twenty, or thirty balloons," he noted, rather than needing hundreds.
Teller mentioned that "real users" could start accessing the system in the "coming months," although he didn't disclose where the initial rollout would occur.
Google aims to connect the nearly four billion people worldwide who currently lack internet access, especially in remote rural areas.

Rather than building extensive infrastructure to mirror the connectivity of the developed world, the company is testing a method of delivering internet from large, tennis-court-sized balloons in the stratosphere, about 11 miles up.
The balloons can change direction by adjusting altitude to ride different weather streams.
Utilizing machine-learning algorithms, Google believes they have found a way to predict weather conditions with enough precision to keep balloons stationary over a small area for extended periods.
Last year, they successfully maintained a cluster of balloons over Peru for three months.
Over the past year, Google has faced increasing pressure from shareholders to reduce spending on its more extravagant projects.
Recently, the company spun off its self-driving project into a new company, Waymo, and increased efforts to commercialize the technology amid criticism of its slow profitability.
Mr. Teller remarked that Project Loon is one of the company's more "mature" ambitious projects.
While they are working on agreements with telecom firms, Google is in "no rush" to make Project Loon an independent business.
"The service has a much better chance of being profitable, which excites us," he said.
"Things have gone much better than we thought possible, improving Loon's prospects."
However, a significant challenge remains: the reliability of the balloons. So far, the record for continuous flight has been 190 days.

The claim that Ukraine is free of far-right influence is clearly incorrect. While far-right parties did not manage to surpass the 5% threshold required for parliamentary entry, they might have succeeded if their votes hadn't been fragmented.
Presently, only one government minister has connections to nationalist parties, yet he is neither a neo-Nazi nor a fascist.
Furthermore, Volodymyr Groysman, the Jewish speaker of parliament, holds the country's third highest-ranking position.
Despite these facts, Ukrainian officials and much of the media often claim politics in Ukraine are entirely devoid of fascism—another misconception.
Consequently, the issue of far-right presence in Ukraine remains sensitive, with officials and media avoiding the topic to prevent giving Russian propaganda any leverage.
However, ignoring the problem can be risky, as it allows ultra-nationalists to operate unnoticed and leaves many Ukrainians unaware of what neo-Nazis or fascists believe.
This sensitivity was evident when President Petro Poroshenko granted Ukrainian citizenship to an individual accused of being a "Belarusian neo-Nazi" by human rights activists.

On December 5th, Poroshenko awarded medals to those who defended the Donetsk airport from Russian-backed forces, including Serhiy Korotkykh, whom he praised for his "courageous and selfless service." A photo showed Poroshenko with Korotkykh, dressed in military attire.

Experts on the far right criticized Poroshenko's decision, noting Korotkykh's involvement with far-right groups like the Russian National Unity party and the neo-Nazi National Socialist Society (NSS), which aims to incite a race war, according to academic Anton Shekhovtsov.

Though Korotkykh faced charges for a 2007 Moscow bombing and a 2013 stabbing in Minsk, he was released due to insufficient evidence, though activist Halya Coynash argued the accusations, if true, were grave.

Ukrainian officials, including security services head Valentyn Nalyvaychenko, dismissed claims of Korotkykh's neo-Nazi affiliations as slanderous, asserting no counterintelligence information precluded his citizenship.
Healthcare workers are visibly overwhelmed, and the response to the outbreak has been criticized as "lethally inadequate."

The situation is showing signs of considerable worsening. Although the outbreak has persisted all year, recent alarming statistics reveal that 40% of the deaths have occurred in the last three weeks alone.
What can we anticipate in the coming months, or even years? Predicting the future can be risky, especially in this unfamiliar context.
Past outbreaks were quickly contained, impacting only a few dozen individuals; however, this outbreak has already affected over 3,900 people.
The first insights come from current data. Dr. Christopher Dye, the director of strategy at the World Health Organization, faces the daunting task of forecasting the outbreak's trajectory.
He told the BBC, "We're quite worried about the latest data we've just gathered."
Until recently, Liberia, particularly near the outbreak's epicenter in Lofa County and its capital Monrovia, was most severely impacted.
Meanwhile, Sierra Leone and Guinea, the other two primary affected countries, had been relatively stable, with new case numbers not declining but not surging either.
That's changed now, with a rise in cases everywhere except parts of rural Sierra Leone in Kenema and Kailahun districts.
"In most other areas, cases and deaths seem to be increasing. That surprised me," said Dr. Dye.
Stories of healthcare workers being pushed beyond their limits are numerous. A widespread lack of basic protective gear, such as gloves, has been reported.
Médecins Sans Frontières operates an isolation facility with 160 beds in Monrovia, but it reports growing queues and the need for an additional 800 beds to accommodate the already ill.
This scenario doesn't contain an epidemic; it fuels one. Dr. Dye's preliminary projections are grim: "Currently, we're seeing about 500 new cases each week, and those numbers are increasing.
I’ve just projected five weeks into the future, and if current trends persist, we might see not hundreds, but thousands of new cases weekly, which is incredibly concerning.
The situation is dire, and we must prepare for it worsening." The World Health Organization is basing its response planning on an estimated 20,000 cases before the outbreak is contained.
Conservative MP Fiona Bruce led an initiative to address how the law is "interpreted in different ways" regarding sex-selective abortion, but her proposal was defeated by 292 votes to 201.
Instead, an agreement was reached to review the prevalence of sex-selective abortions.
The government has consistently stated that sex-selective abortion is "already illegal."
Health Minister Jane Ellison noted that the Department of Health issued new guidance last May, which independent sectors must follow.
Before the debate, Bruce had support from over 100 MPs. Her amendment sought not to change the law but to update the 1967 legislation, which predates techniques for identifying a fetus's sex.
An alternative amendment, calling for a review of gender-selective abortion in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland, received overwhelming support of 491 to 2 votes.
Bruce argued that her amendment would clearly state in law that sex-selective abortion is illegal in the UK and provide the government an opportunity to issue best practice regulations.
She explained that the new clause was necessary because the 1967 Abortion Act didn't explicitly address gender-selective abortion, as the technology to determine fetal sex wasn't available then.
Bruce emphasized that her proposal wouldn't criminalize pregnant women but would hold doctors accountable for authorizing abortions.
She denied claims that her proposal would prevent abortions related to gender-linked disabilities.
Conservative David Burrowes supported the amendment, noting that UK law doesn’t explicitly ban gender-selective abortions.
Jim Shannon from the DUP also endorsed it, affirming that accountability would lie with doctors, not women.
However, Dr. Sarah Wollaston, chairwoman of the Health Select Committee, opposed the proposal, arguing it was unnecessary and risked "unintended consequences."
She cautioned it might deter women from discussing pressure to abort due to gender fears, potentially leading to criminalization.
Wollaston insisted there was no evidence of widespread gender-selective abortion in the UK and cautioned against stigmatizing communities.
She also warned that the proposed clause could affect existing abortion laws by "conferring personhood on the fetus."
Widely regarded as the least corrupt country on the continent, Botswana boasts the longest-standing multiparty democracy and one of the world's fastest-growing economies.
However, after the 2008 global economic downturn and increasing volatility in commodity prices, concerns have emerged about the country's dependence on diamonds.
For the first time, Botswana is experiencing financial constraints, negative growth, and the need to seek help from international donors.

In response, the nation is aiming to diversify its economy by bolstering existing sectors such as tourism and cattle farming, while investing in emerging industries driven by technology and entrepreneurship.
Despite these efforts, diamonds remain the dominant industry, contributing one-third to the GDP, 70% to export earnings, and one-third to government revenue.
Nevertheless, diamond production has hit its peak, and experts estimate reserves could be exhausted by 2030.
Unemployment is rising, with official rates nearing 20%, and about 45% of the population living below the poverty line.
In 2009, economic growth was negative, and the industrial sector contracted by 30%.

Signs of labor unrest have appeared following recent public sector strikes. Linah Mohohlo, who has served as governor of the Bank of Botswana for 15 years, expressed concerns in a BBC Africa Business Report interview, noting that the government has long been focused on diversifying the economy away from mining.
Botswana is seen as partly a victim of its own policies, which have prioritized and protected the diamond industry, making it challenging to develop and expand newer, alternative industries.
State involvement in the economy and bureaucratic hurdles also deter investors from entering the market, as most contracts are government-sponsored, limiting entrepreneurial ventures.
Although situated in the relatively stable southern African region, an electricity crisis in South Africa and political uncertainty in Zimbabwe create challenges.
Mohohlo is particularly concerned about competition with neighboring countries for foreign direct investment, urging Botswana to improve its competitiveness.
The manufacturing sector, for instance, has not met expectations, contributing only about 5% to GDP, despite employing more workers than the mining industry.
Furthermore, Botswana faces the challenge of its small domestic market of two million people and competing with South Africa.
The 31-year-old cricketer recently signed a two-year extension to play only limited-overs cricket for Glamorgan.
In 2016, Ingram was named Glamorgan's player of the year in one-day formats, but he isn't primarily focused on joining the Indian Premier League at this point.
"The IPL isn't high on my agenda right now, but who knows what might happen in the future," he remarked.
"For now, having a secure position with Glamorgan for the next few years is comforting."
After undergoing knee surgery in August 2016, an injury kept him from participating in four-day Championship cricket that summer.

In 2017, he returned to the longer format for Glamorgan but mentioned that family and fitness considerations are prompting him to scale down his busy schedule, which includes playing for the South African team, the Warriors.
"It's been challenging playing year-round while residing in South Africa, so I'll spend more time there.

My injury history is also a factor," he explained to BBC Wales Sport. "It's vital for me to focus on my best formats, 50-over cricket and T20, so I'm grateful to the club and eager to continue with them.

However, I also want to explore international opportunities if they arise." The IPL and Australia’s Big Bash are currently regarded as the top cricket tournaments globally, drawing large crowds and inspiring the England and Wales Cricket Board to design a major city competition for 2020.
"People often discuss the IPL, but when you're committed to playing in the UK, the IPL becomes less of a priority.
I've always aspired to play county cricket," said Ingram. "The IPL is an amazing event, featuring the best players worldwide and is exceptionally well-promoted.
However, I’m not heavily motivated by money. I simply want to make sound choices, earn a decent living, and enjoy the game I love."
Ingram made these comments after his career-best limited-overs score of 142, which led Glamorgan to a narrow one-run victory over Essex in the One-Day Cup.
He plans to continue playing Championship cricket for the rest of the 2017 season.
In May, Qatar promised to enhance migrant rights amid increasing concerns over their treatment in the Gulf state.
However, Amnesty International reported that little progress has been made in ending exploitation.
The report criticized Qatar for "lagging behind" in reforming controversial laws that restrict migrants to a single employer.
Moreover, it noted that the requirement for workers to obtain exit permits from their employers to leave the country remains unchanged.
Sherif Elsayed-Ali, Head of Refugee and Migrants' Rights at AI, stated, "Time is running out fast.
Four years have passed since Qatar secured the World Cup bid, putting itself in the global spotlight, yet its response to migrant labor abuses has mostly been promises and draft laws."
He stressed the need for urgent action to prevent the World Cup from being associated with forced labor and exploitation.
The Gulf state has seen a surge of foreign workers ahead of the tournament, with expatriates now comprising the majority of the workforce.
Earlier in November, Qatar's Sports Minister, Salah bin Ghanem bin Nasser al-Ali, told The Associated Press that labor reforms are planned for the "next few months."
However, Amnesty believes these proposals fall short. The report noted that while Qatari officials increasingly recognize the need for change, widespread reforms must occur soon.
AI warned that failure to implement significant changes would "call into question the seriousness of Qatari authorities about reform."
Last year, over 180 migrant workers died in Qatar, and many more likely suffered injuries due to unsafe working conditions.
Qatar reportedly spends more than $200 billion (£121 billion) on extensive infrastructure projects, claiming the World Cup serves as a catalyst for nationwide development.

After weeks of speculation regarding whether the Bank of England's Governor would extend his tenure in light of the referendum results, Mark Carney surprised many in the City and the government by making an unexpected decision.
Officials at the Bank generally believed Carney had two choices: either remain until 2021 or leave as initially planned in 2018.
However, Carney introduced a third option: extending his term, but only by one year.

This decision seemed like an awkward compromise. Was Mr. Carney feeling political pressure to avoid extending until 2021, or was he discouraged by the bleak economic forecasts for the UK post-Brexit, prompting a desire to leave?
Another possible factor was how his family, particularly reluctant about another three years in the UK with him often traveling for global summits, felt about the situation.

This seemed to be the deciding factor. When he took office in 2013, it was almost unimaginable that the UK would soon be negotiating its exit from the EU, a process Pascal Lamy, the former WTO head, compared to "taking an egg out of an omelette."
That changed on June 23, complicating matters for Carney. Leaving in 2018 would mean departing in the midst of Brexit negotiations.
Should he then extend his term to the typical eight-year period expected of governors to reassure nervous markets?
Carney recognized the job's evolving challenges, even telling confidants he "wanted to serve" longer, which led to media predictions that he'd fulfill the eight-year term.
However, in more private discussions weeks ago, he started considering a "third way"—a brief extension.
The reasons were personal. In 2018, one of Carney’s daughters will finish her A-levels, and another her GCSEs.
Like everyone, he has personal obligations to handle. This role demands complete dedication, and he is committed to providing that for as long as possible.
Strachan was tight-lipped about his future following last week's 3-0 loss to England.
Currently, Scotland sits second to last in their World Cup qualifying group with four points from four matches.
When asked if Strachan would continue his role, Motherwell manager McGhee expressed confidence, saying, "I'd be amazed if he doesn't.
Based on the performance, he got the best out of the players, so it's fair for him to move on to the next games and aim for better results."
Scotland's next match is against Slovenia at home in March, followed by a rematch with England at Hampden in June.
The qualification campaign concludes with double-headers against Lithuania and Malta, then Slovakia and Slovenia later in 2017.
Group winners qualify for the 2018 finals in Russia, while the eight best runners-up from the nine European groups will compete in playoffs for four more spots.
Scotland began Group F strongly with a 5-1 victory in Malta, but only managed a late draw at home against Lithuania.
They then suffered a 3-0 defeat by Slovakia in Bratislava before the same scoreline against England at Wembley.
"Everyone is entitled to their opinions," McGhee stated. "Regardless of what others say, we'll continue our efforts until we're told otherwise.

If people objectively see that the players are trying their best, despite falling short due to either lack of skill or bad luck, then we're justified in pressing on, because we're still getting the best out of them."
Appointed by Nigel Farage in 2014, Mr. Gill believes he still has the support of most UKIP members.
Now, he faces the task of convincing party members in North Wales to prioritize him on their list of candidates for May's assembly election.
In each of the assembly's five regions, UKIP candidates will be ranked through a ballot of party members.

Mr. Gill claims he advocated for this ballot within the party's National Executive Committee (NEC), addressing concerns about externally imposed candidates from outside Wales, such as former Tory MPs Mark Reckless and Neil Hamilton.
While he refrains from discussing individuals, he insists it's up to the members to decide.
However, some assert he hasn't done enough and that the selection process should have been managed entirely in Wales, urging him to step down.
"I've worked in Wales with UKIP for 11 years, canvassed across every single area, and know the vast majority of members," he states.
"I recognize the quality, passion, and capability of our membership and have stood up for them."
Critics within other parties, often labeling UKIP as anti-Welsh, might question that declaration, but the intraparty critics pose a more substantial challenge.
Since decisions on candidate selection were made in private NEC meetings, critics not present in those meetings must take Mr. Gill at his word.
"Of course, there are people who dislike me, but I believe my supporters vastly outnumber them," he notes.

He considers some who criticize him are driven by "personal reasons," perhaps due to changing their minds about becoming candidates, and dismisses claims that he doesn't represent the rank-and-file as "nonsense."
Acknowledging the messy selection compared to other parties, Mr. Gill emphasizes UKIP's role as a distinct alternative.
Despite serving as an MEP, he doesn't identify with the political class, unsurprising given the prevalent distrust in politicians today.
Who proactively identifies with the political class these days? I visited him at his home—a family-run bed and breakfast on Anglesey—where he and his wife, Jana, raise their five children.
Does he sometimes wish he could avoid the backlash from those urging him to resign? "Naturally, part of me feels that way; after all, I'm human."
In 2016, Zimbabwean MP Joseph Chinotimba, a devoted supporter of President Robert Mugabe, began the year with a romantic gesture.
The 66-year-old war veteran and his wife, Vimbai, entered the Book of African Records after winning a top prize in a Valentine's Day competition.

The couple, married for eight years, claimed victory in "The Longest Kiss in Africa Challenge" by kissing for a record 10 minutes and 17 seconds, surpassing the previous African record by over five minutes.
However, their achievement still fell short of the world record set by a Thai couple who kissed for 58 hours, 35 minutes, and 58 seconds.
Later that year, Nigerian MP Dino Melaye highlighted the challenges women face concerning abusive language and gender equality.
During a heated Senate session in July, he allegedly threatened to assault and "impregnate" fellow senator Oluremi Tinubu.
Melaye denied the remarks, controversially adding, "Biologically, it is even impossible to impregnate Tinubu because she has arrived at menopause."
Despite his statement, reported by Nigeria's Punch newspaper, Tinubu chose to forgive his comments but vowed to remain resilient in the socially conservative nation.
She noted, "I am not championing a cause for women; I am merely standing my ground.
If my space is encroached upon, I must fight back. Rosa Parks wasn't an activist; she simply refused to surrender her seat, sending a powerful message."
Across Africa, women often face various denials of basic human rights; however, they have the right to vote.
In past Zambian elections, women with nail varnish were prohibited from voting unless they wiped their nails clean, as officials claimed it hindered the application of indelible ink.
This changed during the August elections, which saw President Edgar Lungu secure another term.
Days before the vote, the electoral commission announced on social media that women with "painted nails and/or false nails" could still vote, affirming their democratic rights.

Meanwhile, in a unique legislative move towards gender equality, Cameroon's parliament debated a law in June proposing jail time for men committing adultery, matching existing laws penalizing women with two to six months in jail for extramarital affairs.
Saracens defeated Clermont Auvergne 28-17 at Murrayfield on Saturday, keeping their dreams alive for a historic 'double-double' in European and English championships.
Their journey continues next Saturday with a visit to Exeter for the first Premiership semi-final.
"If we're hungry and humble enough, there's no reason we can't improve," said McCall. "The team's age profile is favorable, and our victory was promising."
If Saracens topple Exeter, they'll face Wasps or Leicester in the Premiership final at Twickenham on May 27.
Saracens winger Chris Ashton scored first in the 13th minute, claiming his 37th European try and setting a new record.
He latched onto Alex Goode's precise grubber kick for his milestone try and was quick to credit his teammates for the achievement. "I won't lie, I'm thrilled," he admitted.
"But much of it is thanks to the group I've played with over the last five years.
It's great my name is recognized, but much of the credit belongs to this club."
The former England winger will depart Saracens this summer to join the French Top 14 side Toulon and expressed sadness over his departure.
"I'll miss it. These five years have been incredible," he confessed. "I've experienced amazing highs and definite lows.
The support from players and coaches has been outstanding, so leaving will be tough."
Goode, who contributed the decisive try for Saracens' second European title, has excelled again this season despite being overlooked by England since his last cap against Fiji in 2016.
Goode, last season's Premiership player of the year, is thriving in club rugby.
"We have a young squad eager to improve," he said. "It's a joy to play alongside the team.
Our strength lies in our constant pursuit of improvement, never feeling like we've reached our peak."
Ahmet Davutoglu noted that airstrikes targeting IS positions near the Syria-Turkey border and Kurdish PKK separatists in Iraq could significantly change the dynamics of the conflict.
Turkey's actions are a response to recent violent incidents in the country, including the bombing in Suruc that killed 32 activists.

NATO is set to hold an emergency meeting on Tuesday to address the situation. On Monday, the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG), the armed branch of the main Syrian Kurdish party, called on Turkey to halt its attacks on Kurdish units in Syria.
In a meeting with Turkish newspaper editors, Mr. Davutoglu said that Turkey's military actions have created "new conditions" in the regional conflict.

"With Turkey capable of using its force effectively, the game could change in Syria, Iraq, and throughout the region; everyone should recognize this," he was quoted as saying by the Hurriyet Daily News.
As a NATO member, Turkey has invoked Article 4 of the organization's founding treaty, which allows members to request consultations if their territorial integrity or security is under threat.

"Turkey's call for this meeting is very appropriate and timely, as we need to address the chaos and instability surrounding Syria, Iraq, and Turkey's NATO borders," NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg told the BBC.

Mr. Davutoglu mentioned that Turkey is willing to cooperate with the Syrian Kurdish PYD group—linked to the PKK—if they do not pose a threat to Turkey and cut ties with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.
However, the airstrikes on the PKK in northern Iraq have effectively ended a two-year ceasefire.
Recently, Turkey has arrested hundreds of individuals suspected of supporting IS or the PKK.
Police raids targeting suspected IS and PKK members in Istanbul sparked three days of riots in the Gazi district, resulting in the deaths of a policeman and an activist.
The US has urged both Turkey and the PKK to avoid further violence and recognized Turkey's right to defend against Kurdish rebel attacks.

In a statement on Monday, the YPG reported that Turkish tanks shelled the Kurdish-held village of Zormikhar in Syria on Sunday evening, and later a Kurdish vehicle was "heavily fired upon by the Turkish military east of Kobane, in the village of Til Findire."
They stated, "Instead of targeting IS positions, Turkish forces are attacking our defenders. This approach is not appropriate."
Oliver Burke is far from your typical winger, and his rapid speed combined with his towering presence make him an extraordinary football talent at just 19 years old.
This season, he has become a regular starter under Nottingham Forest's new head coach, Philippe Montanier, rewarding the Frenchman with four goals.

Just days before seeking his third cap for Scotland as part of Gordon Strachan's squad for the World Cup qualifier in Malta, Burke has made a move to the German Bundesliga, with RB Leipzig acquiring him for £13m.
Here are five things to know about this young talent, who is expected to be the football star Scotland has long awaited.
Born in Kirkcaldy on April 7, 1997, Burke was raised in England and joined Nottingham Forest's youth academy at eight years old.
He signed a professional contract shortly before making his first-team debut as a late substitute under Stuart Pearce in a 3-1 Capital One Cup loss to Tottenham Hotspur on September 24, 2014.
A brief loan to Bradford City followed, contributing to a modest start to his career with appearances in two losses in English League One.
Upon his return to Forest, Burke gradually cemented his place in the first-team squad under fellow Scot Dougie Freedman last season.
With his muscular build and 6ft 2in frame, Burke could easily be mistaken for a rugby player rather than a footballer.
By December, when he netted his first Forest goal in a 1-1 draw against Cardiff City, he had overtaken his compatriot Chris Burke at the City Ground.
The elder Burke, previously with Rangers and other clubs, was on trial at Kilmarnock and later moved on loan to Rotherham United before his release at the season's end.

Despite Burke's frequent appearances from the bench—18 out of 31—Strachan called him into the Scotland squad for the first time in March, noting that it was a fortunate coincidence that Burke impressed while the coach was scouting another player, Tony Watt. Some wingers use speed, others rely on trickery, and some depend on power.
Medics, dressed in white gowns and surgical caps, are demanding that the government honor a 2013 agreement to raise their salaries.
During the strike, dozens of mental health patients reportedly walked out of a Nairobi hospital.
Officials argue the strike is premature, insisting that negotiations should continue.
They claim doctors are defying a court order suspending the strike until the end of the month to allow time for further discussions.
However, the Kenya Medical Practitioners, Pharmacists, and Dentists' Union (KMPDU) stated they have lost patience due to the government's unmet commitments.
"We've engaged in a lot of diplomacy and dialogue, but this must end," said union chairman Samuel Oroko.
Around 5,000 medical staff in over 2,000 public hospitals ceased work at midnight on Sunday, with hospitals unable to offer emergency services during the strike, the union claimed.
A BBC correspondent noted that this endangers thousands of lives, as many Kenyans can't afford private healthcare.
At a hospital in western Kenya, a Daily Nation reporter heard a nurse telling a laboring woman to seek help from the county governor.
In Kenya, counties are responsible for paying some medical staff. Amid the strike's turmoil, at least 50 mental health patients reportedly left Mathare hospital in Nairobi.
Video footage from the Standard newspaper showed patients scaling the hospital walls and walking away.
Medical staff are demanding the implementation of a 2013 agreement between their union and the government, which included a 300% pay raise for doctors.
The union also seeks to hire more doctors to improve the doctor-patient ratio, currently one doctor for over 16,000 Kenyans.
"We face a severe doctor shortage, yet our counties say they can't hire more," union representative Gitau Kagona told the Daily Nation.

"These challenges prevent good service delivery in hospitals." Some medical staff brought empty sacks to a strike kickoff event, alluding to money from a contentious government tender that a businesswoman allegedly took away in a sack.
They also launched a social media hashtag, #LipaKamaTender, meaning "pay like the tenders," suggesting their salaries should be paid as promptly as government tenders.
There have been protests and isolated strikes from medical practitioners over salary delays, but this is the first nationwide strike on this issue.
Pae Jun-ho, known in the US as Kenneth Bae, was accused by a Supreme Court spokesman of smuggling anti-government materials and plotting against the state, as reported by the state news agency KCNA.
The spokesman refuted claims that Mr. Bae was being used as a "political bargaining chip" with the US.
Mr. Bae was detained last year after entering North Korea as a tourist. In recent years, North Korea has arrested several US citizens, including journalists and Christians accused of proselytizing.
These individuals were released following interventions by high-profile Americans, including former Presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter, who both visited Pyongyang.

The court spokesman told KCNA that Mr. Bae was "sent to China as a missionary" where he established "plot-breeding bases" to infiltrate at least 250 students into the North Korean port city of Rason with the intention of destabilizing the government.
According to the spokesman, Mr. Bae encouraged overseas North Korean citizens and foreigners to undertake hostile actions to topple the government while conducting a smear campaign.
The spokesman said that Mr. Bae's full confession was why he avoided a potential death sentence, adding that his actions tarnished the dignity of North Korea's supreme leadership.
The spokesman also denied allegations that Mr. Bae's trial lacked transparency or that North Korea was using his case for political leverage.
Mr. Bae, 44, was arrested in November upon entering Rason, a special economic zone near the China-North Korea border.
South Korean activists suspect he was detained for photographing starving children, while other reports suggest he is a devout Christian.
His conviction on April 30 occurred during heightened tension between the US and North Korea after Pyongyang's third nuclear test.
The UN had expanded sanctions against Pyongyang in March following its February 12 nuclear test and December long-range rocket launch.
North Korea reacted angrily to both the sanctions and the annual US-South Korea military exercises, threatening US military bases and severing key communication lines with South Korea.

In an article published on Friday, MacKenzie controversially compared Everton midfielder Ross Barkley, whose grandfather was born in Nigeria, to a "gorilla" and remarked that men with similar salaries in Liverpool were often "drug dealers."
Merseyside Police are currently investigating if these comments amount to a "racial hate crime."
The Sun issued an apology for causing offense, stating they were "unaware of Barkley's heritage."
MacKenzie also emphasized this in his own statement, describing accusations of racism as "beyond parody."
The article, now removed from the Sun's website, originally featured images of Barkley alongside a gorilla with the caption insinuating a connection between them.

This picture was subsequently deleted. Barkley, 23, was recently assaulted in a Liverpool bar, in what his lawyer called an "unprovoked attack," prompting police investigation into the incident's details.
Liverpool Mayor Joe Anderson reported the article to the police for its "racial slur."
In conversation with BBC Sport, Anderson condemned the piece for reinforcing racial stereotypes about Liverpool and highlighted its racist undertones due to Barkley's mixed-race background.
Anderson stated on Twitter that he had spoken to Merseyside Police and informed the Independent Press Standards Organisation about the article.
In another tweet, he argued that "ignorance is no excuse" and claimed the apology was "simply inadequate."
He also criticized Everton's lack of response, urging them to ban Sun journalists from Goodison Park, which he called "a slap in the face to our city."
He encouraged fans at Saturday's Premier League game against Burnley to turn their backs on the pitch at 15:06 BST in protest.

MacKenzie was the editor of the Sun during its infamous 'Hillsborough: The Truth' front-page article, suggesting Liverpool fans were accountable for the 1989 tragedy at Sheffield Wednesday's stadium, where 96 people died.
MacKenzie apologized for this in 2012, and last year's Hillsborough inquests confirmed the 96 fans were unlawfully killed, exonerating Liverpool supporters in causing the disaster.

This Saturday, 15 April, marks 28 years since the tragedy. Burnley midfielder Joey Barton, formerly of Everton, tweeted that MacKenzie's comments about Barkley, "a young working-class lad," were appalling, especially considering his mixed-race heritage.

Prince William's last shift reportedly occurred on Tuesday. It's speculated that he might return to his regiment in London, the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals, which would enable him to undertake more royal duties in support of The Queen.
The duke described the island as a "special place" for him, marking the end of a three-year assignment on Anglesey.
During a speech at Anglesey Show in August, the duke expressed gratitude to the island's residents for their warm welcome to him and his wife.
"I speak for Catherine when I say that I've never known anywhere as beautiful and welcoming as Anglesey," he stated.
"Both of us will miss it dearly when my search and rescue tour concludes next month and we relocate.
From the depths of my heart, thank you for making my wife and me feel welcome, just as you do for thousands of visitors annually."
He mentioned the island was their first home together and would forever hold a special place in their hearts.
"Catherine and I look forward to returning repeatedly with our family in the coming years," he added.
The duke qualified as a search and rescue pilot in September 2010 after starting his training at Valley in January of that year.
He conducted his first rescue in October 2010 during his initial full operational shift.
The BBC's royal correspondent, Peter Hunt, tweeted that Prince William's final shift at RAF Valley took place on Tuesday and noted that the duke's next steps hadn't yet been disclosed publicly.
The text discusses the pardon of Alan Turing, who was convicted of gross indecency in 1952 and subsequently underwent chemical castration.
His arrest followed an affair with a 19-year-old man in Manchester, resulting in the loss of his security clearance and his vital codebreaking work for the Allies during World War Two.
The pardon, granted through the Royal Prerogative of Mercy at the behest of Justice Minister Chris Grayling, honors Turing's exceptional contributions.
Grayling remarked that Turing's research at Bletchley Park during the war significantly shortened the conflict and saved countless lives.
In 2012, events celebrating Turing's legacy were held to commemorate the 100th anniversary of his birth.
Turing's work enabled the Allies to decipher German Naval communications encrypted by the Enigma machine and made foundational contributions to codebreaking, unveiled to the public in April 2012.

Grayling noted that Turing's life was marred by his conviction for homosexual acts, now seen as unjust and discriminatory, emphasizing Turing's deserving recognition for his wartime efforts and scientific legacy.

The Queen's pardon, effective December 24, serves as a fitting tribute. Turing's death in June 1954 from cyanide poisoning was ruled a suicide, though some biographers and friends contest this, suggesting it may have been an accident.
Proponents have advocated for Turing's pardon for years, including Dr. Sue Black, whose campaign included calls for pardoning all men convicted under the anti-homosexuality laws.
She expressed hope for broader positive changes, condemning the mistreatment of many individuals.

Critics argue the pardon is insufficient and merely symbolic, with British home computing pioneer Sir Clive Sinclair labeling it "silly nonsense," despite acknowledging the wrongful treatment of such a remarkable man.
Students reported an error in the multiple-choice questions, which resulted in two valid answers being possible.
As a result, officials decided to accept both answers as correct, and the national exam board's head has offered to resign.
This annual test is crucial as it determines high school students' academic futures.
South Korean media reported that the error could impact the scores of approximately 3,600 to 4,000 students.
Education Minister Hwang Woo-Yea, in a televised statement, expressed deep regret and acknowledged the urgent need to improve the question-making process.

"We will investigate the root cause of the problem," he affirmed. Around 640,000 students took the nine-hour College Scholastic Ability Test on November 13 at 1,216 locations nationwide, according to South Korea's Yonhap news agency.
Many students prepare for years in a highly competitive academic setting, often with significant parental involvement, as a good score secures admission to top universities in South Korea.

The flawed questions in the biology and English sections caused an uproar, leading to complaints from parents and students on the Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation (KICE) website, which oversees the exam.
Controversy also surrounded last year's exam due to a mistake in a world geology question.
After a lengthy legal dispute, the Seoul High Court sided with four students challenging that question.
"We tried our best this year to avoid errors, but once again, flawed questions have caused confusion and inconvenience for students, parents, and teachers," said Kim Sung-Hoon, head of KICE.
In 2014, a report from the public protector concluded that Mr. Zuma "benefited unduly" from upgrades to his residence.
He suggested that the auditor-general and finance minister should decide how much he should repay to resolve the issue.
This announcement comes a week before a constitutional court hearing on the matter.
Africa Live: BBC News Updates The expansion of President Zuma's Nkandla home in KwaZulu-Natal has escalated into a significant political scandal in South Africa.

Funds were used for an amphitheater, swimming pool, and cattle enclosure. Despite the president's latest offer, the opposition Democratic Alliance (DA) and Julius Malema's Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF), who have demanded a corruption probe, are pursuing their court case.
Following Mr. Zuma's announcement, #PayBackTheMoney is trending in South Africa—a slogan EFF MPs famously shouted at the president in parliament last year.

Many commentators remain skeptical. Analysis by Milton Nkosi, BBC News President Jacob Zuma's willingness to repay the funds allocated for the Nkandla upgrades may be a strategic move to avoid embarrassment at the impending Constitutional Court hearing.

It may also relate to the upcoming local government election. The Nkandla scandal has been troubling for the ruling African National Congress (ANC) under Zuma's leadership, as party members campaign for votes.

Political analyst Professor Somadoda Fikeni suggests this could be due to the president's political vulnerability as he enters his 'lame-duck' period, following the controversial appointment of finance ministers last year.

There's also the possibility that Mr. Zuma aims to prevent a repeat of chaotic scenes during last year's parliamentary opening, when EFF members disrupted his state of the nation address, chanting "pay back the money."
Security had to intervene to remove persistently shouting MPs as Mr. Zuma attempted to continue his speech.
Punches at the South Africa Parliament Why did Zuma sack two finance ministers in a week? All figures in 2013 financial terms Source: Public Protector Report
Colin Green, a professor specializing in water economics, asserts that Thames Water could earn at least £100 million annually if they proceed with the project.
The utility company advocates for the tunnel as the optimal solution to prevent sewage discharge into the River Thames.
A spokesman for Thames Water emphasized that the tunnel represents the most cost-effective method to address the issue, though no decision regarding project financing has been finalized.
According to Prof. Green of Middlesex University, current industry regulations allow Thames Water to earn a 4.5% annual return on their super sewer investment.
He suggests, however, that the firm could borrow the necessary funds at around 2% per year.
"To alter this situation, we need to revise the price incentives," Prof. Green noted.
The professor criticized the regulatory framework overseen by Ofwat for encouraging financial investment rather than operational efficiency.

Thames Water's spokesman explained, "Extensive studies led by independent experts have identified the Thames Tunnel as the most economical solution for managing the 39 million tonnes of sewage overflowing into the Thames each year.

The decision on who will finance and construct the tunnel remains unresolved, and it is not guaranteed that Thames Water will take on this role. The investor's rate of return will be independently set by Ofwat."
Prof. Green further claimed that Thames Water's returns would increase once the tunnel's construction loan is repaid, although this might take 30 to 40 years.
He stated, "Even after the loans are repaid, consumers will continue to fund the full capital value of the asset, resulting in a 14% return for Thames Water based solely on the tunnel."

An Ofwat representative commented, "We are collaborating with Thames Water, Defra, and other stakeholders to support the Thames Tunnel's development and financing, ensuring costs are managed efficiently and offer customer value."
Meanwhile, Hammersmith and Fulham Council have advocated for a cheaper solution to London's sewage issue, such as a shorter tunnel.
Councillor Harry Phibbs remarked, "While this aligns with regulations, the company is able to charge customers a much higher rate for borrowed funds than they themselves incur."
In a rare interview, General Petraeus discussed the challenges of handling "industrial-strength" extremists and emphasized that relying solely on military force is insufficient.

Known for his role in the Iraq war, he developed the "surge" strategy that increased US troop numbers and gained support from Sunni tribesmen against al-Qaeda. Now, Iraq's US-backed army is fighting to reclaim territory taken by IS.
Petraeus calls IS "a formidable enemy," describing it as a conventional army with elements of insurgency and significant terrorist components.
Petraeus compared IS to al-Qaeda in Iraq, a group he was key in defeating, noting al-Qaeda had deeper roots and larger numbers in Iraq than IS.
He referred to IS's recent capture of Ramadi, Anbar province’s capital, as "a strategic loss," undermining the narrative of IS being on the defensive.
However, he believes Ramadi will be regained in weeks or less. He stated that this setback calls for strategic reassessment and enhancements, which are already underway.

Career highlights: - 1974: Graduated from West Point, joined the army - 2007: Led US troop surge during Iraq war - 2008: Head of US Central Command - 2010: NATO commander in Afghanistan - Mid-2011: Left military to become CIA director - November 2012: Resigned over an affair After commanding international forces in Iraq and Afghanistan, Petraeus led the CIA, stepping down in 2012 due to revelations of an extramarital affair.
Allegations he provided classified information to his mistress resulted in a guilty plea to a misdemeanor charge.
Despite these personal setbacks, Petraeus remains a notable figure in America’s recent military operations.
He masterminded the "surge," shifting US troops from compounds to local areas to improve security.
He also expanded the Anbar Awakening, mobilizing Sunni tribesmen against al-Qaeda.
In the face of recent challenges in Iraq, the White House, the Pentagon, and Capitol Hill are seeking his insights.
Petraeus continues to advocate for synchronizing political and military strategies.
NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg remarked that Russia and NATO "disagree on the facts, the narrative, and the responsibilities" regarding Ukraine.
Tensions between Russia and the West have been ongoing since Russia annexed Crimea in 2014.
Additionally, Russia’s envoy criticized NATO for conducting a military exercise in the Baltic.
Talks in Brussels on Wednesday exceeded their scheduled duration by over 90 minutes.
Stoltenberg noted at a press conference, "Many NATO allies dispute Russia's characterization of the Ukraine conflict as a civil war."
He emphasized, "This is Russia destabilizing eastern Ukraine, supporting separatists with munitions, funding, equipment, and command and control."
He further stated, "NATO and Russia hold deep and ongoing differences, and today's meeting did not resolve them."
Stoltenberg highlighted the importance of maintaining open communication channels "to discuss our differences and lower the risk of military incidents."
Both sides agreed on the importance of enforcing the Minsk peace agreement, which has led to a fragile ceasefire in eastern Ukraine.
Russia's NATO envoy, Alexander Grushko, accused the U.S. of exerting military pressure by sailing a guided-missile destroyer near the Russian port of Kaliningrad last week.
"We will take all necessary steps to counter these military threats," he stated.
During last week's incident, two Russian warplanes repeatedly approached the U.S. destroyer in international waters of the Baltic Sea, an action deemed "aggressive" by U.S. officials.
The NATO-Russia Council, established in 2002, has not held ambassadorial-level meetings since June 2014, though other political dialogues have occurred.
Ukraine and the West suspect Russia of covertly supporting the rebels controlling much of eastern Ukraine, a claim Russia vehemently denies.
In response, NATO has strengthened its military presence in Eastern European member states to counter what it perceives as a Russian military buildup.
Russia views NATO's growing presence in Eastern Europe as a threat to its national security.
The Senate's 61-38 vote on the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities fell short of the two-thirds majority needed for ratification.
Former Senator Bob Dole, a disabled Republican presidential candidate who uses a wheelchair, showed his support by appearing on the Senate floor.
The treaty was signed by 155 nations and ratified by 126, including the UK, France, Germany, China, and Russia, and aims to ensure equal rights and freedoms for disabled individuals worldwide.
Bob Dole, who was disabled in World War II, along with Senators John McCain of Arizona and Richard Lugar of Indiana, and former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh supported the treaty.

Despite this, only eight Republican senators voted in favor, with others like Oklahoma Senator Jim Inhofe opposing it due to concerns about increased regulation and potential bias from international organizations.

The White House expressed disappointment at the Republican majority's opposition, noting that ratifying the treaty would help extend internationally the rights Americans with disabilities already enjoy, benefiting those who live or travel abroad.
Massachusetts Senator John Kerry emphasized that the treaty is straightforward, merely stating that discrimination against the disabled is unacceptable.
Supporters argued that ratifying the treaty would not require changes to U.S. law, as it is based on the 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act.
This act was the foundation for the UN treaty, negotiated during the George W. Bush administration and signed by President Obama in 2009.
According to UN estimates, about 10% of the world's population, or 650 million people, are disabled.
The Court of Appeal was informed that the Cambridge history student understood the "significance" of the monument but did not realize he was hanging from a war memorial.
Gilmour, a resident of Billingshurst, West Sussex, was sentenced to 16 months in prison for violent disorder in July.
The 21-year-old is appealing his sentence. The judges heard that Gilmour had taken LSD and Valium before participating in the central London protests against tuition fee hikes last December.
He was seen hanging from a Union flag on the Cenotaph and jumping onto the bonnet of a Jaguar that was part of a royal convoy.
A previous ruling by a judge at Kingston-upon-Thames Crown Court found that he had thrown a rubbish bin at the vehicle, a decision his lawyers are contesting in the appeal.

Although the crown court judge acknowledged that the incident at the Cenotaph was not part of the violent disorder, he called it "outrageous and deeply offensive behavior.” During his spree, Gilmour also kicked the window of Topshop's flagship store on Oxford Street and ended the day with a mannequin's leg.

Gilmour's defense lawyer, David Spens QC, argued his client was unaware of the appearance of the Cenotaph and noted his client's lack of a television for 10 years, making this oversight "not actually as surprising as might have been thought."
The court was told Gilmour had resorted to alcohol and drugs after being rejected by his biological father, writer Heathcote Williams.
Mr. Spens stated that Gilmour has "successfully reformed and rehabilitated himself,” addressing his "underlying drug and alcohol problems."
He argued, "My submission is that this sentence was unduly harsh, unnecessarily so."
The court has reserved judgment pending other Court of Appeal rulings related to the August riots, which could impact Gilmour's case.
After a recent reassessment, some have experienced tax increases as high as 900%, a situation many are calling "ridiculous."
This hike means nearly all profits from some energy schemes are being turned over to councils, leading some to operate at a loss, according to BBC Wales.

Aware of the issue, the Welsh Government is contemplating specific assistance. However, the British Hydropower Association has criticized ministers for inaction, and Community Energy Wales remarked that these changes are severely damaging projects.
Typically small and volunteer-run, community energy schemes generate local income.
However, the method for calculating business rates is disproportionately affecting hydro schemes.
These rates in England and Wales are determined by the Valuation Office Agency, with the Welsh Government controlling the rates' implementation in Wales.
The British Hydropower Association has requested support from Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford.
Simon Hamlyn, the chief executive, stated that community hydro schemes are struggling, and businesses might abandon them due to unaffordable rates, which is a scenario they want to avoid.
Keith Jones, director of Community Energy Wales, noted a typical increase of 300%, adding that they hadn’t foreseen such a drastic financial tool in their business plans.
Meanwhile, the Scottish government has offered 100% business rates relief for community energy schemes, and England has capped the increase at £600.
Gavin Gatehouse, involved with the Ynni Anafon hydro scheme in Abergwyngregyn, Gwynedd, says their monthly rate has jumped from around £900 to over £2,000.
The project, which took five years to establish, could generate up to £40,000 in annual income for regional initiatives.
A charity was established to provide grants, but this increase limits available funds. The Bethesda community hydro scheme also anticipates losses.
"It's very frustrating and I'm very angry about it," Mr. Gatehouse expressed. "Our profits are being drastically reduced to compensate for insufficient government grants to local authorities."
Mr. Drakeford noted that over £210 million in rate relief was allocated for 2017-18 to support businesses, including community energy projects.
He also mentioned plans to develop a new small business rate relief scheme starting in 2018.
On Monday evening in Bridport, Dorset, she announced her new role at the charity screening of the show's final episode organized by Dorset Rape Crisis.
Hesmondhalgh expressed pride in having "given a voice" to rape victims through the eight-part crime series.

The charity was "excited" about her accepting the position. The third and final series of Broadchurch, partially shot in West Bay, centered on the rape of Trish Winterman, played by former Coronation Street actress Hesmondhalgh.
One of the show’s highlights is Trish's relationship with her rape counselor, Beth Latimer, portrayed by Jodie Whittaker.

Tracy Parsons from Dorset Rape Crisis, which collaborated closely with Broadchurch's writer and producer Chris Chibnall, commented that the series demonstrated significant support for people dealing with the aftermath of rape.
"We're thrilled that Julie has agreed to be our patron; it's a tremendous boost for our trustees, staff, and clients to have such a well-known figure involved," Parsons noted.
Hesmondhalgh remarked, "It's a relief to have offered a voice—even in a small way—to those who have experienced rape."
Regarding her new role as patron of Dorset Rape Crisis, she said, "I am proud to help elevate awareness of those doing essential, impactful work."
She described rape as an urgent issue, emphasizing the need for conversations at home with family about consent, respect, and healthy sexual relationships.
After the birth of their first son, Dylan, she was met not with congratulations, but with the news: "We're sorry, your son has Down’s syndrome."
Despite her nursing background and her husband’s experience as a doctor, the negative information they received was overwhelming.

"When you have a child with a disability like Down’s syndrome, they tell you about the average life expectancy of 50, that they won't attend mainstream school, and all the things they won't do," she explained.
Fourteen years on, Dylan has surpassed these expectations. He's thriving in Year 9 at a mainstream school and has joined the Down’s Syndrome GB swimming squad.
This initial lack of support inspired his mother and two others to take action.

While Dylan was a toddler, a health visitor introduced his mother to Katharina Barker and Nicky Williams, who also had children with Down’s syndrome. They realized they shared similar experiences of inadequate support.
Though Katharina had a positive experience with her daughter Amelie’s birth, finding specialist support was difficult.
"It’s frustrating," she said, "because unless someone shows you where to go, you won’t find the services."
To address this, they organized a coffee morning for parents of children with Down’s syndrome to connect and share experiences.
Its success led them to establish a charity providing speech and language therapy, educational support, and annual conferences.
Though Nicky has since stepped down from the Monmouth-based 21 Plus charity, now celebrating its 10th anniversary, Victoria and Katharina are committed to expanding its reach.
Their dedication earned them a finalist spot in the national St David Awards citizenship category.
They aim to help children with Down’s syndrome "achieve their potential and access more opportunities."
"One of the moms told me she loves being able to ask us anything, even questions she’d feel silly asking elsewhere," Victoria said. "That’s why I do it."
Albert Newman drove 30 miles in the wrong direction on the M42, A42, and M1 before crashing into a van.
During an inquest, it was revealed that one police force had no motorway patrols on duty and another had previously failed to recognize that Mr. Newman’s license had been revoked.
The coroner postponed the hearing so officers could answer additional questions.

Mr. Newman, a dementia patient from Nottingham, collided his Mazda Premacy with a Transit van near Kegworth, Leicestershire, in October last year, resulting in the death of passenger Michael Luciw and injuring driver Andy Harrington.
The inquest learned that Warwickshire police first received the call about a car moving the wrong way on the M42, but officers initially recorded the wrong direction.

The error was corrected, but Mr. Newman crossed into Leicestershire on the A42, where the specialized roads policing unit had already finished its shift, leaving the county without specialist motorway patrols.
Pamela Oxlade, traveling to Birmingham Airport with her husband, told the inquest: "We had just passed a lorry when suddenly there were two balls of light.
It was incredibly quick and surreal because the car outline was invisible in the dark.
I dialed 999 and explained what happened, and the person indicated they were already aware.
We mentioned we were about half an hour from the M1 heading towards Birmingham.
It was a huge relief to know they were aware." The inquest revealed that about 20 minutes later, Mrs. Oxlade saw signs warning drivers to slow down due to a car moving in the wrong direction.
Coroner Trevor Kirkman commented on Leicestershire police’s role, stating, "It appears the procedure is not functioning very well.

This vehicle traveled a long distance without intervention." At the Loughborough hearing, it was uncovered that Nottinghamshire Police talked to Mr. Newman months before the crash following reports of him driving with signs of dementia.
An officer failed to verify the paperwork, which would have shown his license had been revoked for medical reasons two years prior.
Mr. Kirkman adjourned the hearing until December to determine if the force could have confiscated the car then.
At the conclusion, a senior officer from Nottinghamshire police apologized to the families, acknowledging any possibility the force could have prevented the tragedy.
Today, we often envision new inventions emerging from anonymous laboratories following extensive grant applications.

However, the era of the home-grown inventor might still thrive. David Williams and John Dingley, consultant anesthetists at Morriston Hospital in Swansea, experienced their eureka moment while tinkering in their garages with glue guns and car-body filler.
Inspired by Trevor Baylis's wind-up radio, they joked about creating something similarly economical and user-friendly for the medical field.
Given Dr. Williams’s experience in remote areas, he recognized the importance of equipment that functions independently of constant power sources.
In Zambia, he saw entire operating theaters unused due to a lack of spare light bulbs or reliable power.
Motivated by this, they aimed to invent essential medical tools within a tight budget.

After a week of modifying conventional medical equipment with power tools, they created the ShakerScope prototype—a light source adaptable for examining the eyes, ears, and throat, without the need for batteries.
Dr. Patrick Finlay of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers remarked, "According to the World Health Organization, 95% of medical devices fail in developing countries.
Designers in the West often overlook global conditions. This kind of invention is essential.
Normally, you need three different battery-powered instruments for such exams. For low-income countries, this is impractical."
The ShakerScope operates with a powerful movable magnet surrounded by a wire coil.
As Michael Faraday discovered in 1831, moving the magnet induces an electric current in the coil.
Shaking the ShakerScope for 30 seconds generates enough current to light the device for three minutes.
"While this may seem brief, it's adequate for most ear and eye exams or inserting tracheal tubes," Dr. Williams stated.
Once charged, the device can maintain its power for weeks, and its light-emitting diode lasts up to 10,000 hours.
The team also designed interchangeable heads, enabling conversion into multiple devices.
Former MK Dons midfielder Carl Baker scored on his debut to secure a point for Portsmouth, equalizing after Reggie Lambe's goal put Carlisle ahead.
The Cumbrians played with a man down after Jamie Devitt received a red card before half-time.
Portsmouth started strong, with new signing Milan Lalkovic forcing Carlisle's goalkeeper Mark Gillespie into a fine save within the first five minutes.
However, just five minutes later, Mike Jones sent a precise pass to Lambe, who calmly beat goalkeeper David Forde to give the away side the lead.
Carlisle's Devitt was ejected near the half-hour mark for a second yellow card after pulling Gary Roberts.

Before halftime, Baker leveled the match with a low drive past Gillespie. Early in the second half, Michael Smith missed an open goal for Portsmouth, while Roberts and substitute Kyle Bennett squandered late opportunities.

The Press Association reports the match concluded in a 1-1 draw. In the second half, Carl Baker's shot from the center of the box missed to the right, and David Atkinson replaced Carlisle's Jason Kennedy.
Baker earned a free kick in the attacking half due to Luke Joyce's foul. Bennett's shot from outside the box was blocked, and Baker's next attempt was too high.
A corner, conceded by Gillespie, led to Michael Doyle's shot being saved in the bottom corner.
Bennett's left-foot attempt missed left, and Baker's was saved in the bottom corner.
Noel Hunt substituted for Danny Rose, and Baker won a defensive free kick after Danny Grainger's foul.
Michael Doyle fouled, granting Nicky Adams a free kick. Bennett's shot was saved in the bottom corner.
Rose hit the post with a left-foot strike. Gillespie received a yellow card, and Rose's next shot came close but missed right.
Mark Ellis replaced Shaun Miller for Carlisle. Bennett's final right-foot shot missed to the right.
Portsmouth substituted Conor Chaplin for Michael Smith, and Bennett came in for Lalkovic.
Phil Collins, 66, experienced a severe injury near his eye from a fall on his way to the bathroom.
Following his back surgery, he has difficulty walking, which led to the incident.
He received stitches at the hospital and will be under observation for 24 hours.

His scheduled performances on June 8 and 9 have been rescheduled to November. As the postponement was announced just hours before he was set to perform, some fans were already traveling to London when they got the news.
One fan expressed on Facebook: "Sorry to hear that ... but we are on a train heading to see him.
#gutted .... no idea what to do now ðŸ˜¢." Another fan, who attended Wednesday's concert, commented: "Amazing night last night!!!
What a fantastic fan base you have. Get well very soon xxxxxxxx." His management mentioned on Facebook that Collins struck his head on a chair during the fall but is "recovering well."
Besides expressing "sincere apologies and thanks to fans," the singer, whose condition is termed "drop foot," noted he's had a "fantastic week at his first shows in 10 years."
He expressed gratitude for the warm reception and anticipation for his return. Tickets for the June 8 show will be valid on November 26, and those for June 9 will be good for November 27.
Collins is set to continue his tour with the next stop on Sunday in Cologne, followed by Paris, before headlining BST Hyde Park in London on June 30.
Known for his work with the prog-rock band Genesis, Collins is a highly successful songwriter and performer.
He is among the elite three artists, alongside Paul McCartney and Michael Jackson, to have sold over 100 million albums worldwide as both solo artists and band members.
His chart-topping hits include "A Groovy Kind of Love" and "Against All Odds." Collins has earned seven Grammy Awards, six Brit Awards, an Oscar, and two Golden Globes.
