The University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust received an "inadequate" rating after an inspection by the Care Quality Commission (CQC).
The Royal Lancaster Infirmary and Furness General Hospital in Barrow were pinpointed for needing better quality care.
The trust stated it is "part-way through a process of significant improvement."

Last year, the North Cumbria University Hospitals Trust, covering the northern part of the county, was one of 11 trusts placed in special measures due to the Keogh review, which found higher than average mortality rates.
The CQC's February inspection noted some improvements in services like maternity and A&E, but other concerns remain unaddressed.
Particularly concerning was the medical care in one section of the Royal Lancaster.
The overall recruitment of nurses and doctors is a "fundamental" issue, as there is "too much reliance" on temporary staff.
According to Professor Sir Mike Richards, chief inspector of hospitals, "The trust has a long history of quality issues, so it is disappointing that many issues are still unresolved.
I do not believe the trust will overcome its challenges without external support."
In addition to the hospitals in Barrow and Lancaster, inspectors visited Westmorland General Hospital near Kendal, which was deemed to be providing a good service overall.
The trust's chief executive, Jackie Daniel, acknowledged, "The reports show we are in the midst of significant improvement, which will take several years to complete.
Changing the culture of a large, complex organization is not an overnight task." Detailed inspection reports are available on the CQC website.
At Detroit Metro Airport, the wing of an American Airlines plane collided with the tail of a Southwest Airlines plane while both were taxiing.
The incident occurred on Wednesday at 06:05 local time (11:05 GMT). Passengers remained aboard, with no reported injuries or fuel leaks.
The Federal Aviation Administration announced it would investigate the matter. Passenger Fletcher Sharpe, speaking to the BBC from the airport, expressed frustration as he awaited a new flight.
He recalled that some passengers noted the planes were unusually close, but he didn’t expect a collision until it happened.
"Suddenly, we heard a loud crunch and scraping," he said. "I thought something had been run over.
I saw the American plane’s right wing was damaged and the Southwest plane’s tail was broken off.
It felt frustrating. I understand it's a high-pressure job, but ensuring enough clearance is basic, something learned even when driving a car."
Another passenger, Jim Bishop, told Fox 2 News Detroit about two and a half hours of waiting with minimal initial information.
"There was silence for ten minutes," he said. "Eventually, an announcement acknowledged an accident and urged calm.
A steward explained that in his 35 years, he had never experienced this before."
The temperature was below freezing, and the Southwest plane was being de-iced at the time of the accident.
Both involved aircraft were Boeing 737s. Southwest Airlines stated the affected plane required maintenance and was scheduled for a Dallas flight, with 95 passengers being rebooked.
The airline expressed gratitude for passengers’ patience while working to get them to their destinations.
American Airlines also apologized for the inconvenience, ensuring their 150 Dallas-bound passengers were rebooked on other flights.
Margaret Thatcher passed away peacefully at the age of 87 on Monday, April 8, 2013.
Her ceremonial funeral with full military honors took place on April 17. From the moment she became prime minister, Thatcher sparked debate.
Upon coming to power in 1979, she aimed for significant changes in the nation's governance, leading to a profound transformation of Britain.

One of her major initiatives was shifting control of government-owned entities like British Gas and BT (British Telecom) to private companies, believing they would manage these services more efficiently.
She enabled thousands of ordinary people to purchase their council homes, giving them a greater stake in society.
Her leadership helped the City of London emerge as a global hub for banking and business.
Thatcher became a hero when she dispatched British troops to defend the Falklands Islands in 1982, after Argentina invaded the tiny archipelago located 8,000 miles away in the South Atlantic.
Although the conflict resulted in hundreds of casualties, the victory was celebrated back home.
However, despite considerable support, some of Thatcher's policies were highly controversial, leading to protests and riots.
In 1984, thousands of miners opposed her plans to close numerous coal mines and eliminate many jobs by protesting continuously for a year.
Similarly, in 1990, the introduction of the poll tax led to clashes in London, as critics argued it disproportionately affected the poor rather than the wealthy.
Thatcher, famously known as the "Iron Lady" for her resilience and firm decision-making, reportedly survived on just four hours of sleep a night.
Her life story was brought to the silver screen in 2012 with the movie "The Iron Lady."
After 11 years in power and winning three elections, Thatcher was the longest-serving prime minister of the 20th century.
Despite her success, even her party eventually felt she overstayed her leadership, leading to her emotional departure from Downing Street.
More than 20 years later, she is remembered as a prime minister who reshaped Britain profoundly and stands as one of the most significant figures in modern British history.
She expressed confidence that the Games would bring "honor and pride" to the nation.
Ms. Rousseff, whose popularity has plummeted amid a severe economic downturn, assured that the country would rise to the occasion and organize a safe and successful Olympic event.
She mentioned that 12,000 individuals would be selected to carry the Olympic torch through around 300 cities across Brazil next year.

"We are currently 399 days away from the Olympic Games opening, and on August 5, the world will turn its eyes on us and witness the lighting of the Olympic flame," Ms. Rousseff stated during a ceremony in Brasilia.
The torch relay, commencing in the capital in May, will conclude at Rio's Maracana stadium in August during the Olympics' opening event.
Torchbearers will be chosen by the organizing committee alongside sponsors in the coming months, with each person bearing the torch for 300 meters.
The relay will cover the Federal District, home to Brasilia, and traverse 26 states over a span of 90 to 100 days.
Ms. Rousseff emphasized that security would be paramount, inviting thousands of fans who visited Brazil for the World Cup to return for the Rio Games.
Concerns have arisen from the International Olympic Committee about delays in preparation, as well as pollution in Guanabara Bay where sailing and windsurfing events will occur.
Authorities acknowledge athletes' worries but maintain that water pollution will not pose significant health risks during the Games in August 2016.
"We are confident that we can meet the challenges ahead," Ms. Rousseff declared.
"We will deliver a historic Olympics." This event marks Rio de Janeiro as the first South American city to host the Olympics.
On October 1 last year, a 33ft (10m) deep sinkhole emerged at Fontmell Close, St Albans, a location previously used as a clay pit.
Due to investigations into its cause, some homes still lack utility services and the road remains closed.

Hertfordshire County Council aims to complete repairs by Christmas. Following the hole's sudden formation in the early hours, over 50 families were left without power, water, or sanitation until temporary solutions were arranged for most of them.

Residents continue to rely on a temporary road through a nearby heath. A thorough microgravity survey and exploratory drilling revealed that the hole resulted from old mine workings, with a ground subsidence report indicating no significant additional voids.
Councillor Terry Douris expressed: "We had to determine the collapse's cause before initiating repairs.
This has been highly stressful for residents, and it would be wonderful for them to be safely home by Christmas."
Ben Bagshawe, who evacuated alongside his heavily pregnant wife, welcomed their baby boy a week later.
They've been renting a flat for the past year with the costs covered by his insurance.

"It's been frustrating but not catastrophic," he commented. Rosemary and Derek Broom, residing closest to the hole, have stayed in their house and believe the road is now "the safest place to live in the country."
Mrs. Broom explained, "Everything—the roads, fields, children's play area—has been so thoroughly surveyed that we don't feel worried at all."
In 1943, the fleet's senior medical officer compiled the book as a ninth birthday gift for his son.
Among the autographs is Flt Cdr Henry Melvin "Dinghy" Young, second in command during the raid, who was killed when he was shot down on his return.

The book was later sold in Newark, Nottinghamshire by the seller whose father had collected the signatures at the RAF base in Scampton, Lincolnshire, where Squadron 617, known as the Dambusters, was formed in March 1943.
Using Barnes Wallis' bouncing bomb, bombing raids targeted three major dams in Germany's industrial Ruhr Valley in May, resulting in the loss of eight out of the 19 planes deployed.
Henry Young, nicknamed "Dinghy" due to his survival of two sea crashes in an inflatable boat, piloted an Avro Lancaster called A-Apple during the first wave, which attacked the Möhne Dam.

Signatures also include those from other squadrons at Scampton, such as Gp Capt Robert McFarlane, who later led a Lancaster Bomber squadron during the Battle of Berlin, and Flying Officer Chas Walker, an Australian cricketer who was killed in action in December 1942.

Some signatures are accompanied by illustrations, like a detailed drawing of a Lancaster in flight, a kangaroo by an Australian airman, and two cartoon airmen with the caption "Jolly good show, what?!".
James Brown, who sold the album, also offered a silk map salvaged from a burnt-out Lancaster bomber and his father's official commission as a flying officer.
Chapman's Ice Cream proposed purchasing Beavercrest Community School in Markdale for around CA$1 million ($741,000; £596,000), recognizing the community's role in their development.

Vice-president Ashley Chapman told the BBC that despite challenges like regulations and asbestos, the company aims to collaborate with the school board and partly fund solutions. "Someone needs to step up and help resolve the situation," he stated.
Chapman suggested buying the structure and leasing it back to the school board at an affordable rate to keep it operational.
However, the aging building might demand millions in repairs, and legal constraints make private purchase of public assets complex.
"Our proposal was essentially a stopgap to postpone the closure," he explained.
Beavercrest is one of roughly 600 schools set for closure by the province to cut costs, mostly affecting rural areas.
Should Beavercrest shut, local children might face up to 90 minutes on a bus to reach other schools.
The school currently serves 195 students but can accommodate 319, according to a recent school board report.
Chapman emphasized that changes should prioritize student welfare. Being a Beavercrest alumnus, he believes helping is both ethical and a wise business move.
Founded by his parents in 1973, Chapman's Ice Cream is among Canada's largest producers and has doubled its workforce over the past six years, with plans for further expansion.
The company needs to draw talent to Markdale, a small town of 1,325 residents, but finds this challenging despite increased wages.
"How can we attract new people if there's no elementary school here?" Chapman asked.
In a series of Tuesday morning tweets, the president described any release of intelligence information as a strategic effort to further U.S. national security priorities.
Later that day, National Security Adviser HR McMaster defended Mr. Trump's actions as "wholly appropriate" during a press conference.
This was indeed the most effective response, given the president's broad authority to declassify information at his discretion.
As the old Richard Nixon quote suggests, "When the president does it, that means it is not illegal."
However, the president’s justification doesn’t make the issue disappear, and a Twitter statement alone won’t quell the controversy.

Here are five reasons why. Let’s address the impeachment topic first. After the Washington Post reported the allegations, some of Mr. Trump’s fiercest critics accused him of "treason" and demanded his immediate removal from office.

Although casually disclosing highly classified intelligence due to ignorance or boastfulness might not be a criminal offense, it could spark a political scandal that, worst-case scenario for the president, could lead to impeachment.
The process, defined in the U.S. Constitution as for "high crimes and misdemeanors," is inherently political.
A simple House majority can impeach, which sets off a Senate trial requiring a two-thirds vote for removal.

As highlighted by the writers of Lawfare Blog, Mr. Trump’s critics could accuse him of violating his oath to "preserve, protect, and defend" the U.S. Constitution—an inclusive category invoked in the three prior serious presidential impeachment efforts.
Though possible, it isn’t inevitable, as it hinges on politics, not law—and on how the story progresses.
Some in the Trump White House might be echoing Indiana Jones’ famous lament: "Russians.
Why did it have to be the Russians?" Claims of overly close ties with America's geopolitical rival have dogged Mr. Trump since his presidential campaign began.

He has faced scrutiny over his praise for President Vladimir Putin, some aides are involved in the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election, his attorney general recused himself over an undisclosed meeting with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, and his first national security adviser was dismissed for misleading about his Russian connections (and is now under FBI investigation).
Scientists and charities emphasize that the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine can protect against head and neck cancers.
HPV is transmitted sexually, and girls aged 12 and 13 receive this vaccine to guard against cervical cancer.
The Welsh government is currently awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.
Organizations such as Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team plan to send a letter to the Welsh government on Monday advocating for broader vaccination coverage.
They reported on BBC Radio Wales' Eye on Wales program that head and neck cancer cases are on the rise.
Dr. Mererid Evans, a consultant oncologist at Velindre Hospital in Cardiff, noted, "I've observed a shift in demographics over the past decade.
These affected individuals are mostly younger men with families, and the average age is 55, with most being non-smokers."
Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care stated, "HPV accounts for 5% of the global cancer burden.
The Welsh government should take a proactive step to combat these cancers and demonstrate its commitment to public health.
We urge them to break from conventional thinking and start vaccinating boys now."
Since 2008, a school vaccination program has resulted in 85% of Welsh girls being vaccinated.
The Welsh government commented, "We will await the committee's recommendations and will review any proposed changes to the HPV vaccination program in Wales."
Mrs. Morgan has initiated a consultation to overhaul a system she describes as "outdated, inefficient, and unfair."
The proposed funding changes will bypass local authorities, directing funds straight to school heads.
Labour has criticized the government for "evading difficult questions" regarding those who might lose funding under these changes.

Mrs. Morgan argues that schools require funding that "truly reflects their needs," and the plan aims to direct money "straight to the frontline," further weakening the connection between local authorities and schools.
On Monday, the education secretary advanced the initiative to introduce a new school funding formula for 2017-18, following complaints about local inconsistencies and funding disparities.
For instance, each student in Rotherham receives £500 more annually than those in Plymouth, despite similar levels of disadvantage.

In December, MPs, led by former Education Select Committee chairman Graham Stuart, urged reform, highlighting that the best-funded areas receive up to £6,300 per pupil annually, while the least funded receive £4,200.
The government has pledged to establish a more consistent method to allocate over £40bn annually from the core schools budget and aims to eliminate funding based on "historical anomalies."
The Chancellor's Autumn Statement unveiled more details, promising a national rate per pupil with additional funds for those with extra needs.

Russell Hobby, head of the National Association of Head Teachers, supports the principle of fairer funding redistribution, advocating for a "significant shift" toward directing more funds directly to schools.
However, he cautioned that the new funding system would have both "winners and losers," and there is still "limited information" on how allocations will be determined.
Concerns have been raised that some schools, particularly in inner London, might lose funding.

Christine Blower, leader of the National Union of Teachers, warned that without additional funding, the proposals could "impose significant cuts on many schools," which are already experiencing real-term reductions in per-pupil funding.
Malcolm Trobe, interim general secretary of the ASCL head teachers' union, also supports changing the funding mechanism.
He emphasized, "Simply redistributing the current funds is insufficient to counter the substantial real-term cuts affecting school budgets.

More investment is necessary," said Mr. Trobe. The Department for Education contends that the current system no longer reflects actual needs, noting that in the past decade, the proportion of pupils eligible for free school meals has doubled in Lincolnshire and nearly halved in Southwark.
Five years ago, the Criminal Justice Psychoactive Substances Act was enacted, implementing a blanket ban.
Prior to this law, around 100 "headshops" sold legal highs throughout the state, but that number has since dropped to zero.
"The headshop industry is gone," remarked Det Supt Tony Howard, a member of the Garda Drugs Unit charged with enforcing this legislation.

"We were worried because we saw a whole generation of young people starting to experiment with these new psychoactive substances, generally among those who wouldn't have otherwise misused drugs," he explained.

"They assumed it was safe due to the perception that these were legal highs." Following the ban, it became illegal to advertise, sell, supply, import, or export psychoactive substances in the Republic of Ireland, although tobacco, alcohol, caffeine, and medicines were exempt.

Before the law came into effect, selling legal highs was a lucrative business, evidenced when firefighters found a safe containing 450,000 euros (£330,000) in the remains of a Dublin headshop burned in an arson attack.
Since the sale of these substances wasn't illegal at the time, police had to return the cash to the safe's owner, a scenario that would not occur now due to the ban.
Det Supt Howard noted that many headshop operators quickly complied with the law.

"The industry recognized the strength of the legislation and cooperated with us by handing over any remaining products," he explained. Should the UK consider following Ireland's example and ban legal highs?
While the ban removed headshops from the high street, not everyone believes it's the best way to protect users.
Tony Duffin, director of the Ana Liffey Drug Project in Dublin, mentioned that significant harm still exists from substances previously sold by headshops.
He stated that many recreational users now purchase psychoactive substances online, while more frequent users turn to drug dealers.
"In New Zealand, legislation is being introduced to regulate headshop drugs, so the UK should explore all available options in terms of drug policy," Mr. Duffin advised.
Police issued an alert after receiving complaints that two men were behaving suspiciously near secondary schools in Carrickfergus.
Pictures circulating online of a clown and his balaclava-wearing companion have stirred concern in the town.
While some social media users criticized the police for dampening fun, officers launched an investigation following reports from parents worried about their children's fear of the clown.
A police officer expressed on the PSNI Newtownabbey and Carrickfergus Facebook page: "Fun is fun, but scaring school pupils is another matter."
The clown, who refers to himself as the Carrick "Killer Clown," contacted the police to apologize for any distress caused.
He explained it was intended as a prank and not meant to frighten students or trigger distress.
The officer noted, "He is fully aware of the sensitive nature surrounding schools and photographs etc.
near schools." During an interview on BBC Radio Ulster's Evening Extra program, the clown admitted receiving concerned messages from parents.
"That wasn’t the aim. It was meant to be just fun. As a parent myself, I realized there was a problem when someone voiced concern," he said.
"I discussed with the officer in charge the possibility of apologizing personally to school heads, though in civilian clothes.
The officer conveyed my apology, which was accepted, so hopefully parents will be informed."
Earlier, on the Carrick Killer Clowns' Facebook page, a post mentioned: "Due to mixed reactions to the school photos, they have been removed.
This event was meant to be a laugh, but some parents found it offensive and not humorous."
Shortly afterwards, another photo was posted showing them outside the Carrickfergus police station.
Liberty Global, the parent company of Virgin Media, announced that Virgin originally claimed to have connected 465,000 new premises in the UK and Ireland in 2016.
However, after a review, this figure was adjusted to 314,000. Liberty revealed that Virgin had overstated its ability to complete these connections swiftly.
In a regulatory filing, Liberty explained that Virgin's reporting included premises where installation was "essentially complete" but not fully finished.
This included 142,000 sites expected to be connected in the first quarter of 2017.
Yet, in late February 2017, Liberty realized that "the construction work needed to connect a significant number of [these premises] had not progressed as originally understood".
This discovery led to a review, uncovering that the "completion status" of some premises had been "misrepresented".
Additionally, Liberty found Virgin Media had "inadvertently" classified 9,000 unfinished connections as completed.
Dan Howdle, a consumer telecoms analyst at Cable.co.uk, informed the BBC: "Clearly, the reporting method allowed for premature conclusions, though there is no evidence of intentional deceit."
He continued: "Virgin Media seems to be addressing the issue decisively, though errors leading to such stories can blemish a brand."
Four Virgin Media employees have been suspended due to Liberty's investigation and may face disciplinary actions, including dismissal.
Virgin Media stated that this setback would impact the number of premises connected in the first half of 2017 but has implemented measures to accelerate Project Lightning.
They appointed a new managing director, Robert Evans, to lead the project and will no longer count unfinished connections in their reports.
Launched in 2015, Project Lightning aims to connect about four million UK homes and businesses to internet speeds of 300Mbps.
By the end of December, Virgin had reached 567,000 premises, lower than the previously reported 718,000.
To preserve the 1733 portrait of Gambian Ayuba Suleiman Diallo by artist William Hoare, £100,000 must be raised.
The total cost to secure the artwork is £555,000, with contributions from the Heritage Lottery Fund, The Art Fund, and the National Portrait Gallery (NPG).
Although the portrait has never been publicly displayed before, it is currently on view at the London gallery.
Diallo, belonging to a wealthy family of religious clerics, was captured as a slave in Africa at 29 and taken to work on an American plantation.

After an attempt to escape led to imprisonment, he met lawyer Thomas Bluett. Bluett, impressed by Diallo's intellect and education, facilitated his move to England, where Diallo was warmly welcomed by the aristocracy and scholars.
The National Portrait Gallery noted that Hoare's painting is the first British portrait recognizing an African subject as both an individual and an equal.
A gallery spokesperson explained to the BBC News website that the portrait, previously in a private collection, was auctioned at Christie's in London last December for £554,937.50.
Following the auction, Culture Minister Margaret Hodge issued a temporary export bar, granting UK museums and galleries the chance to purchase the artwork by matching the price.
The Heritage Lottery Fund and The Art Fund have offered grants of £333,000 and £100,000 respectively, with contributions also from the NPG.
The Lottery Fund's grant will cover acquisition, conservation, display, and touring costs for other UK galleries and museums.
Zeinab Badawi, a broadcaster and National Portrait Gallery trustee, remarked, "This portrait is a rare example of an 18th-century African depicted in Britain.
It would be a significant and impactful addition to the National Portrait Gallery's collection, representing Britain's rich cultural heritage."
Her endorsement of menstrual leave—and her proposition that all women should have access to it—sparked a lively debate among readers.
Here is a compilation of your experiences and thoughts on the issue. We argue for equality in pay and employment, yet some ask for an extra day's "holiday" each month simply for being female.
That doesn't promote equality; it suggests women can't perform as effectively as men, undermining the argument for equality altogether.
I’m a woman, and despite having a period every month, I can work as competently as any man.
If some women struggle, they should consult a doctor—it's their issue! Charlotte Rachael, Halifax, UK Personally, I endure pain for up to two weeks continuously.
I've fainted at work due to temporary anemia. I've had to stop and hold onto a wall or fence while walking to work.
Yet, I don’t deem it necessary to call in sick, nor do I think additional leave is required.
Those suffering severely should persist in getting specialist help from their GP.
Allowing extra leave exposes companies to exploitation by women who aren't suffering but simply wish to extend their time off for personal reasons.
Lyndsey Victoria Corp, Barnsley, UK Sadly, such issues contribute to lower male-dominated salaries.

If we want equality, we need to toughen up. Valerie Richardson, Oregon, US The concept of menstrual leave seems sensible to an extent, but unpaid leave could widen the wage gap since fewer hours result in lower wages, which is a concern for many.

If it were paid, those taking leave would need to work harder to compensate, or an earnings gap would emerge—a more significant issue than the wage gap, as fewer hours and equal pay lead to higher pay per hour, typically unlawful.
Time off for pain isn’t a holiday, but it doesn’t provide company value either.
Perhaps government subsidies could be an option, but I'm generally against excessive intervention.

Alex, Dundee, UK I sympathize with women who face genuine difficulties. As a woman and experienced head chef, I’ve had to retreat to the walk-in fridge to cool down for a minute to avoid fainting. I endure the same challenges and pains.

Determining which event shocked us more—the first positive steroids test in Scottish rugby history or the criticism of Scottish, Welsh, and Irish teams qualifying for the Heineken Cup from a non-relegation league—is challenging.
However, let's focus on the steroids issue and leave the Heineken Cup discussion for another time.
Sam Chalmers, son of one of our esteemed players, Craig Chalmers, publicly apologized, claiming he bought the steroids online.
This explanation resembles the "lone wolf" narrative. Was Sam truly the only one using them?
Did he discuss it with others? Coaches in youth rugby have mentioned that weight training and supplement use are closely linked.

It's understandable that players feel pressured to grow bigger and heavier—while the rugby field size hasn't changed in 150 years, people have. Modern rugby often involves more brute force than agility.
What I don't accept is the notion that players feel pressured to use steroids. This is cheating.
Purchasing steroids is knowingly breaking the rules and hoping to evade detection by drug testers.
Some players might have considered steroids but decided against it. If you're not naturally large enough, perhaps rugby isn't the right path for you.

It’s no longer a sport for all body types. Young players are often with supplements; they use them before, during, and after workouts, perhaps believing they can't achieve their goals with food alone.
This mindset might lead to the dangerous conclusion that artificial aids, including steroids, are necessary.

So, can one achieve size with just a natural diet? According to the IRB's 2012 data, they conducted 1,542 tests in and out of competition, across all IRB tournaments, including the HSBC Sevens World Series, Rugby World Cup 2015 qualifiers, Test matches, and Age Grade Rugby.
After the attacks, files were discovered on a computer dumped in a rubbish bin, as confirmed by an informed source.
This computer contained a final message from Ibrahim el-Bakraoui, one of the airport bombers.
Belgian authorities have identified all 32 victims who perished on March 22, with 17 being Belgian nationals and the remaining 15 hailing from various countries.
There are still 94 individuals hospitalized, many of whom are in intensive care.
The first funeral held was for Raghavendran Ganeshan, whose remains were sent back to Chennai, India, on Tuesday.
The computer was found a day after the Brussels attacks in a bin on Max Roos Street in Schaerbeek, Brussels.
The three suspects seen on airport CCTV had left a house on this street by taxi, and the driver subsequently directed police to the site where explosive materials were uncovered.

According to De Tijd newspaper, citing reliable sources, the computer files contained information and images of the prime minister's building and office at 16 Rue de la Loi (or Wetstraat in Dutch), as well as details about his official residence on Lambermont Street.
It remains uncertain if the bombers themselves captured these images or if they were downloaded from the internet.
A spokesman for Mr. Michel mentioned that security at these locations had been heightened well before the attacks due to vulnerabilities.

The chancellery is adjacent to the US embassy and is on the same street as Maelbeek metro station, where Ibrahim el-Bakraoui's brother detonated a bomb just over an hour following the airport bombing.
This computer is now a crucial piece of evidence for Belgian investigators searching for the third airport suspect, who fled when his suitcase didn't explode.
Ibrahim el-Bakraoui's final message expressed feelings of being hunted and unsafe.
The FBI has reportedly received copies of laptop hard drives associated with the Brussels attack suspects.
Following a test involving hundreds of staff, Brussels airport remained closed for flights on Wednesday.
The airport operator announced no flights until at least Thursday afternoon as trial results were still under evaluation. A temporary check-in area was set up along with boosted security measures.

Flights will only resume once operations reach 20% capacity. CEO Arnaud Feist indicated that fully reopening would take months, necessitating a complete overhaul of the departures hall, including air conditioning and check-in desks.
Several airlines have diverted flights to Liege, Antwerp, Ostend, and Charleroi.
The strike is about a 1% pay raise awarded last year to midwives in England, Scotland, and Wales.
During the stoppage, the Department of Health ensured services were safely provided.
It stated that midwives in Northern Ireland received the same settlement as those in England.

"Though we wish we could have done more in 2014/15, it's important to acknowledge that midwives and other non-medical staff got at least 1% extra, with an average rise from incremental progression being 3.7%, and some staff seeing increases of 6.7%," a spokesperson said.
While the most senior midwives in Northern Ireland received this as a one-time payment last March, lower pay bands did not, with most getting an annual boost of about £1,500.
The Royal College of Midwives (RCM) insists all midwives should get the 1% raise like their counterparts in the UK, plus the built-in salary progression.
Talks between the Department of Health and some health unions resumed Tuesday, described as positive, though more industrial action is planned, including overtime claims.
Amy Leversidge from the RCM said the department "acted cheekily" by proposing Northern Irish midwives got the same raise as their English peers.
She noted that higher pay bands received a 1% "temporary uplift" in February, but their pay reverted to 2013 levels that April.
Incremental progression based on experience and performance is part of the NHS structure rather than a pay raise, according to the union's employment relations adviser.
"We don't want to wait until February 2016 to know the outcome — we want to negotiate a solution now," she said.
Midwife Hazel McAllister told the BBC: "We're no less passionate, caring, or hard-working than colleagues in other UK regions who received the 1% pay raise.
We feel greatly undervalued by those refusing to pay. I've been a midwife for 37 years—it's a fantastic profession, but I'm concerned about its future."
On Wednesday, Kevin McGuigan Sr was fatally shot at his home on Comber Court in the Short Strand.
Police suspect two men shot him multiple times at close range in the head and chest before fleeing.
The BBC reports that the 53-year-old was among several suspects in the murder of Gerard 'Jock' Davison last May.
Sinn Féin has denied claims that the Provisional IRA might be involved in McGuigan's murder, while the DUP warned of "repercussions" if these claims are true.
McGuigan, a father of nine, was taken to the Royal Victoria Hospital but died shortly afterward.
BBC Northern Ireland home affairs correspondent Vincent Kearney described McGuigan's killing as a "professional, execution-style" attack by two masked men with semi-automatic weapons.
Detective Chief Inspector John McVea, leading the murder investigation, said the gunmen were on foot, wearing dark clothing, and covering their faces.
He appealed for anyone with information about the gunmen’s movements before and after the shooting to come forward.
Previously, McGuigan was questioned by police regarding the murder of 47-year-old Jock Davison in the Markets area of Belfast three months prior.
Davison, a former IRA commander and once a friend of McGuigan, was involved in a feud with him.
Both were co-founders of the paramilitary group Direct Action Against Drugs (DAAD), which targeted and killed over a dozen alleged drug dealers.
In this feud, McGuigan survived a "punishment attack," which was allegedly ordered by Davison.

Det Ch Insp McVea acknowledged public speculation over McGuigan’s murder motive but emphasized that McGuigan was never considered a suspect in Davison’s murder, only a potential witness, which remains the police stance.
He warned that speculation is dangerous and urged the public to allow the police investigation to proceed while providing any relevant information.
While McVea did not completely dismiss McGuigan as a suspect, he stated at a press conference that the investigation into Davison’s murder remains open to all possibilities.
He also urged community leaders to work towards reducing tension and promoting calm and restraint during this challenging period.
Britain’s decision on Brexit has stirred mixed reactions: while some believe it serves the nation’s interests, others worry that Russia will be the main beneficiary.
Criticism has been directed at David Cameron, echoing sentiments across Europe that he prioritized the Conservative Party over the UK by calling for the referendum.
Estonian Health and Labour Minister Jevgeny Ossinovski commented via Facebook, accusing Cameron of gambling with Europe's future.

Similarly, Parliament Speaker Eiki Nestor questioned his statesmanship, stating, "David Cameron did not deceive the British people when encouraging them to vote, yet prioritized electoral results over the fate of the UK and Europe."
Former Latvian President Vaira Vike-Freiberga tweeted that Cameron would be remembered as a less successful British prime minister.
Lithuanian conservative politician Audronius Azubalis viewed the referendum outcome as a "political irresponsibility."

Popular Lithuanian journalist Algis Ramanauskas expressed skepticism, noting on Facebook, "Despite my affection for Britain, it’s easy to see there are plenty of fools there too," a post that garnered over 1,000 likes.
While criticisms are prevalent, there are supporters of Brexit among Baltic Eurosceptics on social media.
Estonian MEP Martin Helme celebrated the Brexit vote as a "joyous day for freedom and national independence," comparing 'Land of Hope and Glory' to a second anthem for the British.
Lithuanian journalist Andrius Uzkalnis described the vote as a push against "European integration zealots," suggesting that Britons were frustrated with continuous preaching.

He added, "No worries, Trump will also get elected." Estonian analyst Ahto Lobjakas criticized calls for harsh EU-Britain negotiations, tweeting, "Why assume the EU's sole option post-Brexit is the UK's honour killing?"
Pro-Russian activist Aleksandr Gaponenko perceived Brexit as a chance for Latvia to follow suit, planning to collect signatures for a petition.
He foresees that authorities will suppress signatories, leading Europe to condemn such repression—an act that could expel Latvia from the EU.
In Latvia particularly, some commentators view Russia as gaining the most from Brexit.
Swiss curator Hans Ulrich Obrist has topped ArtReview's annual Power 100 list for the second time; he first achieved this in 2009.
This year, Polish curator Adam Szymczyk climbed from 14th to take second place.
Art dealers Iwan and Manuela Wirth, who led the list in 2015, have now dropped to third.
Oliver Basciano, Deputy Editor of ArtReview, explained to BBC News, "Hans Ulrich Obrist is omnipresent.
His global network links artists, thinkers, scientists, curators, and more, helping him spread ideas.
Ideas, rather than objects, drive contemporary art today." US art dealer David Zwirner has fallen to fourth place.
Sir Nicholas Serota, who announced his departure from the Tate after 30 years to chair the Arts Council, maintains his fifth-place status.
Frances Morris, the newly-appointed director of Tate Modern, shares this position with him.
The ArtReview top 10 includes Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, who has dropped nine spots to rank 10th.
New entries down the list feature feminist theorist Donna Haraway at 43, UK artist Ed Atkins at 50, and Indian art group Raqs Media Collective at 86.
The rankings are determined by a 16-member jury comprised of writers, artists, curators, and critics, evaluating influence over the past 12 months.
The complete list is available on the ArtReview website. Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts or Instagram, or email story suggestions to entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

In the US, the film brought in $204.6 million (£132 million) according to early estimates, making it the second-largest opening weekend ever, just behind 2012's Marvel's The Avengers with $207.4 million (£133.8 million).

What contributed to the film's success? Despite spending years in supporting roles and gaining fame for his comedic performance in the cult US sitcom Parks and Recreation, Chris Pratt has become one of Hollywood's most reliable stars over the past year.
He appeared in two of 2014's top five highest-grossing films at the US box office: The Lego Movie and Guardians of the Galaxy.
With a blend of charm, vulnerability, and humor, Pratt manages to bring humanity to even the most special-effects-heavy blockbusters.

This talent was evident in Marvel's Guardians, where his co-stars were a talking raccoon and a giant animated tree—yet the film unexpectedly grossed $774 million (£499 million) worldwide, making it the third highest-grossing film of 2014.
Pratt’s appearance certainly doesn't detract from his appeal. China, the world’s second-largest film market after the US, restricts foreign film screenings to 34 a year.
This makes it crucial for Hollywood blockbusters to secure a spot on that list to significantly boost box office earnings.
Unlike most Hollywood films, which don't release in China at the same time as in the US, Jurassic World debuted simultaneously in both regions.
It opened in a total of 66 international markets, earning $307.2 million (£198 million), with China contributing $100.8 million (£65 million)—almost 20% of the global total.
When the original Jurassic Park was released, IMAX screens were rare, typically showing short films, documentaries, and theme park features.
Now, with about 800 IMAX screens worldwide, the chance to see dinosaurs larger than life is a major draw.
The option to watch a T-Rex in 3D has led audiences to pay premium prices for the added spectacle, boosting box office revenues.
According to Rentrak, a box office analyst, nearly 50% of Jurassic World's US earnings came from 3D showings.
Steven Spielberg's 1993 blockbuster Jurassic Park holds a nostalgic place for many moviegoers.
It set new standards for CGI and became a defining film of the 1990s, captivating an entire generation.
"I was 12 when Jurassic Park came out, and it blew me away," Jurassic World actress Bryce Dallas Howard told the BBC.
"Watching it felt like seeing real dinosaurs." Her co-star Chris Pratt added, "I was 13 and felt the same way."
In a statement, the US criticized the "extra-judicial release" of detainees, considering it "a major step backwards."
These detainees belong to a group of 88 prisoners initially held by the US but transferred to Afghan control in 2013.
The US claims they are "dangerous individuals," while Afghanistan argues there's insufficient evidence against them.

Earlier this month, the Afghan government decided to release 72 of these prisoners, leading to swift condemnation from the US, which asserted that there was "strong evidence" connecting them to "terror-related crimes."
Since the Afghan government assumed control of Bagram jail in March last year, hundreds of prisoners have been freed.

However, the release of these 88 detainees remains highly controversial. For 45 out of the 72 prisoners set for release, the Afghan government claims no evidence exists, and for the remaining 27, the evidence is inadequate for trial.
The US argues that releasing any of them breaches a memorandum of understanding made when control of Bagram jail was transferred to Afghanistan.

"The ARB [Afghan Review Board] is releasing back to society dangerous insurgents who have Afghan blood on their hands," the US military stated upon learning that 37 detainees were ordered to be released.
The statement noted that among these 37, 17 are linked to bomb attacks, and others were knowledgeable about or directly involved in attacks injuring or killing Afghan and coalition soldiers.
The two countries have been in conflict over President Hamid Karzai's refusal to sign a security agreement with Washington to finalize the framework for the US withdrawal from Afghanistan.

As directed by the UN Security Council mandate, the US-led international military force in Afghanistan is slated to hand over all security responsibilities to Afghan forces before the full withdrawal by the end of 2014.
Signing a "Security and Defence Cooperation Agreement" could allow about 10,000 US troops to remain in Afghanistan for an additional 10 years.
Batsman Joe Root is the frontrunner to succeed Alastair Cook, who stepped down on Monday after leading England in a record 59 Tests.
Root, from Yorkshire, has been the Test vice-captain under Cook since May 2015.
"Root may be quiet, but he has a fiery spirit and is an impressive young man," commented Anderson on The Tuffers and Vaughan Cricket Show.
If appointed captain at age 26, Root would be a year younger than Cook was when he became a full-time Test captain in August 2012.
Since his debut on December 13, 2012, Root has scored an unmatched 4,594 Test runs, with only India captain Virat Kohli surpassing his 8,469 international runs in all formats with 8,536.

Anderson, England's leading Test wicket-taker, has seen five full-time Test captains since debuting in May 2003: Nasser Hussain, Michael Vaughan, Kevin Pietersen, Andrew Strauss, and Cook, with Andrew Flintoff filling in for several Tests in 2006 and 2007.
Anderson remarked, "Root handles one-on-ones well and speaks wisely; he’s an impressive contender."
He added, "It's a significant decision since he's our best player, and you don't want his performance to be impacted."
While England's next Test isn't until July, they'll have seven home Tests against South Africa and the West Indies over three months, followed by the Ashes in Australia in November.
Root scored 1,477 Test runs in 2016, notching centuries against South Africa, Pakistan, and India, along with 796 runs in ODIs and 297 in T20s.
"His love for cricket is rare among players with such success," noted Anderson.
"Whenever Cook stepped off the field for breaks, Root was there making strategic changes.
He's handled it well." Root has captained Yorkshire four times in the County Championship, including leading the team to the 2014 title while regular captain Andrew Gale was suspended.
He also captained Yorkshire when Middlesex, under Australian Chris Rogers, set a record 472-3 and won by seven wickets in the same year.
If you've recently enjoyed a spicy chicken wing in Angola or a tangy "yassa poulet" in Senegal, chances are the chicken traveled quite a distance to reach your plate.
Depending on your location in Africa, chickens are increasingly being imported—frozen—from Brazil, Germany, or other European Union countries.
According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, chicken imports to sub-Saharan Africa tripled between 2004 and 2014.
Here are four reasons for this surge and potential strategies to boost the continent's poultry industry: 1) Why Chicken, Not Beef?
Africa's population is projected to double to 2.5 billion by 2050, escalating the demand for meat, particularly chicken.
"Chicken is the preferred meat for most Africans," says Kevin Lovell, CEO of the South Africa Poultry Association.
The high cost of beef and religious restrictions on pork in some regions contribute to this preference.
As urban populations grow, people are more likely to eat at local fast-food eateries or global chains that have expanded across Africa.
For instance, Kentucky Fried Chicken now boasts over 700 outlets in 13 African countries.

"Meat production hasn't kept pace with the surge in demand, driven by both population growth and urbanization," explains Calestous Juma, a professor of International Development at Harvard University.
This trend is remarkable. By 2030, an estimated 50% of Africans—more than half a billion people—are expected to live in urban areas, up from 36% in 2010, according to World Bank estimates.
2) Feeding the Birds Many Africans know the "road runner" chicken, often found freely roaming backyards.
These birds, known for being tough yet flavorful, typically fend for themselves and provide sustenance or a small income with minimal input.
However, intensive farming requires a steady supply of chicken feed, mostly comprising maize and soy.
Africa's weak agricultural systems mean feed often has to be imported at high costs, hindering farmers' ability to scale up grain production.
The beach where Seifeddine Rezgui stood on Friday and unleashed Tunisia's deadliest terror attack by pulling a Kalashnikov from his parasol has already reopened its doors.
Camera crews are capturing the location, while passers-by stop for a moment of reflection.
Yet, the emotional scars of the tragedy will linger for a generation. For 57-year-old Sabi, the wounds are still fresh.
He's responsible for the boat club on the beach, which is mainly used by customers of the Hotel Imperial, the target of the attack.
Sabi gestures to the spot where Rezgui first appeared to make a phone call before throwing his mobile into the sea and starting his rampage.
"People around me were falling," he remembers, "and I just grabbed as many customers as I could and ran."
They escaped through a staff gate to a hotel basement, but Sabi returned to rescue more. "I saw six of our loyal guests die, people who always came to this hotel.
They were like brothers to me. This beach should be lively now, but it's empty."
Sabi pauses and looks at the rows of vacant sunbeds. "We will fight," he says, his lips trembling and tears forming.
"At least we can still smile." Tunisia finds itself in shock, with its critical tourism industry facing a severe threat.
Thousands of holidaymakers have already departed on emergency flights arranged by tour operators.
I observed another busload from the Hotel Imperial arriving at the local Enfidha airport on Saturday night, heading to Manchester.
Among them was a man who had witnessed his fiancée die in front of him. Most were too traumatized to speak.
However, at nearby hotels, dozens are choosing to stay. "I wanted to leave early," says Isabelle Campbell from Gateshead, "but my husband said: if we go, they win.
I'm nervous about the beach though." Her husband, Bob Taylor, recounts their earlier visit, where they saw a speedboat moving in the water, revving its engines toward them.
"For a moment, we thought: Oh God, something is going to happen again. We switched from Egypt to Tunisia due to security concerns there," he adds.

"Now we don't know what will happen here." One in ten Tunisians is employed in the tourism industry, which was already impacted by the Bardo museum attack in March and is now expected to decline further.
This only heightens Tunisians' distress over the alarming increase in Islamist attacks.
Mobile operators, Culture Secretary Maria Miller, and communications regulator Ofcom are set to discuss expediting the allocation of spectrum to enable faster mobile download speeds.
Ofcom has advised the government that the process could be accelerated, potentially launching 4G networks in various areas by May or June, contrary to the previous expectation of a year-end launch.
Prior to the meeting, O2 expressed optimism about launching 4G services in the summer of 2013.
Ronan Dunne, O2's chief executive, remarked, "It's been a very good process, and it feels like we've made significant progress, so I'm hopeful we'll have a basis for moving forward."
However, he also voiced frustration over the delays, stating, "We're pleased with the progress but frustrated by the time it has taken."
An Ofcom spokesperson clarified that the delays were due to litigation—actual and threatened—by competing companies.
Earlier, O2 and Vodafone were upset that rival network EE, formerly Everything Everywhere, was permitted to use its existing 1,800MHz spectrum to launch a 4G service earlier.
O2 had even considered legal action to block EE's advantage. A forthcoming deal may allow EE to announce its 4G launch date by the end of this month.
O2 and Vodafone can't offer 4G until other radio spectrum parts, previously used for analog TV and air traffic control, are cleared and sold.
The UK’s fourth largest network, Three, is set to acquire part of EE’s 4G spectrum but not until September 2013.

Ofcom suggested it might advance its airwave auction by about two weeks from its planned January schedule, speeding up the transfer of frequencies, potentially cutting EE's exclusive period to about half a year.
However, any legal challenges could delay this process. "Ofcom made a clever move by letting EE launch early," said Matthew Howett, a telecoms analyst with Ovum.

"It's really set things in motion and will push others to act." A major network source mentioned to the BBC that they also sought a guarantee from EE not to obstruct Mitco, an organization set up to address potential 4G interference with other signals, like digital TV.
In the early 1990s, a woman, then just 14, recounted to detectives her belief that Robert Howard attempted to rape her in his Castlederg flat.
The following year, in August 1994, 15-year-old Arlene went missing. Her body was never recovered, and Howard, who passed away in prison last year, was the main suspect.
It has come to light that after the alleged assault, the woman had warned Arlene Arkinson to avoid Howard.
She remains anonymous for legal reasons but shared her feelings of discomfort around Howard, noting his unsettling gaze.
She told detectives, "He would glare at me, making me feel very uncomfortable."
Most visits to Howard's flat were uneventful, yet one turned into a "nightmare" when he assaulted her.
She testified, "I thought we were just innocently playing hide and seek," only for the situation to escalate.
"I feared Bob Howard would force himself on me, and I was fortunate to escape," she said.
She cried out for Donna Quinn, Howard's girlfriend's teenage daughter, who was also in the flat.
Desperate to get away, she thought, "He might rape me, and I had to act." Ultimately, she managed to knee Howard and flee.
She found Donna sitting in another room, then left and severed all ties with Howard and Donna.
The woman revealed she remained silent about the incident for years, only confiding in detectives in 2002.
She told a barrister, "It was a living nightmare I had to block out." Howard was later convicted of another teenager's assault and the murder of Hannah Williams in London.
Meanwhile, Arlene from Castlederg disappeared after a disco night in County Donegal in 1994.
A social worker at the inquest remarked on the challenges Arlene faced, particularly after her mother died in 1990. Michelle McKernan reported Arlene missing in August 1994.

Brook, the IBF welterweight champion from Sheffield, will leap up two weight classes to challenge the undisputed world middleweight champion, Golovkin, in a high-stakes bout in London on September 10.
At 30 years old, Brook is one of Britain's 14 world champion boxers. He expressed to BBC Sport, "Defeating Golovkin would establish me as the top pound-for-pound boxer globally.
Years ago, with only a few champions, winning a world title was a massive national deal.
Now, it seems more routine, like: 'Oh, there’s another British world champion.'
The shock value is gone, so you need to do something extraordinary to stand out."
Unbeaten in 36 professional fights, Brook has successfully defended his IBF welterweight title three times since claiming it from American Shawn Porter in 2014.
However, critics have pointed out the lack of high-caliber opponents he's faced until now.

Golovkin, a 34-year-old knockout specialist from Kazakhstan, is undefeated in 35 bouts, with 32 wins by knockout, boasting an impressive 91% knockout rate, the highest in world middleweight championship history.
Brook said, "The anticipation is electric—this is a mega-fight. It’s not just any champion-versus-champion bout; it's the biggest clash in boxing today.
You have two undefeated fighters with plenty of knockouts taking each other on.
It's remarkable that I'm moving up two divisions to face someone no one else wants to fight.
This fight has everything, which is why everyone should watch." Brook is aiming to achieve what his fellow Brit, Amir Khan, could not.
Khan, from Bolton, moved up two weight classes to face then-WBC champion Saul Alvarez in May but was knocked out in six rounds.
Golovkin, who holds the WBA, WBC, and IBF titles, is one of boxing’s most avoided fighters. In fact, Mexico’s Alvarez chose to vacate his WBC title rather than face him.
Mr. Blair emphasized that the party he previously led should aim to govern rather than become a "fringe protest movement."
He has openly criticized leader Jeremy Corbyn, warning before Corbyn's leadership victory that the party risked "annihilation" under his leadership.
Mr. Corbyn's office chose not to respond to Blair's remarks, published in a Spectator article.
Blair wrote, "All factions of the Labour Party that support its ambition to govern, rather than act as a fringe protest movement, recognize the tragedy of the party's current state."
While the article doesn't mention Corbyn by name, Blair's comments highlight the party's internal divisions regarding its future direction.
Although most Labour MPs opposed Corbyn's leadership bid, he won decisively with more than half of the membership's vote.
Tensions have emerged, especially after the Commons voted on air strikes in Syria, where some MPs reported online abuse for supporting military intervention.

Corbyn has warned that "abuse and intimidation" won't be tolerated. Additionally, there's concern that moderate Labour MPs could be ousted due to pressure from the grassroots Momentum group, formed from Corbyn's leadership campaign—something the group denies.
Blair also defended the party's track record under his leadership, stating that it "effectively discarded" socialism's ideological commitment.

According to Blair, the party "fell short" in areas where difficult decisions were required, with "significant elements" unhappy with the "compromise" and "pragmatism" necessary for governance, perceiving it as a betrayal of Labour's purpose.
Looking ahead, Blair argued that "more modernizing and less ideological thinking" is essential to address challenges like housing shortages and social exclusion.
"We risk not asking the right questions, let alone failing to find the right answers," he warned.
Many current Labour members believe the party "lost its way" while in government, but Blair concluded, "I feel we found it."

He noted, "I acknowledge that in our efforts, we didn't convince enough people that true progressives are always modernizers—not because they abandon principle, but because they courageously uphold it in the face of reality."
One of the early touring productions this season is "All My Sons," presented by the black-led theater company Talawa.
This play focuses on the all-American couple, Joe and Kate Keller, whose son is missing after World War II.
The director, Michael Buffong, shares with arts correspondent Tim Masters why this play is a 20th-century classic.
On taking "All My Sons" on tour during Arthur Miller's centenary, Buffong notes that this milestone draws extra attention to an exceptional piece of work by an extraordinary writer.
Although the tour coincides with the centenary, it was unplanned but fortuitous.
What makes "All My Sons" an American classic? Its themes are universal, delving into the pursuit of the American dream, and the costs associated with it.
The play explores loyalty, trust, betrayal, family secrets, and the collapse of illusions when truths surface.
Joe Keller, driven by familial loyalty, believes actions are justified if done for family, ignoring broader social responsibilities—this is his downfall.
The 2013 production received five-star reviews; does this add pressure to the current tour?
Buffong admits he hasn't dwelled on it, as overthinking might disrupt his sleep.
Reviews, both positive and negative, are an inseparable part of theater. How much is being adjusted this time?
Revisiting a fantastic play reveals new depths. With half of the cast being new, fresh elements are naturally introduced, showcasing the text's enduring richness.
Does a black cast offer a new perspective? It adds nuance, especially when considering a black family striving for the American dream, amplifying the stakes given black history in the US.
Yet, it remains at heart a family drama about an all-American family. Taking the helm of Talawa in 2012, Buffong believes he's still at the beginning of his journey.

While the two governments agree on certain issues, such as the need for free trade within the single market, Carwyn Jones expressed frustration at not seeing the letter before it was published on Wednesday.

He's not alone in this; most of Mrs. May's cabinet shared the same surprise. The first minister informed AMs: "I discussed the Article 50 letter with the prime minister in general terms during our meeting in Swansea last week.
However, I must clarify that I didn't see the actual letter until today and we weren't invited to help draft it.
This is unacceptable and highlights a deeply frustrating process where the devolved administrations have consistently been treated with disrespect.
It's particularly disappointing since the UK government claimed to aim for a negotiating framework encompassing the entire UK."
Although Mr. Jones may be appealing to his audience, Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns responded: "I'm somewhat disappointed by that reaction.
The prime minister has visited Wales three times in the past six weeks. We've discussed the letter's content for months.
We've all made our contributions, but ultimately, the UK government must act in the interests of the whole UK, including Wales."

Mrs. May did mention Wales in the letter to Donald Tusk, stating: "When powers are returned to the UK, we will fully consult on which should remain in Westminster and which should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.
The government expects this process to significantly increase the decision-making power of each devolved administration."
While this may have had Scotland in mind, it raises questions: Which powers will be redistributed?
Will this include farming or economic aid? And crucially, will funding accompany these powers?
Alun Cairns did not answer these, though Carwyn Jones voiced concerns that no additional funding would follow the powers after 2020.
This perhaps suggests Mr. Jones doubts Jeremy Corbyn will win power that year, despite Labour's promise to maintain EU funding levels for regional aid post-2020.
Some in Whitehall argue that the spending of EU money in Wales, highlighted in Nick Clegg's film from Ebbw Vale, justifies moving powers to Westminster, but this now seems politically unlikely.
The Board of Community Health Councils (CHCs) is remaining silent on the reason for chief executive Tony Rucinski's suspension.

Prior to his suspension, emails indicate that Dr. Rucinski had expressed concerns that the board's chair, Mutale Merrill, might have been influenced by a government minister to prevent him from doing media interviews.
Ms. Merrill refuted the emails' content, asserting they are not "factually correct."

Dr. Rucinski has been "instructed not to comment." The organization, which calls itself the "independent voice of patients" in Wales, along with the seven CHCs it manages, had a 2015-16 budget of £3.8 million.

Dr. Rucinski had stepped into a newly-created role as chief executive in July 2015, stating to BBC Wales at that time that his purpose was to "make things happen" and to transform CHCs into a "more proactive and effective patient voice."
Four months later, the Welsh Government appointed Ms. Merrill as the new chair, and Dr. Rucinski was suspended in February 2016.
Sources informed BBC Wales about the existing tension between Mr. Rucinski and Ms. Merrill before his suspension.

In emails procured by BBC Wales, Mr. Rucinski expressed concerns about being halted from interviews concerning a Welsh Government digital health initiative in December 2015 and an OECD report comparing UK health services in February 2016.

Dr. Rucinski indicated that media interviews were part of his job description and implied that Ms. Merrill's directive to him might have been influenced by her meeting with a Welsh Government minister.
He voiced, "I am genuinely concerned about the comments you have relayed from your meeting with the minister."
Post-suspension, a board meeting transpired where Ms. Merrill sought to clarify the media coverage dispute with the chief executive.
The minutes reveal Ms. Merrill mentioned the "media embargo" was limited to the chief executive regarding the OECD report, adding that the decision had context which couldn't be disclosed.
She had required the chief executive to provide a briefing before commenting on any issue for optimal media strategy.

The minutes also noted discussions with the chief executive about establishing a media protocol and mentioned that he shared a text message from Ms. Merrill with staff "without her knowledge and without context of previous discussions."
Joe Robinson, 24, from Leeds, was arrested in the coastal town of Didim along with his fiancée Mira Rojkan and her mother.
He is suspected of sharing content on social media related to his time in Syria with Kurdish militia.

Lawyer Kaya Sertkaya stated, "We do not know when he will be taken to court." Mr. Robinson, a former British Army soldier who served in Afghanistan, traveled to Syria in 2015 to spend time with Kurdish rebels, the YPG, who are fighting against Islamic State (IS).
He has been open about his experiences in media reports. The YPG is viewed by Turkey as linked to the Kurdish militant group PKK, which has been active in Turkey since 1984.
However, the YPG is not banned in the UK and is seen as a significant ally of the US in combating IS.
His father, Andrew Robinson, appealed for diplomatic aid, saying to the BBC, "When I heard that he'd been arrested on terrorist charges, I was devastated.
I wasn't aware of the situation in Turkey. We’re just hoping someone—perhaps the government or the Foreign Office—will help us find answers."
Sharon Robinson, his mother, termed his arrest "the most ridiculous thing I have ever heard in my life."
His lawyer indicated that Mr. Robinson is currently jailed in Aydin, western Turkey, accused of "being a member of a terrorist organization."
Sertkaya added, "I visited him yesterday; he looked well and in good spirits, but there is uncertainty about court proceedings.
Due to the state of emergency, arrests on terror charges cause delays in the indictment process."
He also mentioned, "He probably won't be taken to court for at least three months."
The Foreign and Commonwealth Office issued a statement saying it is supporting the family and maintaining contact with Turkish authorities.

Guney Yildiz, a Turkish affairs analyst from the European Council on Foreign Relations, commented that it is "not a surprise" Robinson may face legal issues in Turkey, given his past ties with a group viewed as a security risk by Turkey.
Sandwell Councillor Mahboob Hussain faces accusations of breaching the council's code of conduct on six counts, as stated by solicitors Gowling WLG.
The law firm was tasked with examining alleged irregularities in the sale of former council properties over 15 months ago.
Suspended from Labour, Mr. Hussain maintains his innocence. Gowling focused on sales from 2011 to 2013, which included three old public toilet blocks and a former coroner's office in Smethwick.

A parallel police investigation concluded in March without further action. Legal action delayed releasing Gowling's report, but it was published on Friday "in the public interest," according to the council.

Information previously leaked to the BBC highlighted its conclusions. The council's chief executive, Jan Britton, stated the forthcoming step is to refer the allegations to the internal standards committee for review.
A comprehensive audit will examine the policies on land sales and potential disciplinary measures for employees.
The report outlines accusations that led former economy chief councillor Mr. Jones and Mr. Hussain to resign from their cabinet positions once investigations commenced.
Both had their party suspensions lifted before the May elections, but Mr. Hussain has been suspended again, the party confirmed.
Tipton Green ward councillor Mr. Jones, who was cleared of misconduct, expressed satisfaction with the report's release and conclusions.
He stated, "I've consistently asserted my innocence and fully cooperated with all investigations."
Oldbury ward councillor Mr. Hussain explained he was unaware of the toilet blocks' buyers because purchases occurred under a company name rather than his friend's name.
He claimed ignorance about the transactions and their pricing. Despite requests, Mr. Hafeez, who was arrested last year, presented no evidence, per the report.
He has not responded to further BBC inquiries. Police informed him in November 2015 that no action would be taken against him.
Mr. Hafeez mentioned then that his arrest was unrelated to any Sandwell Council property sales and was contemplating legal action against various people and organizations.

This situation carries significant irony: the council originally adopted the asset management strategy to streamline operations, reduce overhead by consolidating into fewer buildings, and generate revenue from selling unnecessary properties to offset government cuts.
Gunners Joseph Rowbottom, 27, from Wrawby, North Lincolnshire, and Albert Venus, 22, from Hull, died on 24 May 1915 in the Second Battle of Ypres.
Their remains were discovered during construction of a new housing development.
Relatives attended the reinterment at Ypres Town Cemetery, where their coffins were draped with the Union Jack.
The soldiers' remains, along with shoulder titles from the North and East Riding Batteries of the RFA, were unearthed in April 2013.
Ministry of Defence (MoD) researchers managed to identify Rowbottom and Venus out of the six sets of remains found.
Gunner Venus's great-nephew, John Howden, 73, from Roos, East Yorkshire, received the folded Union Jack from his coffin.
He remarked, "When they gave me the flag, I felt a lump in my throat and had tears in my eyes.
I hadn't expected to be so affected. You feel distant, but suddenly you're involved, and it's emotional."
Mr. Howden learned about his great-uncle only after receiving a letter from the MoD and expressed satisfaction at the confirmed DNA link.
Caroline Rowbottom, the granddaughter of Gunner Rowbottom's cousin, accepted the flag for his family.
Residing in Brigg, North Lincolnshire, Mrs. Rowbottom said she was shocked by the MoD's letter, noting, "Until then, we were unaware of his existence; he wasn't in our family tree, which is very sad.
The ceremony was very moving and well-organized." A traditional five-gun salute was omitted due to heightened security following recent Brussels attacks.
Before the war, Gunner Rowbottom was known as Milky Joe in local newspapers for his work as a milkman.
Gunner Venus had enlisted in the 2nd Northumbrian Brigade in December 1914, later joining the Hull Batteries to complete his gunner training.
Mr. Netanyahu's statements have upset the White House, despite his subsequent attempts to soften his remarks.
Tensions between the US and Israel have been rising due to disagreements over several issues.

Nevertheless, Mr. Obama characterized his relationship with Mr. Netanyahu as "businesslike," noting, "I've met with him more than any other world leader." He claimed that their personal relationship is not central to their disputes.
"He is representing his country's interests as he sees fit, and I'm doing the same," he added.
"The issue isn't about personal relations but rather a clear, substantive challenge," Mr. Obama emphasized, stating, "It can't just be about everyone holding hands and singing 'Kumbaya'."
Earlier on Tuesday, Israeli officials denied reports that Israel was spying on US-led talks.
Mr. Netanyahu has criticized the United States' involvement in the nuclear negotiations, which he believes could pose security risks to Israel.
Meanwhile, Mr. Obama has criticized Mr. Netanyahu's pre-election comments that rejected the establishment of a Palestinian state.
During a Tuesday news conference, originally meant to discuss the situation in Afghanistan, President Obama declined to comment on the spying allegations reported by the Wall Street Journal.
However, he reassured that Israel and other regional partners have been updated on the negotiations' progress.
Mr. Obama also remarked that Mr. Netanyahu's efforts to clarify his pre-election statements have not effectively advanced a two-state solution.
"Based on the prime minister's statements, it's hard to see how that would happen," he stated.
"I've previously mentioned, and I'll reiterate: Prime Minister Netanyahu, during the election, said a Palestinian state would not be realized while he was in office.
I took him at his word," the president explained. In a US TV interview, Mr. Netanyahu expressed support for a two-state solution but insisted "circumstances have to change."
Mr. Obama acknowledged that Mr. Netanyahu did not explicitly say a Palestinian state would "never" be established.
In the past three years, police in England and Wales have spoken to nearly 400 children under the age of 12.
According to data obtained by the BBC, there have been over 4,000 incidents since 2013 where children created and shared explicit images of themselves.
It is illegal to possess, create, or distribute sexual images of anyone under 18, including oneself.

A five-year-old from County Durham was interviewed by Durham Constabulary last year, making him the youngest to be involved in a sexting investigation by police in response to a BBC Newcastle inquiry.
DCI Steve Thubron stated that sexting cases are addressed on an individual basis, with an emphasis on protecting children.
He assured that incidents are documented according to national crime recording standards and that children are not criminalized in this process.
"We collaborate with other organizations to offer guidance to teachers and young people," he said. "We urge children with concerns to talk to a trusted adult or contact 101."

The typical ages of those involved in sexting are 13 and 14. Notably, a 10-year-old boy, just at the threshold of criminal responsibility, was cautioned by Northumbria Police after sending a sexual image of himself to an 11-year-old via Oovoo, a social media app for video and image sharing.
Greater Manchester Police reported the highest number of child sexting cases, tallying 695, including instances involving four seven-year-olds and four eight-year-olds.
Even without prosecution, once an indecent image or video is sent, it's beyond the sender's control.
If such content appears on a public social media platform, it may be seen by friends, family, or potential employers.
Many children have recounted experiences where an image shared with a partner was then widely distributed.
Kerry Smith from Plan International UK, an organization advocating for children's rights, remarked on the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire show that sexting pressures are gendered.
"Girls face more pressure to share," she noted. "When they do, they are shamed, not the boys who request or possess the images."
She emphasized the importance of education, highlighting that awareness of the issue exists.
"Parents want this knowledge conveyed to their children, and it's crucial that schools are ensuring this," she added.
Hart, 29, has yet to make an appearance for Manchester City this season and has been informed he can leave the club if he wishes.
"It is a big concern," said Sam Allardyce, who told BBC Radio 5 Live he will announce his captain this month.
Despite this, the former Sunderland boss confirmed that Hart will be part of the squad for next month's World Cup qualifier against Slovakia, with the roster announcement due on Sunday.
Hart, with 63 caps for England, had a disappointing Euro 2016, making mistakes against Wales and Iceland, which led to England's exit in the last 16.
Currently, Hart is out of favor with new City manager Pep Guardiola, and Argentinian Willy Caballero has been consistently in the lineup this season.
Everton shows interest in signing Hart, but he is not tempted to join Sevilla or Borussia Dortmund, despite their interest.
Barcelona announced on Saturday that they are close to an agreement with City regarding the transfer of their goalkeeper, Claudio Bravo.
"We want as many players as possible starting for their clubs to join the squad, and then play for England and succeed," said Allardyce.
"This doesn't happen as much now as it did 20 or 25 years ago because fewer English players are in the Premier League."

England's opening Group F qualifier for the 2018 World Cup will take place in Trnava on September 4, marking their first game under Allardyce, who was appointed after Roy Hodgson resigned following the loss to Iceland.
Allardyce is still to decide if Manchester United forward Wayne Rooney will continue as captain.
"I will reveal the captain by Wednesday at the latest because everyone keeps asking," he stated.
