Having just secured Taiwan's presidency, she is unwavering in her belief that Taiwan's future should be determined by its own people.
This stance is a direct challenge to China, which views the island as a breakaway province to be reunified by force if necessary.
Beijing is left to interpret where exactly Ms. Tsai stands regarding Taiwan's sovereignty and what her next steps might be. She has adeptly maintained ambiguity on this issue.
Her enigmatic nature extends beyond China; many Taiwanese perceive her as a quiet, unpredictable force.
She describes herself as a person who prefers to stay out of the spotlight, characterizing her rapid rise in politics as an "accidental life."
Why is this election significant? Is it merely about the economy? And what fuels the China-Taiwan divide?
Ms. Tsai is Taiwan's first female leader, but unlike many other prominent Asian women, she didn't come from a political dynasty.
As the youngest of 11 children from her father's fourth wife, she enjoyed a well-off upbringing.
Her father owned a successful car repair business and profited from land investments but insisted that she attend public schools to broaden her societal exposure.

She devoted the first 30 years of her life to academia, earning a law degree from National Taiwan University, a master's in law from Cornell University in the U.S., and a Ph.D. from the London School of Economics, eventually becoming a law professor.
Her expertise and fluency in English led her, in the 1990s, to be called upon as a legal consultant for Taiwan's World Trade Organization (WTO) entry negotiations, marking her entry into public life.

Serving as national security advisor to former President Lee Teng-hui, she helped formulate his special state-to-state relations doctrine, portraying Beijing and Taipei as two separate countries, a stance that angered China.

However, under the subsequent president, Chen Shui-bian, during a particularly tense period in cross-strait relations, Ms. Tsai, leading the Mainland Affairs Council, found ways to engage with a hostile China.

She launched the groundbreaking "Small Mini Links" program in 2001, which enabled direct ferry transport and trade connections between Taiwan's outlying islands and mainland China. She later advocated for the first chartered flights between the two sides.

By 2003, despite unease about Taiwan's opening up too fast to China, Ms. Tsai persuaded Mr. Chen and legislators to amend Taiwan's law on relations with China to legalize Taiwanese business investments on the mainland.
Germany's Mueller is purchasing the dairies operation, which handles milk processing and distribution, for £80 million.
This move follows a dramatic 95% drop in profits at the UK's largest dairy food company, leaving them at £900,000 for the six months leading to September.
Dairy Crest processes and delivers about 1.3 billion liters of milk annually to both retailers and homes.
In their statement, Dairy Crest expressed that the sale benefits consumers, customers, and dairy farmers.
The dairies business represents around 70% of the company's revenues which grew by 1% to £682.1 million over the six months.
Following the sale, pending shareholder approval and potentially taking several months, Dairy Crest plans to concentrate on its more profitable cheese and spreads sectors.
Approximately 14,000 dairy farmers in the UK produce 3.3 million liters daily, although there's ongoing debate about the industry's economic viability owing to declining milk prices.
Investors reacted positively to Dairy Crest's strategy to exit a struggling sector, causing shares to rise by 10% in morning trading on Thursday.
Muller expects the acquisition to lower costs and boost exports of UK-made dairy products.
Ronald Kers, CEO of Muller UK & Ireland, stated: "We believe the current conditions in the UK fresh milk market are unsustainable for dairy processors in the mid to long term.
This acquisition allows us to cut costs, enhance efficiencies, and secure future investments."

As part of the acquisition, Muller Wiseman Dairies, Mueller's UK division, will assume control of factories in Foston (Derbyshire), Chadwell Heath (Essex), Severnside (near Gloucester), and the Hanworth glass bottling site in Middlesex, where Dairy Crest is consulting with staff about the site's future, along with 72 depots. Muller previously acquired Robert Wiseman in 2012.
The headmaster of Beaulieu Convent School in Jersey has expressed concerns over the increasing costs and extravagance parents face regarding the school prom.
He also highlighted issues with alcohol and drug use during the Year 11 event for students aged 15-16.
A former pupil criticized the school for overreacting, emphasizing the prom's importance as a milestone.
Headmaster Chris Beirne stated the distraction caused by the prom contradicts the school's values.
In a letter to parents, he quoted an unnamed colleague who believed the preparations for the event were neither positive nor beneficial.
This colleague mentioned the financial pressure and competition as overwhelming for many parents and noted concerns about substance use at after-parties.
The pressure to be slim, fashionable, and have perfect skin was also deemed stressful.
Mr. Beirne concluded he can no longer handle the risks associated with the event.
Instead, the independent Catholic school will continue to hold a celebratory mass for Year 13 leavers and their families, followed by a drinks reception.

The £5,400-a-year school has approximately 760 students aged 4-18. Former student Hannah Hosegood, 20, described the prom as "a first taste of maturity" and suggested addressing concerns individually if there are issues with drugs or alcohol.
She lamented that current students will miss an event anticipated and cherished for many years.
At the upcoming charity event, he will also engage in a Q&A session with the audience.
The dinner in Edinburgh on May 26 is expected to be one of his prominent speeches since completing his presidential term.

Hosted at the EICC, the event is organized by The Hunter Foundation, established by renowned businessman and philanthropist Sir Tom Hunter. A table of 10 at the dinner is anticipated to sell for around £5,000.
In the past, The Hunter Foundation has brought prominent figures like Bill Clinton, Leonardo DiCaprio, and George Clooney to Scotland.
Last year, DiCaprio visited Edinburgh, speaking at the Scottish Business Awards at the EICC and visiting Home, a Queensferry Street restaurant donating its profits to the homeless.
Fans eagerly awaited his arrival, braving hours of rain. The year before, George Clooney visited Social Bite in Rose Street, leaving $1,000 (about £650) for the cause and meeting a crowd of 200.
All funds raised will be divided between children's charities in Scotland and the Obama Foundation, founded by the former president and his wife Michelle.

Sir Tom plans to reserve some seats for local young people. He expressed, "From the South Side of Chicago to the White House has been an epic, historic journey, and it's a true honor to hear that story from the man who made it.
We are both proud and delighted to host the 44th president of the United States in Scotland."
Sir Tom shared his excitement with the Press Association, saying, "We're always seeking inspiring speakers for Scotland, and having President Obama is truly thrilling."
The philanthropist also mentioned a special surprise in store, noting, "President Obama loves music, so we have some exciting guests lined up."

From New York, during her five-day US visit, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told BBC Scotland she was "really excited" about the announcement, adding, "Many people in Scotland are eager to welcome President Obama and hear his insights."
Around 1,000 individuals gathered outside the Senedd to observe a minute of silence and light candles.
Over 2,000 French nationals living in South Wales are registered with the French consulate in London.
Marie Brousseau-Navarro, Honorary Consul of France in Cardiff, described the messages of support as deeply moving.
She declared: "We are united in shock and sorrow, alongside all those who have marched around the globe."
Saleem Kidwai, chairman of the Muslim Council of Wales, received applause as he urged everyone to "stand together, shoulder to shoulder."
He stated, "My condemnation is absolute. Ultimately, truth will triumph over falsehood, and light will overcome darkness."
First Minister Carwyn Jones joined many others in holding a candle during the silence, while some participants held up pencils. The silence concluded with applause.
Earlier, Jones remarked: "Tonight's vigil in Cardiff Bay allows the people of Wales to honor the victims of the horrific Paris attack.
It is also a moment to express solidarity with the French people and all who uphold our democratic values and freedoms, threatened by such senseless acts of terror."
Welsh Secretary Stephen Crabb tweeted: "Standing with the French community in Wales and in support of freedom of speech everywhere.

6pm this eve. Senedd, Cardiff. #CharlieHebdo." To show unity, London landmarks were illuminated in the colors of the French flag, and world leaders gathered in Paris for a massive unity march of over a million people, eclipsing Saturday's marches of 700,000.
On Saturday, Swansea City striker Bafetimbi Gomis dedicated his team's goal in the 1-1 draw with West Ham to the Paris attack victims.
Police forces and media outlets in Wales observed a minute's silence to honor those affected by the Charlie Hebdo attack in Paris on Wednesday.
In subsequent developments, a police officer was killed on Thursday, and French forces, on Friday, stormed two hostage sites around Paris, killing three hostage takers.
Ms. Brousseau-Navarro expressed appreciation for the overwhelming support and solidarity: "We have been truly moved by the hundreds of messages of support and condolences."
The former health minister has proposed that NHS funding should be supported by a dedicated tax clearly indicated on every payslip.
According to Mr. Lamb's plan, taxes wouldn't increase because the new levy would be balanced by reductions in income tax or national insurance.
He warned that the NHS faces a potential collapse without an urgent influx of funds.

Though the plans have not yet become party policy and won't be presented at this year's conference in Bournemouth, Mr. Lamb, the party's health spokesperson, expressed great interest in an exclusive NHS and care contribution, distinctly separate from other taxes and visible on payslips.
He is also keen on allowing local areas to raise additional funds for the NHS and care services if they choose.
The Liberal Democrats aim to implement these ideas across the UK; however, as health and social care are devolved issues, it's uncertain how enforcement would occur.
Mr. Lamb, who was defeated by Tim Farron in the leadership election in July, suggests forming a cross-party commission to explore these concepts.
He plans to consult with health organizations, professionals, patients, trade unions, and academics.

While ministers have pledged £2 billion for the NHS this financial year, with an additional £8 billion by 2020, Mr. Lamb told the BBC that this is inadequate, warning of a potential £30 billion funding gap by 2020 unless more investment is made due to the growing demand from an aging population.
He also stressed that the social care system is "on its knees," requiring a £5 billion cash injection to avoid collapse.
Having seen the financial details during his tenure, Mr. Lamb is deeply concerned.
He emphasized that ignoring these issues could lead to a system failure. Currently, taxpayers receive annual personal tax statements that show their contributions to the health service.
A previous attempt at forming a cross-party commission on social care before the 2010 election, partly led by Mr. Lamb, ended in discord.
James Vaughan opened the scoring in the 61st minute and soon doubled Bury's lead six minutes later.
However, things took a turn for Bury when Niall Maher was sent off after conceding a penalty in the 70th minute, which Shaun Williams successfully converted for Millwall.
In the 86th minute, Callum Butcher headed in the equalizer. Then, substitute Aiden O’Brien secured a stoppage-time winner, extending Bury’s losing streak to a record 10 games.
Earlier in the match, Millwall were initially awarded a penalty, but referee Chris Sarginson reconsidered.
Vaughan narrowly missed a header, and Neil Danns' shot was deflected off target.
Millwall came close with attempts from Harry Smith and Fred Onyedinma, and a Joe Martin free-kick was tipped over.
Bury’s advantage came with Mayor’s cross, which allowed Vaughan to score off the bar, followed by a side-footed second goal from a Scott Burgess pass.
Shortly after, Maher blocked Onyedinma's shot with his arm, leading to Williams' successful penalty shot.

Bury's keeper, Ben Williams, denied an Onyedinma header, but Millwall managed to equalize with Butcher scoring from Shane Ferguson’s free-kick before O’Brien scored the winner from Mahlon Romeo’s cross.
The Press Association provided the match report. Final Score: Bury 2, Millwall 3.
In the closing moments, Kelvin Etuhu of Bury was yellow-carded for a foul, with Fred Onyedinma winning a free kick for Millwall.
A corner was conceded to Bury by Onyedinma, followed by a blocked shot from Danny Mayor.
Aiden O'Brien also received a yellow card for over-celebrating his decisive goal, where he clinched the match for Millwall with a right-footed shot from the center of the box, assisted by Onyedinma.
Bury’s Antony Kay had a close header over the bar, and Tom Pope earned a free kick after being fouled by O'Brien.
Another blocked shot by Mayor followed a loose chance by Millwall’s Harry Smith, missing a header to the right.
Millwall made a substitution with Alfie Pavey replacing Joe Martin, and another corner was conceded by Ben Williams.
Shaun Williams' header was saved from the bottom left corner, and Smith’s efforts went wide, leaving Millwall victorious.
Mark Bellamy, president of the Intensive Care Society, emphasized to the BBC that antibiotic resistance will worsen unless new and effective treatments are developed.
Sepsis, which stems from infections, causes approximately 37,000 deaths annually in the UK.

NHS England urges hospitals to collaborate in addressing this issue. Typically arising from blood poisoning, sepsis prompts an intense immune response that, if not treated swiftly, can lead to organ failure or death.
Early symptoms often include fever and rapid heartbeat. To combat preventable deaths, the Intensive Care Society recently initiated a campaign to heighten sepsis awareness.
Annually, the UK sees around 37,000 deaths due to sepsis, surpassing those from lung cancer, which number just over 35,000, and bowel cancer, with 16,000.
The society, alongside the UK Sepsis Trust, contends that hospitals inadequately record sepsis cases and lack sufficient knowledge on recognizing and treating it early.
Julie Bignone nearly died from sepsis, spending seven weeks in hospital, part of which was in critical care.
Mistaking her fever for a severe flu, she remained in bed all weekend before visiting her GP, who advised her to return if her condition worsened.
Later that day, her family's concern grew, leading to her hospital admission via ambulance, where she was diagnosed with pneumonia and sepsis, putting her survival at risk.
Intensive care and high doses of antibiotics eventually saved her. Julie believes she should have trusted her instinct that her illness was more serious than flu.

She states, “Sepsis symptoms are nonspecific, creating room for error—we need a system where doctors better hear patients and value their opinions.” Prof Bellamy, from the Leeds Institute of Biomedical and Clinical Sciences, noted that recently, he encountered a few patients without effective antibiotic treatment—an occurrence he once found theoretical.
He stresses the importance of raising sepsis awareness and ensuring timely intervention for the best survival chance.
He warns of an emerging "specter" indicating a shift into a post-antibiotic era due to diminishing antibiotic effectiveness.
Ann Maguire, 61, was tragically killed at Corpus Christi Catholic College in Leeds in April 2014.
Sixteen-year-old student Will Cornick was sentenced to a minimum of 20 years in prison after confessing to her murder.
Mrs. Maguire's family expressed concern that Cornick's guilty plea meant the evidence was never thoroughly examined.
Having taught at the school for 40 years, Mrs. Maguire was set to retire just months later.
Cornick, who was 15 at the time, attacked her from behind, stabbing her seven times in the neck and back while she was assisting another student.
Her husband, Don Maguire, emphasized the importance of understanding whether anything could have been done to prevent her death.
"Due to the guilty plea at last year's court hearing, there was no full criminal trial to examine all the evidence," he stated.

"We believe a comprehensive, open, and independent statutory review of all the information is essential to learning lessons from this horrific incident, which traumatized pupils and staff and devastated our family.
While an independent inquiry won't bring Ann back, it will provide us peace in knowing if anything could have been done to prevent her death, ensuring other families don't endure similar suffering."
The Department for Education (DfE) acknowledged the family's wish for an inquiry into "the tragic events," stating that the Secretary of State understood their concerns.

"We are aware that the Leeds Safeguarding Children Board has initiated a two-stage learning lessons review, which we trust will be open and thorough," the statement continued. The DfE noted that no decision would be made until the review was complete.
During Wednesday's Premier League match at St James' Park, Jonny Evans and Papiss Cisse seemed to spit at each other.
Referee Anthony Taylor spoke to the players after the first-half incident but did not issue any bookings.
The Football Association is awaiting Taylor's report before deciding if disciplinary action is necessary.
Previously, George Boyd received a three-match ban for spitting at Manchester City’s Joe Hart.
However, current FA guidelines mandate that offenses of this nature now warrant a six-match ban.
Cisse's penalty might be harsher because he was sent off in December for elbowing Everton’s Seamus Coleman, which could add an extra one-match suspension according to FA rules.

Several former players think Evans and Cisse deserve punishment. Dietmar Hamann, ex-Newcastle midfielder, called the behavior "unacceptable" and "disgusting," while Phil Neville, former Manchester United defender, stated that both players should feel embarrassed.
Speaking on BBC’s Match of the Day, Hamann emphasized the negative influence on young viewers and the weekly decline in player conduct toward each other and officials.
Jermaine Jenas, another former Newcastle player, voiced his disgust on BBC Radio 5 live, asserting the game does not need such actions.
TV replays indicate that Evans spat at Cisse, who was on the ground, and Cisse appeared to retaliate in kind.
Neither Newcastle manager John Carver nor Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal witnessed the incident.
Carver, whose team lost 1-0, stated, "I can't comment on it. I just know there was a fracas on the halfway line."
Van Gaal remarked, "I don’t think Jonny Evans is a spitter. Maybe spitting on the floor, but from the bench, it’s impossible to see."

Media playback is not supported on this device The 32-year-old Welsh triathlete achieved her first World Series victory since 2012, ending Gwen Jorgensen's 13-event winning streak and defeating British competitor Jodie Stimpson.
"Helen has made a compelling case," said Stanford, who, along with Vicky Holland, has already qualified for Rio.

With an official announcement expected in June, two-time world champion Jenkins and England's Commonwealth champion Stimpson are vying for a spot on Britain's female triathlon team at the Rio Games this summer.
"Helen has clearly demonstrated her potential," remarked Stanford, Jenkins' Welsh compatriot.
"British Triathlon emphasized the need to show medal potential for Rio; Helen has certainly done that.
She not only won the race but also defeated Gwen Jorgensen, who is favored to win gold in Rio.
Beating her showcases Helen's medal potential, so it would be surprising if she isn't selected."
Stimpson began the season strong, winning the World Series opener in Abu Dhabi and the sprint distance World Cup in Australia.
However, she finished 12th, trailing more than three minutes behind the winner at the Gold Coast.
"Jodie had an excellent start," said Stanford, the 2013 world champion. "Unfortunately, her performance at the Gold Coast selection race didn't meet expectations.
That was the pivotal moment to demonstrate capabilities, although she presented a strong case earlier in the year. The selectors have a challenging decision."
After her victory in Australia, Jenkins commented: "The team hasn't been announced yet, but I believe I did enough today.
Our team is incredibly strong, and it feels unfair that Jodie might miss the Games."
Cynthia Cheroitich, 19, resorted to drinking body lotion to stave off hunger and thirst.
She was finally rescued on Saturday morning after security forces enlisted the help of a familiar teacher to assure her it was safe to emerge.

Ms. Cheroitich recounted her ordeal beginning around 05:30 (02:30 GMT) on Thursday while she and other students were preparing for exams. "Suddenly, we heard gunshots and started asking, 'What is happening?'"
she shared with the Associated Press. "We ran to our rooms, but the attackers followed.
Once inside, we hid under the beds." She explained that the attackers demanded they come out, but instead, she concealed herself in a wardrobe, covering with clothes.
The gunmen then entered the room. Ms. Cheroitich's account mirrored that of other survivors.
Her roommates were taken and separated based on their ability to recite Koran verses, with no clarity on their fate.
In her hiding spot, she found body lotion bottles and drank them, describing the experience as "nice and lovely," though fear kept her from moving.
"I was just praying," she said. It wasn't until 10:00 on Saturday, well after the attack, that authorities convinced her to come out.
She initially doubted the rescuers, fearing they might be al-Shabab: "How do I know you are the Kenyan police?"
she questioned. Only after a college staff member reassured her did she finally emerge.
In March, the first minister signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with SinoFortone and another Chinese company.
Following reports of the agreement's cancellation, the Scottish government cited a "climate of hostility" from opposition parties.

Critics demanded a full statement on the "regrettable episode." The deal, potentially worth £10bn, was signed at Nicola Sturgeon's official residence, Bute House in Edinburgh, with SinoFortone Group and China Railway No.

3 Engineering Group (CR3). Opposition parties expressed concerns due to the parent company, China Railway Group, being named in an Amnesty International report on human rights violations and blacklisted by Norway's oil fund.
Ms. Sturgeon assured that no specific deals would proceed if genuine concerns emerged, with investments subject to Scottish Parliament scrutiny.
The Sunday Times reported the deal's collapse in August, dubbing it the "Scottish shambles" in China.
The Economy Secretary Keith Brown's spokesman acknowledged some concerns but hadn't believed the deal was canceled.
He criticized opposition parties for jeopardizing investments, stating: "We didn't think the MOU was canceled but knew SinoFortone couldn't proceed amid hostility from other parties.
However, they still see benefits in a partnership with China for Scotland’s infrastructure, and we remain committed to these opportunities.
The MOU is about relationship-building for investment, and we're open to future collaboration."
Opposition remained firm, with Labour's Jackie Baillie urging the government to "come clean" about the agreement's status urgently.
Baillie stated, "Scotland deserves clarity on this secretive deal—the affair raises serious concerns about SNP ministers' transparency and competence.
The SNP's handling has been awkward from the start, leading to its 'shambles' label.
They kept this deal quiet during the election, and now it’s revealed it fell apart months ago, leaving Scottish citizens in the dark yet again."
Scottish Conservative economy spokesman Dean Lockhart added, "This episode shows the SNP lacks reliability on economic matters."
Norman Rimmington, affectionately known as "Rimmo," joined Barnsley in 1945 as a goalkeeper, earning £3 per week.
Following his playing career, he served the club in various capacities, including coach, assistant manager, groundskeeper, physiotherapist, and kit manager.
As his funeral procession passed the Tykes' Oakwell Stadium, fans paid their respects.
Born in Staincross, Mr. Rimmington was recognized by the club as a "fearless" keeper, appearing in 27 matches before transferring to Hartlepool United in 1947.
In addition to football, he worked as a pit fitter and mechanic. After returning to Barnsley in 1952, he remained with the club until his death in late December at the age of 93.
A service was held at All Saints Church in Darton, followed by a ceremony at Barnsley Crematorium, attended by family, friends, colleagues, and former teammates.
In a BBC Sport interview, Mr. Rimmington recalled getting "some stick as a goalkeeper" in his playing days.
"They could knock you into the back of the net and it was a goal; it’s not the same game," he noted.
"Now they go down as if they’ve been shot, but there’s nothing wrong with them."
Before his passing, he learned he had been awarded the British Empire Medal for his contributions to football.
Reflecting on his bond with the club, he said, "I was born in Barnsley, raised in Barnsley, and played at Barnsley.
I love the club and everything I've done here." The club released a statement praising Rimmo as "a true club legend" who represented Barnsley with immense pride and dedication throughout his life.

- Born: November 29, 1923, Staincross, near Barnsley - Occupations outside football: Pit fitter and mechanic - 1946-47: Barnsley FC (27 appearances) - 1947-52: Hartlepool United (127 appearances) - 1952-61: Barnsley 'A' team coach - 1961-1972: Head coach and physio - 1972-1978: Groundsman and physio - 1978-1980: Assistant manager and physio - 1980-1985: Physio - 1985-2016: Kitman and laundry
Ms. Yellen commented that current market valuations were "quite high," but she did not foresee any bubbles developing.
Among regional markets, Chinese shares experienced the largest drops, with the Shanghai Composite falling 2.8% to close at 4,112.21, marking its third consecutive day of declines.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 1.3% to 27,289.97, extending its losing streak to six days.
This downturn came as several mainland companies announced share offerings, prompting investors to withdraw funds from other stocks.
Concerns also arose over reported regulatory measures in China, such as imposing limits on margin financing and restricting the types of stocks bought with borrowed money.
In Japan, the Nikkei 225 fell 1.23% to 19,291.99 after reopening following a week-long holiday.

The Australian S&P/ASX 200 index declined 0.82% to close at 5,645.70. On Wednesday, Australian shares had their most significant one-day fall in over two years, triggered by disappointing outcomes from the country's largest banks.

There is apprehension about the future growth of Australia's top four banks. National Australia Bank (NAB), the last of the major banks to announce its results this week, reported a 5.4% increase in cash profit for the six months to March.
NAB also disclosed a massive 5.5 billion Australian dollar ($4.4 billion; £2.8 billion) capital-raising initiative, which involves issuing new shares.
This move aims to demerge and list its problematic British bank, Clydesdale, and strengthen its balance sheet.
Australia's media has described this capital-raising effort as possibly the largest in the nation’s corporate history.
Furthermore, investor sentiment was impacted by the latest unemployment figures, which showed a slight increase to 6.2% in April. In South Korea, the Kospi index declined 0.65% to close at 2,091.00.
Jono Gibbes, a former New Zealand player now aged 40, is the forwards coach at Clermont Auvergne, having previously held a similar role at Leinster.
Gibbes will be working under Les Kiss, the director of rugby, though the future of current head coach Neil Doak remains uncertain.
Gibbes remarked, "My respect for Les as both a coach and person was a key factor in my decision."
Ulster currently ranks sixth in the Pro12 and has had a disappointing season, exiting the European Champions Cup.
Gibbes added, "Les shared his vision for Ulster’s future, which greatly influenced my decision.
I’m familiar with Ulster, having faced them several times. The recent Clermont-Ulster matches gave me valuable insight into the squad's strengths, and I'm eager to join this environment next season."

Having joined Leinster in 2008, where he won three Heineken Cups, Gibbes commented, "My experience over six years at Leinster and three at Clermont has given me diverse opportunities with talented coaches and players.
I'm excited to apply this knowledge at Ulster, and my family looks forward to becoming part of the vibrant community in Belfast."
He moved to France in 2014, contributing to the coaching team that led Clermont to both the Top 14 and Champions Cup finals in his first season.
Kiss, 52, expressed confidence in Gibbes, saying, "Jono's credentials are impressive, and he is eager to join Ulster.
Since retiring from playing, he has been vital to the coaching teams of two top European clubs.
His expertise as a forwards coach is evident, but his comprehensive understanding of the game will also benefit us greatly."
He continued, "We are reviewing our coaching structure for next season, with Jono's appointment as head coach being the initial step.
Additional announcements regarding the coaching team will follow soon to ensure the right balance."
A video featuring a father inviting "everyone" to his daughter's party was posted publicly on Facebook, creating quite a stir.
Crescencio Ibarra, the father, initially intended to invite only neighbors and friends to the event which features local bands, a meal, and a horse race.
However, he announced he wouldn't turn anyone away. The video shows Mr. Ibarra standing beside his daughter Rubi, who wears a tiara, with his wife Anaelda Garcia.
"Hello, how are you? We invite you to our daughter Rubi Ibarra Garcia's 15th birthday party on December 26th," he says as Rubi smiles.
He lists three bands set to perform and offers a 10,000 pesos ($490; £390) prize for a horse race winner, concluding with a warm invitation to everyone.
In Mexico, a girl's 15th birthday is a significant celebration marking her entry into adulthood.
Lavish parties with live music are common, and the girls often wear elegant dresses and tiaras, reveling in their "queen for the day" status.
The reason for this video's viral spread—garnering over 800,000 shares and countless memes—is unclear.
Mr. Ibarra admitted in a TV interview he didn't know what captured public interest.
"We just wanted to invite the people from our area," he stated, dismissing rumors he had uninvited everyone except close friends.
Initially saddened by the widespread and sometimes mocking attention towards their rural lifestyle, the family adapted and decided to continue with the party outside La Joya, in San Luis Potosi.

Ms. Garcia fondly called Rubi her "queen" and shared her favorite meme about Donald Trump and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto agreeing to let undocumented Mexican migrants return to Mexico for Rubi's party.
Local official Roberto Alejandro Segovia Hernandez assured that police would secure La Joya and its access roads for crowd safety, a move which spawned further memes.
Rubi's older sister noted that Rubi is now "very excited" and eagerly anticipating the party.
Regardless of one's views regarding Mr. Aamer, his return to the UK was widely welcomed across Whitehall as a relief.
His 5,017 days of detention deeply strained the transatlantic relationship and hindered government efforts to engage with the most isolated Muslim communities.
Initially, he will receive expert medical care, including a psychiatric evaluation, and finally meet the son born on the day he arrived at Guantanamo Bay.
However, his return also poses a potential risk. Davis Lewin from the Henry Jackson Society, a security and foreign relations think tank, cautions the UK to carefully manage and monitor Mr. Aamer.
His legal team has stated he will comply with necessary monitoring, although they contend it's unwarranted, as the allegations against him were obtained through torture.
If MI5 opts to monitor him, he might never be aware of it, given the covert nature of such work.
Larger questions loom for the UK concerning legacy and lessons learned. Critics assert that post-9/11, the US wasn't alone in losing its legal and moral bearings.

London's reluctance to advise Washington against Guantanamo and failure to demand the return of British detainees from Afghanistan was, according to critics, a neglect of Britain's justice principles.
"Human rights and justice and the rule of law are universal," states former Conservative cabinet minister Andrew Mitchell, part of the group lobbying for Mr. Aamer's release.
"He's been denied these rights. It's terrible for him, and we must uphold these principles to combat terror.
We must adhere to the rule of law and recognize human rights for everyone." Some American interrogations utilized intelligence from Britain, potentially implicating complicity in torture.
Consequently, many MPs now demand answers regarding Britain's actions in the period following 9/11.
"A crucial development is for [Shaker Aamer] to speak on camera about his experiences in Britain," says Mr. Mitchell.

The proposal to introduce 30 minutes of free parking was rejected. Four DUP MLAs suggested the changes, but Infrastructure Minister Chris Hazzard criticized their motion, calling it "seriously misguided."
He argued that enforcing a free parking system for 30 minutes would require substantial resources.
Nonetheless, the assembly approved a Sinn Féin amendment for reviewing on-street parking arrangements, which Mr. Hazzard expressed interest in implementing.
"I'm not against a review — a strategic look at on-street car parking policy and its future direction," the minister told BBC News NI.
"But I opposed the DUP motion, which had a predetermined outcome suggesting we should drastically decrease penalty fines before even reviewing.

That approach isn't suitable," he explained. The DUP motion, signed by former minister Edwin Poots and his colleagues William Humphrey, George Robinson, and Alex Easton, advocated for "greater flexibility" in parking policies to boost trade in towns and villages.
Parking enforcement in Northern Ireland was privatized in 2006, with initial fines set at £60, offering a 50% reduction if paid within two weeks.
However, in 2012, Stormont MLAs voted to raise penalties to £90 — or £45 if settled within 14 days.
Former Roads Minister Danny Kennedy suggested that higher fines would better deter improper parking.
The current minister noted that "at least two-thirds" of parking violators pay within two weeks, benefiting from the reduced £45 rate.

"Considering many regions, this amount seems appropriate," Mr. Hazzard added. Meanwhile, a Belfast City Council committee recently voted to end the city's annual tradition of offering free parking in the city center before Christmas.
Barclays reported a 10% drop in pre-tax profits to £1.43 billion for the July-to-September quarter, excluding settlement costs.
This announcement came a day after confirming that Jes Staley would take over as the bank's new CEO in December.
The bank's non-core businesses, which are in the process of being sold, have shown minimal progress.
Losses from these areas, including certain investment bank assets and parts of the European retail banking arm, surged to £337 million.
Barclays allocated £270 million to settle U.S. mortgage bond claims and £290 million to compensate clients affected by unfavorable foreign exchange rates.
For the businesses Barclays intends to keep, like its UK High Street bank and Barclaycard, profits rose 1% to £1.76 billion.
Including a £560 million impact and other one-off costs and gains, third-quarter pre-tax profit decreased to £861 million from £1.22 billion the previous year.
Revenue fell from £6.4 billion to £6.1 billion for the June-to-September timeframe.
Mr. Staley, currently with US hedge fund Blue Mountain Capital Management and formerly at JP Morgan, will replace Antony Jenkins, who was dismissed in July after disagreements with board members.
Staley's compensation includes a £1.2 million salary, £396,000 in pension contributions, and bonuses up to £5.5 million, mostly paid in shares.
He will also receive £1.15 million in shares annually, which he must hold for five years.
His total potential earnings for the year could reach £8.2 million if he receives the full bonus.
Additionally, he will be compensated with Barclays shares valued at approximately £1.93 million to replace those lost from JP Morgan amid his departure.

In his communication to staff, Mr. Staley expressed plans to concentrate on investment banking sectors requiring less capital, such as advisory services for mergers and stock trading, according to analyst suggestions.

Electoral Commission results reveal that Mr. Akufo-Addo of the New Patriotic Party (NPP) secured over the necessary 50% plus one vote to defeat his main adversary, President John Dramani Mahama of the National Democratic Congress.
The president-elect will be inaugurated on January 7 following a one-month transition period.
Mr. Akufo-Addo experienced defeats in the 2008 and 2012 elections, yet his dignified handling of those losses resonated with many.
He is praised for preventing potential violence in 2012 by accepting the election results—despite a 300,000 vote loss to President Mahama—and not inciting mass protests.
Instead, he opted for legal recourse and accepted the Supreme Court’s decision.
The 72-year-old son of former Chief Justice and ceremonial President Edward Akufo-Addo has upheld his 2012 promise of free high-school education.
However, his chief campaign pledge was the "one district, one factory" policy aimed at industrializing Ghana by establishing factories in each of the country's 216 districts.
"The time has come for us to advance our industrial development," he stated at a rally in eastern Ghana.
"We need jobs; the current government’s lack of them threatens our country’s future stability."
In the north, Mr. Akufo-Addo promised a working dam "in every village" to boost agriculture.
Critics from the NDC have dismissed his promises as unachievable, but Mr. Akufo-Addo insists they are substantive.
His wife, Rebecca Akufo-Addo, was active in his campaign, characterizing him on a TV show as a "very loving" family man.
"He is also deeply passionate about politics and has always cared about Ghana, wanting to contribute to the nation," she added.
Mr. Akufo-Addo is recognized for strengthening the NPP, which first contested an election in 1992 as Ghana returned to multiparty democracy after years under military rule.
With a political career spanning more than four decades, he was involved in political movements in his early 30s, opposing the military government of the day.
He was educated in Ghana and the UK, practiced law in France, and served as an MP for the Abuakwa South constituency in eastern Ghana from 1996 to 2008.
Harrison Ford is set to star in the fifth Indiana Jones film, slated for release in 2019.
He revealed to the BBC, "I've always believed we could do another. But I wanted both Steven [Spielberg] and a great script onboard."
Happily, both are in the works—Spielberg is crafting a script that will likely satisfy everyone's expectations as he takes on the director's role again.
Spielberg directed the previous four Indiana Jones films, all produced by Star Wars' George Lucas.
Ford debuted as Indiana Jones in 1981’s Raiders of the Lost Ark and continued through three more films, the latest being 2008's Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.
During an interview with the BBC for the DVD release of Star Wars: The Force Awakens, Ford reprised his role as Han Solo.
When asked if Han Solo, killed off in the film, might return to future installments, Ford quipped, "Anything is possible in space."
He explained his wish for Han Solo to sacrifice himself for the greater good, adding "I wanted to add some gravitas to the story."
Reflecting on his role in the film, Ford remarked, "Working with talented actors, on a script I trusted, under a director with a confident and generous hand, was truly a pleasure."
However, he noted he doesn't emotionally connect with his characters: "I aim to give an emotional depth to the characters, offering audiences a recognizable experience.
I want them to be engaged in seeing the character's journey unfold instead of knowing him," Ford elaborated.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens became the UK's top film of 2015, earning £94.06m within just 16 days of release.
John Collins, 74, Terry Perkins, 67, Brian Reader, 76, and Daniel Jones, 58, confessed to their crimes at Woolwich Crown Court.
The raid at Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Company in London's jewelry district resulted in the theft of items valued at over £10 million, with more than 70 safety deposit boxes being plundered.

Arrested in May, Perkins from Heene Road, Enfield, Collins from Bletsoe Walk, Islington, Jones from Park Avenue, Enfield, and Reader from Dartford Road, Dartford, admitted to conspiracy to burgle, specifically intending to steal from Hatton Garden Safe Deposit in London between January 1 and April 7.
Although they were also charged with conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property, the prosecution agreed not to pursue this charge following their guilty pleas for the burglary conspiracy.

Earlier this month, a law firm announced that Hatton Garden Safe Deposit was liquidated because the company was insolvent and in debt to various creditors. The sentencing date for these men has yet to be determined.
After the burglary, the Met Police began an investigation into why no response was made after an intruder alarm went off at the crime scene.
The police apologized for not adhering to procedure and committed to investigating the decision to categorize the alarm call as not requiring a response.
Five other men are still awaiting trial, having pleaded not guilty to conspiracy to commit burglary.

Hugh Doyle, 48, of Riverside Gardens, Enfield; William Lincoln, 60, of Winkley Street, Bethnal Green; and John Harbinson, 42, of Beresford Gardens, Benfleet, Essex, also reject laundering charges and will stand trial in November.
Paul Reader, 50, of Dartford Road, Dartford, and Carl Wood, 58, of Elderbeck Close, Cheshunt, Hertfordshire, are yet to enter their pleas.
Perkins' daughters, along with their husbands, appeared in court with charges of conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property between January 1 and May 19.

Brenn Walters, known as Ben Perkins, 43, Laura Perkins, 40, both of Manor Court, Enfield, and Terri Robinson, 35, and Steven Robinson, 46, both of Sterling Road, Enfield, were charged last month in connection with the raid.
Gen. Sir Nicholas Houghton expressed in an interview with Andrew Marr on BBC that refusing to deploy nuclear weapons would "seriously undermine" Britain's deterrent capabilities.
He also voiced concerns about such a stance potentially gaining political power.
In response, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn urged the defense secretary to reprimand Sir Nicholas for his comments.
Corbyn stated that it is concerning when the chief of the defense staff intervenes in political matters, emphasizing that military officials must remain politically neutral in a democracy.

He accused Sir Nicholas of breaching this constitutional principle by publicly participating in political debates and announced he would formally request the defense secretary to uphold the impartiality of the armed forces.
Corbyn, a prominent figure in the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, faced controversy with his shadow cabinet at a party conference when he declared he would never use nuclear weapons.

He later praised Scottish Labour’s opposition to Trident. Corbyn, who became Labour leader advocating against Trident renewal, is dedicated to promoting an international nuclear weapons convention aimed at achieving a nuclear-free world.
When asked about Corbyn's refusal to use nuclear weapons, Sir Nicholas expressed concern that such a view could influence political power.
He explained that deterrence depends on the credible possibility of use; the deterrent's effectiveness lies in never having to use it because its threat prevents conflict.
If a prime minister publicly stated they would never use nuclear weapons, "the deterrent is then completely undermined," Sir Nicholas added.
He suggested that many politicians understand this once they face the responsibilities of power.
During a wreath-laying ceremony in his Islington North constituency after Remembrance Sunday commemorations at the Cenotaph, Corbyn remarked that Sir Nicholas's comments were "unhelpful."
On Channel 4 News, he advised Sir Nicholas that in a democratic system, elected politicians are entrusted with making political decisions.
If Sir Nicholas has concerns, "he should talk to me about it," Corbyn suggested.
